Title: Cherry grower in Kern County, California pieced together water supply
Description: A cherry grower in Bakersfield who gets his irrigation water from the Arvin-Edison water district, expected to get 60 percent of a full allocation, but he managed to buy unused water from neighbors that will cost him $36,000 during the next two months.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Aug. 15, 2016
Places: Kern County, CA, Bakersfield, CA

Title: Water shortage affected crop plans, produce availability in Kern and Ventura counties in California
Description: A produce grower working fields in Kern and Ventura counties notified his customers that a 42 percent reduction in his water supply from Lake Casitas, stemming from last year’s state-mandated reductions for urban users combined with local restrictions, would lead to higher prices and reduced harvests.  Seasonal items like melons and cranberries were no longer on the farm’s roster, and plantings of lettuce and kale were severely reduced.  Many other Southern California growers were dealing with similar water challenges.Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Aug. 15, 2016
Places: Kern County, CA, Carpinteria, CA, Ventura County, CA, Oak View, CA

Title: Chimney fire burned many structures near Lake Nacimiento in Southern California
Description: The Chimney fire was 85 percent contained after burning 46,344 acres.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Aug. 31, 2016The Chimney fire has burned more than 45,000 acres near Lake Nacimiento and destroyed 49 homes since it began on Aug. 13.  The blaze was 47 percent contained, with the expectation of full containment by Sept. 3.KSBY-TV San Luis Obispo (Calif.), Aug. 26, 2016The Chimney fire charred 38,956 acres and 45 homes and 20 outbuildings since it began on Aug. 13 in northern San Luis Obispo County.  The blaze was 35 percent contained on the evening of Aug. 23.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Aug. 23, 2016The Chimney fire continued to burn aggressively, consuming 31,644 acres and coming within 2 miles to the east of Hearst Castle, which was closed to visitors, due to the fire’s proximity.  The castle is a national historic landmark built by newspaper magnate William Randolph Hearst beginning in 1919 to entertain his Hollywood friends and house his vast collection of European art and architectural artifacts.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Aug. 22, 2016The Chimney fire destroyed 4,300 acres, 12 structures and threatened another 200 structures near Lake Nacimiento in San Luis Obispo County.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Aug. 15, 2016
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: Wildfire consumed more than 100 homes in Lower Lake, California
Description: A wind-driven blaze consumed nearly five square miles of parched vegetation, more than 100 homes and businesses in Lower Lake, destroying the post office, an antiques store, a historic firehouse and the Habitat for Humanity office in the downtown area.  Orange County Register (Calif.), Aug.  15, 2016
Places: Lake County, CA, Lower Lake, CA

Title: Drought, fire increased tree mortality rate in Calaveras County, California
Description: Trees in Calaveras County were dying at a faster rate than other Sierra communities because drought has weakened the trees and the Butte fire drew many bark beetles to the region.  More than 650,000 trees—mostly ponderosa, lodgepole, sugar and other types of pine trees—were killed by the beetles.The Union Democrat (Sonora, Calif.), Aug. 9, 2016
Places: Calaveras County, CA

Title: Pilot fire charred nearly 12 square miles in San Bernardino County, California
Description: The Pilot fire in San Bernardino County blackened nearly 12 square miles in the San Bernardino Mountains and was roughly 6 percent contained on Aug. 9, according to the U.S. Forest Service.  About 4,700 homes in Hesperia, Apple Valley and Lake Arrowhead received voluntary and mandatory evacuation orders.  A spokeswoman for the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection stated that the blaze was burning up vegetation that was as dry as it would typically be in late September.  Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), Aug. 9, 2016
Places: California, San Bernardino County, CA, Apple Valley, CA, Hesperia, CA, Lake Arrowhead, CA

Title: Drought-tolerant landscaping at San Bernardino County Government Center in California
Description: Drought-tolerant landscaping was being installed to replace existing grass, shrubbery and trees around the San Bernardino County Government Center as a fifth year of drought persisted.  The landscaping project, which cost $1.75 million, began on Aug. 5 and should be completed by Dec. 31.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Sept. 21, 2016
Places: San Bernardino County, CA, San Bernardino, CA

Title: Bike pedal striking rock sparked fire in Inyo National Forest in California
Description: Fire investigators determined that the cause of an Aug. 5 wildfire that burned 122 acres of dry grass 20 miles southeast of Mammoth Lakes was a bicycle pedal striking a rock.  A piece of the metal pedal and a shaving from a rock strike were found near the fire’s origin.  A spokeswoman for the U.S. Forest Service said that the finding shows how drought had dried out the state’s wildlands.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Aug. 24, 2016
Places: Mono County, CA

Title: Goose Fire charred 2,185 acres in Fresno County, California
Description: The Goose Fire burned 2,185 acres of steep, parched terrain in the Sierra foothills near Prather.  Four homes and five other structures were lost to the flames since the fire began on July 30.  The cost of battling the blaze reached $5.4 million on the morning of Aug. 2. The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Aug. 2, 2016
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Pastures, crops in Texas Panhandle becoming drier
Description: Hot, dry and windy conditions were stressing crops and depleting soil moisture in the Texas Panhandle.  Pasture and range conditions were deteriorating, and some acres of corn may be abandoned if they do not get water soon.  Producers will likely begin supplemental feeding soon if the dryness continues.  Fire danger was high.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), July 27, 2016

Title: Wildfire closed parks along California's Big Sur as Soberanes fire burns
Description: The Soberanes fire, which has consumed more than 126,000 acres and several dozen homes since it began from an illegal campfire on July 22, continued to burn in very rugged terrain for more than two months.  The cost of battling the blaze has risen to $229 million, with about $69 million spent on firefighting equipment and about $73 million on housing for firefighters, including laundry facilities, sleeping quarters, showers and other necessities.  Los Angeles Times, Sept. 30, 2016The Soberanes fire was just 60 percent contained after burning nearly 94,000 acres.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Aug. 31, 2016The Soberanes fire continued to burn in Big Sur, consuming 85,212 acres since it began about a month ago, making this the largest blaze to burn in California this year.  The fire was 60 percent contained.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Aug. 22, 2016The Soberanes fire claimed more than 105 square miles north of the Big Sur area as more than 5,000 firefighters, numerous tankers and helicopters battled the 18-day old fire.Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), Aug. 9, 2016The Soberanes fire blackened more than 67 square miles in Monterey County, destroyed 57 homes, damaged or completely destroyed another 15 buildings and killed one person since the blaze began on July 22.  The source of the fire was determined to be an abandoned, illegal campfire a few miles east of Highway 1 north of Soberanes Creek Trail.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Aug. 2, 2016Many parks along the Big Sur coastline were closed as firefighters battled a wildfire, which consumed 30 square miles, or 78 square kilometers, and was just 10 percent contained.  The blaze also claimed 20 homes and one life.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 26, 2016
Places: Monterey County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: Wildfire north of Los Angeles charred 41,432 acres
Description: The Sand fire, which was 98 percent contained, scorched 41,432 acres and took the life of a man.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Aug. 2, 2016A fire in the rugged wilderness between the northern edge of Los Angeles and Santa Clarita expanded to 58.5 square miles, or 152 square kilometers, and was 25 percent contained.   Fleets of aircraft dropped water and fire retardant on the flames, while hundreds of fire engines aided in the fight as 3,000 firefighters fought the conflagration.  Parts of Santa Clarita remained under evacuation on July 26. San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 26, 2016
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: More grass fires occurring in Hunt County, Texas
Description: More grass fires have occurred in Hunt County as the rain clouds stay away, but no burn bans were in effect just yet.Greenville Herald Banner (Texas), July 20, 2016
Places: Hunt County, TX

Title: Burn bans in Hays, Caldwell counties in Texas
Description: The increasingly dry conditions led county commissioners to reinstate 90-day burn bans in Hays and Caldwell counties as the Keetch-Byram Drought Index crept up to around 560.San Marcos Daily Record (Texas), July 20, 2016

Title: Fire restrictions in Sequoia, Kings Canyon in California

Places: Fresno County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Water revenues down for Napa, California
Description: Napa’s Water Division revenues have fallen by an estimated $7.1 million for the fiscal year to end in June 2017 and were on track to bring in $19.5 million rather than the projected $26.6 million.  Lower income from water sales was the main reason for the revenue shortfall.  The water utility must find a way to pay for its pipes, water treatment plant and equipment, as those expenses remain constant.Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Feb. 24, 2017
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Napa County, CA, Napa, CA

Title: California's firefighting costs
Description: Since July 1, the start of the 2016-17 fiscal year, Cal Fire has spent $165 million of the budgeted $425 million emergency fund to fight fires.  The emergency fund covers all expenses apart from paying day-to-day staffing.  For the 2015-16 fiscal year that ended in June, Cal Fire spent $547 million in emergency funds fighting fires, in comparison with$402 million in the 2014-15 fiscal year, $242 million in the 2013-14 fiscal year, $311 million in the 2012-13 fiscal year, $140 million in the 2011-12 fiscal year and just $90 million in the 2010-11 fiscal year.“The drought is the biggest factor in this,” said Daniel Berlant, chief of public information for the Cal Fire. “Not only have we seen larger, more damaging fires in the last couple of years, we’ve also seen an increase in the number of fires.”Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Aug. 21, 2016

Title: Coyote Lake closed to boating, being consumed by water customers in Santa Clara County, California
Description: Coyote Lake was closed on July 18 for the remainder of 2016 after the water level was drawn down below the bottom of the boat ramp, although the lake would typically be open through September.  Water from the lake was being used for drinking water in Santa Clara County.  The Santa Clara Valley Water District would normally be using water from their primary source, the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta, or the San Luis Reservoir, but both had higher than normal levels of algae, giving the water an earthy taste and smell that customers did not appreciate.  So in late June, the water district turned to Coyote Lake and Anderson Lake, which will likely close in mid-August.  Drought was thought to be playing a role in the presence of algae in the Delta and the San Luis Reservoir.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), July 25, 2016

Places: Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: Rapid-moving blaze claimed lives near Lake Isabella, California
Description: A wind-driven wildfire claimed more than 19,000 acres, two lives and at least 80 homes and another 20 structures near Lake Isabella, east of Bakersfield.  The blaze continued to threaten 1,500 homes and displayed erratic behavior.  Residents were evacuated from nearby communities.Gov. Jerry Brown issued a state of emergency for Kern County to allow more resources to be directed toward the affected communities.Los Angeles Times, June 24, 2016
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Kern County, CA, Lake Isabella, CA, Mountain Mesa, CA, South Lake, CA, Weldon, CA

Title: Fire danger led to closing of fire-prone areas in Riverside County, California
Description: The Cal Fire/Riverside County Fire Chief John Hawkins closed seven areas particularly prone to fire, including Avery Canyon, off Gibbel Road east of State Street in Hemet; North Mountain and Indian Canyon in the San Jacinto area; Whitewater Canyon in Cabazon; a hilly area east of Menifee Road in the Nuevo/Lakeview area; the area around Sage Road and Minto Way in the community of Sage; Reinhardt Canyon north of Highway 74 and California Avenue in Hemet; and the area around the Ramona Bowl and Bautista Canyon southeast of Hemet.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), June 21, 2016
Places: Riverside County, CA, Cabazon, CA, Hemet, CA, Lakeview, CA, Nuevo, CA, Sage, CA, San Jacinto, CA

Title: Fire department in San Bernardino County, California needs public to be on heightened alert for fires
Description: The San Bernardino County Fire Department relies on the public to be on heightened alert for fires, said the department spokeswoman Tracey Martinez.  The recent extreme heat dried out vegetation that grew from the winter rains, putting landscape in the county six weeks ahead of schedule with respect to a typical fire season, according to the agency’s predictive services department.  There are parts of San Bernardino County that have not burned in more than 100 years, and the fire department continued to keep watch over those areas.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), June 21, 2016
Categories: Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Two fires threaten homes north of Los Angeles
Description: Two blazes north of Los Angeles —the Fish Fire and the Reservoir Fire—have burned more than 4,500 acres as they crackled through extremely dry vegetation and threatened to merge in a canyon.  Firefighters strove in the sweltering heatwave to keep the fires separate.  Occupants from more than 600 homes were ordered to evacuate, with some receiving little more than 10 minutes’ notice.CBS News (New York), June 21, 2016
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: Border Fire prompted evacuations in far southern San Diego County, California
Description: The Border Fire charred about 7,500 acres in far southern San Diego County and consumed several outbuildings, caused power outages and led to injuries of three firemen since the fire began on the morning of June 19.  Potrero was evacuated, and examples of “extreme fire behavior” led officials to expand the evacuation order to encompass additional small communities on June 20.  The fire was 5 percent contained on the morning of June 21.  The region was experiencing extreme drought.FOX 5 San Diego (Calif.), June 21, 2016
Places: San Diego County, CA, Alpine, CA, Canyon City, CA, Potrero, CA

Title: Wildfire burned in southern Santa Barbara County, California
Description: A wildfire in southern Santa Barbara County charred 9 square miles of heavy brush and threatened about 270 homes and ranches.  The flames caused authorities to close U.S. 101, California’s major coastal highway for two nights.  ABC News (New York), June 17, 2016
Places: Santa Barbara County, CA

Title: Burn permits suspended in Riverside County, California
Description: All burn permits issued by Cal Fire in Riverside County were suspended on June 10 by the Cal Fire/Riverside County Fire Chief John Hawkins, due to the elevated fire danger.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), June 21, 2016
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Bill to ban new wells in "critical overdraft" areas of California
Description: Thousands of new wells have been drilled across California, drawing down groundwater levels, in the two years since historic legislation passed to better manage the state’s aquifers.  California’s Senate approved a bill to prohibit the drilling of new wells in places where aquifers were in “critical overdraft,” and by requiring cities and counties in other areas to start requiring permits to put checks on the proliferation of wells.  The bill will move on to the Assembly.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), June 9, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Merced, CA, Orange County, CA, Sacramento, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Jim Wells County, Texas, browning grasses, poor hay production, moved cattle to different county, ponds drying up
Description: It has been bone dry since June, with native grasses turning brown due to lack of rain. Ponds are drying up where this station is at. Hay was not so productive this year. We had to move the cattle to a different county and started supplementing feed for native deer. CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Palito Blanco 1.0 ESE on 8/4/2016
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Jim Wells County, TX

Title: Fire forced evacuation of residents from Calabasas, Topanga, California
Description: A wildfire burned around 500 acres in Los Angeles County, forcing about 5,000 residents to evacuate their homes in Calabasas and Topanga, as firefighters tried to control the flames which threatened about 3,000 homes.  The blaze burned exceedingly dry brush in a steep canyon and was difficult to access, but ultimately, people were allowed to return home, first to Calabasas and later to Topanga.  The Washington Post (D.C.), June 5, 2016
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Calabasas, CA, Topanga, CA

Title: Discolored tap water in Calaveras County, California
Description: Discolored water is flowing from taps in Rancho Calaveras and La Contenta, but the water is safe to drink.  A spokesman for the district said that increased water use has pulled off minerals built up inside the pipes.The Union Democrat (Sonora, Calif.), June 2, 2016
Places: Calaveras County, CA, Rancho Calaveras, CA

Title: Rains County, Texas, dormant grasses
Description: The grasses have stopped growing, going dormant, and don't need to do much mowing. CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Point 3.7 ESE on 7/13/2016
Places: Rains County, TX

Title: Improved water quality at Southern California beaches
Description: Water quality was better at most Southern California beaches for the second straight year, according to the annual Beach Report Card released by Heal the Bay, an environmental group. The severe drought, which has reduced the amount of polluted runoff into the Pacific Ocean, was responsible for the improved water quality.  About 97% of Southern California beaches received an A or B grade for water quality during the busy summer months, while 95% of state beaches earned an A or B during the summer, the same as 2015.Los Angeles Times, May 26, 2016 and Aug. 28, 2016
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Thousands of trees killed, harmed by drought in Bakersfield, California
Description: Roughly 1,880 trees in Bakersfield were killed by drought and another 2,000 trees were thought to be dead or dying and need to be removed, said the Water Resources Department manager.  Most of the affected trees were non-native coastal redwoods.Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), May 25, 2016
Places: Kern County, CA, Bakersfield, CA

Title: House’s endorsement of Republican water plan for California
Description: The House endorsed a Republican plan to send more water to San Joaquin Valley farmers and cut the flow for threatened fish and growers in the inland Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta.   Democrats argued that the measure would hurt fish stocks and Delta farmers.Pendleton East Oregonian (Ore.), May 25, 2016
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Insects, tree mortality increased in Lake Tahoe Basin
Description: More trees in the southern Lake Tahoe Basin were succumbing to drought-exacerbated issues, such as tree-killing insects and tree mortality, said Jeff Marsolais, supervisor of the Lake Tahoe Basin Management Unit of the U.S. Forest Service.Reno Gazette-Journal (Nev.), May 24, 2016
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: Parts of Texas’ South Plains in need of rain for crops and planting
Description: Parts of Texas’ South Plains were in need of rain for crops and planting.  In Cochran County, pasture and rangeland needed moisture.  Some farmers in Garza County cotton, while other farmers waited for rain before planting to improve topsoil moisture.  Rain was needed to encourage warm season grass growth as some early season grasses had begun to slow down and dry out.Most row crops in Starr County were not irrigated, according to the AgriLife Extension agent, and sorghum, sunflower and corn crops were stressed from the lack of rain.  Forages and tanks also showed signs of stress, prompting beef producers to begin moving cattle to market in case rain does not fall soon.  Producers do not want to allow the dryness to stress the animals and hurt body condition scores, given that the cattle market was down and buyers were particular.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), May 22, 2016
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bailey County, TX, Borden County, TX, Castro County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Starr County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: Goats eat dry brush in Ventura County, California
Description: The Ventura County Fire Department enlisted the assistance of more than 450 goats to clear away dry brush on a Simi Valley hillside to reduce the amount of potential fuel for a fire.  Ventura County Fire Chief Mark Lorenzen said, “We still have this dead, decadent brush as a result of the years of drought.”  ABC News (New York), May 12, 2016
Places: Ventura County, CA

Title: Strong opposition to U.S. Forest Service's proposal to grant Nestlé a new permit
Description: The public, the bottled water industry and environmental activists have responded passionately to the U.S. Forest Service’s proposal to grant Nestle a new permit to continue pumping water out of the San Bernardino National Forest. The forest service received 568 letters, emails and other written comments at its website. Also submitted was a petition with more than 280,000 signatures of people insisting that the forest service undertake a “thorough and unbiased” environmental impact review. The Courage Campaign Institute, The Story of Stuff Project and the Center for Biological Diversity have sued the forest service, hoping to shut down Nestlé’s pipeline.  Nestlé’s permit expired in 1988, but the company continued to take 36 million gallons in 2015 while awaiting an environmental review.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), May 4, 2016
Categories: Business & Industry, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Bernardino County, CA

Title: More in favor of enlarging Los Vaqueros Reservoir in Contra Costa County, California
Description: Plans for enlarging the Los Vaqueros Reservoir in eastern Contra Costa County were finally gaining traction after years of drought and funds became available from the 2014 state bond measure to fund water projects.  The reservoir is nearly 3 miles long and 170 feet deep and is popular with boaters, anglers and hikers and a primary water source for local residents.  Environmentalists also support the idea of raising the dam because there would be less need for the controversial $17 billion plan to build twin tunnels beneath the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta.  Raising the earthen dam 51 feet would cost approximately $800 million and would increase the reservoir’s capacity from 160,000 acre-feet to 275,000 acre-feet.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), April 27, 2016
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Dead, dying ponderosa pines in California removed to reduce fuel for wildfires
Description: As drought and Western bark beetles kill many of California’s ponderosa pines, several organizations were taking steps to remove the dead trees to reduce the amount of fuel available for wildfires.  Republican Rep. Tom McClintock, whose district includes parts of Madera and Fresno counties which have been very hard-hit by ponderosa deaths, said he was attempting to shift $200 million from the U.S. Department of Interior land acquisition programs into tree removal.  Caltrans and the state’s two largest electric companies were removing dead and dying trees.  The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection issued several fire-prevention grants.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 25, 2016
Categories: Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions
Places: California, Fresno County, CA, Madera County, CA

Title: Lawsuit filed over relaxed water standards allowing harm to fish in California's Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta
Description: Three conservation groups brought a lawsuit on April 22 against the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency for failing to protect Delta fish and the environment during the drought when it eased water-quality standards to allow water to continue flowing to California’s cities and farms.  The three groups, the National Resources Defense Council, the Bay Institute and Defenders of Wildlife, claim that a series of 20 decisions made by the State Water Resources Control Board has hurt wild fish, including the endangered Delta smelt and Sacramento winter-run salmon.  The groups feel that the EPA should have reviewed and overruled the actions of the water board rather than allowing the decisions to stand.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), April 26, 2016
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Drought among factors wiping out Quino checkerspot butterflies in southern California
Description: The population of the Quino checkerspot butterfly, known for its distinctive checkerboard-patterned orange, black and white wings, has crashed due to drought and development.  A number of factors has caused substantial losses to the butterflies’ habitat, including urban and agricultural development, invasion of nonnative species, habitat fragmentation and degradation, increased fire frequency and other human-caused disturbances, according to experts with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.  Quino checkerspot butterflies will be bred at the San Diego Zoo in an effort to revive the population.Los Angeles Times, April 18, 2016
Places: Imperial County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Poor quality water damaged California's avocado trees
Description: Many of California’s avocado trees were being damaged by salt from poor quality groundwater as the water table drops amid years of drought.Capital Press - Agriculture Weekly (Salem, Ore.), April 14, 2016
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Drought damage to trees, water lines in Mount Diablo State Park in California
Description: Many oak and pine trees at Mount Diablo State Park toppled during winter storms after drought and bark beetles damaged and weakened the trees, according to a naturalist who guides hikes in the park.Some spigots were still in need of repair because a considerable length of time without water in the pipes caused damage.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), April 11, 2016
Places: Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Initial allocations for California's Central Valley Project
Description: The federal water allocation for the Friant Division rose from 65 percent to 75 percent, for the fourth increase in supply since April 1. The Fresno Bee (Calif.), July 18, 2016The Central Valley Project, operated by the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, will provide 50 percent of full allocations for Friant Division contractors of Class 1 water supply, up from the 40 percent previously offered.Central Valley Business Times (Stockton, Calif.), April 22, 2016The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation announced its initial allocations for the Central Valley Project.  Water customers north of the delta will receive 100 percent of contract supply, while agricultural water customers south of the delta will be allocated 5 percent; municipal and industrial users will get 55 percent; and San Joaquin River Exchange and Settlement Contractors will get 100 percent.  Eastside water service contractors, such as Central San Joaquin Water Conservation District and Stockton East Water District, will receive 0 percent of their contract supply.Central Valley Business Times (Stockton, Calif.), April 1, 2016
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Section of Sacramento River above Redding, California closed to all fishing
Description: The Sacramento River above Redding closed to all fishing from the Highway 44 bridge in Redding to Keswick Dam from April 1 through July 31 to “protect critical spawning habitat and eliminate any incidental stress or hooking mortality of winter-run Chinook salmon by anglers.”  Recent years of drought have warmed water temperatures to lethal levels for the eggs and young fish.  Salmon fishing was already prohibited, but angling for trout is typically open year-round.  The section of the Sacramento River above Redding was closed to salmon fishing from May 1 through Aug. 1, 2015 for the first time.
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Shasta County, CA, Redding, CA

Title: Water rate increase needed to increase revenue for Valley of the Moon Water District in Sonoma County, California
Description: The Valley of the Moon Water District notified its customers of projected rate increases that would take effect on July 2 for the following year.  The monthly service charge increase, based on the pipe size in home plumbing, is about 15 percent, plus a smaller 3 percent water-use increase.  The rate increase is needed because income from water sales has decreased as people conserve water.   Sonoma Index-Tribune (Calif.), March 29, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sonoma County, CA, El Verano, CA

Title: San Juan Water District in California done with water conservation mandate
Description: Officials of the San Juan Water District notified the state water board that they would no longer ask their customers to abide by the state water conservation mandate, but would urge them to voluntarily cut water use by 10 percent.  The State Water Resources Control Board will meet in late April to review water conservation mandates.  The SJWD has some of the wealthiest and heaviest water users in the state.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 25, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Granite Bay, CA, Roseville, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Citrus Heights, CA, Fair Oaks, CA, Folsom, CA, Orangevale, CA

Title: Large water releases from Lake Shasta drawing attention of water customers
Description: Redding and Bella Vista residents were concerned about the amounts of water being released from Keswick Dam after heavy rainfall refilled Lake Shasta.  Water conservation has been a priority for months, and to see 18,600 cubic feet per second flowing out—six times the 3,100 cfs of water that was streaming from the dam at the start of March—was remarkable for residents.  Many customers have called the manager of the Bella Vista Water District to inquire about the massive water releases.   Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), March 22, 2016
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Shasta County, CA, Bella Vista, CA, Redding, CA

Title: California lawmakers, others travel to Australia to learn lessons about drought
Description: The nonprofit California Foundation on the Environment and the Economy paid the way for several lawmakers to travel to Australia during the week of March 21 to learn about the country’s 15-year “millennium drought” and bring home techniques to help California withstand its drought.  Some interest group representatives, including officials from unions representing pipe workers and electrical workers; members of the Environmental Defense Fund and the Natural Resources Defense Council; and employees of Chevron, Comcast and the California Farm Bureau Federation will also make the trip.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 17, 2016
Places: Sacramento County, CA, Sacramento, CA

Title: Pacific Fishery Management Council to curb chinook salmon fishing to protect the species
Description: The Pacific Fishery Management Council was aiming to protect chinook salmon by cutting the number of places and times that commercial salmon fishers can fish.  The council will look over three proposals and make a final decision about closures in April before the salmon season opens on May 1.  Regulations on salmon fishing in Oregon and Washington state could be much more stringent than in California because one proposal called for the complete closure of the commercial salmon season in Washington and northern Oregon.Drought on the West Coast warmed rivers and streams, increasing the water temperature to a point that killed most of the spawning fish.  Only 3 percent of last year’s young winter-run chinook salmon were thought to have survived their journey to the ocean. San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 16, 2016
Categories: Business & Industry, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions

Title: Almond trees uprooted in western Kern County, California
Description: Wonderful Orchards was pulling out 10,000 acres of almond trees in western Kern County because water resources were limited and the price of almonds has fallen from $4 per pound to $2.KFSN-TV ABC 30 Frenso/Visalia (Calif.), March 2, 2016

Title: Project underway to document drought-related changes to West Central Texas lake ecosystems
Description: Dr. Terrence Boyle, a professor with McMurry University has begun a 4-year project studying how changes in climate affect the ecosystems of West Central Texas lakes.  Hubbard Creek Lake is one of a dozen Big Country reservoirs being surveyed to establish a baseline data set for plankton, periphyton and macrobenthic organisms found in local lakes.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Feb 27, 2016

Title: Fire danger rising, crops experiencing stress in South Texas
Description: In the eastern part of South Texas, the fire danger was elevated from dry conditions and led to a brush fire consuming more than 800 acres.  In Kleberg and Kenedy counties, pastures were stressed from the lack of moisture.  Ranchers increased supplemental feeding.  In the western part of South Texas, the growth of wheat and oats slowed because the crops needed rain.  Rangeland and pasture conditions deteriorated, prompting livestock producers to continue giving supplemental feed.  Soil moisture was short in Dimmitt, Maverick, Zapata and Zavala counties.  Dry conditions also increased the fire danger.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 23, 2016

Title: Farmers in Swisher County, Texas worried by warm dry weather
Description: Windy, dry weather in Swisher County concerned farmers who were still making planting decisions.  The area saw several wildfires in Conservation Reserve Program fields.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 23, 2016

Title: Winter forages, wheat showed signs of stress in Rolling Plains of Texas
Description: Rolling Plains pastures, rangeland and winter wheat were drying out, due to warm weather and plenty of sunshine.  Fire danger rose, and some commissioners’ courts were considering enacting burn bans.  Topsoil moisture decreased markedly, leaving winter forages and wheat starting to manifest signs of stress. Description: Some farmers in Southwest Texas were waiting for rain before planting, deeming the soil too dry at present.  Dry conditions hurt pastures too.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 23, 2016

Title: Water conservation hurt revenue for water agency in Riverside County, California
Description: Water conservation led to a revenue slump for the Mission Springs Water District at a time when the district needs funds to address new state water quality standards and replace aging infrastructure, prompting the district’s board to consider higher water and sewer rates to bring in more revenue.  The water agency provides water for Desert Hot Springs and its outlying area.  The Coachella Valley Water District and Desert Water Agency may also be raising water rates in the near future.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Feb. 15, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, Desert Hot Springs, CA

Title: Plans to protect winter-run chinook salmon in Northern California
Description: The National Marine Fisheries Service added winter-run chinook salmon to a list of endangered species that are “the most at-risk of extinction” and also outlined a five-year plan to "turn the trend around for this species from a declining trajectory to a trajectory toward recovery."The Winnemem Wintu tribe offered a plan to the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation to support the winter-run chinook salmon because the tribe believes that their lives are intertwined with the salmon, which have perished in large numbers during the past two years due to epic drought and warm water temperatures.   The tribe’s plan suggests that the fish swim up Sacramento River tributaries to a point less than a mile from Lake Shasta.  The salmon would then swim through large pipes to the lake and on to the McCloud and Sacramento rivers. After the young fish hatch, they would return to the lake, swim back through the pipes, into the creeks and back to the Sacramento River.The fisheries service and the bureau were willing to consider whether the tribe’s proposal would work.Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), Feb. 13, 2016
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health

Title: Too dry for firefall in California's Yosemite National Park
Description: Drought conditions prevented Horsetail Fall in Yosemite National Park from flowing, meaning that the February firefall was not there.  During a two-week period in February when the fall is flowing, the sun angle at sunset is just right to illuminate the water, creating the appearance of lava.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com) (Calif.), Feb. 12, 2019

Title: Fire danger in Central Texas prompted Austin Fire Dept. to staff five brush trucks
Description: The Austin Fire Department began staffing five brush trucks, due to the high fire risk in Central Texas and nearby parts of the Hill Country.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 8, 2016

Title: Push for a burn ban in unincorporated parts of Travis County, Texas; Rain ended burn ban
Description: After Travis County officials rescinded a burn ban that was to remain in effect through March 9 after rainfall eased the fire danger.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 23, 2016The Travis County fire marshal favored a burn ban for the unincorporated parts of the county, due to recent dry weather, and intended to pass the recommendation along to Travis County commissioners.  In spite of the dry weather, the soil was still moist, and many of the branches and other fuels have dried out.  The wildfire risk will remain high until things begin greening up in the spring.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 8, 2016
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Fire prevention fee funds used to pay for tree removal in several Sierra Nevada counties in California
Description: Dead and dying trees killed by drought and bark beetles were scheduled for removal from several Sierra Nevada counties to reduce the fire danger, said Daniel Berlant, Cal Fire spokesman.  The work will be paid for with $1.75 million in funds from a fire prevention fee paid by some 37,000 California residents and business owners in the foothills and mountains to reduce the fire risk in Tuolumne, Fresno, Kern, Mariposa, Madera and Tulare counties.  There were about 29 million dead or dying trees in the Sierra in 2015.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Feb. 6, 2016
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: California water board eased conservation mandate to 23 percent
Description: Dozens of leaders of California water agencies asked Gov. Jerry Brown’s administration to ease the conservation mandate since it’s raining, reservoirs were filling, water customers were frustrated with the demand for water conservation and reduced water sales were costing water districts hundreds of millions of dollars in lost revenue.  The Water Resources Control Board, however, voted for modest adjustments to the conservation mandates, giving relief to hot areas like the Southern California desert and the Central Valley, but offering no change for most Bay Area cities, Los Angeles and San Diego through May.   Whereas the previous drought rules required a savings of 25 percent compared to water use in 2013, the modified rules require conservation of 23 percent compared to 2013.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Feb. 3, 2016
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: California homeowners protected against HOA pressure to keep grass green
Description: Local water districts in California can fine homeowners associations that attempt to prevent homeowners from reducing outdoor watering or allowing their grass to turn brown amid drought after the State Water Resources Control Board approved the regulation on Feb. 2.  A state law passed in 2014 ruled to the same effect, but homeowners had to take HOAs to court to get relief from fines.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Feb. 4, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Riverside County, CA

Title: Employment opportunities for California's drought-affected individuals
Description: The Employers’ Training Resource Program was seeking unemployed individuals, due to drought, to fill a number of positions after the program received national dislocated worker grant funding through the California Employment Development.KERO-TV ABC 23 Bakersfield-Turn to 23 (Calif.), Jan. 27, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Kern County, CA, Bakersfield, CA

Title: Trees in California's East Bay parks succumb to drought
Description: Bay Area trees in the East Regional Park District have succumbed to drought and were marked for removal.  In the Del Valle Regional Park south of Livermore, roughly 100 trees died and a grove of 100-foot tall poplar trees will be taken out and replaced with drought-tolerant oak trees.  An employee with the park district reported that similar tree deaths had occurred in other area parks as well.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Jan. 25, 2016
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Drought-Related USDA Disaster Declarations in 2016
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture began declaring counties as primary and secondary disaster areas related to drought in January, for the 2016 growing season. Farmers in affected counties have eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for low-interest emergency loans. For more information, agricultural producers should contact their Farm Service Agency office. From Farm Service Agency press releases.

Title: Ag Chat conference to be held in Reno will address drought conditions
Description: An Ag Chat conference was scheduled for Feb. 19-20 in Reno.  Presenters will share social media success stores and teach new ways to share the story of agriculture using social media platforms.   Participants will be able to see clips from the new Thirsty Land film, which addresses drought conditions in the western U.S.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Jan. 18, 2016

Title: Delta smelt nearly absent in Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta, California
Description: Only six Delta smelt were netted during the February trawl survey, the fewest fish ever recorded.  In February 2015, 68 smelt were caught; in Feb. 2014, 55 smelt were netted, and in Feb. 2005, 211 smelt were caught.  Some biologists fear that the Delta smelt cannot recover and could become extinct.  Pete Moyle, a fishery biologist and associate director of the Center for Watershed Sciences at UC Davis said, "Presumably there is still a small probability of a miraculous recovery, but I am not optimistic, especially if California goes back to drought conditions after this current spate of storms."  State fish and wildlife officials have higher hopes for smelt survival because the population rebounds when wetter weather returns.  Contra Costa Times (Calif.), March 8, 2016The January 2016 trawl for delta smelt found just four males and three females, in comparison with the January 2015 trawl when about twice that many fish were found.  In January 2014, about twenty times that many fish were seen.KCET-TV Los Angeles, Jan. 27, 2016

Title: Panel to explore safety of using oilfield wastewater on crops
Description: Some California farmers lacking irrigation water amid years of drought have turned to oilfield wastewater as an alternative for watering crops, but it was unknown how chemicals in the wastewater affected food safety.  A new panel of state officials, academic experts and industry representatives began investigating food safety and toxicity concerns because the effect of oilfield chemicals in food is “largely unstudied and unknown,” according to the Pacific Institute.  Leftover production fluid from at least five oilfields was being used to irrigate tens of thousands of acres of mainly almond, pistachio and citrus crops.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Jan. 12, 2016

Title: Above-normal fire activity in California's fifth year of drought
Description: More than 3,800 fires burned more than 112,900 acres in California since the start of 2016.  The number of fires is 20 percent more than the state had experienced through mid-August 2015 and exceeds the five-year average of 3,200 fires and 85,900 acres for the same time frame.  Including blazes on federally owned land, there have been 4,600 fires affecting more than 306,000 acres in 2016.Washington Post (D.C.), Aug. 16, 2016

Title: Drought decreased overall agricultural value in Fresno County, California
Description: Drought dented Fresno County’s overall agricultural value in 2016, pulling it down for a second straight year to $6.1 billion, a decrease of 7.3 percent compared to the previous year.  It was mentioned in the 2016 report that the third year of a statewide drought affected agricultural value. The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Aug. 22, 2017
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Drought cost California farmers an estimated $603 million in 2016
Description: Drought has cost California farmers an estimated $603 million in 2016, according to a study from the University of California at Davis.  Winter precipitation lessened the impacts felt from drought in previous years, but parts of the state, such as the San Joaquin Valley, still desperately need rainfall.  Farmers fallowed 78,780 acres in 2016 for lack of water, compared to 500,000 unplanted acres in 2015, costing farmers $247 million in crop revenue and shorting the rural economy about 1,815 jobs this year.  Farmers also spent an extra $303 million to pump groundwater to replace water that state and federal water projects could not provide.  Including indirect costs, the total economic cost of drought in 2016 may be about $603 million, which is less damaging than in 2015 when drought cost the farm economy $2.7 billion.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 15, 2016

Title: Continued subsidence in California's Central Valley
Description: Land subsidence in the Central Valley, accelerated in the past four years of drought as groundwater pumping increased, has damaged bridges and canals at an estimated cost of billions of dollars.  Groundwater comprises 40 percent of water used in a wet year, but during drought, can provide up to 65 percent.  Decades of heavy pumping have buckled canal linings, forcing irrigation districts to raise the canal sides to keep water flowing.  The cost of rebuilding one canal came to $4.5 million, while the expense of rebuilding a Los Banos bridge was put at $2.5 million.  Some areas have subsided more than a foot in less than a year.Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), Dec. 27, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: California homeowners defend water use for lawns
Description: California residents who do not want to be confronted about their green lawns have put up signs reading, “Our gardens are watered by a well,” or, “non-potable water in use for irrigation.”  They feel that the signs should deter passers-by from criticizing their water use since they are not using the “public” supply to water their lawns.  The New York Times, Dec. 9, 2015

Title: Uranium contamination a growing concern for water in California's Central Valley
Description: An increasing number of wells in California’s Central Valley were contaminated with uranium, which was threatening the health of those who consume the water.  About 25 percent of families using private wells in the Central Valley were consuming water containing dangerous amounts of uranium.  Up to 10 percent of public water systems use raw water that contains more uranium than allowed by government safety standards.  Long-term uranium exposure can damage kidneys, increase cancer risks and cause other problems.  The average amount of uranium in the public-supply wells in the eastern San Joaquin Valley increased 17 percent from 1990 to the mid-2000s, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.  Uranium enters the water supply when snowmelt picks up uranium-laden sediment before it is used to irrigate crops, which produce a weak acid that draws uranium from the sediment.    As wells are used, the contaminated water is drawn down into the ground where it eventually is pumped for use as drinking water.  Drought has worsened the problem because groundwater is being overpumped to compensate for the lack of rain.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Dec. 8, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Allocation offered for California's State Water Project
Description: The California Department of Water Resources announced that it will deliver 60 percent of water allotments for agricultural and municipal use as March storms brought more rain to refill reservoirs, particularly in the northern part of the state.  Orange County Register (Calif.), April 21, 2016Additional winter precipitation has made it possible for the State Water Resources Board to offer larger water allotments of 45 percent this year, an improvement over February’s estimate of 30 percent.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 17, 2016The Department of Water Resources increased the estimated delivery via the State Water Project to 30 percent of full allotments, up from 15 percent in January.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Feb. 24, 2016The Department of Water Resources projected a water delivery of 15 percent of full water allotments for 2016 after rains increased reservoir levels.  In 2015, State Water Project delivered 20 percent of full allotments, and, in 2014, delivered just 5 percent.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Jan. 26, 2016The 2016 initial allocation for the State Water Project was 10 percent of normal supplies, or half as much as was delivered in 2015, despite the expectation of heavy winter precipitation, due to El Niño.  Allocation estimates will be updated as the winter progresses.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Dec. 1, 2015

Title: Most of California's endangered winter-run salmon died in 2015
Description: Only 318,000 of California’s juvenile winter-run salmon survived in 2015, for a meager 3 percent survival rate, given nearly 10 million eggs.  Water temperatures became too warm in the drought-stricken Sacramento River and its tributaries for the young fish to survive, making 2015 the second straight year of paltry survival numbers for the fish.  In 2014, just 5 percent of the salmon survived, compared to the pre-drought year of 2011 when 41 percent survived.The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service intends to release hundreds of thousands of hatchery-raised winter-run salmon in February 2016 to compensate for the high mortality rate in 2015.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 1, 2016Most endangered winter-run Chinook salmon in 2015 died from low water levels and high temperatures before they traveled as far south as Red Bluff.  This was the second consecutive year of death rates of at least 95 percent of the young winter-run salmon, pushing state and federal agencies to do all in their power to help the fish avoid extinction.  U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service officials intend to release as many as 425,000 winter-run salmon in the Redding area in late January and early February to make up for the many winter-run salmon that succumbed to low river water and high temperatures in 2015.  Fish and wildlife officials typically release about 175,000 fish each winter, but bumped up the number due to the fishes’ high death rate.Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), Jan. 14, 2016
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Christmas trees stunted in northern California
Description: Tree farmers in northern California lost seedlings and saw mature trees stunted by drought in 2015.  In Los Gatos, a Christmas tree farmer lost 90 percent of his year-old seedlings.  He also noticed that trees’ needles grew less and trees grew less in height than could be expected in a good year.  Near Auburn, growers of prized silver tipped trees opted not to sell any because parched trees drop their needles within days after being cut.  Tree growers in Sebastopol rented water trucks and used hoses to hand water seedlings during the summer.  They also installed a drip irrigation system to water their trees from the spring through the fall.  With fewer trees attaining the desired height for lack of water, there will be a smaller selection of trees available this year at higher prices.San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), Dec. 1, 2015

Title: Survey captured Southern Californians' sentiments on water conservation
Description: About 1,000 customers of the Metropolitan Water District in Southern California were surveyed by telephone and another 800 people responded to an online survey in December to measure people’s attitudes and awareness of the drought.  The survey found that nearly 90 percent of respondents said they strongly or somewhat agree that “I’ve already cut back on water use at my home as much as I can" and "There's not much more I can do to save water."  Most participants were also willing to decrease their consumption, yet statewide water conservation slowed in the last three months of 2015, with conservation slipping below the 25 percent mark, while cumulative savings remained above 25 percent.Sixty-two percent of respondents said they "strongly agree" that they had saved as much water as they could, while 26% "somewhat agree."Los Angeles Times, Feb. 10, 2016
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Imperial County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Ancient artifacts vulnerable to looting in California
Description: Low water levels across California have provided ample opportunity for looters to scavenge for artifacts on exposed lakebeds, riverbeds and reservoirs.  In Lake County, looting continued to be a problem at Anderson Marsh State Historic Park where archaeological deposits date back at least 13,000 years.  A man arrested by a Lake County detective had collected more than two dozen obsidian spear points, early stone hunting tools, a clay pottery bowl and other Native American relics.Clear Lake in Lake County is another site popular with treasure hunters.  It is the ancestral ground of the indigenous Pomo people who settled there 14,000 years ago and holds artifacts ranging from obsidian dart points to items from the Gold Rush.  An archaeological crimes class was held to educate law enforcement and others to cut down on looting.The New York Times, Dec. 1, 2015
Places: Butte County, CA, Lake County, CA, Clearlake, CA

Title: Conservation mandate causing revenue shortfall for utility in San Diego, California
Description: The water conservation targets assigned by the State Water Resources Control Board were causing problems for San Diego, which has 99 percent of the water it needs.  With lower water sales, due to people conserving, local water agencies have raised water rates to increase revenue.  In addition, the desalination plant in Carlsbad will begin producing enough water in December to meet 7 to 10 percent of the county’s demand.  County water officials hope that the state will ease conservation mandates for parts of the state where water supplies are ample.Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Nov. 25, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Diego County, CA, Carlsbad, CA, San Diego, CA

Title: Water conservation hurts California water providers' bottom lines
Description: Mandated water conservation continued to cut into water suppliers’ revenue, forcing them to add drought surcharges, tap monetary reserves and postpone maintenance projects.  The general manager of Riverside Public Utilities said that water restrictions will cost about $9 million in 2015.  More fixed charges, such as a drought surcharge ranging from $0.71 to $1.98, depending on water use and also a penalty for exceeding water allotments, were being added to customers’ bills to meet the utility’s costs.  In Hemet, water rates rose 19 percent on Oct. 1 and will be followed by additional rate increases of 19 percent in March 2016, 4 percent in January 2017 and 3 percent increases each January through 2020.  Eastern Municipal Water District in Perris loses about $1 million monthly due to water conservation, said the district spokesman.  Mandated water conservation for Eastern, the largest water supplier in Riverside County, is 28 percent.  The district increased water rates by 3.8 percent in January 2015 and added two fixed charges for water and sewer use.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Nov. 24, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, Hemet, CA, Perris, CA, Riverside, CA

Title: El Paso Water Utilities plan, search for additional water sources
Description: The Rio Grande River supplied less water for the El Paso Water Utilities, driving the utility to plan and search for additional water sources to meet future demand.  The EPWU also proposed increasing water and wastewater rates by 11 percent.  El Paso Times (Texas), Nov. 17, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Paso County, TX, El Paso, TX

Title: California environmental groups sue Sacramento River water users
Description: The Natural Resources Defense Council and other environmental groups have sued Sacramento River water users, accusing them of misusing water that should have gone to endangered winter-run salmon.  The defendants in the lawsuit include San Luis and Delta Mendota Water Authority, State Water Contractors, Westlands Water District, California Department of Water Resources, California Farm Bureau Federation, Glenn-Colusa irrigation District, Natomas Central Mutual Water Company, Pelger Mutual Water Company, Princeton- Codora-Glenn Irrigation District, Provident Irrigation District, Reclamation District 108 and River Garden Farms.Other plaintiffs were Earthjustice, San Francisco Baykeeper, The Bay Institute, the Winnemem Wintu Tribe, and Pacific Coast Federation of Fisherman’s Association/Institute for Fisheries Resources.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Nov. 11, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Large Southern California water district aims to purchase islands in Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta
Description: The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California decided to go ahead with plans to purchase 20,369 acres of land encompassing Webb Tract, Bacon Island, Bouldin Island, most of Holland Tract and a part of Chipps Island in Contra Costa, San Joaquin and Solano counties.  The land in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta is located in the proposed path of Gov. Jerry Brown’s twin-tunnel project to move water through the delta.  Delta advocates and environmentalists consider the purchase to be a water grab, but MWD says that it intends to capitalize on environmental benefits, including waterfowl protection, fish food supply enhancement, carbon sequestration and turbidity studies, said the general manager of the MWD.  He also noted that the islands could be used for storage and water transfers when needed.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Nov. 11, 2015
Places: Contra Costa County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Solano County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: California water districts preparing to bank groundwater during El Niño winter
Description: An irrigation district in Fresno County and others were preparing to bank groundwater ahead of the El Niño-enhanced storms expected to be rolling through California and alleviating drought during the winter.  The Semitropic Water Storage District also wants to direct some of the flows from the Kings River into historic Tulare Lake and on to groundwater banking facilities.Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Nov. 9, 2015
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Hungry bears invade Three Rivers, California
Description: Hungry bears have invaded Three Rivers, on the west side of Sequoia National Park, in search of food as they prepare to hibernate for the winter.  The ongoing four-year drought left the berry crop shriveled and acorns were relatively scarce, leading bears to seek out food in residential areas.  Residents have gotten used to seeing bears and seem to enjoy the visitors hanging out on the golf course, near a pool, in trees and gathering acorns in the town where acorns were plentiful.Portland Oregonian, Hillsboro Argus, Oregon Live.com (Ore.), Nov. 8, 2015
Places: Tulare County, CA, Three Rivers, CA

Title: Grants assist Central Valley communities with water supply improvements
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture awarded $3.3 million in grants to improve water supplies in eight communities in Fresno, Tulare and Kings counties.  One of the USDA grants will cover well drilling in East Porterville and another grant would eventually assist with getting the town connected to Porterville’s water system.  Some of the other grants gave $500,000 to the city of Orange Cove, $494,300 to Big Sandy Rancheria near Auberry, $170,000 to Alpaugh Community Services District in Tulare County and $142,000 for the Kettleman City Community Services District in Kings County.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Nov. 2, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Fresno, CA, Orange Cove, CA, Kings County, CA, Kettleman City, CA, Stratford, CA, Tulare County, CA, Alpaugh, CA, East Porterville, CA, Monson, CA

Title: Calrose rice won top award
Description: Calrose rice, grown in the Sacramento Valley, took top place as the world’s best rice variety at the seventh annual World Rice Conference in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.  This is the first year the California rice has been the sole winner of the award.  The dry weather improved the rice’s overall texture, stated a rice grower.  Ninety-seven percent of the state’s rice is grown in the Sacramento Valley, and about 80 percent of the crop is Calrose rice.Rice production has continued to decline in California due to water shortages.  In 2013, 567,000 acres of rice were harvested; while in 2014, just 434,000 acres of rice were grown, and in 2015, rice acreage amounted to 411,000, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Nov. 2, 2015
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Water taste, smell affected by drought in San Jose, California
Description: Tap water in the San Jose area has a “dirt-like” flavor and smell, acknowledged Santa Clara Valley Water District officials.  Low water levels in reservoirs allow the water to heat up, promoting algae growth, all of which can be traced back to drought.  The water’s aesthetics may not improve until the drought abates.KRON4 (San Francisco, Calif.), Nov. 1, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: Cloud-seeding used to enhance rainfall in Los Angeles County, California
Description: When the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors met in Oct. 2015, they approved a one-year contract with North American Weather Consultants, based in Utah, for up to $550,000 a year.  The first cloud-seeding effort took place on March 6 when clouds were seeded with silver iodide to enhance rainfall, which is collected in dams and in the Pacoima, Big Tujunga and San Gabriel watersheds.Los Angeles Times, March 8, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Pacoima, CA, San Gabriel, CA, Sylmar, CA

Title: Fines for four California water districts
Description: Four California water suppliers—Beverly Hills, the cities of Indio and Redlands, and the Coachella Valley Water District—were issued a $61,000 penalty for not achieving their water conservation mandates.  Statewide, Californians curbed their water use 26.1 percent in September, compared with 2013 water use.   San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Oct. 31, 2015

Title: Preparations for El Nino flooding in California
Description: California authorities were stockpiling extra sandbags, wooden stakes and plastic sheeting in flood-prone areas and enlisting 1,200 personnel in flood-control training.Reuters (New York), Oct 28, 2015

Description: Some California pumpkin growers imported pumpkins from Oregon because water restrictions kept growers from irrigating as usual.  KGET-TV (Bakersfield, Calif.), Oct. 28, 2015

Title: Groundwater recharge in California's almond orchards
Description: The Almond Board of California and Sustainable Conservation, a conservation nonprofit that promotes economically sensible stewardship of California’s resources, announced a partnership to assess the possibility of using the state’s one million acres of almond orchards for groundwater recharge.  To evaluate the potential for putting the concept into practice on a large scale, Sustainable Conservation will collect information from almond growers already capturing excess floodwater and using it for groundwater recharge to examine any crop impacts.KOTV-TV CBS 6 Tulsa (Okla.), Oct. 26, 2015
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Solano County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Most California farmworkers surveyed lost hours, jobs due to drought
Description: A survey of more than 350 farmworkers in Madera and Fresno counties revealed that 92 percent of participants had less work or no work, due to the drought.  Working conditions have deteriorated because there were fewer jobs, so workers will do whatever they must to hold onto their jobs, which may mean being deprived of shade, water or their rights.  Eighty-one percent of those surveyed did not know about any programs to help drought-affected farmworkers.   Many undocumented farmworkers would not be eligible for the drought-related job retraining programs because they were undocumented and would not have a social security number, GED or high school diploma.  Undocumented farmworkers obviously cannot get unemployment benefits.  The survey was done by a collaboration between several nonprofit organizations in Fresno and Madera County, including Binational Center for the Development of Oaxacan Indigenous Communities, Central California Legal Services and the CRLA Foundation.Farmworkers at the greatest disadvantage were indigenous Mexicans, or those whose language and culture predate the Spanish conquest of Mexico.  These people are often discriminated against both in the U.S. and in Mexico, making them the first to lose jobs when positions are cut.   KQED Public Media (San Francisco, Calif.), Oct. 24, 2015
Places: Fresno County, CA, Madera County, CA

Title: More California trees stressed, dying from drought
Description: Drought has stressed and killed more trees in California’s forests than previously realized, found a biologist with the Carnegie Institution for Science, who estimated that up to 20 percent of the state’s forests, or about 120 million trees, could die from drought stress.  An earlier survey by the Forest Service revealed an estimated 12.5 million dead trees in the state’s central and southern forests.Los Angeles Times, Oct. 20, 2015
Places: Imperial County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Survey to better understand health, drought in Tulare County, California
Description: Volunteers in Tulare County were knocking on doors in East Porterville, Cutler and Orosi and asking residents questions about health problems.  The goal was better understanding of the relationship between drought and health problems and whether stress and poverty typically follow such a combination.  The results of the three-day survey will help county officials know how to use available funding more effectively.KFSN-TV ABC 30 Fresno/Visalia (Calif.), Oct. 20, 2015
Places: Tulare County, CA, Cutler, CA, East Porterville, CA, Orosi, CA

Title: Monarch butterflies benefit from drought-tolerant California yards
Description: Many Californians have gotten rid of their lawns and replanted with native, drought-tolerant plants.  Milkweed has been among the new plants, which is the only type of plant female monarch butterflies will lay eggs on, so the move to save water has also benefited monarch butterflies.  A nursery owner in San Diego sold more than 14,000 milkweed plants this season alone.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Oct. 20, 2015

Title: Many burn bans in East Texas
Description: A spate of wildfires in parched East Texas has led many counties to adopt burn bans to reduce the likelihood of additional fires.  Waller, Liberty, San Jacinto and Grimes were some of the counties prohibiting outdoor burning.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Oct. 17, 2015
Places: Grimes County, TX, Liberty County, TX, San Jacinto County, TX, Waller County, TX

Title: Grass fire in Waller County, Texas burned quickly
Description: A grass fire in Waller County burned 50 acres in a few hours, said the spokesman for the Waller County sheriff.Houston Chronicle (Texas), Oct. 17, 2015
Places: Waller County, TX

Title: California ag workers to be trained for other jobs
Description: Proteus intended to train 120 drought-affected agriculture workers from Tulare, Kings and Fresno counties for renewable energy jobs.  The education, employment and community services nonprofit based in Visalia expected to get about $800,000 of a more than $1.7 million grant awarded by the California Employment Development Department to La Cooperativa Campesina de California.  La Cooperativa is a Sacramento-based consortium of five nonprofits, including Proteus.  Low-income, underemployed agriculture workers will be trained in weatherization and solar installation.  The Employment Development Department grant will support training for an estimated 267 workers total in California. The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Oct. 15, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kings County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Visalia, CA

Title: More fires in Ark-La-Tex
Description: More fires than usual have occurred in the Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas area as drought persists.KEEL-AM (Shreveport, La.), Oct. 14, 2015
Places: Columbia County, AR, Lafayette County, AR, Miller County, AR, Union County, AR, Bienville Parish, LA, Caddo Parish, LA, Sabine Parish, LA, Webster Parish, LA, Bowie County, TX, Cass County, TX, Harrison County, TX, Marion County, TX

Title: Hidden Pines Fire destroyed several dozen homes in Bastrop County, Texas
Description: The Hidden Pines Fire, began on Oct. 13, scorched 4,582 acres in Bastrop County and destroyed up to 34 homes.  The blaze was just 25 percent contained on Oct. 16.  A DC-10 air tanker was flown in from California to battle the flames feeding on the tinder dry landscape.Houston Chronicle (Texas), Oct. 17, 2015
Places: Bastrop County, TX

Title: Water emergency in Fort Bragg, California
Description: Fort Bragg officials declared a stage-three water emergency because ocean water began leaking into municipal pipes as detected at the water treatment plant.  The Noyo River provides water for the community of 7,300 people, but the flow of the river was too low to push back the ocean water at high tide.  The emergency drought measures require restaurants to use disposable plates and silverware rather than washing reusable ones and cut down on washing cloth napkins and tablecloths.  Residents cannot water their yards or wash cars or paved surfaces with municipal water.Bend Bulletin (Ore.), Oct. 9, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Mendocino County, CA, Fort Bragg, CA

Title: Upper Big Falls closed in San Bernardino National Forest in California
Description: A seven-acre area around Upper Big Falls in the San Bernardino National Forest was closed by the park on Oct. 8 because too many climbers have chosen to scale the face of the falls, but have gotten into trouble and needed a rescue.  Between 1995 and 2012, just three to five rescues were performed annually, but in 2013, 14 rescues were needed, and in 2014, 16 rescues were performed.  Then with the drought and lower water flows, more climbers have attempted the climb in 2015, with 57 people needing assistance, many with serious injuries often incurred after slipping on algae-covered rocks.  The rescues usually require the use of a helicopter.  The waterfall was last closed for this reason in the 1980s, said a spokesman for the San Bernardino National Forest.Los Angeles Times, Oct. 27, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation
Places: San Bernardino County, CA

Title: California pot growers need permits to divert, store water
Description: The Central Valley Regional Water Quality Control Board warned medical marijuana growers that they need to obtain permits to divert or store water.  Water conservation and waterway protection measures were strongly encouraged by both the North Coast and Central Valley Regional Water Quality Control Boards. Los Angeles Times, Oct. 2, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Water conservation enforcement in Palm Springs, California
Description: The Coachella Valley Water District issued 402 formal warnings and 13 fines ranging from $50 to $100 to water use violators in the last three months.  The district has trained 22 employees to identify violators, up from just two people focused on enforcement.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Jan. 13, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, Coachella, CA, Indio, CA, Palm Springs, CA

Title: Nonprofit organizations in California's San Joaquin Valley struggling to meet needs of clients
Description: A survey conducted by the Fresno Regional Foundation revealed that nonprofit organizations in the San Joaquin Valley were struggling to meet the needs of their clients and needed more funding to increase drought-related programs and build capacity.  Only 11 percent of survey respondents said that their organization was well-prepared to serve their clients.  Some of the most significant effects of the drought were income loss, inadequate access to food, reduced water access and stress.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Sept. 30, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
