Title: California beekeepers move bees elsewhere
Description: Some California beekeepers were letting bees keep the honey that they produced and were taking their bees out of state because there was not enough nectar and pollen to sustain the bees.KEYT-TV ABC 3 Santa Barbara (Calif.), Sept. 30, 2015
Places: Imperial County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Spate of grass fires in Grimes County, Texas
Description: Dry conditions elevated the fire danger in Grimes County, which has seen a spike in grass fires.  Near the end of September, three fires were sparked on the same day, charring 70 acres of farmland within two hours.  On Oct. 14, fire crews battled 22 fires in Grimes County, but the fires were kept to 5 acres or less.Houston Chronicle (Texas), Oct. 17, 2015
Places: Grimes County, TX

Title: Rice production down at least 30 percent in California's Sacramento Valley
Description: Rice production in the Sacramento Valley was expected to fall about 30 percent, due to water shortages as California endured drought.  Only about 375,000 acres of rice were cultivated in 2015, in comparison with a more typical year of about 560,000 acres.  More than half of the state’s rice is typically exported, but international buyers were buying Southern rice while drought lowered California’s rice output.  California rice growers worry that they will lose market share if production does not rebound quickly.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 26, 2015
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Dry reservoir, dead fish in Lassen County, California
Description: Mountain Meadows Reservoirs went dry, killing fish and leaving 5,800 acres of mud.  An official with Pacific Gas & Electric Co. blamed the drought for the empty reservoir, but the chairman for Mountain Meadows Conservancy stated that the utility provider did not stop outflows from the reservoir when the water level reached a minimum.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Sept. 24, 2015
Places: Lassen County, CA

Title: Emergency water station in Magalia, California
Description: Butte County and Del Oro Water Co. set up an emergency water station in Magalia for provide water for residential Butte County well owners whose wells went dry or were not producing enough water.  Residents can take up to 500 gallons of water daily for uses such as showering or flushing toilets, as the water was not potable.   The water was not intended for people served by a water district or company.  Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Sept. 23, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Chico, CA, Magalia, CA, Nimshew, CA

Title: Metropolitan Water District of Southern California considering constructing a water recycling plant in Carson, California
Description: The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California was considering building a water recycling plant like the one in Orange County.  The recycling plant would be constructed in Carson and would purify 60,000 acre-feet of treated sewer water from the neighboring Sanitation Districts of Los Angeles County water treatment plant.  The purified water would then be pumped to several recharge areas.  Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), Sept. 21, 2015
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Carson, CA, Orange County, CA

Title: Customers of East Bay Municipal Utility District in California noticed change in taste of water
Description: Customers of the East Bay Municipal Utility District called about the taste and smell of their water as more Sacramento River water has been blended with Mokelumne River water in the municipal supply.  A large amount of Sacramento River water was purchased to ease the water shortage for the district’s 1.3 million customers.Contra Costa Times (Calif.), Sept 22, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Alamo, CA, Danville, CA, San Ramon, CA, Walnut Creek, CA

Title: Wildfire expanded rapidly in Monterey County, California
Description: A wildfire broke out in Monterey County on Sept. 19 and rapidly expanded to cover 1,200 acres and destroyed or damaged 10 homes.  One person perished in the blaze.CBS (New York), Sept. 21, 2015
Places: Monterey County, CA

Title: City council in Napa, California discussed water exports, possible limits
Description: The Napa city council discussed the export of municipal water to vineyards, homes and a popular resort outside of the city limits and considered limits on the practice to save water supplies for Napans.  Council members agreed that water deliveries should first serve existing homes whose water supplies were spent.  The issue of large water sales attracted more criticism as Napans strove to conserve water in the state’s fourth year of drought.Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Sept. 16, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Napa County, CA, Napa, CA

Title: Barbecues banned in parks in Sacramento County, California
Description: The use of barbecues and “incendiary devices” was prohibited in county parks, except in picnic areas, by Sacramento County supervisors on Sept. 15 as the number of fires on the American River Parkway rose.  Between Jan. 1 and Sept. 4, there were 53 wildfires in all county parks.  Drought and an increase in illegal camping were likely behind the uptick in fires.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 15, 2015
Places: Sacramento County, CA

Title: Low water levels, fires expose Native American sites in Lake County, California
Description: Prehistoric Native American sites have been revealed as wildfires burn away vegetation and water levels fall, exposing obsidian spear points and other long-hidden artifacts.Contra Costa Times (Walnut Creek, Calif.), Sept. 14, 2015
Places: Lake County, CA

Title: State of emergency due to wildfire in Lake, Napa counties in California
Description: A state of emergency was declared in Lake and Napa counties by Gov. Jerry Brown after a wildfire consumed more than 60 square miles within 12 hours, driving thousands of people from their homes.  The declaration will hasten debris removal and waive fees for people needing to replace official documents burned in the fire.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 13, 2015
Places: Lake County, CA, Napa County, CA

Title: The Valley Fire charred more than a thousand homes in Lake County, California
Description: The Valley Fire killed four people and destroyed 1,958 structures in Lake, Napa and Sonoma counties as the fire raged from Sept. 12 through Oct. 6 when the fire was contained.  The California Department of Insurance said the blaze caused about $700 million in insurance losses alone.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Jan. 25, 2016The Valley Fire remained the state’s third most destructive fire after burning 76,067 acres, destroying 1,910 structures and taking four lives.  Los Angeles Times, Sept. 24, 2015The Valley Fire has become the state’s third most destructive blaze in recorded history after killing at least three people, destroying 1,325 homes and businesses and blackening 76,067 acres.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Sept. 23, 2015A more comprehensive damage assessment revealed that the Valley Fire destroyed 1,238 single-family homes.  The blaze was 80 percent contained on Sept. 23.  The President issued a disaster declaration for the Valley Fire, allowing federal funds to be made available for displaced people and to support firefighting efforts.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 22, 2015The Valley Fire in Lake County consumed 75,100 acres and at least 888, structures, including nearly 600 homes.  The blaze was 53 percent contained on the morning of Sept. 20 and has become the 6th most destructive fire in California's history.  Three people lost their lives in the flames.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Sept. 21, 2015The Valley Fire consumed 73,700 acres in the Middletown area in Lake County.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Sept. 17, 2015Through Sept. 16, the Valley Fire has been the 9th most destructive fire in California history.  The blaze destroyed at least 585 homes and  70,000 acres and was 30 percent contained.  One life was lost.  When official counting was complete, the count of lost homes could reach 1,000 or more.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 16, 2015The Valley Fire consumed 67,000 acres in Lake, Napa and Sonoma counties and was just 15 percent contained on Sept. 15.  One elderly woman lost her life in the fire.  At least 400 homes in and around Middletown and a popular resort burned, although nearly 2,400 firefighters strove to slow the fire.  USA Today, Sept. 15, 2015The Valley Fire began in Lake County on Sept. 12 and quickly blew up into a 50,000-acre blaze that destroyed 400 homes and 10 commercial buildings in the vicinity of Boggs Mountain, Hidden Valley Lake and Middletown.  Firefighters had zero containment on the fire.Many California wildfires have spread faster than computer models predicted, while fire officials described the speed and destructive nature of the fires as the worst they had seen in decades.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 13, 2015
Places: Lake County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Drought among factors contributing to high rate of blanks in California pistachios
Description: Drought, heat and unusual weather on the West Coast were responsible for the high rate of blanks, or hollow nuts, in pistachios.  The blank rate is typically around 10 percent, but this year, the rate was nearer to 50 percent, said the executive director of the Fresno, Calif.-based industry group American Pistachio Growers.  Pistachios in the lower-lying parts of the San Joaquin Valley looked good, but those at higher-elevation edges of the valley and in the southern reaches were seeing the high rate of blanks.  The 2015 harvest could amount to 300 million pounds or less, down from 520 million pounds in 2014.National Public Radio (Washington, D.C.), Sept. 11, 2015
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Increasing vulnerability to saltwater intrusion in California's Salinas Valley
Description: Farmers in the Salinas Valley depended heavily on groundwater as the region endured drought.  The more water that is pumped from the aquifer, the more room there is for saltwater intrusion to contaminate the aquifer.  Lakes Nacimiento and San Antonio were constructed to replenish groundwater via the Salinas River, but drought has drained the reservoirs, leaving the area rather dry and vulnerable to saltwater intrusion.Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), Sept. 10, 2015
Places: Monterey County, CA, Greenfield, CA, King City, CA, Salinas, CA, Soledad, CA, Atascadero, CA, Paso Robles, CA, Shandon, CA

Title: State of emergency amid growth of Butte Fire in Calaveras, Amador counties in California
Description: The Butte Fire killed two people and damaged 818 structures as it burned from Sept. 9 through Oct. 1 in Amador and Calaveras counties.  The California Department of Insurance said the blaze caused $300 million in insured losses.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Jan. 25, 2016The Butte Fire charred 70,760 acres, 535 homes and 347 outbuildings in Amador and Calaveras counties and took two lives through Sept. 20.  The fire was 70 percent contained and has become the seventh most destructive fire in California’s history.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Sept. 21, 2015The Butte Fire destroyed 252 homes.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Sept. 17, 2015The Butte Fire was recognized as California’s 14th most destructive fire through Sept. 16 when the fire had consumed at least 233 homes and 71,780 acres.  Containment was at 45 percent.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 16, 2015The Butte Fire grew to 71,660 acres and was 37 percent contained on Sept. 15.  More than 4,500 firefighters were battling the blaze, which has consumed 166 homes and more than 100 other buildings.USA Today, Sept. 15, 2015The Butte Fire blackened 65,000 acres, 135 homes and 79 outbuildings since the blaze began on Sept. 9.  The fire was 25 percent contained on the evening of Sept. 13.  Many California wildfires have spread faster than computer models predicted, while fire officials described the speed and destructive nature of the fires as the worst they had seen in decades.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 13, 2015Gov. Jerry Brown declared a state of emergency in Calaveras and Amador counties on Sept. 11 as firefighters battled the Butte Fire, which had already consumed 64,728 acres and had the potential to grow rapidly.  The blaze was burning in steep topography through dry trees and brush, enhancing the fire’s spread on multiple flanks.  Officials feared the fire would continue to grow.  On the morning of Sept. 12, there were 3,299 firefighters, including 67 hand crews, 17 helicopters and 383 fire engines fighting the fire.  Fire crews worked to defend structures, rather than suppressing the fire’s growth.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Sept. 12, 2015The Butte fire grew rapidly and had blackened 4,000 acres in Amador and Calaveras counties through the morning of Sept. 10. Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 9, 2015
Places: Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA

Title: Remnants of Mormon Island emerged from Folsom Lake near Sacramento, California
Description: Remnants of Mormon Island have emerged as the level of Folsom Lake continued to fall.  Rusted tools and trinkets, a large road bridge and withered building foundations could be seen from the Gold Rush-era town.  On Sept. 9, Folsom Lake held about 188 acre-feet of water and was at 19 percent of total capacity, but could drop below the 1977 record-low of 150 acre-feet, say officials with the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 13, 2015
Places: Sacramento County, CA

Title: Water bottler ordered to stop taking water in foothills of Tuolumne County, California
Description: The State Water Resources Control Board ordered Sugar Pine Spring Water to stop tapping springs in the foothills of Tuolumne County and pay nearly $225,000 in fines after being notified to end pumping two years ago.  The company continued pumping water despite the unavailability of water for junior water rights holders.Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), Sept. 2, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Lavaca County, Texas, dry pastures, supplemental feeding required
Description: We had a lot of rain during the late winter and early spring. When summer hit, the water was simply shut off. We've had dribs and drabs of rain, but nothing substantial. The pastures are very dry with little for the cattle to graze on. Supplemental feeding with hay will begin early this year, if it hasn't already started. I run a small plant nursery and am still having to water daily and watch for some areas that need twice daily watering. This is also due to our unusually high temperatures for October. My retail customers are all commenting on the drought conditions and are reluctant to start their fall gardens.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Hallettsville 8.0 N on 10/16/2015
Places: Lavaca County, TX

Title: Ag company donating money for drought-affected families in California's Central Valley
Description: GAR Tootelian, Inc. worked with Farm Credit West and KMJ Radio to raise money to help feed Central Valley families affected by drought.  The agricultural company hopes to raise $100,000 to provide 500,000 meals for needy families.  For every $10 donated, GAR will donate $5.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Sept. 3, 2015

Title: More bats being found in pools in vicinity of Sacramento, California
Description: People have been finding more bats in their swimming pools than usual, which a Sacramento bat expert attributed to the drought and thirst.  Bat pups were born about two weeks early this year.  CBS, Sept. 1, 2015
Places: Sacramento, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Rangeland and pastures in the Coastal Bend of Texas deteriorating
Description: Rangeland and pastures in the Coastal Bend of Texas were deteriorating due to the hot, dry weather.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 1, 2015

Title: 90-day ban on outdoor burning in Bastrop County, Texas
Description: Bastrop County commissioners extended a ban on outdoor burning through Nov. 9, after several brush fires, 21 citations and three warnings for violating the no burn order.  The fire restriction began in August and prohibited the ignition of any combustible material outside of an enclosure to contain the flames or sparks.  The Bastrop County emergency management coordinator stated that he intended to raise awareness of the ban and the fire danger through social media and the county’s website.  Across the state, there were 125 counties with active burn bans, according to the Texas A&M Forest Service.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 29, 2015
Places: Bastrop County, TX

Title: Small community on edge of Tulare, California struggling with dry wells, praying for rain
Description: Domestic wells have run dry in Okieville, a small community on the edge of Tulare, leaving a group of residents to rig up a system and share water from a nearby well at a cost of $50 per month.  The manager of Tulare County’s Office of Emergency Services described such situations as “Third-World-type conditions.”Others have water trucked to their homes to refill 2,500-gallon water tanks that sit in the yard and get boxed drinking water, courtesy of the state’s $3.7 billion drought relief program.  Roughly 50 community members with dry wells were meeting together, trying to devise a manageable plan for getting running water for their homes again, but the water cannot flow soon enough for these people enduring another hot, dry summer.  Some people in the community resort to prayer for rain and relief from the drought.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Aug. 30, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tulare County, CA, Tulare, CA

Title: Water saving measures at jail in Orange, California
Description: Water-saving devices were being installed at the Theo Lacy jail in Orange to reduce the amount of water used in the facility.  Low-flow toilets, using 1.6 gallons of water rather than 3 gallons, were being tested to see how well they perform, given the many items inmates flush.  Installation of the 1,186 toilets would cost about $24,000.  New, water-saving timed shut-off valves were being installed in the showers to limit water waste.  One hundred forty-five valves were installed, with another 82 yet to be installed.  Each valve costs $6,000.A 3,000-square foot area previously covered with grass was replaced with free decomposed granite from Orange County Public Works.  Orange County Register (Calif.), Aug. 29, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Orange County, CA, Orange, CA

Title: Cal Fire urged caution to prevent additional wildfires
Description: Cal Fire urged people to be aware that mowers or trimmers with metal blades can spark fires when metal blades hit rocks as happened with two recent fires in Lake County.  Hot vehicles should not be parked in dry grass because hot engines can also start a fire, as can welding in dry grass.  All yard maintenance requiring the use of a gas or electrical motor ought to be completed before 10 a.m., not during the hotter part of the day or on windy days.  Lawn mowers should not be used in dry vegetation, but weed trimmers with a string line are a safer alternative.  Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Aug. 28, 2015
Places: Lake County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Algae bloom in Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta in California
Description: A large microcystis bloom has developed in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta as evidenced by small flecks of bright green in the water.  Microcystis is a type of blue-green algae that can produce lethal toxins in high concentrations to fish and people, but was not currently present in such concentrations.  The algae bloom was observed in the central and north parts of the Delta, and the highest microcystis concentrations were found nearest to the freshwater side of the salinity barrier.Scientists from the University of California-Davis, state water agencies and federal research groups were monitoring the unique algae bloom and were unsure of the exact cause, but thought that the bloom was produced through a combination of factors related to the warmer, slower water flow, due to the drought.  With winter’s snowpack delivering so little runoff, less water was flowing through the Delta, possibly allowing higher concentrations of nutrients from sewage, fertilizer and other pollutants to foster the algae bloom.Roughly 25 million people from Napa to San Diego to some extent rely on fresh water from the Delta, as do about 3 million acres of irrigated farmland.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 26, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Assistance for California families confronted by dry wells, wildfires
Description: The California Drought Relief Fund, a crowd-funding campaign, was started by a group of non-profit organizations and businesses to offer assistance to California families touched by drought and wildfires.  The fund will support local relief organizations helping families who run out of water due to severe drought, mainly in the Central and Salinas valleys, and wildfire victims statewide.  All funds raised will be shared among three local relief organizations: Self-Help Enterprises, the Environmental Justice Coalition for Water and the California Fire Foundation.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Aug. 26, 2015
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Federal judge allows water to continue flowing for fish on Klamath River in northern California
Description: A federal judge in Fresno denied a request for a temporary restraining order to block emergency water releases to protect Klamath River salmon from low, warm river flows.  The Westlands Water District and San Luis & Delta-Mendota Water Authority sought the order.  The judge felt that the water districts were not likely to win their lawsuit, which claims that the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation has no authority to release the water and should have done a more thorough study of the possible environmental harms.The bureau began releasing water for salmon from a reservoir on the Trinity River on Aug. 21.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 26, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Farmers offered assistance with converting from flood irrigation to drip system in Coachella Valley, California
Description: The Coachella Valley Water District offered farmers $1,500 per acre to permanently convert date and other tree groves from flood irrigation to drip systems.  The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, Central Arizona Water Conservation District, Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, Denver Water and Southern Nevada Water Authority contributed to the $1 million fund to support the conversion.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Aug. 25, 2015
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Group trying to stop Crystal Geyser from bottling water from Mount Shasta in California
Description: Crystal Geyser was the subject of a lawsuit filed in Napa County Superior Court by the group We Advocate Through Environmental Review (Water) which wants to prevent the company from bottling water from an aquifer that feeds the Sacramento River.  The group accused Crystal Geyser of failing to get the proper permits and violating land-use provisions if it goes ahead with plans to take water from Big Springs.  Siskiyou County was also named in the suit for allegedly disregarding its own rules and “rubber stamping” the plant, said the president of the nonprofit group’s board of directors.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com) (Calif.), Aug. 25, 2015

Title: Livestock receiving supplemental feed in parts of South Texas; rangeland, pastures deteriorating
Description: The rangeland and pastures in the western portion of South Texas deteriorated further from the dry weather. Soil moisture was short to very short. In McMullen County, deteriorating rangeland and pastures led ranchers to wean herds to ease grazing pressure. Soil moisture was short to very short in the northern counties of South Texas. Forage availability and quality had declined in the western area because soil moisture was short.Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 25, 2015

Title: Forage, hay crops, irrigated cotton in West Central Texas stressed from heat and drought
Description: Dryland cotton in West Central Texas was severely stressed by the lack of moisture and high temperatures, and even irrigated cotton was struggling.  Rangeland and pastures were drying up.  Producers were cutting hay, but yields were lower than those from earlier in the summer, due to the extremely dry weather.  Soil moisture was rapidly depleted.  Restrictions on outdoor burning remained in effect for all counties, with extremely high fire danger in areas with tall, dry forage and high winds.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 1, 2015Forage and hay crops in West Central Texas were stressed from heat and drought. Title: Less water for California wildlife refuges
Description: National wildlife refuges at Sacramento, Delevan and Colusa received just 75 percent of their typical water supply.  The Merced refuge had only enough water to flood half of its wetlands as drought limited water resources throughout the state.  With refuges getting less water, millions of migrating waterfowl will find less food and water awaiting them as they fly along the Pacific Flyway.  Salem Statesman-Journal (Ore.), Aug. 23, 2015

Title: Water conservation at Monterey County, California vineyard
Description: Delicato Family Vineyards near King City in Monterey County was lining its 14 miles of irrigation canals with fabric to keep water from seeping into the ground.  Difficult choices have also been made to conserve water:  selecting which of its 20 varieties of grapes are more important to cultivate and getting crop insurance on the less favored vines.  Drought has forced many other vineyards in the state to revisit their use of water to find any means of cutting back on water use.The New York Times, Aug. 20, 2015

Title: Citizens propose moratorium on new well drilling in Glenn County, California
Description: A Glenn County farmer brought the topic of a moratorium on new well drilling to the Glenn County Board of Supervisors.  With the water table dropping through four years of drought, the farmer and others from the group Save Our Water Resources wanted to make their voices heard.  Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Aug. 16, 2015

Title: Wildfire surged to nearly 37 square miles in Fresno County, California
Description: A lightning-sparked wildfire in Fresno County surged to nearly 37 square miles in a remote part of the Sierra National Forest on Aug. 18.  The fire was burning without any containment and prompted mandatory evacuations in the Hume Lake area and the closing of Highway 180.  The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 18, 2015
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Cuesta fire charred at least 300 acres in San Luis Obispo County, California
Description: The Cuesta fire charred at least 300 acres in San Luis Obispo County after the blaze was sparked by a vehicle which also started two other fires.  Embers jumped containment lines, carrying the fire toward Santa Margarita.  The blaze was 5 percent contained and was being worked by more than 250 firefighters.Years of drought and sustained heat have made California’s vegetation extremely susceptible to fire.Los Angeles Times, Aug. 17, 2015
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Margarita, CA

Title: High number of West Nile virus cases in California
Description: Butte County officials believed that drought is part of the reason for the high number of West Nile virus cases this year.  Thirty human cases have been detected in Butte County alone.  Eighty-eight mosquito groups—a record number—tested positive for the virus in the county.  The California Department of Human Health reported 36 human cases in 10 counties, including Butte, Glenn, Kern, Los Angeles, Nevada, Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino, Santa Clara and Tulare.  The state website updates its figures each Friday.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Aug. 17, 2015
Places: California, Butte County, CA, Chico, CA, Glenn County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Drought pushed grape harvest ahead of schedule in California's wine country
Description: Pinot Noir grapes grown in Mendocino, Sonoma and Santa Barbara counties were harvested far earlier than normal as the warm, dry winter and early budbreak moved the vines’ growing season earlier in the year.  Yields were low, allowing the harvest to be completed in a week rather than a month.  The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Aug. 16, 2015
Places: Mendocino County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Rainbow trout moved from warm Millerton Lake to cooler waters in Fresno, Madera counties in California
Description: About 80,000 pounds of rainbow trout were moved from the San Joaquin Hatchery in Millerton Lake to the cooler water in Shaver Lake to save the fish from warm water temperatures near 70 degrees.  The first trout transport began on Aug. 12, and another 50,000 pounds of trout will be moved to lakes in Fresno and Madera counties.  This was the first time fish had to be rescued from warm waters of the San Joaquin Hatchery.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Aug. 13, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Madera County, CA

Title: Shade balls to protect water in Los Angeles Reservoir
Description: Ninety-six million shade balls made from high-density polyethylene were dropped into the Los Angeles Reservoir to protect water quality, prevent algae growth and slow evaporation from the reservoirs.  The L.A. Reservoir has a surface of 175 acres and contains more than 3.3 billion gallons of water, 300 million of which are expected to be prevented from evaporating annually, thanks to the shade balls.  The project cost $34.5 million and was far cheaper than covering the reservoir with a more traditional protective cover.  The plastic balls do not leach any chemicals and ought to last 10 years.Los Angeles Times, Aug. 12, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Los Angeles, CA

Title: Many East Texas counties restrict outdoor burning
Description: Most East Texas counties also had bans on outdoor burning, given the intense heat and lack of rain in July and August and the rising fire danger.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 12, 2015 and Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 1, 2015

Title: Kaufman County, Texas, heat and drought hurting crops, trees, and grasses
Description: Temperatures reaching 105 degrees for several days and six weeks with no appreciable rain is devastating crops, trees, and grasses.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Terrell 8.2 SSW on 8/11/2015
Places: Kaufman County, TX

Title: 90-day burn bans in Montgomery, Brazoria and Fort Bend counties in Texas
Description: Burn bans were adopted in Montgomery, Brazoria and Fort Bend counties for the next 90-days, due to the recent and continuing hot, dry weather.  The Keetch-Byram Drought Index for Montgomery was 672; for Brazoria, 690; and for Fort Bend County, 679.  The two week outlook predicted values in the 740s for the counties.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 11, 2015
Places: Anderson County, TX, Angelina County, TX, Brazoria County, TX, Brazos County, TX, Burleson County, TX, Chambers County, TX, Cherokee County, TX, Fort Bend County, TX, Galveston County, TX, Gregg County, TX, Grimes County, TX, Hardin County, TX, Harrison County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Houston County, TX, Jasper County, TX, Jefferson County, TX, Lee County, TX, Liberty County, TX, Madison County, TX, Marion County, TX, Montgomery County, TX, Nacogdoches County, TX, Newton County, TX, Orange County, TX, Panola County, TX, Polk County, TX, Rusk County, TX, Sabine County, TX, San Augustine County, TX, San Jacinto County, TX, Shelby County, TX, Smith County, TX, Trinity County, TX, Tyler County, TX, Upshur County, TX, Walker County, TX, Waller County, TX, Wood County, TX

Title: California's Lake Isabella revealed long-submerged town
Description: Drought-depleted Lake Isabella revealed the tops of white cottonwood trees as more and more lakebed became exposed with the lake at 5.8 percent of capacity, holding 32,632 acre-feet of water.  The trees may have stood on old ranches along the Kern River or in the original site of Kernville, which was inundated when Lake Isabella was created.  The foundations of Old Kernville could be seen at the edge of the lake.Bend Bulletin (Ore.), Aug. 11, 2015
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: Burn ban in Harris County, Texas
Description: An outdoor burn ban was approved by the Commissioners Court in Harris County for the next 60 days, as requested by the county fire marshal.  Open-flame barbeque pit fires and campfires in designated rings were still allowed.  The Keetch-Byram Drought Index for Harris County was 670 on Aug. 11, compared to a typical August value of 400 to 600.Despite heavy rainfall and flooding in May and June, high temperatures dried out the area to the extent that the fire danger was a concern.  This is Harris County’s first open burn ban since the 2011 drought.Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 11, 2015
Places: Harris County, TX

Title: Only two boat launches still open at Lake Oroville in California; archeological finds
Description: Just two boat ramps remained open at Lake Oroville as the water level fell to 219.16 feet from the top of Oroville Dam on Aug. 10.  The two open boat launch areas were at Bidwell Canyon Marina and Spillway.  Bidwell Canyon’s three concrete lanes will likely close within days when the water level dips to 220 feet below the dam.  At that point, there would be just a gravel lane open at Bidwell, along with an asphalt lane at Spillway, which opened on July 31, said the state parks superintendent.  The low level of Lake Oroville has exposed more archeological finds that were previously underwater.  The park’s patrol staff was spending more time investigating crimes involving the disappearance of such items.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Aug. 10, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA

Title: Many California lakes still open, some boat ramps closed
Description: A fourth dry winter in California has depleted rivers and reservoirs, making vacationers adjust their summer plans to find somewhere appropriate for the activities they desire.  Despite years of drought, travel spending continued to climb 3.6 percent in 2014 to $117.5 billion, with 2015 being on track to be another great year.  The owner of a river rafting business near Healdsburg took numerous calls from potential visitors wondering if rafting was still available.  There was adequate water for rafting, but patrons must be prepared to climb out and walk in shallow areas.  A reservation manager at Shasta Marina Resort was also taking many calls from people making sure there was enough waterDespite the abysmal appearances of Lake Shasta and Lake Don Pedro, given the drastic drop in water levels over the years, visitors have still enjoyed their stay at the lakes.At Shadow Cliffs in Pleasanton, migrating Canadian geese were making themselves comfortable on the sandy beaches, to the annoyance of beachgoers and park rangers.  The rangers use remote-controlled “Goosinators” to get the birds to move.  In previous years, the geese congregated on the lawn, which is unwatered this year and apparently less appealing to the geese.Lexington Reservoir in Santa Clara County was closed to recreational users because the water level no longer allowed the safe launch of canoes or any other vessels.At Lake Tahoe, many boat launches were closed, causing more traffic at the available launches.  The Truckee River wasn’t suitable for tubing or rafting because the river was a series of puddles.  A visitor near the Truckee River opted to rent a bike to ride along the river rather than tube down the river as they usually do.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Aug. 9, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Alameda County, CA, Fremont, CA, Oakland, CA, Pleasanton, CA, Alpine County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Healdsburg, CA, Carson City, NV, Churchill County, NV, Douglas County, NV, Pershing County, NV, Storey County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: The Jerusalem Fire grew quickly near the Rocky Fire in Lake County, California
Description: The Jerusalem Fire burned 25,156 acres, nine homes and 18 other structures, but firefighters finally have the blaze more than 82 percent contained as of Aug. 16, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Aug. 16, 2015As of the afternoon of Aug. 13, the Jerusalem Fire had blackened 23,500 acres, or more than 36 square miles, but firefighters have made good progress on the fire, attaining 33 percent containment.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Aug. 13, 2015The Jerusalem Fire devoured 20,500 acres through the morning of Aug. 13 and was just 16 percent contained.  The fire tripled in size from the previous day, but the driver was the exceedingly dry vegetation, not wind, as often aids fire growth.  The energy release component of the vegetation, or amount of energy given off during combustion, was at record levels, stated Ken Pimlott, the director of Cal Fire, during an interview with KQED.  More than 2,000 firefighters and support personnel were battling the fire with 15 helicopters and 150 fire engines.Washington Post (D.C.), Aug. 13, 2015The Jerusalem Fire began on Aug. 9, roughly 7 miles to the southwest of the immense Rocky Fire, where 70,000 acres and 43 homes had burned near Clear Lake.  By Aug. 10, the Jerusalem Fire had charred 6,000 acres and was moving quickly through dry brush.  At least 150 people evacuated their homes.Many of the 1,100 firefighters, 83 fire engines, 17 helicopters and 23 bulldozers responding to the Jerusalem Fire were taken off the Rocky Fire, which was 85 percent contained on Aug. 10.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Aug. 10, 2015
Places: Lake County, CA, Napa County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Kendall County, Texas, trees dying
Description: Shrubs and small plants requiring more watering to survive. Lost several young flame-leaf prairie sumac trees.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Boerne 2.2 WNW on 8/9/2015
Places: Kendall County, TX

Title: Guadalupe River dry in San Jose, California
Description: Eight miles of the 14-mile Guadalupe River in San Jose went dry over the past couple of months, contributing to the absence or deaths of fish and other wildlife.  Water releases from four upstream reservoirs owned by the Santa Clara Valley Water District were effectively halved because years of drought have slashed reservoir storage.  Twelve of the about 30 primary miles of Coyote Creek were also dry.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Aug. 8, 2015
Places: Santa Clara County, CA, San Jose, CA

Title: Water quality standards loosened for California's Stanislaus River
Description: Water quality standards were loosened for the Stanislaus River to leave more water in the New Melones Reservoir.  Dissolved oxygen levels will be permitted to drop to 5.0 mg/L on the Stanislaus River at Ripon from the previous standard of 7.0 mg/L.  Poorer water quality may harm or kill fish in the river, but the change in water quality would allow more water to be kept in the reservoir for fall run salmon.Stockton Record (Calif.), Aug. 7, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Calaveras County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Kaufman County, Texas, high fire danger, crops dying, plants and grass dying
Description: Extremely dry conditions prevail. Surface cracks in the soil indicate that surface moisture has completely evaporated. Plants are dying and grasses are so dry that fire threat is prevalent. Crops are dying in the fields and nothing is growing with the exception of irrigated crops.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Terrell 8.2 SSW on 8/7/2015
Places: Kaufman County, TX

Title: Tehama County, California, wildfires burning, grass browning, weeds flourishing
Description: In July many oak trees started to look like Fall. Today, 8/2 as we look over the oak savannah we live in there are some trees who have lost all their leaves, some that have turned "fall orange" and probably 89% who appear "dusty" but remain green. I have been observing birds here for 14 years. In the past three months there have been three birds (all different breeds) in addition to the normal types that come to our bird baths.  Many fires burning 15+ miles from here. The sun peeks out from overhead clouds.  It is red. We are on an unmetered well but have cut back our use anyway. Our lawn is full of green weeds and brown grass.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Cottonwood 3.6 SSW on 8/2/2015
Places: Tehama County, CA

Title: Heat, drought of late summer halved cotton yields in Texas panhandle, West Texas
Description: The hot, dry August and September weather cut into high cotton yields in the Texas panhandle and West Texas where lush spring rains promised a good crop.  A sorely disappointed Howard County farmer expected about 10,000 bales from his 6,500 acres of cotton fields, but has realized he’ll only get about 4,000 bales.  In Midland, the farmers’ co-op cotton gin baled just 1,300 bales of cotton, considerably fewer than at this time in past years.  Adding to farmers’ problems were the weak prices for cotton since 2011, while production costs remained high.Midland Reporter-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 8, 2015

Title: Emergency pumping barge no longer needed in Lake Cachuma, California
Description: The emergency pumping barge that began sending water to the intake tower in August 2015 was no longer needed as the level of Lake Cachuma rose from about 7 percent at its lowest point to 46 percent of capacity on Feb. 27.Noozhawk (Santa Barbara, Calif.), Feb. 28, 2017An emergency pumping barge in Lake Cachuma, which was at 14 percent of capacity, needs to be moved to a deeper part of the lake.  The Goleta Water District, the City of Santa Barbara, the Montecito Water District, the Carpinteria Valley Water District and the Santa Ynez Improvement District all rely on the lake for water.KEYT-TV (Santa Barbara, Calif.), June 27, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Barbara, CA

Title: State of emergency in 14 California counties fighting wildfires
Description: California Gov. Jerry Brown declared a state of emergency in 14 counties dealing with wildfires to provide access to additional firefighting resources.  The 14 counties were Butte, El Dorado, Humboldt, Lake, Madera, Napa, Nevada, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Diego, Shasta, Solano, Tulare, Tuolumne, and Yolo.Times of San Diego (Calif.), July 31, 2015

Title: Large Southern California water supplier returned to full allocations
Description: The Metropolitan Water District voted to offer full allocations in 2016 after a winter of near-average snowfall in the Sierra Nevada, meaning improved water supplies.  Ten months ago the MWD voted to curb deliveries by 15 percent because winter snow fall was rather sparse and reservoir levels would not be refilled much by melting snow as typically occurs.  Water conservation remained a priority for MWD’s 19 million customers.Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), May 11, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: The Rough Fire charred 130,000 acres in mountains east of Fresno, California
Description: The Rough Fire burned 130,000 acres in the mountains east of Fresno and was the state’s largest fire.  Firefighters were working to protect ancient sequoia trees from the flames, including the General Grant Tree, the second-largest in the world, and the Boole Tree, sixth-largest.The blaze was sparked by a lightning strike on July 31.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 13, 2015
Places: Fresno County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: California's Rocky Fire blackened 65,000 acres
Description: The Rocky Fire was 85 percent contained on Aug. 10 after consuming 70,000 acres and 43 homes near Clear Lake.  As firefighters were wrapping up with the Rocky Fire, the Jerusalem Fire exploded to life about 7 miles to the southwest.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Aug. 10, 2015The Rocky Fire lit up 65,000 acres, or nearly 100 square miles, and destroyed 24 homes and 26 outbuildings in Lake, Colusa and Yolo counties since the fire began on July 29.  More than 13,000 people have been evacuated or warned to be ready to leave if needed.  The fire exploded to roughly three times in size over the weekend of August 1, creating its own winds which turned thousands of acres of manzanita shrubs and other brush to ash within hours.  The blaze was just 12 percent contained on the evening of Aug. 4.USA Today, Aug. 4, 2015
Places: Colusa County, CA, Lake County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Hot, dry weather limited soybean yield in Coastal Bend of Texas
Description: Potential soybean yields in the Coastal Bend were lowered by hot, dry conditions that sapped surface moisture.   My San Antonio.com (Texas), July 28, 2015

Title: Two children injured by falling pine tree in Pasadena, California
Description: Two children were critically injured when a 70-foot tall pine tree suddenly fell on a group of children outside of the Kidspace Children’s Museum in Pasadena.  The tree emitted a cracking sound and began to fall, said a witness.  KTLA-TV WB 5 Los Angeles (Calif.), July 28, 2015An arborist concluded that the prolonged drought, the absence of strong roots and a spate of rainy days preceding the event were the main reasons the tree fell.Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Dec. 18, 2016
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Pasadena, CA

Title: Grass regrowth slow in Montgomery County, Texas
Description: The lack of rain left hay fields in Montgomery County slow to regrow after a cutting.My San Antonio.com (Texas), July 28, 2015

Description: Rangelands and pastures in West Central Texas were manifesting signs of moisture and heat stress.  My San Antonio.com (Texas), July 28, 2015

Title: Drought changes timing of events in Yosemite National Park in California
Description: Drought has shifted the timing of numerous activities in Yosemite National Park as roads and trails opened early, the rafting season began and ended early and wildflowers did not bloom as long as usual.  Yosemite Falls and other falls will go dry earlier than usual.  Lafayette Daily Advertiser (La.), July 27, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Lowell Fire injured firefighters in Sierra foothills in California
Description: The Lowell Fire blackened 1,500 acres west of Alta in Nevada County and threatened 1,800 buildings.  Four firefighters were injured battling the blaze.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 26, 2015
Places: Nevada County, CA

Title: Willow Fire blackened more than 1,121 acres in Sierra National Forest in California
Description: The Willow Fire tore through 1,121 acres in the Sierra National Forest, southeast of Oakhurst in Madera County.  The blaze was just 5 percent contained on the evening of July 26 and was burning in an area of exceptional drought.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 26, 2015
Places: Madera County, CA

Title: Wildfire near Palomar Observatory in northern San Diego County, California
Description: A wildfire near the Palomar Observatory in San Diego County charred 167 acres in the Cleveland National Forest and was 20 percent contained on the evening of July 26.  The observatory was closed on July 25, due to the fire.  USA Today, July 26, 2015
Places: San Diego County, CA

Title: Wragg Fire burning intensely in Napa Valley of California
Description: The wildfire near Lake Berryessa scorched 10 ½ square miles and kept people from their homes.  The fire was more stable and not expanding rapidly as it had done on July 22. San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 24, 2015The Wragg Fire in the Napa Valley exploded to 6,000 acres in the Cold Canyon area near Lake Berryessa and damaged a home.  More than 200 structures were threatened by the blaze, which was only 5 percent contained.  "Super dry vegetation, four years of droughts [are] not helping us any," a CalFire captain told CBS News. "The winds keep changing and shifting direction."CBS, July 23, 2015
Places: Napa County, CA, Solano County, CA

Title: State of emergency in Butte County, California
Description: The Butte County Board of Supervisors ended the drought emergency, which was needed to receive federal funding.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), June 14, 2016Butte County was in a state of emergency due to drought, as declared by the county’s chief administrative officer.  Numerous domestic wells within the county have gone dry, and several sites have been set up to distribute free or low cost water for uses such as showers and dish washing.  People were urged to buy water for drinking.  Homeowners experiencing well failures were asked to call the county Department of Water and Resource Conservation or report the dry well online to help county officials understand how widespread well problems were.  People seemed to be reluctant to report weak wells for fear of being cited for health and safety violations.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), July 22, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA

Title: Land subsidence put bridge in water in Fresno County, California
Description: The Russell Avenue bridge in western Fresno County was in the water because excessive pumping caused the land and bridge to sink.  Boaters used to be able to float beneath the bridge, but no longer can.KFSN-TV ABC 30 Frenso/Visalia (Calif.), July 21, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Firebaugh, CA

Title: Central Valley irrigation district faced fine by California regulators
Description: The State Water Resources Control Board dismissed a $1.55 million fine against the Byron-Bethany Irrigation District and a complaint against the West Side Irrigation District.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 7, 2016The State Water Resources Control Board recommended dropping a $1.4 million fine against the Byron-Bethany Irrigation District, levied last summer when the group of Central Valley farmers was accused of taking water to which they were not entitled.  The board also favored dropping a civil suit against the West Side Irrigation District.  The full water board must approve the dismissals before they become final.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 26, 2016The State Water Resources Control Board was meeting in Sacramento to decide whether it properly restricted pumping last summer and to make a final decision on the fines for the Bryon-Bethany Irrigation District and the West Side Irrigation District.  The districts were accused of diverting water from the delta in June 2015, despite notice that their water rights were too junior for them to continue taking water.  Byron-Bethany was tentatively fined $1.4 million, while the West Side district was issued a cease-and-desist order and tentatively fined $10,000 per day.   San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 21, 2016The Byron-Bethany Irrigation District in the eastern San Francisco Bay area may be fined $1.5 million for taking more water than it is entitled to take, according to the State Water Resources Control Board.  State regulators say their records show that the water district took water from a pumping plant after receiving warning that the district could not legally take the water, despite its senior water rights.  If the fine stands, it would be the first against a holder of a claim dating back more than a century.The Byron-Bethany Irrigation District provides water for 160 farming families and a community of 12,000 people.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 20, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Joaquin County, CA

Title: Mexican immigrants can receive emergency assistance from Mexico
Description: Mexican people in California, unable to find work or suffering hardship  due to drought, can receive emergency rent assistance, clothing and food  and could be flown back to Mexico if they wish, stated the Mexican consul general.  Her jurisdiction includes 922,143 Mexican immigrants in 24 northern and central California counties.  The Sacramento Bee, July 19, 2015

Title: Flow restrictors can help Bay Area water wasters rein in their water use
Description: Flagrant water wasters in the Bay Area and beyond could get a little help in reducing their water use through the use of a flow restrictor, a 2-inch long brass cylinder.  Flow is cut by 72 percent when utility employees place one of the devices on a water meter.  On top of the limited water flow, water customers may also be charged a fee for putting on and removing the restrictor, depending on the policy of the water district using the device.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), July 18, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA

Title: Wildfire damaged, destroyed 30 vehicles in Cajon Pass in Southern California
Description: The North fire leapt over Interstate 15 in the Cajon Pass in the San Bernardino National Forest and damaged or destroyed 30 vehicles.  The origin of the fire was unknown, but it came from the north side of the freeway and burned 4,250 acres, or 6.6 square miles.  The blaze rolled through Baldy Mesa, consuming seven homes, 16 additional structures and another 44 vehicles, according to the U.S. Forest Service.Nearby, a wildfire along the Angeles Crest Highway prompted the evacuation of more than 300 people from campgrounds on July 18 and blackened more than 125 acres northwest of San Bernardino.  Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), July 20, 2015
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Delta smelt numbers dangerously low in Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta
Description: A key index of delta smelt abundance fell to zero in July because there were so few smelt in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta.  The numbers of delta smelt have been declining for years due to invasive predators, pollution, habitat loss and increased water exports through the delta.  Other native fish species, such as longfin smelt, green sturgeon and winter-run Chinook salmon, were also struggling to maintain a presence during the drought.Idaho State Journal (Pocatello, Idaho), Aug. 4, 2015
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: California water rights holders receive reissued notices from the State Water Resources Control Board
Description: The State Water Resources Control Board sent notices to 4,600 California water rights holders, who received similar letters from state regulators earlier this year, telling them to end diversions from the state’s rivers and streams.  The reissued notices have a softer tone, letting users know that they “should be aware that they may be subject to enforcement if they do not stop diversions (from rivers) due to insufficient water supply.”  The letters are not enforcement documents or legal orders, as the initial notices seemed to be.The revised notices came after a Sacramento Superior Court judge ruled that California regulators violated farmers’ rights by ordering mandatory water curtailments without allowing a prior hearing.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 15, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Kaufman County, Texas, ground cracking, plants suffering
Description: Ground cracks are opening in areas where ground is exposed. Trees are beginning to show yellowing leaves and grasses are drying in areas where exposed to sunshine. Even with the extensive rains from spring, dry conditions are beginning to impact plant life.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Terrell 8.2 SSW on 7/14/2015
Places: Kaufman County, TX

Title: Trail closed in Joshua National Park in Southern California to protect  bighorn sheep
Description: The 49 Palms Oasis Trail in Joshua Tree National Park was closed to hikers to allow bighorn sheep access to the one remaining water source in the park without being frightened away.  All other springs and water sources in the northern part of the park had gone dry after four years of drought.  Without people around, the sheep have been seen using the trail to get to the 49 Palms Oasis, which is something the rangers had not witnessed before.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), July 14, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Thirty percent fewer steers grazing in San Mateo County, California
Description: Thirty percent fewer steers were grazing on the coastal range in San Mateo County, due to less available forage.Redwood City-Woodside Patch (Calif.), July 13, 2015
Places: San Mateo County, CA

Title: Dispute over ownership of water in Millerton Lake, California
Description: A dispute over San Joaquin River water stored in Millerton Lake has arisen between growers on the east and west sides of the San Joaquin Valley.  Both parties claim to be the rightful owners of water in the lake as the result of a deal made between the two parties earlier this year.  The deal took place because drought prevented the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation from having enough water from the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta alone to fulfill the allocation for the San Joaquin River Exchange Contractor Authority this year.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), July 13, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Mallard duck breeding population at lowest on record in Sacramento Valley, California
Description: The mallard duck breeding population was the lowest on record at 27 percent lower than in 2014 and half of the long-term average.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 11, 2015

Title: California rinse stations at beaches, parks reopened
Description: The California Department of Parks and Recreation has ended its two-year ban on outdoor shower use at 38 state beaches.  Drought and the need for water conservation prompted the ban, which was not popular with beach goers.Los Angeles Times, April 19, 2017The California Department of Parks and Recreation closed rinse stations at beaches and parks on July 15 to conserve water. Title: Plan approved to release less water from Lake Shasta in northern California
Description: The State Water Resources Control Board approved a plan to keep more water in Lake Shasta to help winter-run Chinook salmon.  With less water leaving Lake Shasta, farmers will get an estimated 200,000 to 250,000 acre-feet less water during the growing season.  Farmers and elected officials besought the water board for more water, fearing that the reduced water flow would severely damage the agricultural economy.  Environmentalists and the fishing industry were a bit skeptical of the plan, too, because it allows water temperatures to rise to 58 degrees, two degrees higher than the normal limit, which may not protect the endangered fish.More water was flowing out of the Oroville and Folsom reservoirs to compensate for less water coming from Shasta.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 8, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Fish threatened by warm waters of West Coast rivers
Description: Nearly three-quarters of the lower reaches of 54 rivers in Oregon, California and Washington surveyed by the Wild Fish Conservancy were warmer than 70 degrees, dangerously high for salmon and trout.  Low snowpack from the warm, dry winter led to little runoff this spring and summer.Roughly 50 dead sockeye salmon at the mouth of the Deschutes River appeared to have died from gill rot, a condition exacerbated by warm water.An inland fisheries manager in California stated that emergency fishing closures were under consideration for the lower Merced, the American and the Klamath.  Fish in those rivers were severely weakened by warm waters.While well-meaning people in Washington have constructed impromptu rock dams to collect cool water for fish, staff from the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife was out clearing away the rocks to allow the fish to move upstream to spawn.  Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), July 8, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality

Title: California celebrity under investigation for water theft
Description: The Calleguas Municipal Water District filed suit against Tom Selleck in Ventura County Superior Court, claiming that the actor had copious amounts of water taken from a fire hydrant since 2013 and delivered to his home in Westlake Village.  The water district spent nearly $22,000 to have a private investigator document the alleged illegal activity.Los Angeles Times, July 8, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Westlake Village, CA, Ventura County, CA, Thousand Oaks, CA

Title: Trout dying in Truckee River in western Nevada
Description: The warm water of the Truckee River was threatening the survival of trout and has already allowed some fish to die.  The warmer the water, the less oxygen it holds, leading fish to congregate in cooler parts of the river, such as where a creek meets the river.  The fish were already weak enough that any effort to relocate the fish could kill them.  An employee with the Nevada Department of Wildlife stated that many of the fish would die this summer.Anglers were calling for a voluntary closure of the river, meaning no fishing, including catch and release.  They were also taking steps to protect the fish by creating shade over popular fishing holes and directing cool water from a creek to the fish.KOLO-TV ABC 8 (Reno, Nev.), July 7, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alpine County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Carson City, NV, Churchill County, NV, Douglas County, NV, Pershing County, NV, Storey County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: Cemeteries in Napa County, California curb water use
Description: The Tulocay Cemetery manager in Napa County was striving to use less water and irrigated every other day rather than daily, but he walks a fine line.  If he doesn’t water enough, relatives complain about the appearance of the grass.  If the grass is healthy, locals complain that too much water is being used.  Well water was being used instead of municipal water.Operators of other area cemeteries were using less water, monitoring for leaks, using variable-speed sprinklers to water smaller areas and choosing drought-tolerant shrubs and trees.Napa Valley Register (Calif.), July 7, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Napa County, CA

Title: Climate change, drought challenging survival of Joshua trees in Southwest
Description: Climate change and drought were taking a toll on Joshua trees in the Mojave Desert.  Seedlings are unable to survive with little rainfall and the rapid evaporation that occurs when moisture does fall.  Joshua trees grow only in the Mojave Desert.Los Angeles Times, June 7, 2015
Places: La Paz County, AZ, Mohave County, AZ, Imperial County, CA, Inyo County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mono County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Clark County, NV, Esmeralda County, NV, Lincoln County, NV, Nye County, NV, Washington County, UT

Title: Efforts to protect fish in the Truckee River in California, Nevada
Description: Trout in the Truckee River were confined by drought and warm water temperatures to the few areas of cooler water in the river.  To protect the fish, the Nevada Department of Wildlife has asked anglers to fish less during the warmer parts of the day and launched a “Rest Your River” campaign to encourage anglers to stop fishing when the water temperature reaches or exceeds 68 degrees, which often amounts to fishing only between 5 a.m. and 11 a.m.Individuals have also taken steps to help the fish by placing limbs over pools to keep water temperatures down and posting homemade signs, urging people to not fish.  Someone also posted a video on Facebook showing a spot where people moved rocks to direct water from a cold spring into a pool area.The flow of the Truckee River in Reno was just 44 cubic feet per second, compared to the average flow of 563 cfs, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.  Reno Gazette-Journal (Nev.), July 7, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alpine County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Carson City, NV, Churchill County, NV, Douglas County, NV, Pershing County, NV, Storey County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: California's Folsom Lake to be drawn down more slowly
Description: Rain and snow, on top of reduced water releases of 800 cubic feet per second from Folsom Lake, have allowed the lake level to rise to above normal levels for early February.  Folsom Lake had fallen to a historically low level in December, but has since refilled, prompting the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation to up water releases to 1,750 cubic feet per second to create “safe space” for potential winter storms that could cause flooding.  Long-standing federal guidelines state that the lake ought not to contain more than 577,000 acre-feet in early February, but at 11 a.m. on Feb. 5, Folsom Lake held 581,000 acre-feet.Folsom Lake was the only large reservoir in California to reach average storage after years of drought.  Other reservoirs were still sorely in need of more precipitation.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 6, 2016The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation released an average of 3,000 acre-feet of water daily from Folsom Lake through August, but will slow the releases to 800 cubic feet per second by the morning of Sept. 4.  As of noon on Aug. 31, Folsom Lake held roughly 196,000 acre-feet of water.  The higher releases during August were to keep saltwater from pushing into the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta and to retain more cold water in Lake Shasta for an endangered species of salmon.  With the smaller releases in September, Reclamation intended to “conserve water in storage,” and keep Folsom Lake above 120,000 acre-feet so the pumping infrastructure for suburban Sacramento would continue to work.  Reclamation was constructing a specially outfitted barge that could pump water to the city of Folsom if the lake were to fall below the city’s intake valves.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 31, 2015Folsom Lake will be drawn down more slowly this summer to ease the concern of Sacramento-area water agencies worried about the water supply.  The lake will likely dwindle down to 120,000 acre-feet at the end of September, but will not be allowed to drop further.  Water officials in the region worry that the valves that deliver water would not work at that level.To slow the drain of water from Folsom Lake, more water will be taken from Lake Oroville, one of the reservoirs in the Central Valley Project.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 7, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Sacramento, CA

Title: Many rural residents in Sonoma County, California missed reporting deadline
Description: Rural residents in Sonoma County within the watersheds of four Russian River tributaries providing habitat for imperiled fish have only partially complied with deadlines for mandatory reports concerning surface and groundwater use.  The State Water Resources Control Board required residents to submit reports documenting their monthly water use.  Only half of the 10,000 residents responded by the deadline, despite the threat of daily fines for failing to report their water use.  Water users were also ordered to end irrigation of ornamental turf, along with other restrictions on the use of potable water drawn from the watershed.  Aerial photography indicated that numerous properties seemed to be benefiting from irrigation, despite the regulations against it.  Low flows in the Russian River and its tributaries during the 2015 summer left water managers scrambling to pull together a plan to protect the watershed and prevent the extinction of Russian River coho salmon.  The river became a series of disconnected pools of warm water, allowing many fish to die.  The regulatory package took effect on July 6.Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), Nov 6, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Californians' water bills not shrinking, despite lower water use
Description: Californians were not seeing their water bills shrink despite lower water use because utilities have fixed costs that must be covered.  Often water rates rise with lower water sales, or drought surcharges help make up the difference in revenue.  Since cities were ordered to trim water use from 8 to 36 percent, revenue statewide was expected to drop $1 billion, which will likely come from customers.  In Santa Barbara, revenue was anticipated to fall $5 million if customers achieved the 20 percent cut in water use.  Consequently, water bills rose from $13 to $20, to cover the loss and pay to activate a desalination plant.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 5, 2015

Title: Drought increased arsenic concentration in water, caused skin condition in young boy in Riverside County, California
Description: Residents of St. Anthony Trailer Park, south of Palm Springs, were warned about the arsenic in their community well.  The ongoing drought has concentrated the arsenic, raising the level to twice the acceptable amount.  A 4-year old boy developed bumps on his head from being bathed in the arsenic-laden water.  Medical professionals said the condition was caused by the toxin.Washington Post (D.C.), July 5, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Pool repairs without draining pool very desirable amid California drought
Description: A Southern California pool repairman who can make the repairs without draining pool water is very popular at a time when water supplies are short and statewide mandatory restrictions are  in place.Los Angeles Times, July 5, 2015

Title: Milam County, Texas, wildlife coming close to houses in search of water, wildfires south of the area, dust and smoke affecting air quality
Description: Three and a half months without rain. Last rainfall was 0.55 on July 2nd.  Things are dying, looks almost as bad as during the drought of 2011. Wildlife is coming to the house to find water. Major wildfires just south of our area. Humidity >15% during the day. Dust & smoke have affected air quality.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Thorndale 8.8 N on 10/18/2015

Title: Coachella Valley Water District in Southern California collected drought penalties
Description: The Coachella Valley Water board decided to drop drought penalty fees for customers who exceed the individualized water budgets as of June 1 since state regulators lifted mandatory conservation targets for local agencies.  Roughly one-fourth of the 108,000 customers in the district have paid drought penalties, which were adopted in July 2015.The district's board will decide on a package of rate increases on June 14.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), May 25, 2016The Coachella Valley Water District collected more than $1.9 million in drought penalties in July, nearly making up for the $2 million shortfall in revenue due to conservation, compared to July 2014.  The penalties ranged from a few dollars up to several thousand dollars, according to the district spokeswoman.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Aug. 10, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: California's Santa Clara Valley Water District adding $4.6 million to its successful landscape conversion rebate program
Description: The Santa Clara Valley Water District added an additional $4.6 million to its landscape conversion rebate program.  While the expanded budget of $22.8 million has been nearly spent for the year, the district was looking for additional funds to continue the rebates.  The district has paid rebates for the removal of 2.9 million square feet in 2015, with another 3.5 million square feet that has been approved and was in progress through the program.  The added $4.6 million will allow roughly another 2 million square feet to be converted, totaling 8 million square feet.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Nov. 9, 2015

Title: Temporary ban on new vineyards, expansions of existing vineyards in Santa Monica Mountains, California
Description: The Los Angeles County supervisors compromised and extended the ban on new or expanded vineyards by only four months, rather than 10 months and allowing existing permit applications to proceed.Los Angeles Times, July 28, 2015The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors imposed a temporary ban on new vineyards or extensions of existing vineyards in the north Santa Monica Mountains because numerous vintners submitted new vineyard applications. Description: A third consecutive year of drought has produced another crop of fine grapes in the Napa Valley.  The grapes turn out smaller, but have more concentrated sugar and a more complex flavor.CBS (New York), June 29, 2015

Title: California's San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District trying to work with EPA on PM-2.5 levels
Description: Drought has dramatically increased the concentration of PM-2.5, particulate matter of 2.5 microns or smaller in width, in the San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District.   The Valley will not be able to bring PM-2.5 levels down enough to meet the Dec. 31 cleanup deadline for the 1997 standard.  To avoid the possibility of a federal takeover of the air quality district’s cleanup plan, or “the nuclear option,” the SJVAPCD offered an improved cleanup plan and asked the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to move back deadlines to 2018 for 24-hour readings and 2020 for the annual average.  The district already sought a waiver on the high readings during extreme drought conditions, which drive PM-2.5 levels higher, but the EPA refused.  The Fresno Bee (Calif.), June 26, 2015
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: San Francisco among senior water rights holders told to stop diversions
Description: Restrictions on California’s senior water rights holders were lifted, allowing them to divert water from rivers and streams.  The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Oct. 27, 2015Another 16 senior water rights holders were told by the State Water Resources Control Board to end diversions.  The order affected senior diverters on the upper San Joaquin River, the Merced River and San Francisco’s rights on the Tuolumne River.  Rights on the Merced River dating back to 1858 were affected, while on the upper San Joaquin, all rights holders except riparian ones were affected, including several irrigation districts, a ranch, a dairy and Pacific Gas and Electric Company.Los Angeles Times, June 26, 2015

Title: Cal Fire suspended burn permits for outdoor open residential burning in 6 counties
Description: Cal Fire suspended burn permits for outdoor open residential burning in Napa, Colusa, Lake, Solano, Sonoma and Yolo counties, effective June 29.  Residents were also urged to clear debris within 100 feet of their homes to protect the structures from fire.Napa Valley Register (Calif.), June 25, 2015
