Title: Some Central Valley water agencies considering ignoring the curtailment notices from the State Water Resources Control Board, litigation underway
Description: Some Central Valley water agencies were considering ignoring the curtailment notices from the State Water Resources Control Board and continuing to divert water from rivers.  Lawyers for the SWRCB clarified the board’s position this week by stating that the curtailment notices were “advisory” and that no punishment or sanction would be dealt to rights holders who disregard the notice.  Water districts have contacted the SWRCB, saying that they agreed with the agency’s attorneys and that the notices need not be respected.  Critics say that the state board does not have the authority to order curtailments and that due process is needed.  At least three lawsuits have been filed over the curtailment notices.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), June 25, 2015

Title: Drought among factors leading grower to bulldoze cherry trees in Leona Valley, California
Description: Drought and monthly irrigation costs of up to $900, in addition to damage from a winter heat wave, late frosts and hungry birds and bark beetles, drove the owner of a cherry orchard to bulldoze the trees.  Experienced cherry farmers said that 2015 was the worst year for cherries in memory.Bend Bulletin (Ore.), June 24, 2015
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Leona Valley, CA

Title: California drought shifts opinions of Bay Area residents on water issues
Description: Bay Area residents have taken a different view of purified toilet water, given the epic drought gripping the state.  In a Bay Area Council poll conducted in April, 58 percent of survey participants said that they approved of adding treated recycled water to the drinking water supply.  Sixty-three percent of respondents were in favor of building more dams and reservoirs, with 23 percent strongly supporting the idea.  "That's a high number in an environmentally-conscious place like the Bay Area," said the spokesman for the Bay Area Council, a pro-business advocacy group. "This all suggests that people want to look more seriously at these types of solutions that, in the past, haven't had this great acceptance either because of environmental, health or cost reasons."San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), June 24, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Numerous wildfires burning in western U.S.
Description: Wildfires engulfed parts of the drought-stricken West and Alaska, triggering evacuations.  In northern California, a wildfire charred more than 25 square miles near Lake Tahoe and threatened the town of Markleeville.  A lightning strike sparked the fire on June 19.  A blaze in a remote part of the San Bernardino Mountains blackened about 27 square miles, while a fire near Santa Margarita in central California consumed nearly 3 square miles and destroyed two homes, four mobile homes, two recreational vehicles and more.In Oregon, firefighters battled two blazes: a nearly 8-square mile fire that was about 50 percent contained in the Rogue River Siskiyou National Forest in the southwestern part of the state, and a 175-acre fire south of the Succor Creek State Natural Area in eastern Oregon.Numerous wildfires raged in the interior of Alaska, with 242 fires burning on nearly 503 square miles.  Washington Post (D.C.), June 23, 2015
Places: Alaska, California, Alpine County, CA, Oregon, Washington

Title: Low water levels in California’s drought-sapped rivers and streams exposed more riverbed for prospectors seeking gold
Description: Low water levels in California’s drought-sapped rivers and streams have exposed more riverbed for prospectors seeking gold.  Some stretches have become too dry for panning and sluicing, but in the meantime, prospectors keep finding new areas rich with gold.  Hardware and mining supply stores from Columbia in Tuolumne County to Auburn in Placer County benefited from the renewed interest of locals and tourists hoping to find a few pieces of gold.  In 2013, sales at Pioneer Mining Supplies in Auburn climbed 25 percent from such activity.  The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 22, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Farmers switch to different crops in San Diego County, California
Description: San Diego County growers were switching from citrus to less thirsty crops, such as grapes, to make the most of expensive water.  In recent years, the number of wineries in the area tripled.  The costly irrigation water also prompted farmers to take several thousand acres of citrus and about 10,000 acres of avocados out of production.  KPBS-TV PBS San Diego, June 22, 2015
Places: San Diego County, CA

Title: More than 2 million dead trees in Southern California
Description: More than 2 million trees died in Southern California, revealed a survey performed by the U.S. Forest Service.  About half of the dead trees were in the Los Padres National Forest north of Los Angeles.  Bark beetles, which thrive on trees stressed by drought, were observed in the trees.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), June 22, 2015
Places: Imperial County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Fireworks prohibited in unincorporated El Paso County, Texas
Description: The sale and use of fireworks in unincorporated El Paso County was prohibited on the Fourth of July for the fifth straight year.  The county judge issued a declaration of local disaster, valid for 60 hours, as drought conditions continued to intensify.  It was hoped that Gov. Greg Abbott would extend the declaration through midnight on July 5.  El Paso Times (Texas), June 22, 2015
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Wildfires burn in Madera County, California
Description: A fire in Madera County charred 134 acres near O’Neals and led to the evacuation of a portion of the town on June 21.  The fire was 20 percent contained and had damaged no structures, according to Cal Fire.The previous day, hundreds of firefighters fought two wildfires in North Fork and near Oakhurst.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), June 21, 2015
Places: Madera County, CA, North Fork, CA, Oakhurst, CA

Title: More water held back in Shasta Reservoir to protect California winter-run salmon
Description: Water releases into the Sacramento River were reduced to 7,250 cubic feet per second to hold back more water in Shasta Reservoir in an attempt to prevent a massive fish die-off later in the year.  In September 2014, there was not enough cold water to avoid the deaths of 95 percent of the winter-run salmon. Woodland Daily Democrat (Calif.), June 20, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Massive wildfire burning in Alpine County, California
Description: The massive wildfire in Alpine County blackened 18,000 acres through the evening of June 28 and was 45 percent contained.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), June 28, 2015A wildfire charred more than 25 square miles near Lake Tahoe and threatened the town of Markleeville.  A lightning strike sparked the fire on June 19.  Washington Post (D.C.), June 23, 2015
Places: Alpine County, CA

Title: Limestone County, Texas, dry soils, pastures dead, farmers depleting hay stores to feed cows, low water levels
Description: Limestone County Texas is currently in a state of exceptional drought.  The last significant precipitation at this station was on June 17, 2015, and the only measurable precipitation during that period was 0.06 on August 21, 2015. At Station TX-LT-4, Crockett 2 soils are dry, packed, with deep cracks; native and domestic grasses in pastures are dead, and native ferns are dormant or dying.  Older trees are still in remarkably good shape, thanks to last years' spring rains.  Wildfires have been common here, with losses of hay and pasture in Shiloh VFD fire district, and the threat to animals and humans lives is great.  Ponds to mid sized reservoirs are at 1/2 to 3/4 capacity; larger reservoirs are faring better due to soaring rains.  Hay that was harvested in the early summer is being depleted due to use for animals this fall; most pastures are no longer able to support large animal operations.  The main economic impact of the current drought so far has been on cow-calf operations, who are being forced to use up valuable winter hay stores before the fall is halfway over; a hay shortage may occur in small- to mid-sized operations.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Mexia 5.9 S on 10/22/2015
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Limestone County, TX

Title: Lake Fire raging in San Bernardino County, California
Description: The Lake Fire in the mountains east of San Bernardino scorched 30,000 acres and was 50 percent contained.  The fire began on June 17 and was the largest fire burning in California as of June 30.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), June 28, 2015
Places: San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Most beaches in California's Bay Area received top marks
Description: The annual Beach Report Card survey found that 98 percent of Bay Area beaches got top marks, indicating that bacteria counts in the water were relatively low.  Droughts result in better water quality along California’s coastline when less storm-drain runoff is released into the water, thanks to drought.  Drought allowed about 50 beaches to receive better ratings than they would have received apart from the drought, according to a water expert and head grader for the survey.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), June 17, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Plumas County, California, high water rates, water use restrictions
Description: Increased water rates, mandatory restrictions on water use.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Quincy 2.3 E on 6/15/2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Plumas County, CA

Title: Mountain House, California seeking alternative water supply
Description: Mountain House, a community of 11,000 people, lost its only water supply when the Byron-Bethany Irrigation District had its water rights curtailed recently by the State Water Resources Control Board.  Officials with the Mountain House Community Services District announced a tentative water deal with South San Joaquin Irrigation District, which has not yet approved the sale.  The SSJID curtailed water deliveries to its customers and was suing the state over water rights curtailments.In any case, the state has a “health and safety” exemption to keep water flowing to communities with no other water supply, providing Mountain House with water. The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 22, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Joaquin County, CA, Mountain House, CA

Title: Senior water rights holders in the Sacramento, San Joaquin and delta watersheds in California ordered to stop pumping
Description: Restrictions on California’s senior water rights holders were lifted, allowing them to divert water from rivers and streams.  The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Oct. 27, 2015Senior water rights holders in the Sacramento, San Joaquin and delta watersheds must stop pumping from those waterways as ordered by the State Water Resources Control Board amid California’s fourth year of drought.   The drastic curtailment order involves 114 entities in the fertile Central Valley, from individual landowners to water districts with water claims dated 1914 through 1903.   The SWRCB was expected to order more senior rights holders to stop pumping in coming weeks and has not asked for such significant cuts since the 1977 drought when senior water rights holders also received curtailment orders.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), June 12, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought surcharge of 25 percent for customers of the East Bay Municipal Utility District in California
Description: East Bay Municipal Utility District directors voted unanimously to end the 25 percent drought surcharge imposed in June 2015 after a relatively wet 2015-16 winter boosted reservoir levels to 93 percent of normal.  EBMUD mandated 20 percent water conservation beginning in April 2015, compared to 2013, and customers responded by curbing their water use by 24 percent.  The drought surcharge will end on July 1.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), May 12, 2016The East Bay Municipal Utility District decided to drop drought fines for customers who exceeded the district’s conservation quotas after winter precipitation refilled some reservoirs.  Since July 2015, residential customers have paid nearly $597,000 in fines.Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), April 27, 2016Customers of the East Bay Municipal Utility District will be paying a temporary 25 percent drought surcharge, following a unanimous vote by the board of directors.  The drought surcharge will pay for nearly 60,000 acre-feet of water purchased from four sellers.  The board voted on April 14 to declare a stage four critical drought and order a district-wide mandatory 20 percent reduction in water use.  The EBMUD service area includes Danville, parts of San Ramon, and the unincorporated towns of Alamo, Blackhawk and Diablo.DanvilleSanRamon (Calif.), June 9, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Shrinking reservoir in Monterey County, California, exposes Civil War veteran's gravesite
Description: After drought caused Monterey County's San Antonio Lake to shrink, the headstone of a Civil War veteran, Cpl. John McBride, was exposed. A camper found the headstone and brought it to park headquarters. A park ranger who was familiar with the story of McBride fastened the headstone to the gravesite with a metal bracket. San Jose Mercury News (California), June 8, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Monterey County, CA

Title: Riverside dropped lawsuit against State Water Resources Control Board
Description: The Riverside city council chose to drop the city’s lawsuit against the State Water Resources Control Board over water conservation orders because the state water board decided to end mandatory water conservation and allow local district to set their own conservation standards.  Riverside sued the state on June 4, 2015 after the state board ordered the city to curb water use by 28 percent over 2013.  Riverside wanted a 4 percent savings mandate because its water supply came from groundwater, while the state said that the city’s water use or savings affected the state’s groundwater system.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 31, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, Riverside, CA, Sacramento, CA

Title: Drought may have played a part in increase in West Nile in San Diego, California
Description: So far this year, 29 birds, mostly crows, have tested positive for West Nile virus in San Diego County. Health officials believe that drought conditions may be partly to blame, because changes in stream flow can cause water to pool in unusual places. People are also more likely to let swimming pools gradually dry out or collect rainwater in containers. San Diego Union-Tribune (California), June 4, 2015
Places: San Diego County, CA

Title: Lawsuit over water, fish well-being in California's Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta
Description: The California Sportfishing Protection Association and others brought a lawsuit against the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation and the State Water Resources Control Board, claiming that Reclamation and the SWRCB were violating environmental laws by dividing diminishing water flows through the delta from the Sacramento and San Joaquin rivers.  The alleged mismanagement of water networks has resulted in near extinction for some native fish.U-T San Diego (Calif.), June 4, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Smartphone apps for water conservation in Placer County, California
Description: The Placer County Water Agency has two smartphone apps to help people conserve water.  One app is a shower timer which calculates approximate water use.  The second, and more controversial, app allows people to report water wasters, with the goal of promoting water conservation.  Northwest Cable News (Seattle, Wash.), June 3, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Placer County, CA

Title: Fire danger closed hiking trails in Riverside County, California
Description: High fire danger spurred Cal Fire and Riverside County Fire officials to close seven hiking trails on June 3 to prevent human-caused fires and to protect the public.  Areas off-limits are the North Mountain/Indian Canyon area in the mountains between San Jacinto and Beaumont; the Ramona Bowl/Bautista Canyon areas just east of Hemet; Avery Canyon near Gibbel Road and State Street on the west side of Hemet; the Lakeview/Nuevo area and Reinhardt Canyon, both west of San Jacinto; the Minto Way area in Sage, south of Hemet; and Whitewater Canyon near Cabazon, north of I-10.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), June 3, 2015
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Officials plan to use satellite surveillance over fallowed fields in Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta
Description: Water officials will use satellite surveillance in the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta to confirm that fields have been left fallow, as stipulated in voluntary conservation agreements with farmers. Growers offered to reduce their water consumption by 25 percent in summer 2015 to avoid deeper mandatory cuts later in the year. To achieve the water reductions, farmers are planting fewer crops like alfalfa and more crops that grow faster, such as silage for corn livestock feed. The San Diego Union-Tribune (California), June 2, 2015.
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: California's water conservation resulted in energy savings, reduction in greenhouse gas emissions
Description: Water conservation in California between June 2015 and February 2016 resulted in energy savings of 922,543 megawatt-hours, which is enough to power 135,000 homes for a year, and also reduced greenhouse gas emissions, found researchers from the University of California-Davis.  During that time, Gov. Jerry Brown’s initial emergency conservation program was in effect, requiring all water users to curb their use by 25 percent.  Electric utilities and water districts were also ordered to submit reports on their operations, reports that were used by UC Davis to determine the savings.Los Angeles Times (Calif.), June 7, 2016
Categories: Energy, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Roughly $29 million in landscaping lost to water conservation efforts in Placer County, California
Description: Four hundred of Placer County Water Agency’s 29,000 customers were surveyed and sixty-three percent admitted to losing landscaping while conserving water last year.  The estimated value of the lost vegetation amounted to about $29 million across the water agency’s service area.  Most water customers, or 83 percent of survey respondents, voiced a positive view of the agency’s performance, and 81 percent have a positive view of the agency’s communication efforts during the drought. Sixty-nine percent of the customers surveyed were willing to conserve in 2016 at a level comparable to 2015, while 23.5 percent were less likely to conserve as much and 5.8 percent were unsure of their conservation commitment in 2016.  The survey’s margin of error is plus or minus 5 percent.  Auburn Journal (Calif.), March 10, 2016
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Placer County, CA

Title: Southern California's Coachella Valley water agencies missing conservation targets
Description: Five of the six water agencies in Coachella Valley missed their water conservation mandates in October, which could lead to more fines from the State Water Resources Control Board.  The Coachella Valley Water District and Indio were fined $61,000 each toward the end of October.  The CVWD’s board of directors voted to appeal the fine, while Indio officials have not yet decided whether to appeal.  Their conservation efforts in October amounted to a savings of 28 percent for the Coachella Valley Water District, short of their target of 36 percent, and a savings of 20 percent for Indio, falling short of their 36 percent target.  Coachella water users cut their water use by 27 percent in October, topping their 24 percent conservation goal for the first time since June.  The Desert Water Agency missed its target the most, curbing water consumption just 21 percent, short of their 36 percent mandate.  From June through October cumulatively, none of the water agencies hit their targets.  Most of the agencies had not fined any individual water users for excessive consumption.  In the second week of November, the Coachella Valley Water District pushed toward greater compliance by increasing penalty fees for its heaviest water users and banning outdoor watering on two days from December through March.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Nov. 11, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, Coachella, CA, Indio, CA

Title: California’s State Water Resources Control Board responded to water districts missing targets
Description: California’s State Water Resources Control Board issued 97 warnings, 119 other documents asking for compliance and four fines since June 2015 when water users statewide were ordered to save 25 percent of water used through February 2016, compared to the same month in 2013.  The overall conservation since June 2015 slid to 24.8 percent and will be difficult to improve by the end of February.Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), Feb. 25, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Orange County, CA, Anaheim, CA, Costa Mesa, CA, Fullerton, CA, Garden Grove, CA, La Habra, CA, Newport Beach, CA, San Juan Capistrano, CA, Santa Ana, CA, Seal Beach, CA

Title: Water district in Riverside County, California asked for larger cut to outdoor watering
Description: Eastern Municipal Water District ordered its customers to cut irrigation by 70 percent in an effort comply with the 28 percent water target that the district has missed for six months.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Jan. 7, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, Hemet, CA, Menifee, CA, Moreno, CA, Murrieta, CA, Perris, CA, San Jacinto, CA, Temecula, CA

Title: Coyote sightings, missing pets more common in Santa Cruz County, California
Description: Coyote sightings have become more common than previously in Santa Cruz County, as have reports of missing pets.  The California Department of Fish and Wildlife received seven reports of coyote sightings since June 1, including attacks on dogs, cats and chickens.  The Santa Cruz County Animal Shelter has taken more calls about coyote sightings near residential areas than usual.  The police department in Capitola has received a number of reports of fatal coyote attacks on cats in the past few weeks.  Fish and Wildlife has been getting roughly a dozen reports weekly about coyote attacks since June, shared a wildlife biologist with Fish and Wildlife, monitoring Santa Clara, San Mateo, San Francisco and Santa Cruz counties.  While the number of sightings was above normal, the biologist thought that drought could be part of the reason for the increase as the animals search for food and water in residential areas.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), July 22, 2015
Places: San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Capitola, CA

Title: Burn permits suspended in San Diego, Imperial counties in California
Description: Effective June 1, Cal Fire suspended all outdoor open residential burn permits in San Diego and Imperial counties because drought has elevated the fire danger.  KGTV-TV ABC 10 San Diego, June 2, 2015
Places: Imperial County, CA, San Diego County, CA

Title: Some California celebrities promote water conservation
Description: Some celebrities residing in California have been drought-shamed on social media for having luxurious lawns and landscaping, in contrast to other Californians who strive to conserve as much water as possible.  A number of celebrities have stepped up to promote water conservation and responsible water stewardship through the installation of drought-tolerant gardens.  The Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 31, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Beverly Hills, CA, Hollywood, CA, Malibu, CA

Title: Attempts to stop salt water intrusion into Delta lead to complications for boaters, ferries in Contra Costa County, California
Description: After the state of California installed a salinity barrier on the False River as a drought measure to protect Delta drinking water from salt water intrusion, currents shifted dramatically, causing problems for boaters and ferries. Bradford Island and Webb Tract are accessible only by ferry or boat. San Jose Mercury News (California), June 8, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Wild salmon died in Butte Creek, California
Description: More than 10 percent of the largest population of wild salmon in the Central Valley died from warm water temperatures in Butte Creek.   Repair work was being performed near a power plant to fix a leaky canal.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), June 19, 2015
Places: Butte County, CA

Title: Trees suffering in California
Description: Water conservation in California has had an unintended effect: trees have gone unwatered and were showing signs of stress.  Statewide, trees were dying, which will reduce habitat, shade and property values, prompting cities to act before more trees are lost.  In Palo Alto, water from basement excavations is collected in a large water truck and is used to water trees.  A city arborist noted that trees were turning color at least a month ahead of schedule.  Species suffering the most along the Sierra’s western slopes included pine trees, especially Jeffrey, lodge pole, ponderosa, sugar and white bark varieties.  In the canyons of the state’s Central Coast, the Santa Lucia firs were dying at higher rates.  The giant sequoia trees in Sequoia and Kings Canyon national parks were also affected by drought, with more dead foliage than usual in 2014 and 2015, reported a spokeswoman for the parks.  A researcher with UC Davis, who manages biodiversity data for the California Department of Fish and Wildlife, stated that the drought was transforming landscapes, promoting the establishment of chaparral over woodland.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Aug. 16, 2015Persistent drought, high winter temperatures and insufficient irrigation were killing coast redwood trees in Southern California.  The trees fare better in Northern California, but even there the trees manifested signs of stress.  California oaks, a relatively drought-resistant species, were struggling amid the drought too.Oakland Tribune & Inside Bay Area (Calif.), May 25, 2015
Places: California, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mono County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Palo Alto, CA, Sierra County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Sod grower in Oxnard, California unhappy with downturn in sales and the public's distaste for grass
Description: A sod-grower in Oxnard expressed frustration that Californians suddenly were averse to putting in lawns amid ongoing drought and water restrictions.  His sales were suffering, and he felt that he was under fire because he sold a product that had become unpopular.CBS, May 23, 2015
Places: Ventura County, CA, Oxnard, CA

Title: Environmentalists, ranchers cooperating to guard Owens Valley, California habitat, wildlife
Description: Environmental activists and ranchers in Owens Valley began cooperating to protect ranch land after the Department of Water and Power revealed plans in April to drastically cut irrigation allotments for half of Inyo County’s 50 ranches.  If the ranches were to receive no water, the land could not support livestock or the natural habitat, which would be detrimental to wildlife.  To protect the ranch land, environmentalists agreed to end water diversions to restore the Lower Owens River and control dust blowing off of the dry bed of Owens Lake.  Los Angeles Times, May 20, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Inyo County, CA, Mono County, CA

Title: Los Angeles receiving no water from Owens Valley over the summer
Description: An earthen and concrete dam which diverted runoff to Owens Valley was removed after irrigation season ended, and Los Angeles Department of Water and Power had met its legal obligations in the Owens Valley to keep the Owens River flowing, control dust from a dry lake bed and irrigate pasture where cattle graze.   San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Oct. 28, 2015Los Angeles will not receive any water from Owens Valley through November, due to the thin snowpack.  The Owens Valley has provided Los Angeles with water since the aqueduct was completed in 1913.Los Angeles Times, May 20, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Inyo County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Los Angeles, CA, Mono County, CA

Title: West Nile virus arrived early in Tulare County, California
Description: Ongoing drought is thought to be playing a role in the early appearance of mosquitoes with the West Nile virus in Tulare County.   No people have reportedly contracted the virus yet.  Visalia Times-Delta (Calif.), May 20, 2015
Places: Tulare County, CA, Dinuba, CA, Orosi, CA, Visalia, CA

Title: Parasite infecting nearly all juvenile salmon in Klamath River in northern California
Description: Nearly all of the juvenile chinook salmon in the Klamath River in northern California were infected with a deadly parasite that thrives when the river is warm and low.  Additional water releases would wash parasite-laden worms down the river, but water stored in the Klamath Basin reservoirs was already set aside for endangered sucker fish and threatened coho salmon.  The Klamath Fish Health Advisory Team say that a major fish kill is likely.Roughly 6 million juvenile chinook were being held at the Iron Gate fish hatchery with the hope that conditions will improve and the fish can be released.Porterville Recorder (Calif.), May 20, 2015
Places: Del Norte County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Trinity County, CA

Title: Water quotas on tap for customers of San Jose Water Co. in California; customers protest
Description: More than 350 San Jose residents attended a public hearing to voice their comments, which were mostly negative, about the upcoming water rules to take effect June 15.    People protested to San Jose Water Company officials that the proposed regulations should be revised because the rules did not fully appreciate the water needs of large families and those with large yards.  From July through September, all residential water users will be allotted 13 units of water monthly, based on the district’s average  residential use, and will be charged $7.12 per unit above the stated amount.  The company intends to go ahead with the new rules.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 29, 2015The San Jose Water Co. sent notices to its customers, warning them of strict water quotas beginning in mid-June, and penalties for exceeding those quotas.  The limit for residential water consumption is 70 percent of the average water use per home for the same period in 2013, or a cut in water use of 30 percent on average.  The San Jose Water Co. provides water for one million customers in San Jose, Saratoga, Los Gatos, Monte Sereno, Campbell and part of Cupertino.San Jose Water, being a private company, must receive approval from the California Public Utilities Commission before the water quotas can take effect.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), May 20, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Campbell, CA, Cupertino, CA, Los Gatos, CA, Monte Sereno, CA, San Jose, CA, Saratoga, CA

Title: State Water Resources Control Board accepted plan offered by farmers with senior water rights in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta
Description: Around 120 farmers with senior water rights in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta turned in their plans outlining how they would achieve 25 percent water conservation.  The Fresno Bee (Calif.), June 2, 2015The State Water Resources Control Board approved the plan put forth by farmers with senior water rights in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 22, 2015Farmers with senior water rights in the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta have offered to curb water use by 25 percent in exchange for having no further restrictions on their water use for the summer.  Water would have to be left in the delta or 25 percent of crops would be left unplanted.  The State Water Resources Control board was considering the proposition.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 20, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Water held back in Lake Shasta to aid survival of California's winter-run Chinook salmon
Description: The State Water Resources Control Board ordered a 10-day reduction in water releases from Lake Shasta to protect an endangered species of salmon.  The reason for keeping more water in the lake was to hold water temperatures at or below 56 degrees for the benefit of winter-run Chinook, which will lay their eggs this summer.   It seemed certain that the water level would exceed the 56-degree threshold.Weeks ago, farmers agreed to leave their water in Shasta Lake longer than usual, but despite that effort, water temperatures were rising more than expected because there was very little snowmelt to cool the lake.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 3, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: About 1,900 wells have dried up in California
Description: Mark Cowin, director of the state Department of Water Resources, reported to a California Senate joint oversight hearing that roughly 1,900 wells have gone dry.  Of the 4,500 or so monitored wells in the state, 40 percent have dropped more than 2 feet, more than 15 percent have fallen more than 10 feet and some wells plummeted more than 25 feet in central California.  "Significant to severe" drops in groundwater were also seen in the Central Coast and Southern California.Los Angeles Times, May 17, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Tulare County, CA, East Porterville, CA

Title: Attendance down at Lake Oroville in California
Description: Prior to the summer season, State Parks lowered fees at Lake Oroville to draw more people to the lake because attendance has dropped nearly 50 percent in recent years.  Lower fees only increased park visitation by 5 percent, compared to 2014.  Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Aug. 10, 2015
Places: Butte County, CA

Title: California golf courses making water-saving landscaping choices
Description: Operators of California’s golf courses were tearing out turf and replacing it with drought-tolerant landscaping to cut down drastically on water use and the cost of irrigation and maintain an attractive appearance.  The landscaping change is being carried out in areas where play will not be affected.Average 18-hole golf courses in the state cover 110 to 115 acres and conservatively use nearly 90 million gallons of water annually, stated a water management consultant who works with golf courses statewide.  Some golf courses pay as much as $500,000 to keep grass lush and green.Turf replacement rebate programs have golf courses snapping up the assistance with landscaping costs because they can get $2 to $3 for each square foot of turf removed.  Metropolitan Water District, on the other hand, was considering lifetime rebate caps to avoid exhausting its funds.  A golf course architect appreciated all of the available work with so many golf courses making big changes to save water and money.Associated Press (New York), May 13, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Orange County, CA, San Diego County, CA

Title: Charity fishing tournament moved from Southern California's Diamond Valley Lake to another lake with a usable boat ramp
Description: A charity fishing tournament that was to be held at Diamond Valley Lake was moved to Vail Lake because Diamond Valley Lake's boat ramp was closed.   Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 12, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Public urged to use wastewater from washing machines to irrigate landscaping in Kern County, California
Description: Kern County supervisors ordered staff to push the idea of the public using water from their washing machines to irrigate yards as historic drought persists.  The county has no plans to limit residential watering, but wise use of resources is always beneficial.  The washing machine wastewater must be released a minimum of two inches below the ground.Kern County officials were also considering building a water conservation website and employing county communication systems to disseminate conservation information to residents.Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), May 12, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: Stage 4 drought restrictions in California's East Bay
Description: The East Bay Municipal Utility District moved to stage 4 drought restrictions to urge even greater water conservation.  This is the first time such stringent water restrictions were enacted.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), May 11, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Californians becoming increasingly outraged at companies bottling and selling the state’s water amid drought
Description: Protesters planned on May 20 to rally outside the Los Angeles and Sacramento water bottling plants operated by Nestle Waters North America to express their opposition to businesses profiting from selling California’s precious resource.  Other water bottlers in the state include PepsiCo, Starbucks and Coca-Cola.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 19, 2015Californians were becoming increasingly outraged at companies bottling and selling the state’s water amid a four year drought.  Crystal Geyser Water Co. was opening a plant at the base of Mount Shasta in Siskiyou County and intends to take up to 365,000 gallons of groundwater daily, according to the San Francisco Chronicle.  Nearby residents worry that the plant will run their wells dry.  There are 108 bottling operations in the state.California law in general does not limit the amount of groundwater that property owners can withdraw, but regulation of the most endangered aquifers will begin after 2020 per legislation passed in 2014.Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), May 10, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Siskiyou County, CA

Title: San Diego, Orange County opposed to California water targets regardless of districts' water source
Description: San Diego and Orange County water authorities were irritated that the new water reduction targets imposed by the State Water Resources Control Board did not consider how and where cities get their water or give credit for mitigation efforts undertaken years ago.  Drought in the early 1990s led San Diego water officials to construct the Western hemisphere’s largest desalination plant, which will begin operation in the fall of 2015.  The Orange County Water District, serving 2.4 million people, began recycling wastewater in 2008 by sending it through ground basins.  The district was increasing production from 70 million gallons of water daily to 100 million gallons.  Both water districts feel that the SWRCB ought to give them more credit for water conservation.The Denver Post (Colo.), May 10, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Orange County, CA, San Diego, CA

Title: California's Bay Area pool, hot tub construction not thriving amid new water restrictions, drought
Description: Bay Area pool builders and hot tub retailers were struggling to keep customers from cancelling construction contracts as water restrictions and intense drought deter people from using water.  During the past two months, six customers cancelled contracts for new pools, said the manager of pool companies in Pleasanton and San Jose. Even before the recent tightening of water restrictions, the recession, combined with the persistent drought, pulled down business 30 to 40 percent, he reported.  The anxiety over the slump in business has contractors wondering if they ought to be looking for a different line of work.  Contractors have also had to locate new sources of water to fill the pools, given that water restrictions prohibit the use of potable water for pool and hot tub filling.  Business owners feel that they are being misrepresented as water wasters when they claim that pools actually use less water than lawns do.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 10, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Officials from Santa Clara, California met to generate new ideas for motivating public to conserve water
Description: About 100 members of city councils, school boards and other local bodies came together at the Santa Clara Convention Center to discuss ways to fire up the public about water conservation and to reform attitudes about other people’s water use and behavior being the problem."We really need people to step up and make some significant behavioral changes," said Felicia Marcus, chairwoman of the State Water Resources Control Board.  "We can't act too soon."The Santa Clara Valley Water District asked its customers for a 30 percent reduction in water use.  Results of an April survey found that 80 percent of registered voters support the goal, but 36 percent say they cannot cut their water use further, and 44 percent say they could curb their water consumption more.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 9, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Clara, CA

Title: Unpleasant water taste for East Bay Municipal Utility District in California
Description: As the East Bay Municipal Utility District begins drawing warmer water near the surface of Pardee Reservoir, the taste of the water will change as it did in late March 2015 when EBMUD took water from the upper level of the reservoir.  The warm water has algae that give the water a distinctive taste, prompting complaints in March.  EBMUD must preserve the pool of cold water in the lower part of the reservoir to meet legal obligations to protect threatened fish species which need the cool water.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), May 8, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Berkeley, CA, Oakland, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Walnut Creek, CA

Title: Turf removal programs popular in Riverside, California
Description: Turf removal rebates offered by Riverside Public Utilities were popular, with customers rapidly exhausting the nearly $5 million fund.  The utility’s assistant general manager said that the public was taking advantage of the rebate as quickly as the program receives funds.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 7, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Sacramento County Sheriff patrol saving water on vehicle washing, making inmates more aware of drought
Description: Sacramento County Sheriff’s patrol vehicles were being washed less frequently to conserve water as California’s drought barreled into its fourth year.  The Sacramento and Branch Center car washes will be open to wash patrol cars and county vehicles one day per week, rather than three.  Bumper stickers explaining the dusty appearance of patrol cars will be attached to each patrol vehicle.The sheriff’s department aims to curb water use in county jails and its own department by posting signs alerting inmates to drought and asking them to save water taking shorter showers, using water sparingly and by flushing toilets only “when necessary.”  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 6, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sacramento County, CA

Title: California, Nevada and Arizona wildlife search for food, water
Description: Drought is threatening the viability of some ecosystems because the devastation of one species can start a chain reaction among other species.  This situation is being played out on the Carrizo Plain, northwest of Los Angeles with the near loss of the giant kangaroo rat, which are often found emaciated and starved.Elsewhere in California, wildlife is suffering, too, from the absence of food and water sources.  Fish kills, destruction of salmon eggs and disease among migrating waterfowl are a few of the tragedies arising from drought, as is the predation by other hungry species desperately looking for a meal.  The Nevada Department of Wildlife is also preparing for an increase of concern for animal welfare.  To help animals, the department placed guzzlers in more than 1,000 wilderness areas statewide to water thirsty animals.  In Arizona, the Game and Fish Department cautioned residents of Flagstaff to be prepared for an influx of wildlife looking for food and water.  Washington Post (D.C.), May 6, 2015
Places: Coconino County, AZ, Flagstaff, AZ, California, El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Nevada, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: Hiker rescued along dry stretch of the Pacific Crest Trail in Alpine County, California
Description: An 18-year old hiker became stranded and disoriented on the Pacific Crest Trail in Alpine County and activated his spot satellite personal tracker.  The man used up his water supply and planned to refill at water sources along the way, but the sources were dry due to drought.  USA Today, May 6, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alpine County, CA

Title: California golf courses using private wells ordered to curb water use by 25 percent
Description: California golf courses that rely on private wells must reduce their water use by 25 percent or water no more than twice weekly per the governor’s mandate for water restrictions.  The golf courses are required to keep records of their water use and must share them with the state if asked.Los Angeles Times, May 3, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Riverside County, CA

Title: Tuolumne County, California, stressed trees and plants, huge fires
Description: This summer was end of four year below normal rain.  Only had a trace of rain since spring, which is normal, but trees & vegetation are cumulatively stressed.  Thousands of both conifer & hardwood trees are dying on private and National Forest Land.  Catastrophic fires are occurring in central and northern California.  75,000 acres burned last week in Calaveras County in Central California.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Tuolumne City 2.0 N on 9/15/2015
Places: Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Outfitters on the Kern River in California faced another year of dismally low flows
Description: Outfitters on the Kern River faced another year of dismally low flows at 10 percent of normal, cramping business plans while stimulating business owners to come up with new activities to bring in a few dollars.  Some businesses have closed and await a better year.  River’s End Rafting & Adventure on the lower Kern River closed for the 2015 season, leaving its 20 employees to seek work elsewhere.  The rafting business owner tried running an adventure camp for kids in 2014 and an “amphibian” land-and-water 5K, but lost money despite his creative effort.  On the upper Kern River, some rafting companies were offering scenic kayak trips and stand-up paddle board lessons.   In Kernville, Sierra South Paddle Sports only sees up to 150 customers per day, in comparison with better years when 600 to 700 people would navigate the river per day.  What used to be an exhilarating 20-mile trip has become a lazy three-mile drift relying more on kayaks rather than inflatable rafts.Los Angeles Times, June 30, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: Ongoing subsidence in California's San Joaquin, Sacramento valleys
Description: NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory identified two major bowls of subsidence in California related to additional groundwater pumping associated with recent years of drought.  They were located near Chowchilla, south of Merced, and Corcoran, north of Bakersfield, and continued to sink nearly 2 feet per year between May 2015 and Sept. 2016.  Other parts of the San Joaquin Valley were sinking, as well, such as near Tranquility, where sinking increased in the past year and occurred at a rate of up to 20 inches per year.  Some subsidence occurred in the Sacramento Valley near Davis and Arbuckle.  A new patch of subsidence was discovered in Sierra Valley, north of Lake Tahoe.YubaNet.com (Nevada City, Calif.), Feb. 28, 2017
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Arbuckle, CA, Fresno County, CA, Tranquillity, CA, Glenn County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Avenal, CA, Corcoran, CA, Lake County, CA, Madera County, CA, Chowchilla, CA, Merced County, CA, Napa County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Solano County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Davis, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Junior water rights holders must end diversion in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta of California
Description: More than 2,700 junior water-rights holders along the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta and the Sacramento River were ordered by the State Water Resources Control Board to end diversions for the second year running.  Most of those affected are farmers.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 1, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Butte County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Limited water releases from Lake Mendocino in California
Description: The State Water Board approved lowering water releases from Lake Mendocino into the Russian River from May 1 through Oct. 27, 2015.  Sonoma County Gazette (Calif.), May 1, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Hiking trail in California's Yosemite National Park opened three weeks early
Description: Sparse snowfall in Yosemite National Park and early snow melt allowed Glacier Point Road, Tioga Road and Half Dome trail to open weeks ahead of schedule. Snow and ice normally impede travel into May.Los Angeles Times, May 3, 2015The Half Dome trail in Yosemite National Park opened three weeks early on May 3, due to drought and low snowpack after a disappointing winter.  The trail normally opens on May 23.Los Angeles Times, April 30, 2015
Places: Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: California rice acreage expected to drop as water shortage limits production
Description: The California Rice Commission anticipated more idled rice fields in 2015, due to reduced water allocations in the Sacramento Valley.  In 2014, rice growers planted 23 percent less rice acreage than the previous year, reported the commission.Rice growers in the Sacramento Valley were warned to plan on receiving less water in 2015 than last year.  Farmers along the Sacramento River with senior water rights can expect 75 percent of their full allotment.  Irrigators diverting from the Feather River will get 50 percent of their contracted amount.  On the east side of the valley, growers will get 40 to 70 percent of their allotments, while farmers who buy water from the Central Valley Project will get no water for the second year in a row.These reduced water allocations mean that rice growers will have to fallow land to wisely use the water they do receive.  The shortfall also means that there will be less water available for transferring to others in need of water.  Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), April 29, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Placer County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: California Water Service Co. to assign customers water budgets to meet conservation targets
Description: California Water Service Co. stated that in order to meet the water conservation target of as much as 36 percent, customers will be given monthly water budgets starting June 1.  Customers who use more water than their budget allows will see drought surcharges of twice the highest residential water rates on their water bills.  Water budgets vary by customer.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), April 29, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Livermore, CA, Chico, CA, Oroville, CA, Selma, CA, Willows, CA, Kern County, CA, Bakersfield, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Redwood Valley, CA, King City, CA, Salinas, CA, Stockton, CA, San Mateo, CA, South San Francisco, CA, Los Altos, CA, Dixon, CA, Visalia, CA, Thousand Oaks, CA, Marysville, CA

Title: California's East Bay Municipal Utility District seeking additional emergency water supplies
Description: The East Bay Municipal Utility District secured one emergency water supply and was looking to purchase a total of 65,000 acre-feet of emergency water at a cost of $55.8 million.  Such a purchase would provide four months’ worth of water for the district that serves 1.3 million customers.  Customers may have to pay higher water rates to cover the water purchases and must reduce water use by 20 percent, compared to 2013 water use.The purchase of up to 21,000 acre-feet, comprised of 10,000 acre-feet from the Glenn-Colusa Irrigation District in Willows, 5,000 acre-feet from the Sycamore Mutual Water Co. in Colusa and 6,000 acre-feet from Reclamation District 1004 in Colusa, may cost as much as $25 million.  The Glenn-Colusa water became available because rice farmers chose to fallow fields, said the district’s general manager.  A portion of the sale revenue will be shared with farmers who idled fields.Oroville Mercury-Register (Calif.), April 28, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA

Title: Water diversions in California's San Joaquin River watershed ordered to stop
Description: The State Water Resources Control Board began notifying 1,500 water rights holders, mostly Central Valley farmers in the San Joaquin River watershed, that they must stop pumping from streams to leave the water for rights holders with more seniority.  The order only affects those who obtained their water licenses after 1914, but further restrictions on water access are expected in coming months.Senior water rights holders, those with rights prior to 1914, in the San Joaquin River watershed may face cutbacks this year, the State Water Board cautioned.  Statewide, farmers, cities and energy companies have about 36,000 claims to divert water.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), April 23, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Water diversions ordered to end along Scott River watershed in Northern California
Description: Roughly 100 rights holders along the Scott River watershed in rural Northern California were told by the State Water Resources Control Board to end water diversions.  Further restrictions on water access are expected.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), April 23, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Siskiyou County, CA

Title: Smelt numbers very low in Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta
Description: The March trawl survey for adult smelt conducted by the California Department of Fish and Wildlife found only four females and two males in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta.  The April survey turned up just one fish.  Counts of longfin smelt have also fallen to record lows.  Early in April, the State Water Resources Board chose to limit Sierra runoff to the estuary, due to drought, and depriving fish of the cold, fresh water that enhances survival.  Among the threats to the smelt are water being pumped from the delta, increased salinity in the fall, improved water clarity in the summer and fall and competition and predation from introduced species, according to California Fish and Wildlife.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), April 20, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Aggressive wildfire threatened 300 homes in Riverside County, California
Description: The Highway Fire near Corona grew explosively and blackened at least 300 acres in Riverside County and threatened 300 homes.  "This is an example of what the drought has done, these fuel conditions, normally this wouldn't burn in this kind of area," said a fire chief with Cal Fire.CNN (Atlanta, Ga.), April 19, 2015
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Kern River Festival in Kern County, California cancelled
Description: The Kern River Festival, scheduled for April 18 and 19, was cancelled due to the drought and low flow in the river.Los Angeles Times, June 30, 2015
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: Water conservation program in the works for Contra Costa Water District in California
Description: The Contra Costa Water District board voted unanimously in favor of a conservation program to help its 500,000 customers cut water use by 25 percent.  Outdoor watering would be permitted twice weekly, and higher water rates would begin in June to encourage lower water use.  Those who violate the conservation rules would be fined.  The conservation program, increased water rates and fines must receive final approval at a June meeting before taking effect.   San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), April 15, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Low water levels close Lake Tahoe boat ramps
Description: Lake Tahoe, having been below its natural rim since October 2014, will have fewer boat ramps open during the 2015 summer.  The ramps that are likely to remain closed the entire summer include the popular Sand Harbor ramp, just south of Incline Village; Coon Street on the north shore at Kings Beach, California and on the south shore at El Dorado Beach and Tahoe Vista, California.  The summer boating season typically begins on May 1.San Diego Union-Tribune, April 15, 2015
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: Congress not eager to address water concerns of group from Fresno, California
Description: Officials and business leaders from the Fresno area embarked on their annual federal lobbying trip to Washington D.C., with the goal of securing aid to improve water supplies during epic drought.  Their meetings were not particularly fruitful where water was concerned as drought and the water supply were apparently seen to be a California issue.  Legislation about California’s water issues did not seem to be an urgent concern to the dismay of the Fresno group.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 14, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Wildfire burning in Plumas National Forest in Northern California
Description: The Ward Fire charred 185 acres since it began on April 13 and moved into the Plumas National Forest.  The blaze was driven by winds and compounded by drought.  More than 158 firefighters fought the fire on April 14, trying to get a handle on it before it grew larger.  USA Today, April 15, 2015
Places: Plumas County, CA

Title: Fire agencies increasing staffing early along California's central and southern coast
Description: Along California’s central and southern coasts, fire agencies have upped staffing levels ahead of schedule, due to the exceedingly dry landscape after years of drought.  Ventura County Fire, Santa Barbara County Fire and state fire crews in San Luis Obispo County and the San Benito-Monterey area were bringing in firefighters, fire engines, bull dozers, helicopters and air tankers.  In the Los Padres National Forest, firefighters and equipment were put into place early.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), April 13, 2015
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Orange County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: More water conservation projects in the works for Coachella Valley communities in Southern California
Description: Palm Desert responded to the governor’s call for 25 percent water conservation by curtailing water use in its parks and median landscapes by 25 percent.  The water feature in Joe Mann Park was turned off and will remain so during the summer, saving the city at least 1,500 gallons of water per day, according to the city spokesman.  Irrigation at Civic Center Park is being cut by 10 percent, and all other parks will be watered 25 percent less.  Misting systems will not be used this year, conserving about 100 gallons per hour.The neighboring communities of La Quinta, Cathedral City, Palm Springs and Indio were also making changes to conserve water.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), April 8, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, Cathedral City, CA, Indio, CA, La Quinta, CA, Palm Desert, CA, Palm Springs, CA

Title: Possible cuts in water deliveries from Metropolitan Water District in California
Description: The Metropolitan Water District officials will vote next week on cuts in water deliveries to its member agencies and cities.  The reduction in water delivery is anticipated to be in the 10 to 20 percent range.  The MWD serves 19 million Californians.Manteca Bulletin (Calif.), April 7, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Reduced irrigation supplies in the Klamath Reclamation District on the Oregon-California border
Description: The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation announced that irrigators in the Klamath Reclamation District would receive just 65 percent of their full allotment in 2015, due to low snowpack.  The 300-square-mile irrigation district will actually provide 100 percent of requested water to some farmers, while others will get no water on account of the complex maze of irrigation districts, reservoirs and contracts, said a representative of the KRD.  Oregon authorities are not likely to permit additional groundwater pumping to compensate for reduced water deliveries, due to over pumping in recent years.  Farmers are expected to suffer greatly this year.Local wildlife refuges will get no water in 2015, except for those on lands leased to farmers to grow crops, stated a spokesman for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.  This year is the region’s fourth consecutive year of water shortages.The Bulletin (Bend, Ore.), April 9, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Klamath County, OR

Title: Emergency drought salinity barrier in Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta in California
Description: The emergency drought barrier in the West False River between Jersey and Bradford islands was completely dismantled after being installed in May and June to keep saltwater out of the central Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta from San Francisco Bay.  The barrier maintained the water quality in the delta without releasing large amounts of water from upstream reservoirs to flush out salty water.East County Today (Antioch, Calif.), Nov. 17, 2015The California governor’s order announcing mandatory water restrictions also cut red tape for permitting and review of the emergency drought salinity barriers, one of which will be constructed on Bradford Island.  State water officials got the permit from the reclamation board and began surveying, but a supervising engineer with the Department of Water Resources said that building the barrier was not a certainty.  State officials took steps toward the construction of drought barriers in 2014, but significant rainfall made the measure unnecessary. Some locals vehemently oppose the construction of the barrier, fearing Discovery Bay would become a mosquito-infested, stagnant swamp with invasive weed overgrowth.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), April 12, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Water shortfall in Western Nevada's Carson Valley
Description: Carson Valley irrigators relying on surface water were expected to run short early in 2015 because the Carson River Basin held just 14 percent of average moisture for March and had less than 50 percent of the year to date average.  Some producers will see a second year of no irrigation water.To help agricultural communities cope with the shortage, University of Nevada Cooperative Extension held drought workshops in Gardnerville, Lovelock, Fallon and Yerington in April and May.The Record-Courier (Gardnerville, Nev.), April 3, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alpine County, CA, Churchill County, NV, Douglas County, NV, Lyon County, NV, Pershing County, NV, Storey County, NV

Title: Farm community leaders passionately urge California's Gov. Brown to send more water to the Central Valley
Description: Farm community leaders from Fresno and Tulare counties met in Selma to passionately urge Gov. Brown to send more northern California water to the San Joaquin Valley to keep land in production, keep farmworkers employed and prevent groundwater levels from continuing their rapid decline.  The Tulare County supervisor spoke about the 1,000 domestic well failures, the majority of which were in the eastern part of the county, since the drought began.  He urged the state to create a low-interest loan program to replace unproductive wells, rather than force the families to rely on emergency water deliveries from the county.The Fresno County supervisor mentioned the ramshackle homeless encampment created by unemployed farm laborers on the edge of Mendota.  He stressed the need for water to flow in the valley again to reduce unemployment and described the situation as being “like a Third World country.”The Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 2, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Skiers must climb to reach skiable snow in Sequoia National Park in California
Description: Good skiable snow could be found at 10,000 feet in Sequoia National Park, but it was quite a trek to get there.  Drought and warm temperatures have erased much of the snow at lower levels.Eureka Times-Standard (Calif.), April 2, 2015
Places: Tulare County, CA

Title: Power plant lacked cooling water in Palo Pinto, Texas
Description: The R.W. Miller 403-megawatt power plant in Palo Pinto went offline due to the lack of cooling water.  The area remained in extreme to exceptional drought.The New York Times, April 22, 2015
Places: Palo Pinto County, TX, Palo Pinto, TX

Title: Possible regulation on air pollution from fireplaces in the Bay Area of California
Description: The Bay Area Air Quality Management District is considering new regulations to improve air quality because the Bay Area has experienced more Spare the Air days in recent years.  Spare the Air days are called when the amount of particulate matter in the air exceeds standards, prompting the district to prohibit all wood burning.   All Bay Area property owners may need to install federally certified fireplace inserts or wood-burning stoves that filter out fine particles from the chimney.  Drought and the lack of storms has contributed to the poor air quality by not clearing the air of particulate matter.Bay Area Air Quality Management District board members were expected to reach a decision on the issue in the fall of 2015. San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 31, 2015
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Nestle targeted for water use in California
Description: Nestle changed its operation and installed new filtration systems at its Modesto plant to reuse wastewater from its condensed milk-making process.  After treating the liquid, it will be used, rather than fresh water, for cleaning and cooling, said Jose Lopez, the company’s head of operations.  “It doesn’t make economic sense to do this, obviously. The drought this year is teaching us you have to think of ways to adapt. What seems today not fully advisable from an economic standpoint will become a necessity,” said Lopez.  Nestle made the change amid very recent criticism of the company’s and other water bottlers' use of California’s freshwater.  In March, protesters with plastic pitchforks blocked gates at Nestle’s water-bottling facility in Sacramento.  More than 82,000 people signed a petition urging Nestle to stop bottling water from a spring in southern California.Washington Post (D.C.), May 13, 2015Nestle has become the target of a group protesting the bottling and sale of Sacramento water for profit.  The leader of the group opposing Nestle termed the company’s bottling of water during the drought as “extremely egregious.”A spokeswoman for Nestle stated that the company purchased roughly 50 million gallons from Sacramento in 2014.Napa Valley Register (Calif.), April 27, 2015
Categories: Business & Industry, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kern County, CA, Bakersfield, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Sacramento, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Modesto, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tulare, CA

Title: East Bay water customers complain about new taste, odor in water from Pardee Reservoir in California
Description: Some East Bay residents noticed their water had a different taste and odor in late March 2015, and logged more than 200 complaints with the East Bay Municipal Utility District.  The problem began after EBMUD began drawing water from the upper levels of Pardee Reservoir to leave the cooler water near the bottom for use in the fall when salmon spawn in the Mokelumne River.   More algae exist in the upper layers of the water than in the lower levels, giving an earthy taste to the water.  EBMUD was expected to resume pulling water from the deeper parts of the reservoir within a matter of days, which would resolve the issue, although they said the sequence of events could recur again later in the year. San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 30, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Visitor bureaus emphasizing different activities in Yosemite National Park as drought continued to parch the landscape
Description: Visitor bureaus were emphasizing different activities in Yosemite National Park as drought continued to parch the landscape and shrink water sources.  Majestic Yosemite Falls was not highlighted so much, and instead, activities like hiking, biking and photography were recommended to prospective visitors.  Yosemite Falls is expected to run dry in June, two months earlier than usual.  The Merced River, which supplies water to Nevada and Vernal falls, is also anticipated to slow to a trickle in June.  Los Angeles Times, March 28, 2015
Categories: Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Lack of snow allowed opening of road in Yosemite National Park nearly two months early
Description: Glacier Point Road in Yosemite National Park opened March 28, the earliest date in the park’s history as drought and warm temperatures chased away what little snow existed in the park during the winter.  The Sierra Nevada snowpack measurement in March showed historical or near-historical lows.Los Angeles Times, March 28, 2015
Places: Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: California salmon being trucked to Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta again
Description: Twelve million juvenile Chinook salmon are being trucked from the Coleman National Fish Hatchery in Anderson to Rio Vista in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta because the warm flow of Battle Creek, a tributary of the Sacramento River, is very low.  The 3-inch long smolts would likely perish before they reach the delta, leaving very few to return as adults to reproduce in three years.  Six trucks will take approximately 22 working days to deliver the fish to the delta, with the project planned to be finished by mid-May.Salmon were transported to the delta in the spring of 2014, as well, because there was too little water to allow safe passage to the delta.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 26, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Solano County, CA, Rio Vista, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Temporary water release from Folsom Lake in California to protect endangered steelhead
Description: As endangered steelhead trout in the American River prepare to hatch, the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation decreased water releases from Folsom Dam to 500 cubic feet per second on March 26.  This flow is below a negotiated standard agreed to by the Water Forum to protect the river environment, but allowable during periods of severe drought.The outflow was temporarily increased through gates in the dam’s face to draw out cold water from deeper parts of the reservoir to cool water in the American River for the nearly hatched fish.  The release will end on the afternoon of March 30.  The brevity of the water release underscored the importance of conserving the region's precious water.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 29, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sacramento County, CA

Title: Minor tweaks to water restrictions in southern Orange County, California
Description: In much of southern Orange County, water restrictions will change little, despite the State Water Resources Control Board’s updates to the statewide water regulations.
