Title: Populations of breeding waterfowl fall in California
Description: The populations of breeding waterfowl in the Sacramento Valley declined 19 percent this year, while decreases of such birds were larger elsewhere in California, on account of drought and poor habitat conditions, revealed a study by the California Department of Fish and Wildlife.  The survey was performed over prime nesting areas in the Central Valley and northeastern California and estimated 315,580 breeding ducks in 2015, a decline of nearly 30 percent from the 448,750 breeding ducks in 2014.  The largest population drops were noted in the northeast, where decreases of 40 percent occurred, stated a biologist with the CDFW.  There were 27 percent fewer breeding mallards, the most common duck species in the state.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 29, 2015
Places: California, Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Lassen County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Southern Central Valley farmworkers struggling to survive without work
Description: Farmworkers in the southern Central Valley continued to struggle to get by as agricultural employers cut jobs, due to drought, leading to hunger in an area where half of the country’s fruits, vegetables and nuts are grown. Many laborers relied on charity to keep food on the table. Undocumented workers suffer most because they cannot get food stamps and other federal assistance. The ripple effects are felt by farm-related businesses as the regional economy shares the pain.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Dec. 26, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Clovis, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Hanford, CA, Kettleman City, CA, Stratford, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Alpaugh, CA, Ducor, CA

Title: Bears making trouble in Lake Tahoe area
Description: Bears in the Reno-Tahoe area caused more havoc than usual as drought drastically reduced their normal food and water resources, driving them to seek food in human-inhabited areas. In addition to diving into garbage, one bear sought entry to a bakery, and another crashed a hotel hors d’oeuvres table. During 2014, the Nevada Department of Wildlife caught and released 93 bears, an increase of 130 percent compared to 2009 and a 34 percent increase from ten years ago. In 2013, 97 bears were caught and released. The year of record bear activity was 2007 when 159 bears were captured amid drought.Las Vegas Sun, Dec. 24, 2014
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: Bird species in the Sonoran Desert were delaying nesting
Description: Thirteen bird species in the Sonoran Desert were delaying nesting by two or more weeks in response to drought conditions and by several weeks during episodes of intense drought.  These delays can jeopardize reproduction or leave birds in poor condition and unable to recover before the next breeding season.Science World Report (New York), Dec. 23, 2014
Places: La Paz County, AZ, Maricopa County, AZ, Pima County, AZ, Pinal County, AZ, Santa Cruz County, AZ, Yuma County, AZ, California, Imperial County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: High prices at Palo Alto, California farmers market mirrors high production costs for farmers
Description: Some farms in San Luis Obispo County have closed during the drought to minimize losses until substantial rain returns.  Farmers with springs and wells are pumping heavily, more quickly than the source can be replenished.  A ranch owner in Cayucos said his costs have tripled and will not likely break even this year.  A dairy farmer reported that her expense for hay and alfalfa feed had risen 2½ times from 2011 to this year.  With feed costs rising from $20,000 to $50,000, she had to give up her organic certification and may have to quit the business.  A profit this year is an impossibility.Demand for imported hay and alfalfa is high, as are costs, further keeping profits down.  Hay production in 2014 was 6 million tons, in comparison with the 8 million tons grown in 2002. Similarly, prices at the Palo Alto farmers market have skyrocketed.  A half-gallon of raw milk goes for about $8, one dozen eggs sells for $10, and a pound of rib steak runs about $27 per pound.  In spite of the high prices, farmers’ expenses still are not covered.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Dec. 21, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA, Palo Alto, CA

Title: Lack of snow in Sierra Nevada in California drove skiers to travel to ski areas in Washington, Idaho
Description: Thin snowpack in the Sierra Nevada has driven downhill and Nordic skiers to snowier areas, such as Sun Valley in Idaho and Methow Valley in north central Washington, for good skiing until the California mountains get more snow.  Precipitation in California has come down as rain rather than snow or has stayed at high elevations, leaving ski resorts bare.Twin Falls Times-News (Idaho), Feb. 9, 2015
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, Placer County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Blaine County, ID, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV, Okanogan County, WA

Title: Residents not always appreciative of water conservation in Coachella Valley, California
Description: Golf courses in the Coachella Valley were asked by the Coachella Valley Water District to curb water use by 10 percent between 2010 and 2020.  People who live around the golf courses and pay high membership dues and initiation fees expect the grass to be lush and green, drought or not.  The area draws from a large aquifer and does not have the same water concerns that many others in the state have.  In addition, water agencies may not charge more than it costs to treat the water, so water rates remain low--$1.12 for 748 gallons, which does not encourage conservation.Los Angeles Times, Dec. 20, 2014
Categories: Business & Industry, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Metropolitan Water District in Southern California to sell water to Water Replenishment District
Description: Abundant rainfall in December increased the water allocation to the Metropolitan Water District, making it able to sell 25,000 acre-feet of water to the Water Replenishment District for the first time in three years.  The water will be used to refill underground aquifers in Southeast Los Angeles County and will be transferred from January through April 2015.Drought and other factors have prevented MWD from selling water to replenish underground aquifers.San Gabriel Valley Tribune (Calif.), Dec. 20, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: East Bay Municipal Utility District in California considering purchase of federal water from Sacramento River
Description: The rate hike for East Bay has been suspended until the East Bay Municipal Utility District decides whether to pump Sacramento River water. The start of the pumping and the surcharge could begin on Jan. 19 if the district chooses to move ahead with the plan.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Jan. 6, 2015Despite the recent storms, the East Bay Municipal Utility District will raise water rates 14 percent for the next few months to pay for extra federal water.  The EBMUD board voted to buy water from the Sacramento River and request a further reduction in water use from 10 percent to 15 percent.  If the region gets heavy storms in the next few weeks, the water purchase and uptick in water rates may not happen.San Leandro Times (Calif.), Dec. 18, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, San Leandro, CA, Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Possible rate hike in Alameda County Water District in California
Description: The Alameda County Water District’s board of directors was considering the possibility of another rate hike in 2015 for the 13th straight year.  Drought has pushed up expenses which the agency passes on to customers.  The general manager for the ACWD said the goal was to increase revenue by 8 percent.  Unfortunately as customers use less water, the agency takes in less revenue and must increase water rates.A drought surcharge which took effect in July remained in effect.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Dec.
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Fremont, CA, Newark, CA, Union City, CA

Title: Council members in Santa Barbara, California considering new restrictions, preparing for continuing drought
Description: Santa Barbara council members considered more water-use and development restrictions as drought persisted despite recent rainfall.  All seemed to be in favor of the possibility of suspending approvals of new private groundwater well permits and of water restrictions on turf, but disagreed about whether to prohibit installing new pools and issuing  building permits for projects with net new water use.To prepare for a continuation of the drought, city groundwater well replacements took on new urgency, as did preparations to reactivate the city’s desalination facility. Noozhawk (Santa Barbara, Calif.), Dec. 16, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Barbara County, CA

Title: Consideration of moratorium on new wells, groundwater exports in Merced County, California
Description: A moratorium on new wells and groundwater export was under consideration by the Merced County board of supervisors as the past few years of drought raise concern about having a sufficient supply of water.  The moratorium was voted down at the Dec. 16 meeting, but will be revisited in 2015. KFSN-TV ABC 30 Frenso/Visalia (Calif.), Dec. 16, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Merced County, CA

Title: Report recommended less groundwater pumping near coast, more pumping from inland sources in Salinas Valley, California
Description: A Salinas Valley groundwater basin report recommended that pumping be shifted away from the coast to deeper underground water sources to reduce seawater intrusion worsened by drought.  Agricultural interest groups opposed the recommendation.  While seawater intrusion changed little during 2011-13, it seems to have penetrated further inland in 2014.  The report was researched and prepared by Brown and Caldwell, a firm based in Sunnyvale.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Dec. 17, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Monterey County, CA, San Benito County, CA

Title: Rain barrels, rain collection systems increasingly popular in East Bay, California
Description: Rain barrels and large scale rain collecting systems have become increasingly popular in East Bay as a three year drought hangs on despite recent storms.  A Los Gatos man constructed a network of pipes, tanks and filters to capture rainwater and has collected more than 10,000 gallons.  A rainwater and greywater collection business saw an uptick in sales of 30 percent as people invest in collection system equipment, design and consultation.  Several large systems capable of holding 20,000 to 40,000 gallons were in the works.  Because large systems can cost up to $70,000, many people opt for small cisterns.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Dec. 16, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA

Title: Suspenstion of higher water rates in East Bay, California
Description: The rate hike has been suspended until the East Bay Municipal Utility District decides whether to pump Sacramento River water.  The start of the pumping and the surcharge could begin on Jan. 19 if the district chooses to move ahead with the plan.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Jan. 6, 2015The East Bay Municipal Utility District board voted unanimously to supplement its Sierra reservoirs with water purchased from the Central Valley Water Project and to raise rates for customers, if needed.  If district managers determine this month that additional water is needed, a 14 percent surcharge will be added to bills possibly for six months or so until the cost of the extra water has been paid .  The district may purchase 16,000 acre-feet of water and maybe up to 35,000 acre-feet from the Central Valley Water Project if deliveries are limited due to drought.  The price tag for the water would be $16 million.The district board voted to raise voluntary water conservation from 10 percent to 15 percent beginning Jan. 1.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Dec. 9, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Cemetery unwelcome for some neighbors in Contra Costa County, California
Description: A proposal for a new cemetery near San Ramon in Contra Costa County has raised the hackles of potential neighbors for various reasons.  Some fear that the cemetery will slurp up too much water in an area where at least one homeowner already has to have water transported to her home thrice weekly because her well output has declined.  Other neighbors from China and India object to the proximity of the proposed cemetery for cultural reasons, believing that living near a cemetery is taboo.New York Times, Dec. 9, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Contra Costa County, CA

Title: El Paso, Texas water utility drawing more water from Hueco Bolson aquifer
Description: The El Paso Water Utility has pumped more water than usual from the Hueco Bolson aquifer to replace water normally taken from the Rio Grande River.  The chief executive officer with the utility said that such pumping was not a sustainable option and that drought-proof components must be added to the utility’s water options.El Paso Times (Texas), Dec. 9, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Paso County, TX, El Paso, TX

Title: Drought damaging California's Christmas trees
Description: California-grown Christmas trees suffered from drought. The assortment of potted Christmas trees at a South Bay nursery had fewer classic Christmas pines because those required more water than spruce. Baby trees and seedlings near Sacramento were the first to succumb to the drought, but adult trees with deeper roots managed to do better.  More interior browning and needle drop than usual plagued the trees.Los Angeles Times, Dec. 3, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Redondo Beach, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA

Title: California’s Department of Water Resources announced water allocation estimate
Description: The State Water Project increased its allocation estimate to 20 percent of contracted amounts, up from its January estimate of 15 percent.  While the uptick is an improvement, this amount would be the SWP’s second lowest water delivery since 1990.  The additional water helps water agencies, but many will have to rely on groundwater and carefully manage supplies to get through the year.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), March 2, 2015Estimated water deliveries from the State Water Project rose from 10 percent to 15 percent with the California Department of Water Resources’ Jan. 15 announcement.  Continued water conservation could help water deliveries go up even further, said the DWR Director Mark Cowin.  The statewide water equivalent in the Sierra Nevada was 4.9 inches or 36 percent of normal for Jan. 15.  Lake Oroville in Butte County held 39 percent of its capacity of 3.5 million acre-feet.  Shasta Lake, the largest reservoir in the state and for the Central Valley Project, was 42 percent of capacity of 4.5 million acre-feet, amounting to 66 percent of its historical average for this time of year.   San Luis Reservoir contained 47 percent of its capacity of 2 million acre-feet, which was 65 percent of normal for Jan. 15.  Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), Jan. 15, 2015California’s Department of Water Resources announced an initial water allocation of 10 percent from the State Water Project, based on a more optimistic rain and snow forecast for 2015.  The estimate could be revised downward if the precipitation does not materialize.  Only 5 percent was delivered in 2014.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Dec. 1, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Butte County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Napa County, CA, Orange County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Yuba City, CA, Tulare County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: More water being stored in California's Prado Dam
Description: Prado Dam rose by only 6 inches in December, prompting the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to temporarily increase water levels to bolster water supplies during the ongoing drought.  Water is typically released from the lake as it peaks at a certain level during the winter.  The Army Corps and the Orange County Water District will assess the possibility of storing 30,000 acre-feet of water in the groundwater basin in central and northern Orange County.Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), Feb. 24, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Orange County, CA

Title: Watershed project completed in Solano County, California
Description: The California Department of Fish and Wildlife finished a watershed project benefiting fish and wildlife affected by drought in the Lindsey Slough in Solano County.  The restoration project was done at Calhoun Cut Ecological Reserve in November.  It included excavation and placement of fill at Lindsey Slough to reestablish tidal connection to the old marsh and channel system and improve existing marsh habitat and connected vernal pools and grassland.noodls (New York), Dec. 19, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Solano County, CA

Title: City council in Odessa, Texas offered more than $38 million to boost production from Ward County well fields
Description: The Colorado River Municipal Water District board members turned down a $38 million offer by City of Odessa officials to increase production at the Ward County well fields.Odessa American (Texas), Feb. 25, 2015The Odessa City Council decided to offer more than $38 million to the Colorado River Municipal Water District to increase the water production of the Ward County well fields to provide additional water to supplement surface water from reservoirs during times of drought.  The city council would like to see well output increased from the current withdrawal rate of 45 million gallons daily to 65 million gallons daily.  The mayor stated that the city’s water supply was a hindrance to luring businesses to Odessa.Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 26, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Odessa, TX, Ward County, TX

Title: More California grape growers are considering dry farming
Description: More California grape growers are considering dry farming as ongoing drought reduces the region’s water supply.  The right type of soil to absorb and retain natural moisture is essential.  Growers also need to plant vines that produce deep roots to reach moisture.  Growers must also till carefully and manage soil well to help vines get through the summer months.  Dry farming can lead to reduced yields, but often produces higher quality grapes.  Dry farm workshops held across California drew more attendees than in previous years.  At one workshop in Napa County, 60 farmers, or three times as many farmers, attended.Los Angeles Times, Nov. 22, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA, Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Lake County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Riverside County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Ventura County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: The Monterey Peninsula Water Management District in California has free water-saving devices and fixtures
Description: The Monterey Peninsula Water Management District offered free water-saving devices and fixtures during “Drought Days Drive-Thru” events, held four times from Nov. 24 through Dec. 6.  Members of the public were invited to pick up a water conservation kit for homes and businesses, containing leak detection kits, nozzles, faucet aerators, dish scrapers and other water-saving devices.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Nov. 20, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Monterey County, CA

Title: Guzzlers upgraded in the Temblor Mountains of California
Description: Guzzlers in the Temblor Mountains were upgraded by members of the South Valley Chapter of Quail Forever to provide needed water for wildlife year round.  Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), Nov. 20, 2014
Places: Kern County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority seeking permission to cut irrigation water releases from Highland Lakes
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority is seeking permission from the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality to cut the amount of water it releases from the Highland Lakes for irrigation for the fourth straight year.  Water releases take place for six weeks in late spring to aid spawning of blue sucker fish.  “This was not an easy decision, but we must protect the region’s water supply,” said the LCRA’s General Manager Phil Wilson. “More than a million people depend on water from the Highland Lakes, and right now, there is just not enough water for everyone to have all they want."Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 19, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Groundwater recovery plant in San Juan Capistrano, California not producing as much water as anticipated
Description: The San Juan Capistrano groundwater recovery facility normally produces as much as 50 percent of the city’s drinking water, but low groundwater levels have dropped production to 30 percent.  The city stopped using two of its eight wells to allow the basin to recharge, but drought continues to cause the level of the remaining six wells to drop.Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), Nov. 19, 2014The groundwater recovery plant, leased and operated by San Juan Capistrano, was not producing as much water as anticipated, due to depleted groundwater levels.  The city, however, still owed more than $40 million for the plant.Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), Nov. 19, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Orange County, CA, San Juan Capistrano, CA

Title: More California cities considering recycling water after three intense years of drought
Description: San Diego and other California cities are considering recycling water after three intense years of drought.  San Diegans, although they did not embrace the idea years ago, were seeing it as a drought-proof water supply.The Orange County Water District intends to boost recycled water production from 70 million gallons daily to 100 million gallons daily.  Recycled water has supplied Orange County homes since 2008.  The Santa Clara Valley Water District decided in September to construct water recycling facilities which may be used to purify water for Sunnyvale and western Santa Clara County.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Nov. 18, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Orange County, CA, San Diego, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Sunnyvale, CA

Title: Cal Fire on alert for fires in Los Angeles, San Bernardino counties
Description: With drought increasing the amount of parched vegetation, the forecast for high winds and low humidity for the Los Angeles/San Bernardino area prompted Cal Fire to borrow three strike teams, including 15 engines, from Central California.  One strike team was placed in San Bernardino, another team in the Los Angeles area and the other strike team in Santa Clarita to be well-positioned to reach fires quickly if needed.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Nov. 18, 2014
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Drought kits distributed to residents in Humboldt County, California
Description: About 2,400 drought kits from Home Depot were given out to North Coast tribes and drought-affected residents in Humboldt County.  The kits contained a low-flow shower head, faucet aerators, a garden hose nozzle with shutoff valve, toilet leak detectors and a shower timer.   The Governor’s Office of Planning and Research and The Home Depot came up with the idea of making the kits.About 2,000 of the kits were given to the Hoopa Valley tribe, which shared them with Karuk and Yurok tribes.  Humboldt County got 400 kits that they offered to low-income residents in Rio Dell, Garberville and the Food for People distribution network.  The Humboldt County emergency planner said wells have been going dry and a few water districts were under curtailment orders among other long-term issues.  She was also grateful for local businesses, Randy Jones Trucking, Hilfiker Pipe Company and the Crescent City Home Depot, for transporting, storing and supplying the kits.Eureka Times-Standard (Calif.), Nov. 18, 2014
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Humboldt County, CA

Title: Fire watchers out in Orange County, California
Description: Drought and a forecast for dry, windy conditions has members of the Irvine Ranch Conservancy’s fire watch program out scanning high-risk areas and parks for fires.  Fire officials regularly monitor the moisture levels of plants to evaluate the fire danger, but drought has increased the dryness of vegetation.  Some of the areas that have Orange County fire officials on edge include the Santa Ana River, Silverado and Modjeska canyons, as well as areas near Santiago Canyon Road.Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), Nov. 18, 2014
Places: Orange County, CA

Title: Drought slowed the salmon spawning run in Sacramento Valley, California
Description: Drought has slowed the salmon spawning run in the Sacramento Valley where more than 300,000 fall-run Chinook, also known as king, salmon are expected to swim up rivers and streams and spawn during October and November.  Volunteers working with the Dry Creek Conservancy walked sections of creek to count the number of salmon swimming upstream.  They found more than 120 salmon on Nov. 14 on four sections of creek, which was many fewer than the 800 salmon spotted ten years ago, but this year’s count was still good, given the drought.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.) Nov. 17, 2014
Places: Butte County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Tourists flocking to see relics in drought-stricken California lakes
Description: More tourists were flocking to see foundations, old bridges and other relics as drought depletes California lakes and exposes objects not seen in many years.  In Lake Don Pedro, the foundation from the stamp mill of the old Eagle-Shawmut mine has reappeared.  Hundreds of curious people have visited the lake to have a look and sometimes enjoy a picnic.  Many visitors to the New Melones Visitor Center near Highway 49 on the Tuolumne County side of the New Melones Lake inquire about when certain landmarks will become visible.  At Lake McClure, the old Yosemite Railway tunnels are high above the water line and have been exposed for several months.  Tourists can also view the concrete pillars of the railroad’s old Barrett Bridge and bits of the foundations from the town and rail stop of Bagby.Merced Sun-Star (Calif.), Nov. 16, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Calaveras County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Irrigation data being gathered in Shasta County, California for an upcoming irrigation scheduling workshop
Description: A researcher from the University of California Cooperative Extension has been working with a rancher in eastern Shasta County to measure the efficiency of water use on irrigated pasture.  The information gleaned will be used to help growers make the best use of precious water during the epic drought and will be shared at a workshop on irrigation scheduling in McArthur in January.Capital Press - Agriculture Weekly (Salem, Oregon), Nov. 16, 2014
Places: McArthur, CA, Shasta County, CA

Title: Water limiting agricultural production, daily activities in San Mateo County, California
Description: The few hundred growers in southern San Mateo County who produce around $100 million worth of goods each year have been hurt significantly by the depleted water supply.  Most have curbed production as a result, some by as much as one-third.  There was not enough grass for cattle, forcing ranchers to move them elsewhere at a high cost.  One farmer shut down his farm because the stream behind his home went dry, and the output of his two wells dropped 90 percent.  His crops died without water.  Marchi Central Farms planted nearly 30 percent less because a length of the San Gregorio Creek went dry, something that has not happened in 25 years.Many domestic wells have gone dry along the southern San Mateo County coast.  People have had to make drastic changes to all daily routines involving water and must shower less, flush toilets less and avoid using water when possible.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Nov. 16, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Mateo County, CA

Title: San Mateo County, California received $3.9 million to assist homeowners needing water
Description: The San Mateo Resource Conservation District received $3.9 million from the state to assist residents of San Mateo County who are without water to improve water systems and increase storage capability.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Nov. 16, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Mateo County, CA

Title: Restrictions on campfire use in San Bernardino Forest and the Cleveland National Forest in Southern California
Description: Fire restrictions were in effect in the San Bernardino Forest, limiting campground fires to designated fire rings.  In the Cleveland National Forest, campground fires may be used only at certain campgrounds, due to the elevated fire danger.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Nov. 15, 2014
Places: Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Fleas pester pets in Northern California
Description: Northern California pets are being pestered by fleas, and pet owners are buying medications to prevent or get rid of fleas, whose population boom has taken many by surprise.  A registered veterinary technician said that the insect influx started in November.One pet groomer in Chico reported that 95 percent of the dogs coming in have fleas, although some of the pet owners were unaware of the issue.  Some pet stores were running out of flea treatments and were having a difficult time replenishing stock, due to the high demand.Chico Enterprise-Record (Calif.), March 25, 2015

Title: Roughly 1,252 dry wells in Tulare County, California; water tank systems being installed
Description: Through the end of August 2015, there were 1,252 dry household wells in Tulare County, which was more than the rest of California put together.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Aug. 30, 2015Roughly 1,200 homes in Tulare County continued to use temporary water tanks to provide water after wells went dry, and nearly that many homes were still without running water.  The tanks have been used for a year and were intended to be a temporary measure.The Washington Post (D.C.), July 5, 2015There were 810 dry wells in Tulare County, and funds from a $50,000 donation from Bank of the Sierra, Self-Help Enterprises, public funding and county agencies were helping people get tank systems set up before winter arrives.  With a tank hooked up to a home’s plumbing system, although the water is not potable, at least homes will have hot water for showers and flushing toilets.  The cost for a water tank system is $1,200 to $1,500 for materials, plus labor, said a community development manager for Self-Help.  The State Water Resources Control Board pays for bottled water for homes with dry wells.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Nov. 15, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tulare County, CA, East Porterville, CA, Monson, CA, Porterville, CA

Title: Water agencies in Kern County, California to be awarded a total of $12 million in emergency drought funds
Description: Four water agencies in Kern County will be awarded a total of $12 million in emergency drought funds to upgrade the local water supply.  The aid will pay about $2 million to construct wells and pipelines to move recently discovered perched water for the Buena Vista Water Storage District.  A little more than $4 million will be spent to line a section of the Cross Valley Canal to reduce seepage for the Kern County Water Agency’s Improvement District 4.  The town of Buttonwillow will receive $3.7 million to replace main valves, meters, fire hydrants and 2.5 miles of pipes.  Having water meters will allow the city and residents to better monitor water use.  The Arvin-Edison Water Storage District is the fourth project to receive funding.  They will get $2 million to set up “in-lieu” banking between the AEWSD and farmers.  During wet years, the AEWSD will provide excess water to farmers who rely exclusively on groundwater.  In dry years, the AEWSD would withdraw stored water through pipelines connecting to the farmers' wells.Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), Nov. 15, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: Short supply of potable water for delivery in Tulare County, California
Description: Some Tulare County water suppliers are having trouble finding water to deliver to homes with dry wells.  One of two water haulers in the county with a license to deliver potable water ended his service because a municipal supplier could not provide him with water any longer. The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Nov. 15, 2014
Places: Tulare County, CA, Monson, CA

Title: Numerous deer, bears and other large animals in the Sierra Nevada of California have been struck and killed by vehicles
Description: Numerous deer, bears and other large animals in the Sierra Nevada have been struck in greater numbers this year because drought and wildfires have driven them to seek areas with better food and water supplies.  Caltrans and the California Department of Fish and Wildlife issued a public warning, urging drivers to be cautious and on the lookout for wildlife along roadways.  Fourteen deer and four black bears, including a cub, were struck and killed in 23 accidents on Highway 50 and Interstate 80 in Placer and El Dorado counties between Nov. 14 and 19.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Dec. 8, 2014
Places: Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mono County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: More calls to wildlife hospital in Bay Area, California
Description: The number of calls to a wildlife hospital in the Bay Area has increased 20 percent from last year, as the state endures its third year of drought. Animals were also suffering from more parasites, possibly due to dehydration.KNBC-TV NBC 4 Los Angeles (Calif.), Nov. 14, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Public expressed concerns about new development in Riverside County, California
Description: The Coachella Valley Water District approved the plans for a proposed development on 577 acres of desert near the Agua Caliente Casino Resort Spa.  The land will become a neighborhood with roughly 2,400 homes and retail shops, officials and various businesses.  A water supply assessment was approved by the water district’s board, but some residents have expressed concerns about the wisdom of constructing so many homes in the desert.  They also have questions about the local water supply, which comes from an aquifer, the State Water Project and the Colorado River, being able to provide for the new development.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Nov. 13, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: California oranges unevenly sized, due to drought and insufficient water
Description: California oranges were unevenly sized, due to drought and insufficient water.  Survey data showed that fruit had an average circumference of 2.205 inches, compared to the five-year average of 2.256 inches.  The U.S. Department of Agriculture’s initial 2014-15 navel orange crop forecast in September estimated a harvest of about 78 million cartons, slightly lower than the 2013-14 season of 81 million cartons.  There was still time for rain to increase the fruit size, said a member of the California Farm Bureau Federation citrus advisory committee.California produces 85 percent of the country’s fresh citrus, with navel oranges being one of the state’s top crops, valued at more than $721 million annually.Ag Alert (Sacramento, Calif.), Nov. 12, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Drought challenging for Southern California gardeners
Description: Southern California gardeners are finding that they must adapt and learn to install and maintain drought-tolerant landscaping if they want to remain employed.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Nov. 12, 2014
Places: Imperial County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Funds for water conservation, recycled water programs in Coachella Valley, California
Description: Coachella Valley water districts learned they will receive $5.2 million from the $221 million in funds awarded by the California Department of Water Resources.  Coachella Valley Water District, one of five public water agencies to get some of the funds, says it will use the money for water conservation and recycled water programs to curb the use of groundwater.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Nov. 11, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Drought, less water from the Colorado River combining to allow the salty Salton Sea in southern California to slowly shrink
Description: Drought and less water from the Colorado River are combining to allow the salty Salton Sea to slowly shrink.  Less shallow water and fewer fish hurt the hungry migrating pelicans and grebes.  As more of the lakebed is exposed, more dust blows and affects children’s respiratory systems.  The highest childhood asthma rates in the state are near the Salton Sea.New York Times, Nov. 10, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Imperial County, CA, Riverside County, CA

Title: Remnants of two communities reappearing in Lexington Reservoir in California
Description: As water levels recede, the remnants of Lexington and Alma were reappearing in Lexington Reservoir.  The towns were submerged with the construction of the James Lenihan Dam in the 1950s.  Stone foundations of homes and part of the Santa Cruz highway were visible, and visitors were making off with artifacts, such as silver spoons and silver coins.KTVU-TV Oakland, San Francisco, Bay Area (Calif.), Nov. 9, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: Water table fell in Tulare, California, leading city to lower its well pumps
Description: A water line connects Matheny Tract to Tulare, from which the small community hoped to get water.  Tulare has said that it cannot provide the water because one well was taken out of use because it was contaminated with arsenic.  Another problem was that drought caused the water table to fall, prompting the city to lower well pumps to maintain water pressure.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Nov. 8, 2014
Places: Tulare County, CA, Tulare, CA

Title: More waterfowl than usual at Staten Island in the San Joaquin Delta in California
Description: About twice as many sandhill cranes as usual have come to winter on Staten Island in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta.  A much larger population of greater white fronted geese has also arrived on the island.  A conservation scientist with The Nature Conservancy and other scientists were unsure of the exact reason for the change, but think that drought and a shift in crops grown are responsible for the vast number of birds showing up on the island.  Rice acreage fell by about 24 percent, compared to 2013, and flooded rice fields provide good habitat during the winter for the waterfowl.  With less suitable habitat, the birds seem to be crowding into the available areas.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Nov. 7, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Joaquin County, CA

Title: Many pine trees lost to drought in Torrey Pines State Reserve in San Diego County, California
Description: Hundreds of Torrey pines have died as drought stresses the trees and makes them less able to produce sap to fend off bark beetles.San Diego XETV (Calif.), Nov. 7, 2014
Places: San Diego County, CA

Title: Water thefts becoming more common in California
Description: Water thefts were becoming more common in the Bay Area and from urban suppliers in California, according to the Association of California Water Agencies and several Bay Area water districts.  Some water rustlers filled up at water hydrants during the night, while others were bolder and took water in broad daylight.  The Contra Costa Water District planned to address the topic of increasing water theft with fines from $25 to $250 to discourage thefts and was considering installing security cameras to monitor certain hydrants.  A number of cities including Lemoore, Modesto, Los Gatos, Dublin, San Ramon and others have recently dealt with such thefts.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Nov. 7, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Sacramento, Yolo counties in California to receive $14 million in drought relief funds for water infrastructure projects
Description: The California Department of Water Resources will fund 19 water infrastructure projects at a cost of $14 million to help the Sacramento area deal with current and future droughts.  Many of the projects will upgrade stored groundwater distribution to areas presently dependent upon surface water.  Of the $14 million, $9 million will be used to finance 17 projects for the Sacramento Regional Water Authority, and two projects at a cost of $4 million will benefit the Yolo County Flood and Conservation District.  The drought relief funds come from $220 million in expedited grant money from Gov. Brown’s Water Action Plan.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Nov. 7, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sacramento County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Big boats cannot be launched at Cooper Lake in Texas due to low water level
Description: Boaters cannot launch big boats from ramps on Cooper Lake after the water level dropped significantly in October.  Lake Tawakoni was low also.Tyler Morning Telegraph (Texas), Nov. 5, 2014
Places: Delta County, TX, Hunt County, TX, Rains County, TX, Van Zandt County, TX

Title: Most West Central Texas wheat growers waiting for rain before planting
Description: Some West Central Texas farmers planted their wheat, but most growers were waiting for rain before planting.  Some early-planted small grains showed signs of moisture stress.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 4, 2014

Description: Most Bermuda grass fields in Central Texas continued to recover from drought.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 4, 2014

Title: Forage condition declined in Jim Wells County, Texas
Description: Forage condition declined in Jim Wells County due to the lack of rain.  Soil moisture remained short throughout most of South Texas.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 4, 2014
Places: Jim Wells County, TX

Title: Wheat moisture-stressed, dying in Glasscock County, Texas
Description: Wheat was moisture-stressed in Glasscock County.  Newly emerged stands were struggling and some of those were beginning to die.  Some wheat did not emerge well, resulting in skimpy stands.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 4, 2014
Places: Glasscock County, TX

Title: Some California avocado growers leaving the business
Description: Some California avocado growers were leaving the business in 2014 due to short water supplies in California, rising fertilizer costs, and level wholesale prices caused by to cheap imports from Peru, Chile and Mexico.Yahoo! News (Sunnyvale, Calif.), Nov. 3, 2014
Places: San Diego County, CA

Title: Food available for drought-affected families in Kern County, California
Description: Emergency prepackaged foods will be given to Kern County residents who can offer proof of underemployment or unemployment due to drought.  Fourteen food distribution events will be held in February.Bakersfield Californian, Jan. 27, 2015The Community Action Partnership of Kern Food Bank has boxes of food available for families who have been hurt by drought.  Food will be distributed in Bakersfield, Buttonwillow, Lamont and Arvin.Bakersfield Californian, Nov. 1, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Kern County, CA, Arvin, CA, Bakersfield, CA, Buttonwillow, CA, Lamont, CA

Title: 2014-2015 ski season better than previous year at Bear Mountain, Snow Summit in San Bernardino County, California
Description: During the 2014-2015 ski season, visits to Bear Mountain and Snow Summit were about 25 percent higher than the 2013-2014 season, but still below the 10-year average of roughly 750,000, said the vice president of marketing for Big Bear Mountain Resorts.  Both winters brought below normal snowfall as drought persisted in California. Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), March 29, 2015
Places: San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Drought reducing air quality in Southern California
Description: The South Coast Air Quality Management District saw even more no-burn days between November 2014 and February 2015 as the air quality deteriorated, due to drought and few rainfall events.  No-burn days are called when forecasts predict the air pollution levels will rise above the federal 24-hour limits at the monitoring station in Mira Loma.  During the 2014-2015 winter season, there were 25 no-burn days, compared to 16 such days during the 2013-2014 winter.  By month, there were five in November, one in December, seven in January and twelve in February.  A planning and rule development employee at the air district explained, “What we’ve had in the last two years was just a lack of those storm events.  Typically, the days of less wind, stagnant conditions in the winter, will be the days conducive to higher particulate levels.”The district lowered its threshold for triggering no-burn days two years ago, making the same number of particulates in the air at present closer to prompting a no-burn day than under the previous criteria.  Orange County Register (Santa Ana, Calif.), March 17, 2015
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Drought may be responsible for reduction in rangia clam population in Galveston Bay in Texas
Description: Scientists studying rangia clams found fewer of them in 2014 than in past years in the northeast inlet of Galveston Bay, suggesting to scientists that there was not enough fresh water flowing into the bay from the Trinity River.  Rangia clams are found near sources of fresh water and do not reproduce or mature when the water is too salty.  Because the mollusk is not commercially harvested, its location and abundance has not been closely monitored, except in connection with oyster surveys. One marine biologist noted that the clams' population had been on the decline for decades, before the current multi-year drought and the widening of the shipping channel.Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Oct. 31, 2014
Places: Chambers County, TX, Galveston County, TX, Harris County, TX

Title: Envious eyes again turning toward Lake Mission Viejo in Southern California
Description: Envious eyes are again turning toward Lake Mission Viejo as water becomes scarcer in California.  The lake holds 1.2 billion gallons of potable water that is reserved for the elite living around the recreational lake, while some California communities’ wells and other water supplies have dried up.  Santa Margarita Water District officials are trying to help the Lake Mission Viejo Assn. find ways to reduce water use because the 124-surface acre lake loses roughly 88 million gallons to evaporation annually and is refilled with potable water.  The water district was in Stage 2 water restrictions, and the next stage would require the lake association to get a permit to replace water lost to evaporation.There was scandal about filling the lake in 1977 during a historic drought, which led to an order from the California Water Board to stop filling the lake. When the drought eased one year later, the lake was filled with water from the Colorado River.Los Angeles Times, Oct. 30, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Orange County, CA

Title: Sacramento Valley farmers asked to flood fields to aid migrating waterfowl
Description: The Natural Resources Conservation Service has offered money to farmers in Butte, Colusa, Glenn, Sutter, Yolo and Yuba counties to flood rice fields through Feb. 1 to provide more habitat for migrating waterfowl.   Typically, Sacramento Valley rice farmers flood about 300,000 acres to encourage the decomposition of rice stubble, but this year, the California Rice Commission estimated that about 50,000 acres will be flooded, due to drought.  This will leave millions of ducks and geese without suitable habitat.To increase the amount of flooded land, the NRCS will give farmers an estimated $53 per acre.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Oct. 29, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Low stock tank levels were becoming a serious concern for some ranchers in West Central Texas
Description: Low water levels in stock tanks were becoming a serious concern for some ranchers in West Central Texas.  The Charlotte Observer (N.C.), Oct. 28, 2014
