Title: Salinity higher in North Delta in California
Description: The North Delta Water Agency Board of Directors asserted that the California Department of Water Resources was not complying with its water quality control contract commitments as drought increased salinity in the North Delta.Central Valley Business Times (Stockton, Calif.), Nov. 2, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Solano County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Property valuations around Lake Travis in Texas continued to rise, despite the low level of the lake
Description: Property valuations around Lake Travis continued to rise, despite the low level of the lake and increasing distances from the shoreline to homes that were once waterfront property.  Lake Travis has fallen to 41 feet below average.  Some residents have appealed the appraisal of their land and received decreases on the assessments of their property due to drought.  Real estate agents agree that the land around the lake has less value than it did before the drought and that the Travis County appraisal district’s opinion does not reflect drought's effect on the value of homes that are at least temporarily no longer waterfront properties.  This year property values established by the Travis Central Appraisal District increased 6.5 percent, while in Travis County, property values went up overall by 11 percent.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Oct. 27, 2014
Places: Burnet County, TX, Travis County, TX

Title: Fishing guide near Sacramento, California leads tours to see striped bass rather than salmon
Description: A fishing guide in the Sacramento area stopped offering salmon trips because there were too few salmon, due to the epic drought.  Instead, he takes guests to catch striped bass.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.) Nov. 17, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sacramento County, CA

Title: Synthetic turf industry benefiting from the California drought
Description: The synthetic turf industry is benefiting from the California drought because sales are skyrocketing.  A Redondo Beach landscaper said that annual revenues climbed from less than $300,000 in 2012 to more than $2.5 million in the first nine months of 2014.  Artificial grass supplier, DuraTurf, with its West Coast headquarters in Torrance, reported that turf sales in 2013 amounted to 625,000 square feet and sales looked to be double that of last year.  The West Coast manager for DuraTurf stated that the company's largest growth had taken place in Southern California.  Torrance Daily Breeze (Calif.), Oct. 27, 2014
Places: Imperial County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Growers in the Friant Water Authority sued the State Water Resources Control Board over water supply decisions
Description: Growers in the Friant Water Authority have sued the State Water Resources Control Board over water supply decisions which left them with no federal water. The Friant Water Authority said the state board illegally denied water to the San Joaquin River Exchange Contractors who have senior water rights.   Water from Millerton Lake was then given to the SJREC.  The east side growers claim the decision to withhold the water was illegal and must not be allowed to happen again.  The Friant Water Authority provides water to 15,000 growers who purchase water from Millerton Lake and cultivate 1 million acres from Chowchilla to Bakersfield.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Oct. 28, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Continued water conservation in the North Texas Municipal Water District
Description: Customers of the North Texas Municipal Water District were asked to curb sprinkler use to once every two weeks from Nov. 1 through March 31, 2015.  The district’s reservoirs were very low from years of drought.  Lake Lavon was 12.53 feet below conservation level, Jim Chapman Lake was 11.59 feet low and Tawakoni was 11.3 feet low.  Lakes Lavon and Chapman held less than 50 percent of capacity.  Lake Texoma, which provides about 25 percent of the district’s water, is so salty that it must be mixed with “sweeter” water from Lavon and Chapman at a ratio of 4:1.Dallas Morning News, Oct. 23, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bryan County, OK, Johnston County, OK, Marshall County, OK, Allen, TX, Copeville, TX, Fairview, TX, Farmersville, TX, Frisco, TX, Josephine, TX, Lavon, TX, Lucas, TX, McKinney, TX, Melissa, TX, Murphy, TX, Nevada, TX, Parker, TX, Plano, TX, Princeton, TX, Prosper, TX, Wylie, TX, Cooke County, TX, Garland, TX, Mesquite, TX, Richardson, TX, Rowlett, TX, Sachse, TX, Sunnyvale, TX, Little Elm, TX, Bonham, TX, Grayson County, TX, Crandall, TX, Forney, TX, Kaufman, TX, Scurry, TX, Terrell, TX, Fate, TX, Rockwall, TX, Royse City, TX

Title: High quality organic and conventional hay scarce in California
Description: High quality organic and conventional hay were scarce in California where years of drought have cut into hay production.  Cattle ranchers and dairy farmers have been hard pressed for the past two years to find suitable hay and have had to look to distant sources for hay.  A Tulare County cattle rancher and hay farmer lost his organic certification during the 2013-14 winter because he could not locate organic hay and his own organic oat hay crop yielded next to nothing with the drought preventing any growth.  He sold 75 percent of his herd, but still could not find enough organic hay to get his cattle through the winter.  Some organic hay growers have opted to grow conventional hay to get better yields, further limiting the organic hay supply.  An Imperial County organic hay grower has hay for sale, but Northern California organic dairy farmers were not willing to pay the high cost of the hay and transportation costs.  Woodland Daily Democrat (Calif.), Oct. 23, 2014
Places: California, Imperial County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Kaiser Permanente offered $500,000 in grants to help residents in Fresno County, California
Description: Kaiser Permanente has offered $500,000 in grants to help Fresno County residents impacted by the drought.  Food, drinking water, healthcare and other services will be provided, thanks to the grants.  Community Food Bank will receive $300,000 to include more fresh produce and meat in its monthly distribution events. American Red Cross will receive $24,500 to provide emergency drinking water to those without it. Buddhist Tzu Chi Medical Foundation will receive $75,500 to fund mobile medical and dental visits to Fresno County clinics. The Marjaree Mason Center will receive $100,000 to assist domestic violence victims in the rural communities.Kaiser Permanente is an integrated managed care consortium based in Oakland.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Oct. 21, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: All boat ramps closed at Eagle Mountain Lake near Fort Worth, Texas
Description: Ongoing drought dropped lake levels to the point that many boat ramps were no longer useable in north central Texas.  The last accessible boat ramp at Eagle Mountain Lake was closed mid-September when water levels fell to a critical point.  At Benbrook Lake, the only open boat ramp was at Mustang Park.  Many boat ramps were closed at Lake Grapevine, but most ramps were open at Joe Pool Lake, Lewisville Lake and Lake Ray Roberts.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Oct. 18, 2014
Places: Cooke County, TX, Dallas County, TX, Denton County, TX, Jack County, TX, Tarrant County, TX, Wise County, TX

Title: More oak trees than usual falling in Napa County, California
Description: More oak trees than usual have fallen on land owned and managed by the Napa County Regional Park and Open Space District.  The district general manager feels that drought is to blame.  Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Oct. 18, 2014
Places: Napa County, CA

Title: Mandarins in Placer County, California ripe early
Description: Mandarins in Placer County ripen earlier during drought, noted a citrus grower in Newcastle.  In 2013, harvest began during the first week of November, the earliest harvest ever.  This year, harvest began two weeks earlier in mid- to late October.  On the bright side, the mandarins are sweeter than usual, but they are also a bit smaller.Capital Public Radio (Sacramento, Calif.), Nov. 13, 2014
Places: Placer County, CA, Newcastle, CA

Title: Poor quail reproduction, few duck hunting sites in the San Joaquin Valley of California
Description: The quail shooting outlook on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley was dismal because prolonged drought quashed reproduction in 2014.  Very few quail and chukar chicks hatched in spring as there was no cover or humidity to aid the rearing of chicks.  Most ponds, canals, lakes and streams in the Southern San Joaquin Valley Zone were dry, leaving few sites suitable for duck hunting when the waterfowl season opens on Oct. 18.Bakersfield Californian, Oct. 16, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Drought has lowered lake levels and reduced recreational opportunities in the vicinity of Fresno, California
Description: Submerged hazards, due to low water levels, were unmarked in Eastman Lake in Madera County.  Recent rain brought the lake up to 469.14 feet in elevation and 8 percent of capacity.The boat ramp at Hensley Lake also in Madera County remained unusable to large boats, although smaller vessels could be launched from the shore.  Precipitation brought the level of Hensley Lake up to 447.89 feet and a capacity of 5 percent.All boat ramps were closed at Lake Success in Tulare County, due to low lake levels.  The water level continued its decline to 575.70 in elevation and 4 percent of capacity.The drought has caused fishing interest at McClure Reservoir to wane, and the Barrett Cove North Ramp remained the only one open.  The water level fell 7 feet to an elevation of 606.77 feet and was at 9 percent of capacity.A 5.5-mile stretch of the Merced River in Snelling continued to be closed to fishing, due to low water levels.  Some boat ramps at the Pine Flat Reservoir were closed, due to low water levels.  Rain brought the lake level up one foot to 720.50 in elevation and a capacity of 11 percent.  Few fishermen were willing to launch their boats at Bass Lake with the water being so shallow at 47 percent of capacity.  Drought has really taken a toll on Edison, Florence and Mammoth Pool with the lakes at 4, 4 and 9 percent of capacity, respectively.Boat launching was very difficult at Wishon and Courtright lakes, due to low water levels.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Nov. 5, 2014Drought has lowered lake levels and reduced recreational opportunities in California.  Low lake levels at Hensley Lake in Madera County, made boat ramps unusable, meaning all vessels must be launched by hand.  The lake was at 448.02 feet in elevation and at 6 percent of capacity.At Eastman Lake underwater hazards near the water’s surface posed dangers to boaters.  Eastman was at 469.27 feet in elevation and at 8 percent of capacity.A temporary dock was launched on Lake Isabella near Wofford Heights in the North Fork.  Inflows from the upper river were very low at 90 cubic feet per second.  Care should be used when launching from boat ramps in the South Fork and near the dam.  The lake level receded slightly to 2,531.40 feet in elevation and 9 percent of capacity.  Lake Kaweah in Tulare County was at 592.82 feet in elevation and 9 percent of capacity.Boaters at Lake Success in Tulare County must exercise caution when putting a boat in at the ramp on the Rocky Hill side.  The lake slipped to 577.26 feet in elevation and 4 percent of capacity.The North ramp at Barrett Cove was the only useable boat ramp at Lake McClure in Mariposa County and should stay open through mid-October.  Drought and the low water level resulted in the closing of the South ramp and the marinas at Barrett Cove and McClure Point.  A-1 Bait was selling all plastic worms at a 30 percent discount, due to the drought.  McClure Lake fell to 622.92 feet in elevation and was at 11 percent of capacity.A 5.5 mile length of the Merced River in Snelling was closing to angling, due to the low water.Some of the boat ramps at Pine Flat Reservoir in Fresno County were inaccessible while the reservoir was at 720.63 feet in elevation and at 11 percent of capacity.  In the lower Kings River in Fresno County, the Fresno Fly Fishers urged club members to avoid angling there until further notice due to the low water levels.  The October club meeting was moved to the South Fork of the Kings River at Cedar Grove.  With low water levels in the river as releases were reduced to a minimum from Pine Flat Reservoir, water temperatures were high, resulting in special regulations in the Kings River above and below the Pine Flat Dam.  As San Luis Reservoir and O’Neill Forebay in Merced County become increasingly depleted, users of the launch ramp at Dinosaur Point are warned to use it at their own risk.  The Basalt Ramp was recommended as a safer alternative.  The San Luis Reservoir was at 22 percent of capacity.The ramp and courtesy dock at Bass Lake in Madera County were barely in the water as drought draws the lake level down.  Bass Lake was at 48 percent of capacity.Edison, Florence and Mammoth Pool in Fresno and Madera counties fell to 4 percent, 5 percent and 8 percent, respectively.Low water was problematic at Lakes Santa Margarita and San Antonio.  Only kayaks, canoes and inflatables were useable at Lake San Antonio, where the capacity was 4 percent.  Lake Nacimiento was at 716.05 feet in elevation and 17 percent of capacity.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Oct. 14, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Calaveras County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, Monterey County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Conflict over drought-depleted vegetation in Marin County, California
Description: Organic dairy ranchers with livestock on agricultural land in the Golden Gate National Recreation Area and Point Reyes seashore are frustrated with local tule elk.  The ranchers are trying to get authorities to remove the elk and construct a fence to keep them out to prevent the elk from competing with the cattle for grass.  After three years of drought, the scarce vegetation is extremely valuable to ranchers who must feed their cattle at least 30 percent foraged material to keep the organic certification.  The Marin County agricultural commissioner has urged the Park Service to capture and relocate the 76 elk and fence them off the agricultural land, but to no avail.seattlepi.com (Wash.), Oct. 12, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health
Places: Marin County, CA

Title: One of four boat ramps open on Lake Perris in Southern California
Description: Drought had drawn down the level of Lake Perris to the point that only one of four boat launch ramps remained open as of mid-October 2014, according to a superintendent at the lake.  The state intended to pull water from the lake for three to five months to provide municipal water for Riverside County, which they anticipated would cause a four to eight foot drop in water elevation.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Oct. 12, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Drought leads to exquisite grapes in Napa, Sonoma and other counties in California
Description: This year’s drought has produced grapes of the finest quality for winemaking, as reported in the Wall Street Journal.  Less precipitation results in smaller grapes with concentrated flavor.  Plenty of sunshine helps the grapes ripen ahead of schedule before the fall storms arrive.  Too much rain can cause grapes to mold.A Pinot Noir specialist stated, “This year's vintage could be one for the ages."Des Moines Register (Iowa), Oct. 12, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA, Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Lake County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Riverside County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Ventura County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Record-size but fewer pumpkins grown in Napa, California
Description: Despite the drought, California pumpkin growers managed to produce record large pumpkins, setting a new North American record, which was broken two days later by another pumpkin, both grown in Napa.  Some pumpkin growers were more frugal with water, given the ongoing drought, while others grew fewer pumpkins, but used as much water as usual.  Fewer pumpkins were entered in the Half Moon Bay contest, just 29 compared to last year’s 40 entries, which the contest spokesman attributed to drought.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Oct. 13, 2014
Places: Napa County, CA, Half Moon Bay, CA

Title: Dry winter may have allowed bluetongue virus carrier to survive in Auburn, California
Description: We had a significant outbreak of the bluetongue virus in our sheep in October.  Based on past experience, I believe that the relatively mild and very dry winter of 2013/2014 allowed the vector (a midge) to overwinter.  We've never experienced such a severe outbreak in the past.From a producer in Auburn, California, on November 10, 2014
Places: Placer County, CA, Auburn, CA

Title: Central Valley Community Bank helping to ease hunger in the Central Valley of California
Description: The CEO of the Central Valley Community Bank, based in Fresno, launched a program called “Food Fund Challenge” allowing people to donate to regional food banks through the CVCB’s 21 regional branches.  Food banks in the Central Valley have faced higher demand for food as drought reduces agricultural production, leading to fewer jobs and paychecks and a greater need for food assistance.  The CVCB gave $5,000 to seven food banks, including California Emergency Foodlink in Sacramento and food banks in San Joaquin, Tulare, Fresno, Madera, Merced and Stanislaus counties.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Oct. 9, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Items lost in Castaic Lake nearly 22 years ago recovered in Los Angeles County, California
Description: A fisherman on Castaic Lake found a badge and handgun belonging to a federal agent who lost the items almost 22 years ago.  The level of Castaic Lake was down about 151 feet due to the ongoing drought.Los Angeles Times, Oct. 9, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: Salamanders collected from wild to protect endangered species near San Marcos, Texas
Description: San Marcos salamanders were collected from Spring Lake and will be housed in the San Marcos Aquatic Resources Center’s refuge facilities to have some creatures in reserve in the event that a dramatic change would take place in their habitat, devastating the population.  Drought has led biologists to monitor the salamanders’ habitat more and think about how they could increase their holding capacity to keep more salamanders.Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), Oct. 8, 2014
Places: Hays County, TX

Title: 90-day burn ban for Tarrant County, Texas
Description: Tarrant County commissioners enacted a ban on outdoor burning for 90 days beginning Oct. 7, 2014, because the drought index rose in the preceding six weeks.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Oct. 7, 2014
Places: Tarrant County, TX

Title: Redwood trees, other vegetation drought-stressed in Santa Cruz County, California
Description: Vegetation in the Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park was showing obvious signs of drought stress.  Oxalis on the forest floor was shriveled up, ferns were turning a rusty-brown, conifers were shedding leaves more heavily than usual and redwood trees were dropping their cones prematurely before the cones were open and spreading seeds.Leaf samples from the redwoods seemed to indicate that the trees were not drawing water as easily as usual, particularly the younger trees.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Oct. 7, 2014
Places: Santa Cruz County, CA

Title: California drought produced exquisite grapes
Description: Vintners have not tasted such exquisite grapes as were produced this season since the last California drought in 2007-2009.Wall Street Journal (Public access) (New York), Oct. 7, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA, Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Lake County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Riverside County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Ventura County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Western pond turtles succumbing to starvation, illness at pond in northern Los Angeles County, California
Description: A drying lake in northern Los Angeles County has led to the deaths of many state-protected Western pond turtles, which were dying of starvation and conditions related to starvation, according to necropsies done by the U.S. Geological Survey's National Wildlife Health Center in Madison, Wis.  The lake is normally home to about 300 turtles, but some have been rescued and kept at the Turtle Conservancy's Behler Chelonian Center in Ventura County.  The turtles are unique because they have genetic material from both northern and southern populations of Western pond turtles.  More turtles will likely temporarily reside elsewhere until the drought abates.Salinity levels of the lake were found to range from 31 to 43 parts per thousand, in comparison with the Pacific Ocean, which has a salinity of about 35 parts per thousand.Los Angeles Times, Oct. 4, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: Giant coolers to protect fish at California hatcheries
Description: Giant water chillers were installed at the Livingston Stone National Fish Hatchery below Shasta Dam in northern California and at the American River hatchery near Sacramento to lower the water temperature to a tolerable level for baby salmon and other fish.  ABC News, Oct. 3, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sacramento County, CA, Shasta County, CA

Title: Years of drought threaten California dairy farmers
Description: Years of drought drove California hay prices to record heights, threatening the viability of dairy farms.  Organic farms were even more hard pressed to continue because organic feed is pricier than regular feed.  Premium alfalfa sold for up to $350 per ton in 2014, up from $200 to $250 per ton in 2013.  The cost of water on average in the Central Valley was 10 times higher in 2014 than in 2013.  Milk prices rose as farmers passed along their increased costs, but during drought, farmers can only hang on so long.  One to two percent of the dairy farmers in California went out of business between 2011 and 2014.Los Angeles Times, Oct. 3, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Tulare County, CA

Title: Life is challenging without running water in Tulare County, California
Description: More than 500 homes in Tulare County do not have running water as the drought allows the water table to fall.  Residents with dry wells must rely on donations or  purchase water and do not have the luxury of flushing toilets, turning on a faucet to get a drink, washing clothes or washing their hands without getting water from a bottle or bucket.  Many of the waterless homes rely on wells on unincorporated land and have no municipal system to connect to without extreme expense.  The East Porterville high school lets students who arrive early shower if they need to do so.  Parents are reluctant to allow their children to go to school dirty because they are afraid the children will be taken from them.  Families are turning to canned and fast food because preparing food at home requires water that people cannot spare.New York Times, Oct. 2, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tulare County, CA, Porterville, CA

Title: Humboldt County, California, water rationing taking place
Description: The first week of October is often dry and sunny, as we anticipate fall and winter rains that will replenish our summer dry spell (normal for this area).  However, this year, in addition to "sunny and dry" the first week of October was in the 90's with a few days over 100!  Scorching heat on already stressed plants from the third year drought.   My temps are from a Davis Instrument system which has its sensor under an eave on the west side of the house, so it will record higher temps than the ones supplied by NOAA.  But I didn't have to look at a thermometer to know that the heat was excessive and "over the top" for the season.  The rain in September made it possible to do a few loads of laundry at home, but we are back to taking it to town to save the household water (from a seasonally affected spring) for animals, including our family.  This is the first year we had to start severe water rationing in July.  We also have had to buy water and transport it to our home.  Other years it was mid-September, knowing the rains would begin soon.  The leaves on the oaks didn't change colors this year or last. They went brown.  And instead of blowing away from autumn storms last year, they fell straight down and stayed under the trees - very different from decades of previous observations.  Berries dried up before becoming ripe.  No plumpness this year.  Seed heads fell to the ground, so (seed-eating) birds are doing more ground foraging than clinging to stalks to eat.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Kneeland 3.5 SSE on 10/9/2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Humboldt County, CA

Title: Yosemite Falls resumed later than usual in drought year
Description: Yosemite Falls normally resumes flow with autumn rains, but in 2014, rains did not come until early December. Los Angeles Times, Dec. 21, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Increased rebates through the Santa Clara Valley Water District in California
Description: The Santa Clara Valley Water District has increased its rebate program through Oct. 31 to invite more people to replace turf with drought-tolerant landscaping and install low flow toilets and high efficiency washing machines.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Oct. 1, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: Voluntary Irrigation Suspension Program for the Edwards Aquifer Authority in south Texas
Description: The Edwards Aquifer Authority will offer the Voluntary Irrigation Suspension Program Option in 2015.  The program conserves water in the aquifer by giving payments to farmers and other heavy water users in exchange for them not irrigating.  The VISPO became an option for irrigators because the J-17 index well in Bexar County fell below the historic average of 630.6 feet above sea level, triggering the use of the no-irrigation program.Landowners will leave about 39,000 acre-feet in the aquifer, or nearly 7 percent of the EAA’s total permitted pumping.  Farmers and others will receive $8 million from pumping and customer fees and contributions.My San Antonio.com (Texas), Oct. 1, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Atascosa County, TX, Bexar County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Comal County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hays County, TX, Medina County, TX

Title: Sonoma County, California, high fire hazard, installed new well due to low production of other wells
Description: A period of intense rain in December produced substantial runoff and sediment mobilization because of several prior years of drought which led to less grass cover and thatch. Following the rain, grass growth has continued, with perennial grasses benefiting. This is now starting to show stress, as January has been extremely dry, and although there was some infiltration during the rain, seasonal streams which normally are at peak flows in January are reduced to trickles. There will be continuing water stress, with some tree loss. We have some pines and Douglas fir that died in the last year, and other broadleaf trees are showing stress. Fire hazard in our area will be very high this year, so we will need to be diligent with our fire safety work around the house. We had a new well installed during the summer because the other wells have become far less productive.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Geyserville 10.6 WNW on 1/31/2015
Categories: Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Midpines, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Hungry bears causing problems in Lake Tahoe and Reno, Nevada
Description: Nine hungry bears were captured in the Lake Tahoe/Reno area in the first two days of October and a tenth bear was struck and killed by a vehicle in Reno.  The bruins were ravenous, going through hyperphagia, when they eat excessively to fatten up for winter hibernation.  Drought had dried up streams and cut down on berry production and insect populations, leaving the hungry bears to move into residential areas to look for food.  Nevada Department of Wildlife officials nabbed 42 black bears and released 40 back into the wild between July 1 and Oct. 2.  Two bears had to be put down because they were too bold.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Oct. 2, 2014
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: South Texas ranchers thinking about selling cattle
Description: Despite rains that revived dry rangeland and pastures in northern South Texas, plenty of ranchers were still thinking about selling cattle.Rain helped pastures in southern South Texas also, and improved soil moisture enough that farmers were willing to plant dryland oats and wheat.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 30, 214

Title: Soil too dry in Henderson County, Texas for field work, planting
Description: Producers in Henderson County were holding off on preparing winter fields and planting because soil moisture was too low.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 30, 214
Places: Henderson County, TX

Title: Wells Fargo & Company donated $100,000 to the American Red Cross Capital Region to aid victims of the King, Boles, Junction and Courtney fires in California
Description: Wells Fargo & Company has donated $100,000 to the American Red Cross Capital Region to aid victims of the King, Boles, Junction and Courtney fires.  Wells Fargo customers in northern and central California can also donate to the Red Cross at Wells Fargo ATMs.  No fees will be charged for such transactions and all donations will go to the Red Cross.   Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 26, 2014
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Alameda County, CA, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Butte County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Del Norte County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Inyo County, CA, Kings County, CA, Lake County, CA, Lassen County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Merced County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Mono County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: California firefighting tactics adapted during drought
Description: California firefighters succeeded in having enough water on hand to fight the King Fire and others during intense drought, and that accomplishment required forethought and planning.  In some instances, fire crews used portable pumps that had to be carried to the water’s edge to draw water after lakes dwindled, exposing a muddy or steep lake bed.  At other times, water bodies were too shallow for a helicopter’s bucket to dip into the water to refill, spurring fire crews to be creative to get the water needed to put out a fire.Various water-conserving tactics were used in place of traditional water.  When feasible, crews set backfires to clear vegetation or used firefighting foam to smother a fire rather than spraying water on it.Water agencies were also working more closely with firefighters to make water accessible by allowing firefighters to use small area reservoirs.Portable tanks were another helpful means of getting the needed water for firefighting.  Water-tender trucks can usually carry 3,500 gallons of water, while the portable tanks can hold up to 5,000 gallons, so it can take two vehicles, which sometimes must travel long distances to bring the water, to fill a tank.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 25, 2014
Places: California, El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: Tumbleweeds thriving in Southern California
Description: Tumbleweeds are thriving in Southern California since drought and meager late spring rainfall offered enough moisture at the right time for the Russian thistles to flourish and crowd out other vegetation.  The worst afflicted areas include parts of the San Fernando Valley, Griffith Park, the hill country between Orange and Riverside counties, the foothills of the San Gabriel and Santa Monica Mountains, and the Antelope Valley.  The tumbleweeds pose a fire danger as the vegetation dries out, breaks off and rolls with the wind.  Homeowners are expected to clear their property of dry vegetation that poses a fire danger, and county or state agencies take care of troublesome vegetation on other land.Los Angeles Times, Sept. 25, 2014
Places: Imperial County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, San Fernando, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Park superintendents in the Inland Empire in Southern California taking steps to reduce water use
Description: Park superintendents in the Inland Empire were taking steps to reduce water use as California’s drought continued.  The water spigot at Lake Perris State Recreation Area has been shut off to conserve water.  A message was also posted on the park's website forewarning potential visitors that, “Grass at the day use and group use areas is dead and brown.”  Visitors inquire about the cause of the brown grass, whereupon the superintendent tells them it is due to the drought.Some grassy areas in Eastvale parks in the Jurupa Community Services District were less lush and even yellowing in spots.  The district installed a high-tech irrigation system one year ago that waters minimally.  Watering schedules have been curtailed to conserve water.The San Jacinto-based Valley-Wide Recreation and Park District also installed a high-tech irrigation system that monitors temperature, humidity, water evaporation and moisture levels in the grass and waters according to parameters set by the operator.  The district is connecting to recycled water and putting in drought tolerant plants in place of little-used turf.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Sept. 22, 2014
Places: Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California has used slightly more than two-thirds of its stored supplies
Description: The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California has used slightly more than two-thirds of its stored supplies during the past three years, leaving about 18 months’ worth of water remaining.  If the upcoming winter does not bring plenty of precipitation, the MWD may reduce water deliveries to its regional distributors in 2015, meaning rationing for its Southern California water customers.   Minneapolis-St. Paul Star Tribune (Minn.), Sept. 22, 2014
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: California wine grape growers mitigating the effects of drought
Description: Wine grape growers in California were mitigating the effects of drought by using imaging technology to minimize vineyard water consumption, recycling water for irrigation and changing conservation practices.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 22, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA, Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Lake County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Merced County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Riverside County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Ventura County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Smoke from King Fire prompted cancellation of Ironman events in Lake Tahoe area
Description: Smoke from the blazing King Fire in the Tahoe National Forest prompted the cancellation of two Ironman events in the Lake Tahoe area on the morning of Sept. 21.  Roughly 3,000 competitors from around the globe came to participate, but the air quality was poor.Eugene Register-Guard (Ore.), Sept. 22, 2014
Categories: Fire, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: Mudslide on Mt. Shasta in Northern California thought to be drought-related
Description: An immense mudslide in Mud Creek Canyon on Mt. Shasta has been attributed to drought after debris and mud flowed down the mountain on Sept. 20, crossing Pilgrim Creek Road and Forest Service Road 31.  Experts think that glacial melting, hastened by drought, could have produced water which destabilized huge ice blocks and caused the debris flow in the Shasta-Trinity National Forest.  Los Angeles Times, Sept. 22, 2014
Places: Siskiyou County, CA

Title: States of emergency in El Dorado, Siskiyou counties in California
Description: California Gov. Brown declared states of emergency in El Dorado and Siskiyou counties, due to the King and Boles fires burning out of control.The King Fire in El Dorado County scorched nearly 28,000 acres, was just 5 percent contained and continued to grow.  More than 2,400 firefighters were battling the conflagration.The Boles Fire near Weed in Siskiyou County burned 375 acres and destroyed 150 structures.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 18, 2014
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority plans new reservoir in Wharton County, Texas
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority approved plans on Sept. 17 to construct a new reservoir near Lane City in Wharton County.  Their aim is to bolster the water supply for the basin by locating the $214.9 million reservoir in an area that receives about twice as much rainfall as the Highland Lakes.  The LCRA estimates that the new reservoir will provide an average of 90,000 acre-feet annually to the LCRA’s total water supply.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Oct. 8, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX, Lane City, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Low level of Lake Perris in Riverside County, California revealing tire reef; lake low partly from providing drinking water for region
Description: Drought and lowered water levels for dam repair have revealed the famed tire reef in Lake Perris.  The lake dipped 40 vertical feet to 1,548 feet, the lowest since the reservoir was created in 1973.  Interesting objects, such as boats, trees and the tire reef, have been exposed.  The tires are nearly 8 feet tall and three feet wide, are bound together with rope and were designed to be hiding places for fish.  Anglers recognize the spot for its fabulous fishing.The lake is the southernmost part of the State Water Project, moving water from Northern California to the Inland region.   From September to December, the lake was drawn down to provide drinking water for Riverside County water customers due to shortfalls in deliveries from the SWP.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Feb. 4, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: The Boles Fire in Siskiyou County, California
Description: The Boles Fire near Weed in Siskiyou County burned 375 acres and destroyed 150 structures.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 18, 2014The Boles Fire began on the afternoon of Sept. 15 and quickly engulfed several homes in Weed, a community of 3,000 residents, before firefighters arrived.  A minimum of 100 homes were damaged or destroyed and 375 acres were blackened through the evening of Sept. 16.  Two churches, a Roman Catholic and a Presbyterian, were destroyed.  Warm weather and intense drought across the state have increased the fire danger.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Sept. 17, 2014
Places: Siskiyou County, CA, Weed, CA

Title: Fire retardant record set fighting King Fire in El Dorado County, California
Description: Firefighters battling the King Fire in El Dorado County dropped 203,000 gallons of fire retardant on the blaze on a single day, setting a new daily record, said a state fire spokeswoman.  Through Sept. 19, more than 500,000 gallons of fire retardant had been dropped on the fire because normal amounts of fire retardant were not stopping the fire.  Prolonged drought has turned the timber and vegetation into kindling.Associated Press (New York), Sept. 19, 2014
Places: El Dorado County, CA

Title: The King Fire charred about 149 square miles in El Dorado, Placer counties in California
Description: More than $53 million has been spent in fighting the King Fire, the second costliest fire in California in 2014.  Only the Happy Camp Fire has cost more to fight, at $86 million.  USA Today, Sept. 25, 2014The King Fire was 55 percent contained on the evening of Sept. 25 after burning 95,347 acres or 149 square miles in nearly two weeks.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 25, 2014The King Fire has blackened more than 92,900 acres, or 145 square miles, consumed 12 homes and more than 50 other structures and threatens 21,000 structures.  The fire was 38 percent contained on Sept. 24 as more than 7,600 firefighters struggled to bring the blaze under control.  Washington Post (D.C.), Sept. 24, 2014The King Fire continued to burn through more acres of forest, charring nearly 90,000 acres or about 140 square miles of land in El Dorado and Placer counties.  The blaze has claimed 57 buildings and 12 homes in the White Meadows area, said the El Dorado County sheriff.The fire was 35 percent contained on the afternoon of Sept. 23, an improvement from the 18 percent containment on the previous day.  USA Today, Sept. 23, 2014The King Fire blackened 87,592 acres or nearly 137 square miles through the morning of Sept. 22.  There were 5,400 firefighters from California and other parts of the country struggling to contain the blaze as it burned into timber in the Tahoe National Forest in Placer County.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 22, 2014.The King Fire consumed 10 homes, 22 outbuildings and more than 128 square miles and was 17 percent contained on Sept. 21.	Eugene Register-Guard (Ore.), Sept. 22, 2014The King Fire had charred 76,376 acres or 119 square miles as of early Sept. 19.  The fire grew only 5,000 acres overnight, thanks to cooler, cloudier conditions.  The previous night, the fire exploded to twice its size, reaching 114 square miles as dense, dry vegetation fed the fire.Los Angeles Times, Sept. 19, 2014The King Fire has grown to 111 square miles and forced the evacuation of nearly 2,800 people from their homes since the fire began on Sept. 13.  A man thought to have started the fire was arrested on Sept. 18.Arizona Republic (Phoenix) & AZCentral.com, Sept. 18, 2014The King Fire in El Dorado County scorched nearly 28,000 acres, was just 5 percent contained and continued to grow.  More than 2,400 firefighters were battling the conflagration.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 18, 2014The King Fire consumed nearly 13,000 acres and was just 5 percent contained through the evening of Sept. 16.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Sept. 17, 2014The King Fire charred 3,900 acres in the canyon of the south fork of the American River in El Dorado County.  The fire began and grew rapidly on the afternoon of Sept. 13 near Pollock Pines.  Cal Fire said that 406 homes were evacuated voluntarily.Residents of Reno, Nevada suffered smoky skies as wind carried smoke in their direction.USA Today, Sept. 15, 2014
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA

Title: Silverado Fire in Southern California
Description: A wildfire chewed through 2 square miles of drought-dried brush in Silverado Canyon in the Cleveland National Forest.  The blaze prompted the evacuations of roughly 30 homes as a precautionary measure.  Sacramento Bee (California), Sept. 12, 2014
Places: Orange County, CA

Title: Speed limit of 5 miles per hour on Folsom Lake in California
Description: The speed limit for boaters on Folsom Lake is 5 miles per hour to prevent boaters from harming themselves and their watercraft.  The safety risk is much higher as the depleted lake brings subsurface hazards nearer to the surface.  Los Angeles Times, Sept. 11, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: Nine county public boat ramps closed on Canyon Lake in Comal County, Texas
Description: Nine county public boat ramps on Canyon Lake were closed due to the low water level, but 10 public boat ramps remain open.  With the lake level at 898 feet above sea level, it was no longer possible to safely put a boat in the water.  The president of the Canyon Lake Area Chamber of Commerce stated that the lake was still open for boating with an average depth of 42 feet.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 10, 2014
Places: Comal County, TX

Title: Drought Task Force in Glenn County, California
Description: When the Glenn County Drought Task Force met on Sept. 10, they were notified of 21 dry residential wells, mostly near Orland.  Four homes without water were located on Road M, south of Orland.  County residents with dry wells may purchase water from the city’s well at the airport.  Only one family bought water.Three to five permits for agricultural wells have been requested weekly, said the director of Glenn County Environmental Health.  There has been a record high demand for well permits this year at roughly 150 permits so far.  Water for the 300 residents of Elk Creek was brown about a month ago, due to excess manganese in the soil.  The water was treated with potassium permanganate and meets standards.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Sept. 11, 2014The Glenn County Board of Supervisors voted to create a Drought Task Force to monitor drought issues and provide education to the public.  The task force will meet twice monthly until the drought emergency has eased.  At least 16 residential wells have gone dry in Glenn County, but residents do not know where to turn for help with a dry well.  The task force can gather information such and share it with the public.  The task force can also be in touch with well drillers to have a better idea of how many dry wells or nearly dry wells exist in the area.  Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Sept. 10, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Glenn County, CA, Orland, CA

Title: Shallow well went dry in Butte County, California
Description: A Butte County woman has had no running water since her well went dry a month and a half ago.  She does not have the money to have the shallow well dug deeper, buy an above-ground tank and pump or connect to the local water system.  She’s looking for a job, but at present cannot get a loan for getting an above-ground tank and pump, the least expensive option, because with no job, lenders doubt she will be able to repay the money.Los Angeles Times, Oct. 24, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA

Title: East Texas trees stressed by drought
Description: Water-stressed trees in East Texas showed some leaf scorch.  Trees were also dying or were already dead from previous drought stress.Odessa American (Texas), Sept. 9, 2014

Title: Ninth bear in residential area in Kern County, California this month
Description: A small black bear in a tree led a Bakersfield resident to call the California Department of Fish and Wildlife, who darted the 75-pound juvenile female and relocated her 20 miles from the city.  This was the ninth bear found in an inhabited area of Kern County in the past month.  Drought is thought to be driving bears into residential area in search of food.Bakersfield Californian, Oct. 9, 2014

Title: Many homes in California have no water meters
Description: More than 235,000 California homes and businesses still lacked water meters, according to the most recent data available from the State Water Board.  An analysis by the Associated Press showed that people living in 10 water districts with the most unmetered homes or businesses used more water than the state average.  Many Californians receiving water from roughly 40 water districts along a 300 mile length of the Central Valley still pay a flat rate for their water and have no water meter to keep track of how much water is used.  In Sacramento, 49 percent or 66,250 homes had yet to receive water meters.  In Bakersfield, 35 percent of homes were unmetered; in Modesto, 24 percent of homes remained unmetered; and in Lodi, 55 percent of residences had no meters.Reno Gazette-Journal (Nev.), Sept. 6, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Bridge Fire burned in Mariposa County, California
Description: The Bridge Fire began on Sept. 5 near Yosemite National Park and quickly charred more than 300 acres.  More than 700 homes and five businesses were forced to evacuate.  Extreme drought conditions, high temperatures, low humidity and steep, dry terrain made the fire difficult to control.  Gov. Jerry Brown announced on Sept. 6 that he had gotten a grant from the Federal Emergency Management Agency that may cover up to 75 percent of firefighting costs for local, state and tribal agencies that apply for the reimbursement.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Sept. 6, 2014

Title: Capacity of San Vicente Dam in San Diego, California increased
Description: The San Vicente Dam was raised 117 feet to increase the dam’s capacity by 152,000 acre-feet to more than 242,000 acre-feet, including 100,000 acre-feet of carryover storage to be used during drought. Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Sept. 2, 2014

Title: Pets getting fleas in Napa, California
Description: More Napa pets were suffering from fleas than usual, stated a veterinarian who reported that most pets have fleas and about one-third have itchy skin.  The problem became apparent toward the end of summer 2014 when many people noticed the insects, which may be thriving in the mild weather.  The executive director of Napa Humane said that extreme heat or cold was needed to curb flea populations, but Napa had not seen either extreme for the past year.  Although drought does not directly affect flea populations, it can bring wildlife closer to residential areas and pets, allowing the pets to become infested with fleas.  Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Aug. 13, 2015
Places: Napa County, CA, Napa, CA

Title: Buoys warn of shallow water in Lake Elsinore, California
Description: The shallow level of Lake Elsinore led city employees to put buoys in the water to warn boaters away as the natural lake was about one-quarter full.The Seaport boat launch closed in 2014, due to the receding shoreline.  The La Laguna Resort and Boat Launch remained open, but officials were closely monitoring it.  Nicole Dailey, senior management analyst for Lake Elsinore, said that city officials were concerned about the level of Lake Elsinore this summer because it was as shallow as 3 feet in places, which would damage boat propellers.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 10, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Extreme heat and drought have hindered agriculture in South Texas
Description: Livestock producers in northern South Texas continued giving supplemental feed to cattle because rangeland and pastures were in poor condition.  Soil moisture remained short across much of the region.In eastern South Texas, soil moisture remained short to very short in Jim Hogg and Jim Wells counties.Producers in western South Texas continued the supplemental feeding and light culling of livestock.  Producers who could irrigate were pre-watering fields before planting wheat because soil moisture was short to very short.Odessa American (Texas), Sept. 9, 2014Forage supplies in the northern part of South Texas were not plentiful, and livestock producers were purchasing hay for supplemental feed.  Stock tank water levels were dropping rapidly.  Ranchers had to move cattle from some pastures for lack of water.  In eastern South Texas, rangeland and pastures deteriorated with little to no rain.  Livestock producers in western South Texas increased supplemental feeding because poor forage quality and declining cattle body conditions warranted action.  Austin American Statesman (Texas), Sept. 3, 2014Extreme heat and drought have hindered agriculture in South Texas, where rangeland and pastures were deteriorating.In the northern part of the region, ongoing limited forage availability was a problem in some areas.  Stock tanks were rapidly drying down as heat and evaporation took their toll.  In the eastern part of the region, forages dried out unusually fast due to extreme heat and strong winds; and soil moisture was short to very short.  Producers in Jim Hogg County were feeding corn and hay to livestock and wildlife to compensate for the lack of nutritional range and pastureland forages.Ranchers in the western part of South Texas had reduced stocking rates, so not as much supplemental feeding was needed, but the need for supplemental feeding increased as pastures deteriorated.  High evaporation rates kept water levels in stock tanks falling.  In the southern part of the region, soil moisture was short to very short, and range and pasture conditions were slipping with high temperatures and strong winds.Austin American Statesman (Texas), Aug. 26, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Emergency restrictions on smoking, grilling in Sacramento County, California parks
Description: In an effort to reduce fires in Sacramento County, smoking along the American River Parkway and barbeque grilling in county parks was prohibited by county supervisors on Aug. 26.  Effective immediately, smoking was not permitted in nature areas and on unpaved trails.  Grilling was allowed only at designated picnic areas or beaches, depending on the type of fuel used.  Numerous fires and drought-related fire risk led the Board of Supervisors to unanimously approve the emergency restrictions.  Sacramento County parks have seen 30 fires this year, with 29 of those burning in the American River Parkway.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 26, 2014

Title: Drought continued to hinder agriculture in Texas
Description: Drought continued to hinder agriculture in Texas even while parts of the state have received rain and emerged somewhat from drought.  Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service agents shared how dry conditions were affecting their parts of the state. In Lynn County, crops are stressed by the hot dry conditions, despite the use of irrigation systems.  Pasture conditions in Kaufman County have deteriorated, due to the hot, dry weather.  Ward County ranchers were also seeing a deterioration of range conditions and were weaning and shipping calves early as a result.  The hot, dry conditions stopped all hay operations in Burnet County and have increased the fire danger.  Pastures and timber stands in Orange County were stressed by the heat and lack of rain.  Timber die off has been more noticeable during the past month.  The lack of rain has stressed livestock production in Uvalde County and may force ranchers to sell cattle soon.Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), Aug. 25, 2014
Places: Burnet County, TX, Kaufman County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Orange County, TX, Uvalde County, TX, Ward County, TX

Title: Wind-driven wildfire burning in steep terrain near Weaverville, California
Description: An explosive wildfire roughly 2 miles west of Weaverville has forced the evacuation of 150 homes and threatened another 500 homes and 20 businesses and facilities.  The blaze, which began Aug. 24 along Highway 299, burned about 650 acres in dry, steep terrain and was driven by gusty winds.  USA Today, Aug. 25, 2014
Places: Trinity County, CA

Title: Lawn replacements, lawn painting popular during California drought
Description: Californians have shown more interest in replacing lawns with drought-tolerant landscaping, especially when cities offer good rebates for residents who do so.  During July, the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California received requests to take out 2.5 million square feet of residential lawns, a dramatic increase from 99,000 sq. feet in January, according to the consortium's water efficiency manager.  More than 21 million square feet of turf have been torn out since the district began its turf removal incentives. The Municipal Water District of Orange County receives 20 to 30 applications daily, a big jump from the five requests per week the district saw before the governor’s drought emergency declaration in January.  The Santa Clara Valley Water District has gotten more than 1,700 requests for turf removal rebates during the first half of 2014, five times more than the first half of 2013, said a district spokesman.  More than 1,300 lawn removal projects have been undertaken in Long Beach.Some Californians have chosen to paint their lawns rather than try to keep them green through watering.  A vegetable-based dye lasts for a few months.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 24, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Water releases to aid Klamath River salmon in northern California; SoCal water districts petition for halt in water releases to aid salmon
Description: The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation increased water releases from the Lewiston Dam into the Trinity River on Sept. 16 as evidence of a parasite harmful to salmon resurfaced.  Ichthyophthirius multifiliis, or Ich, can be problematic in stagnant water and harms fishes’ gills, making them suffocate.  Nine of 20 fish tested for the parasite this week were found to be infected with Ich.  This is the same parasite responsible for the deaths of tens of thousands of salmon in 2002.Reclamation upped flows into the river in late August, to the consternation of water districts in Southern California that receive water from Lewiston Dam.  When the water districts sought a temporary injunction on the water releases, a U.S. district judge denied the request.  Reclamation also took into consideration that more water from Lewiston Dam meant less water for the Sacramento River for salmon and agriculture.  The bigger water release will continue for seven days.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 17, 2014U.S. District Judge Lawrence J. O'Neill in Fresno denied the temporary injunction sought by Westlands Water District and the San Luis & Delta-Mendota Water Authority.  The two water agencies wanted the water releases from a reservoir on the Trinity River to end because less water will be left for Central Valley farmers next year.  Portland Oregonian, Hillsboro Argus, Oregon Live.com (Ore.), Aug. 27, 2014The Westlands Water District and the San Luis & Delta-Mendota Water Authority filed a petition in the U.S. District Court in Fresno to stop releases of water from a reservoir on the Trinity River.  The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation began increasing flows into the Trinity River on Aug. 23 to lessen the spread of disease among salmon and to aid the fish in their journey upstream.  Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), Aug. 26, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Trinity County, CA

Title: Black bears seeking food in residential areas in Kern County, California
Description: At least ten black bears disturbed Kern County inhabitants in late summer and early fall 2014 as the bears foraged for food in residential areas.  People were urged to eliminate food sources for the bruins by bringing dog food inside and securing trash cans.Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), Oct. 22, 2014
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: Dry domestic wells in East Porterville, California
Description: A $10 million state project was announced to connect East Porterville residents with dry wells to Porterville municipal water.  The state will cover the hookup costs of $2,000 to $4,000 per connection for the 500 or so homes with dry wells.  In return, homeowners must agree to be annexed into the city in the future.  The Fresno Bee (Calif.), June 22, 2016California officials were still trying to find a better solution for the East Porterville homes with dry wells.  A drought emergency was a new type of event that was not handled well by existing state grants.  Initially, residents were given 300-gallon containers to hold non-potable water, but larger containers were needed.   Huge green tanks with a capacity of 2,500 gallons were installed in 160 front yards as the next step in handling the crisis.  The tanks were connected to the home’s plumbing system.  In 2015, a $1.2 million well was drilled, but the well was still untapped due to disagreements among government agencies.  The most recent plan was to build a municipal water system for East Porterville and connect 500 homes by the end of 2016 and hook up all 1,750 parcels by the end of 2017.Los Angeles Times, May 6, 2016About 700 homes, or roughly 3,000 people, were without well water in East Porterville, a small community of 7,500 that lacks a central water system.  The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 21, 2015East Porterville residents with dry wells were getting assistance from Girl Scouts, who set up collection points and local charities were seeking money to put water tanks next to homes.  Local schools, businesses and a religious group from Cincinnati, Ohio have donated water.  A local bank gave $50,000 to Self-Help Enterprise, a housing nonprofit, to bring more water tanks to homes.Roughly 290 families in the town have dry wells.  Many other dry wells exist in Tulare County, but it was unclear exactly how many there were.  The State Water Resources Control Board has $500,000 to purchase water for East Porterville.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 22, 2014Nearly 1,000 people of the 7,300 residents of East Porterville do not have running water.  Los Angeles Times, Sept. 18, 2014Some domestic wells have run dry in East Porterville, leaving residents to rely on the Tulare County Office of Emergency Services to bring in bottled water since Aug. 22.  At least 182 households of the 1,400 homes in town were without adequate running water, according to the Porterville Reporter.  The county has also supplied a tank of non-potable water for bathing and toilet flushing.  One East Porterville woman whose family has been without running water for four months expressed frustration at being unable to shower her three children and care for them well without water.  Another woman shared that dirt began coming out of her tap about a week ago, although the water barely flows.  She tries to use the least amount of water possible.Some East Porterville residents have been without water for a while, but have been afraid to report it for fear of being evicted or having their children removed from the home by Child Welfare Services.  The emergency services manager for Tulare County assures the public that they simply want to provide water and will not share lists of homes lacking running water.  He also assured families that the CWS will not take children from homes for lack of running water.Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 24, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tulare County, CA, East Porterville, CA

Title: Barge in use to draw water from Lake Bridgeport in northern Texas
Description: A barge with intake pumps was installed several hundred yards from the shore of  Lake Bridgeport in case the lake fell below intake pipes for the Walnut Creek Special Utility District. The lake has fallen about 23 feet, including 3 feet in the last year, and if drought continues, it could be below the intake pipes by October 2014. The Walnut Creek and Brazos Electric Power Cooperative worked together to protect their water intakes as the lake level dropped.  The barge can be moved 1,000 feet to a deeper part of the lake if needed and supports two rotating pumps which can take up to 15 million gallons out of the lake daily. Lake Bridgeport is the main water source for Walnut Creek Special Utility District, which supplies water to Rhome, Boyd, Paradise and several other cities.  Brazos Electric  was using  6.5 million gallons per day from the barge for  a power plant in Jack County.  The project cost $860,000.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Aug. 28, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Jack County, TX, Springtown, TX, Wise County, TX

Title: Several water districts in Southern California adopted more stringent regulations on water use
Description: Several water districts in Riverside and San Bernardino counties have adopted more stringent regulations on water use as drought continued.  Eastern Municipal Water District moved to Stage 3a of its Water Shortage Contingency Plan, forbidding refilling swimming pools and establishing new landscaping.  Water customers supplied by Lake Hemet Municipal and Beaumont-Cherry Valley water districts, and San Bernardino and Ontario city departments also have stricter regulations on water use.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Aug. 21, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, Beaumont, CA, Cherry Valley, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, Ontario, CA, San Bernardino, CA

Title: Emergency pumping facility to send water to South Santa Barbara County, California
Description: The Cachuma Operation and Maintenance Board constructed an emergency pumping facility to draw water from Cachuma Lake to send to southern Santa Barbara County.  Gravity normally keeps water flowing down the conveyance system, but the water level will likely soon be too low for the water intake.  The COMB received $300,000 in drought relief funding from the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, which the board intends to use to pay for electricity to operate the pumps.  The general manager of COMB said the electricity bill would range from $20,000 to $40,000 per month.The total cost of the project, including design, engineering, construction, and materials for the pumps and its associated system parts, was nearly $6 million.Santa Maria Sun (Calif.), Aug. 19, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Barbara County, CA

Title: Victoria County, Texas, wells going dry
Description: Read in the Sunday Victoria Advocate that a well and possibly more than one had gone dry at 70 feet around the Nursery, Texas area.  This was reported on the editorial page and not reported by an official.  My well is 90 feet and although I am seeing more minerals when the water dries, we still have water.  Very worrisome!  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Nursery 0.4 NNW on 8/19/2014
Places: Victoria County, TX

Title: The Way fire blackened 1,200 acres in the Sequoia National Forest in California
Description: A wildfire near Lake Isabella, northeast of Bakersfield, charred more than six square miles of dry brush and consumed eight homes and 10 outbuildings.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 21, 2014A wildfire near Lake Isabella in Kern County exploded on Aug. 18 and was 5 percent contained the next day.  The blaze charred 5 square miles or 3,367 acres and consumed some structures.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Aug. 20, 2014The Way fire blackened 1,200 acres in the Sequoia National Forest and had consumed some structures.  Los Angeles Times, Aug. 18, 2014
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: Junction Fire burning near Yosemite National Park in California
Description: The Junction fire burned roughly 1 square mile and was 40 percent contained.  Strong winds and drought conditions allowed the fire to burn rapidly and consume 8 structures, including two commercial buildings.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Aug. 20, 2014The Junction fire charred 1,200 acres near Oakhurst and led authorities to issue evacuation orders to 15,500 phone numbers.  The blaze began on Aug. 18.Los Angeles Times, Aug. 18, 2014
Places: Madera County, CA

Title: Sacramento National Wildlife Refuge Complex rescue to provide wetlands for migrating birds
Description: The BirdReturns program was in use again during the 2015-16 winter to get and keep more acres of rice fields under water for migrating birds.  Rice growers are asked to flood their fields early or leave water on the fields longer to lengthen the wet season for migrating birds.  Participating growers receive financial incentives.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Oct. 15, 2015BirdReturns, a new rescue program devised by the Nature Conservancy of California, has made bird habitat available during drought by offering money to farmers to flood their rice fields early with well water and keep the fields inundated into April 2015.  The program was developed within the past month because many historic wetlands in the Central Valley and three refuges in the Sacramento National Wildlife Refuge Complex were parched amid ongoing drought, and duck reproduction in central Canada and the Dakotas was particularly successful this spring.An aerial survey of six wildlife refuges in the Sacramento Valley complex performed in August found fewer than 10,000 ducks and 250 geese at the Sacramento and Delevan refuges, 24 ducks and no geese at Colusa, and no waterfowl at Sutter, Butte Sink and Llano Seco, which were dry.  Two million ducks, half a million geese and great numbers of shorebirds are expected to arrive during the fall and winter.  Eighty-five percent of the normal wetland habitat in the Sacramento Valley is forecast to be dry and uninviting for birds in the early winter, while 87 percent of the rice fields will be dry as well.  The government cannot supply the water or prepare the sites for migratory birds before the water fowl arrive, prompting the Nature Conservancy to invite donors to pay farmers to use their own well water to create wetlands for the birds.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Sept. 6, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: The California Department of Water Resources and U.S. Bureau of Reclamation requested analysis of water diversions by farmers in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta
Description: The California Department of Water Resources and U.S. Bureau of Reclamation requested that the State Water Resources Control Board analyze water diversions by farmers in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta.  The agencies release water from their dams on the Sacramento, Feather and American rivers, send it through the Delta,  and pump it out to send elsewhere, but are suffering water losses somewhere along the line.  They suspect that Delta farmers on the 70 Delta islands are taking water that does not belong to them.  The Delta farmers have water rights that allow them to take as much of the “natural” flow as they need to grow crops, and those water rights predate the DWR’s and Reclamation’s water rights.In response, the California Sportfishing Protection Alliance, a group that sympathizes with Delta landowners, has filed a formal complaint against DWR and Reclamation, charging that the agencies illegally divert water from the San Joaquin, Mokelumne, Cosumnes and Calaveras rivers, taking water to which they hold no rights.  The increasing tension over water use and ownership underscores the water shortage stemming from three years of drought in California.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 18, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Lake County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Orange County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Riverside County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Solano County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Yuba City, CA, Tehama County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Ventura County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Stricter water conservation for the Rancho California Water District in Riverside County, California
Description: The Rancho California Water District board adopted stricter water conservation rules, banning watering during the day and urging the installation of “California-friendly” landscaping for new homes.  No one opposed the new rules, but some residents feel that even more stringent rules are needed.Rancho Water serves customers in Southwest Riverside County, including Temecula, De Luz, Wine Country and a small portion of Murrieta.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Aug. 18, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, Murrieta, CA, Temecula, CA

Title: Tecolote Fire burning near Azusa, California
Description: The Tecolote fire scorched 274 acres in the parched mountains of the Angeles National Forest since the blaze began on Aug. 17. The fire burned in steep, rugged terrain and was not threatening homes.Los Angeles Times, Aug. 18, 2014
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Azusa, CA

Title: California's Bay Area residents expressed frustration at water loss from leaks
Description: Bay Area residents expressed frustration at a recent analysis of Department of Water Resources records from 2010, performed by the San Jose Mercury News.  Roughly 23 billion gallons of water were lost annually due to water leaks from aging and broken pipes.  Leak rates ranged from 3 to 16 percent of treated water, but total amounts could not be calculated because water agencies were not required to report water losses.  The water loss is particularly galling because Californians were told to reduce water use by 20 percent to extend water supplies during this historic drought.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Aug. 16, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Native fish in Tuolumne County, California surviving despite reduced habitat
Description: More than 200 Red Hills roach, a fish native only to the creeks and pools west of Sonora, were found to be thriving in Horton’s Creek, although a UC Davis fish biologist expected the fish to have gone extinct, due to the drought.  The Six Bit Gulch creek, which used to be the fishes’ habitat, has gone dry.A post-doctoral researcher at UC Davis explained that after three years of drought, many fish populations and community structures were going down, and diversity in streams was declining, which does not bode well for native fishes.  An inventory of 15 streams and pools in the Red Hills area found that half were entirely dry, while the other half were nearly dry.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 15, 2014
Places: Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Beaver Fire in Siskiyou County, California charred 45 square miles
