Title: Water agencies in Santa Barbara County, California paying water debt
Description: The Central Coast Water Agency bought more than 27,000 acre-feet of supplemental water, costing about $12 million over the past four years to compensate for reduced allocations from Lake Cachuma and the State Water Project.  Paying off the water debt means reimbursing the seller with water, as well as with money.Noozhawk (Santa Barbara, Calif.), March 20, 2019
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Barbara, CA

Title: Marijuana growers in Northern California’s coastal forests taking too much water from the area’s rivers and streams
Description: Marijuana growers in Northern California’s coastal forests were taking so much water from the area’s rivers and streams that they have virtually gone dry.  Drought, on top of heavy water use for the water-intensive crop, has made the problem more apparent.Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), June 1, 2014
Places: Humboldt County, CA, Lake County, CA, Mendocino County, CA

Title: Water-wasting activities banned in the East Bay Municipal Utility District in California
Description: The East Bay Municipal Utility District banned water-wasting activities, such as flooding gutters and watering lawns more than twice a week, and urged the public to push for greater water conservation.  EBMUD’s customers reduced their water use by 10 percent, but that was still short of the 20 percent water conservation sought by Gov. Brown.  Some of the other banned actions include using a hose without a shut-off valve to wash vehicles, using potable water to wash pavement or fill fountains that do not recirculate water, and watering landscaping more than twice weekly.Calls to the district to report water waste rose from 10 calls in June to 211 in July, said a spokeswoman for EBMUD.  The district added another two conservation specialists to its staff, bringing the total of staff handling complaints to 15.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Aug. 12, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Taylor County, GA

Title: Drought reducing number of organic dairy herds in the West
Description: Organic dairy herds in the West, particularly in the San Joaquin Valley, were shrinking because drought has driven farmers to sell their herds and quit the dairy business, according to the USDA’s Dairy Market News.  Net gains from a year of organic milking brought in less than selling the cattle for slaughter.  Some organic producers and representatives in the Northwest did not know of any new organic producers in the region who had gotten certification for starting a new organic dairy in the last several years.Dairy Herd Network (Lenexa, Kan.), May 31, 2014
Places: California, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Oregon, Washington

Title: Late water delivery cost Fresno County, California orange grower his crop
Description: A Fresno County orange grower in the Terra Bella Irrigation District reported that emergency water did not arrive until May, which was too late to save his orange crop, which fell to the ground.  Some orange growers in the region fared slightly better, but have smaller oranges than normal.  Other orange growers have bulldozed the trees or simply let them die.  Managers of the Orange Cove-Sanger Citrus Association expect a smaller crop, but still hope to get a decent crop.  The board chairman of California Citrus Mutual noted that while the oranges may be on the small side now, there was still plenty of time for rainfall before the end of harvest in June.  California produces 85 percent of the country’s fresh citrus, with navel oranges being one of the state’s top crops, valued at more than $721 million annually.Ag Alert (Sacramento, Calif.), Nov. 12, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: The California Water Resources Board ordered 2,648 Sacramento Valley water agencies and users with junior water rights to stop withdrawing water from some rivers and streams
Description: Curtailments imposed by the State Water Resources Control Board have ended for junior water rights holders in the Sacramento and San Joaquin river watersheds dated after 1914 and the Russian River watershed.  Recent rainfall boosted river flow, allowing the board to lift curtailments, but dry weather could bring further curtailments.Curtailments remain in effect for the Scott River in far Northern California and Deer Creek in Tehama County.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Nov. 19, 2014The California Water Resources Board ordered 2,648 Sacramento Valley water agencies and users with junior water rights issued after 1914 to stop withdrawing water from the American, Feather and Yuba rivers and numerous streams.  Those affected are mainly farmers and large irrigation districts, but the city of Sacramento also must stop taking water from the Sacramento River because the city has junior water rights, although it has senior water rights for the American River.  Similar water cuts were last ordered in 1977.Members of the Colusa Drain Mutual Water Co. were warned to expect no water this year, leading growers to plant crops that could be watered using only alternate water sources, such as groundwater or other surface water supplies.  As a result, just 4,000 acres of the 20,000 acres usually planted with rice and irrigated by the Colusa Drain Mutual Water Co. were planted this year.  Drastic cuts in tomato and alfalfa planting also occurred in the district.The state Water board may handle the junior water rights holders in the San Joaquin Valley differently by asking water users to sign a voluntary water agreement, stating that they acknowledge the order and have stopped diverting water.  Senior water rights holders may be affected by curtailments in coming weeks as water supplies dwindle over the summer, but some senior water rights holders have already refused to allow reductions to their water rights and will make no allowances for wildlife and urban health and safety needs.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 29, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Sacramento, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Nevada Irrigation District in California not making deliveries of fall irrigation water
Description: The Nevada Irrigation District has begun storing more water since the state water board ended its curtailment of diversions into storage.  The curtailment was in effect from May 27 through Nov. 12, 2014.Auburn Journal (Calif.), Dec. 17, 2014The Nevada Irrigation District will not deliver fall irrigation water because the district does not have enough storage and supply to do so and also because the State Water Resources Control Board curtailed thousands of water rights across the state earlier this year, leaving the district unsure of whether it has the legal right to divert and deliver water from Sierra Nevada streams.  Several thousand small agricultural customers in Nevada County and parts of Placer County usually receive fall water between Oct. 15 and Dec. 1.  It has been more than 20 years since the district was unable to provide water for fall irrigation.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Oct. 29, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA

Title: Hunters fire in Mariposa County, California burned more than 1,300 acres
Description: The Hunters fire in Mariposa County consumed more than 1,300 acres of dry brush, two homes and an outbuilding near Lake McClure since the fire began on May 26 near Hunters Valley Access Road in Bear Valley.  More than 670 firefighters were battling the blaze, which was 20 percent contained on the morning of May 28.  Steep terrain made the fire difficult to access.  "This fire is burning like it would in summer with the dry conditions we've been experiencing," said Cal Fire spokesman Daniel Berlant. Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 28, 2014
Places: Mariposa County, CA

Title: East side San Joaquin Valley growers filed lawsuit to stop water releases from Millerton Lake
Description: The Friant Water Authority, representing 15,000 growers on the east side of the San Joaquin Valley, filed a lawsuit to stop the release of water from Millerton Lake, saying that water from a Northern California water supply should be used to help west side growers, rather than junior water users, such as wildlife refuges and the State Water Project.  A long-established water-rights prioritization would have east side growers receiving the water in Millerton Lake.Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 22, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Greater water conservation urged in SoCal
Description: Officials with the Metropolitan Water District urged consumers to strive for greater water conservation in case the drought lasts into 2015.  The MWD boosted its Southland water reserves in the past two years and has been drawing heavily from Diamond Valley Lake and Castaic Lake in Los Angeles County.  Water deliveries from the State Water Project was to be 5 percent of normal, although the MWD usually gets about one-third of its annual supply from the SWP.  The MWD has taken a number of actions to help its customers understand the severity of the water situation.  The incentive for turf removal and other water conservation projects has been increased to reduce water use.  The MWD brought back the fuel gauge display to its website to help customers understand how much water the district has in reserve.  A new radio and television campaign was in the works for the summer, underscoring the importance of water conservation.  Two treatment plants that process Colorado River water were shut down to adapt their water delivery system to make drought-related changes.  Some maintenance projects were also deferred to keep the aqueduct system operation at nearly full capacity.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 22, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: California Water Resources Control Board may limit water use in tributaries of Sacramento River to maintain minimum flows for fish
Description: The State Water Resources Control Board approved regulations that could limit water use from low streams flowing into the Sacramento River this summer.  Farmers strongly opposed the new regulations, which set standards for the minimum volume of water that must flow in three Sacramento River watersheds when there are fish in them.  The standards allow state officials to limit water use when water levels are too low. Reuters (New York), May 21, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Kings River in Tulare County, California closed to motorized watercraft
Description: The Kings River in Tulare County was closed to motorized watercraft because there was too little water for boating, said the director of Parks and Recreation.  The river did not appear to be running and consisted of a series of pools.  All-terrain vehicles and motorcycles were prohibited in the riverbed.Boating was impossible in the Kings River in Fresno County, but there were no restrictions on boating, according to a law enforcement official.  The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers will begin releasing irrigation water from Pine Flat Dam in June, and there should be enough water in the river in July to support boating.Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 20, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Opposition to proposed sale of water from Merced County, California
Description: The proposed sale of nearly 100,000 acre-feet of Merced County water per year for four years to west-side water districts in Stanislaus County has some agricultural leaders worried that irrigation supplies will become depleted.  A Merced County supervisor intends to seek the support of her colleagues for an emergency ordinance to prevent the sale.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 20, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Merced County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA

Title: Shortage of water for crop irrigation in California expected to lead to an estimated $1.7 billion loss to the state’s agricultural economy
Description: The shortage of water for crop irrigation in California is expected to lead to an estimated $1.7 billion loss to the state’s agricultural economy and leave roughly 14,500 farm workers looking for jobs, according to a preliminary study by the University of California, Davis, Center for Watershed Sciences.  Computer models and recent water delivery amounts were used to tally up the estimated losses in the survey, commissioned by the California Department of Food and Agriculture.  Central Valley farmers may fallow about 6 percent or 410,000 acres because water deliveries will likely be two-thirds of normal this year.  With less irrigation water from surface supplies, farmers are anticipated to pump more groundwater at an estimated cost of $450 million.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 19, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Drought surcharge for water customers in western Travis County, Texas
Description: The West Travis County Public Utility Agency approved a 20 percent drought surcharge for all water customers starting in July.  Water conservation resulted in reduced revenue for the WTCPUA, while fixed costs mean that the utility must increase revenue, which will happen through the drought surcharge.  Unfilled salary positions have remained unfilled and other measures were taken to cut costs, but the WTCPUA has little choice but to adopt the drought surcharge.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), May 28, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Placer County, California water agency again storing water as curtailment ends
Description: The Placer County Water Agency has been storing more water since the state water board lifted a curtailment order on diversions into storage.  The state board issued the curtailment on May 27, 2014, because demand for water in the Sacramento River exceeded supply, and lifted it on Nov. 12, 2014.  Auburn Journal (Calif.), Dec. 17, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Placer County, CA

Title: Drought Food Assistance Program boxes available to families in Kern County, California
Description: Community Action Partnership of Kern handed out 30-pound boxes of food to Bakersfield families impacted by drought.  The California Department of Social Services delivered the Drought Food Assistance Program boxes, which contain beans, rice, vegetable soup, canned fruit and spaghetti.  The CAPK has 30,854 such boxes to distribute in Kern County.While many of the families were not facing hardships stemming directly from drought, the families simply had to sign a form attesting that the drought had impacted them.The food bank manager for Community Action Partnership said 800 boxes were given out in Arvin, 600 in Shafter and 250 in Tehachapi.Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), May 19, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: Frustration in Fresno County, California over Bureau of Reclamation's decision to take water from Millerton Lake for west side farmers
Description: Farmers, water district authorities and city leaders voiced their frustration that the federal Bureau of Reclamation decided to take water from Millerton Lake to give to farmers on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley to meet contractual obligations to the San Joaquin River Exchange Contractors Water Authority.The mayor of Fresno would like a seat at the table with the bureau, city officials and key stakeholders when deciding water issues to help Valley farmers.  The Fresno City Council approved a transfer of 710 acre-feet of water of its San Joaquin River water to the Orange Cove Irrigation District, which provides water for about 28,000 acres in Fresno and Tulare counties.  Water customers in the central San Joaquin Valley who will get no surface water this year were incensed at the bureau’s decision to take water from Millerton Lake.  Even farmers who will benefit from the water transfer from Millerton Lake were unhappy with the bureau moving the water from Millerton Lake.Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 15, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Fresno, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA

Title: Metropolitan Water District increased rebates on a number of water conservation programs for Southern Californians
Description: The Metropolitan Water District increased rebates on a number of water conservation programs after Gov. Brown urged Californians to step up their conservation efforts.  The rebate for turf replacement is doubled, and rebates for rain barrels and high-efficiency toilets have been extended.  MWD serves customers in Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino, San Diego and Ventura counties.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 15, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Water from Friant Dam to meet contractual obligation to San Joaquin River Exchange Contractors Water Authority in California
Description: The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation began releasing more water from Friant Dam near Fresno into the drought-stricken San Joaquin River to supply as much water as has been contracted to the San Joaquin River Exchange Contractors Water Authority on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley.  The water release will be increased from 200 cubic feet per second to 1,200 cfs.In 1939, the Exchange Contractors, which includes the Central California Irrigation District, the San Luis Canal Company, the Firebaugh Canal Water District and the Columbia Canal Company, agreed to accept water from the Delta-Mendota Canal (DMC) from the Bureau of Reclamation rather than get their water using their senior water rights on the San Joaquin and Kings rivers, hence the “exchange.”  When there is not enough water to meet the obligation from the DMC, then Reclamation must release water from Friant Dam to make up the difference.This is the first time in the Central Valley Project history since the Delta-Mendota Canal has been in use that Reclamation has needed to provide extra water from Millerton Lake.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), May 14, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Mendota, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA

Title: Reduced water allocations for the Klamath Project in southern Oregon, northern California
Description: The Bureau of Reclamation released the 2014 Drought Plan for the Klamath Project because available water supplies were inadequate to satisfy the demands of all Klamath Project contractors during the 2014 spring/summer irrigation season, which runs from March 1 to November 15.  Drought and insufficient participation in the Klamath Water and Power Agency’s Water Users Mitigation Program have brought about the need for Reclamation to formally allocate available water Project supply from Upper Klamath Lake and the Klamath River.  Warren Act Contractors will receive less than the full amount of water.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), May 15, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Klamath County, OR

Title: Water conservation in San Mateo County, California
Description: The North Coast County Water District (NCCWD) and Coastside County Water District (CCWD) in San Mateo County were urging customers to strive for greater water conservation as summer arrives and water consumption typically goes up.  The NCCWD was asking its customers to curb water use by 20 percent, while in mid-May, the CCWD urged a reduction in water use of 10 percent.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), June 24, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Mateo County, CA, El Granada, CA, Half Moon Bay, CA, Pacifica, CA

Title: San Diego County ablaze with nine wildfires
Description: The San Diego wildfires, fed by high temperatures and dry, gusty winds, caused more than $20 million in damage since they began on May 13.  The fires engulfed 39 square miles and destroyed 47 homes, an 18-unit apartment complex and three businesses.New York Times, May 18, 2014San Diego County was ablaze with nine wildfires that burned more than 14 square miles, driving thousands of people from their homes and closing a college campus and Legoland California.  Gusty winds and high temperatures hampered firefighters battling blazes in San Marcos, Carlsbad, Lakeside, Rancho Bernardo and near Camp Pendleton Marine base.  At least eight homes, two businesses and several other structures were destroyed in the fires.The fire chief of Carlsbad said, "This is May, this is unbelievable. This is something we should see in October.  I haven't seen it this hot, this dry, this long in May."Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 14, 2014
Places: San Diego County, CA

Title: Sacramento Municipal Utility District to purchase about $35 million worth of electricity
Description: Three years of drought have hydropower production in the Upper American River Project for the Sacramento Municipal Utility District.  The utility is short on hydropower and must purchase about $35 million worth of electricity.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 13, 2014
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: Two wind-driven brush fires force evacuations in Southern California
Description: Strong winds drove wildfires in San Diego and Santa Barbara counties and were fought aggressive by state and local firefighters.  The wildfires scorched hundreds of acres and caused many evacuations.The brush fire in northern San Diego County charred more than 800 acres, but was checked by Cal Fire and several local departments before too much damage was done.  Three hundred mandatory evacuation calls were made within the city limits, said the San Diego police chief, and the San Diego County sheriff reported that his department made 5,000 calls.  Residents in the Black Mountain Road, Rancho Bernardo, Rancho Penasquitos, Torrey Highlands, Santaluz, Fairbanks Ranch and Rancho Santa Fe areas. The Fairbanks Ranch Country Club was told to evacuate.The wind-driven brush fire in Santa Barbara County blackened 700 acres and forced the evacuation of 1,200 homes and businesses near Lompoc in the San Miguelito Canyon area.  Los Angeles Times, May 13, 2014
Places: San Diego County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA

Title: Fire in Texas Panhandle consumed 156 structures
Description: A fire in Hutchinson County, Texas burned 156 structures, including at least 89 homes, said a spokesman for the Texas A&M Forest Service.  Roughly 2,100 people were evacuated from their homes.  The blaze was 65 percent contained on the evening of May 12.  The region was in exceptional drought.ABC News (New York), May 12, 2014
Places: Hutchinson County, TX, Fritch, TX, Sanford, TX

Title: Santa Clara Valley Water District’s youth media contest
Description: Youths in Santa Clara County were invited to create a video or poster for entry in the Santa Clara Valley Water District’s youth media contest.  The submissions must feature water-saving tips to raise awareness of the present drought.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 7, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: California water agencies aim to move water against natural flow of California Aqueduct
Description: Five California water agencies concocted an innovative plan to move water north up the California Aqueduct to water parched crops, although water normally moves north to south in the aqueduct.  State officials are assessing the plan and will give their decision on the plan in June.If approved, water from underground reservoirs in Kern County and other water supplies would be pumped into the aqueduct to raise the water level.  Then diesel pumps would pump the water north over locks against the gravitational pull downhill.  The aim is to move 30,000 acre-feet of water 33 miles from Bakersfield to Kettleman City.Water agencies in the Bay Area are also eager to move water 70 miles against the normal flow of the aqueduct.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 6, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Additional funds for water conservation measures in Santa Clara Valley Water District in California
Description: The Santa Clara Valley Water District Board of Directors opted to continue the higher rebate amounts for water conservation programs until June 2015.  The public responded very positively to the rebate program and replaced roughly 410,000 square feet of turf from July through October 2014 with ongoing projects to replace another 1.4 million square-feet.  The rebate program also covers irrigation equipment, such as weather based irrigation controllers, rain sensors, high-efficiency nozzles, dedicated landscape meters and efficient sprinklers to curb water use.  To date, about 90,000 pieces of irrigation equipment were or are being replaced.The board also extended the request for 20 percent water conservation until June 2015.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Dec. 16, 2014The Santa Clara Valley Water District’s board of directors approved additional funds for water conservation programs as drought continued in the state.  The board authorized up to $1.25 million in additional funds to give customers bigger rebates for numerous conservation measures and to continue the district’s multi-media water conservation campaign.  The increased rebate amounts are intended to encourage residents and businesses to improve their water conservation habits and will remain in effect through September 2014.  Rebates for some programs have doubled, while other rebates have gone up significantly.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 6, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: At least a dozen private wells went dry in Tulare County, California
Description: More than a dozen private wells in Tulare County have gone dry as groundwater levels drop.  Tulare County officials were looking for ways to help the homeowners through federal or state funding because many of the homeowners cannot afford to have their wells drilled deeper, but the officials have not found any funding. Far more people than usual have called the U.S. Department of Agriculture Service Center about funding for private wells, said a rural development specialist.  She was trying to find a suitable funding category, but was not successful.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), May 5, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tulare County, CA

Title: Burn ban in the Bay Area of California
Description: The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection banned open burning in areas including San Benito County and parts of Alameda, Contra Costa, Santa Clara, San Mateo, Santa Cruz, Stanislaus, San Joaquin and Monterey counties effective May 1.  Drought conditions and an increase in fire activity led Cal Fire to enact the ban.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 2, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Monterey County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA

Title: 12 million trees killed by drought in Sierra Nevada, Southern California
Description: An April aerial survey performed by the U.S. forest Service found that roughly 12 million trees in California’s forestlands died within the last year due to extreme drought.  In Cleveland, San Bernardino, Angeles and Los Padres National Forests, an estimated 2 million dead trees were seen.  Across 4.1 million acres in the Southern Sierra Nevada, surveyors spotted approximately 10 million dead trees. KPBS-TV PBS San Diego, May 4, 2015
Places: Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Imperial County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mono County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Orange County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Kendall County, Texas, cracked, dry dirt, water restrictions
Description: Noticed soil shrinkage starting this spring, resulting in a long crack in backyard several feet long.  Two trees near a wet weather creek have died; estimated benefits per tree (according to http://www.treebenefits.com/) is $71.  Kendall West Utility is currently in Stage II restrictions, with sprinklers only allowed during certain hours 2x per week.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Boerne 2.2 WNW on 6/20/2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kendall County, TX

Title: Awaiting curtailment orders in California
Description: The California Water Resources Control Board posted data on its website estimating the date that curtailments may be requested in various watersheds, depending upon runoff conditions, water demand and the type of water rights.  Hundreds of water agencies, farmers and other property owners will soon have to stop diverting water from rivers in which they have long had water rights.  Specific curtailment orders are expected within days.Junior water rights holders will be affected first and must stop using water from the stream or river or curb the diversion.  Sufficient water must be left in streams and rivers to fulfill senior water rights holders’ needs and for the environment.  Curtailment orders are pending for junior water rights—issued after 1914—on nine rivers and their watersheds, including the Stanislaus, Tuolumne, Merced, Yuba, Kern, Kings, Kaweah, Tule and Middle Fork Eel.  Sacramento could be affected as soon as May 15 if curtailment orders come for the Sacramento, American, Russian River above Healdsburg and the Sacramento and San Joaquin river watersheds.The board expects that even senior water rights holders may be under curtailment orders by June to save water for essential health and safety purposes, and for wildlife and habitat.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 30, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Humboldt County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Santa Ana winds driving wildfire in parched San Bernardino County, California
Description: Santa Ana winds up to 80 miles per hour drove the Etiwanda Fire as it burned 1,000 acres on the edge of Rancho Cucamonga.  The fire began in the San Bernardino National Forest on the morning of April 30 and moved quickly, burning in conditions that the state does not usually experience until the end of August, said Daniel Berlant, a spokesman for the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.By late afternoon, evacuation orders had been issued to 1,650 homes.  Reuters (N.Y.), April 30, 2014
Places: San Bernardino County, CA, Rancho Cucamonga, CA

Title: Neighbor helps neighbor during California drought
Description: Mr. James Turner, a 91-year old man, in Madera County was troubled when a neighbor sank a well 500 feet to irrigate a new almond orchard.  His own well only reached 300 feet, so he knew he faced a limited water supply as his neighbor’s well drew off the water.  He was concerned not just for his own water supply, but for the damage that over pumping was doing to the land.Mr. Turner’s well stopped producing water in April 2014 as did another neighbor’s.  Water was trucked in to meet basic needs, but no water was spared for plants in his yard.  A well driller contacted about deepening the well in April was unable to get there to drill the well until December.  In the meantime, the neighbor with the deep well and the almond orchard noticed that plants in Mr. Turner’s yard were brown and learned that a dry well was the reason for the neglect.  The almond grower dutifully fills Mr. Turner’s water tank every few weeks.Los Angeles Times, Dec. 11, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Madera County, CA

Title: Many farmers in Southwest Texas opted to forgo planting grain sorghum and hay grazer because soil moisture was too low
Description: Many farmers in Southwest Texas opted to forgo planting grain sorghum and hay grazer because soil moisture was too low as hot, windy and dry conditions persisted.  Rangeland was very dry.  Livestock and wildlife still needed supplemental feeding.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014
Places: Bandera County, TX, Bastrop County, TX, Bexar County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Comal County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Gonzales County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Kerr County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Kinney County, TX, Medina County, TX, Real County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Uvalde County, TX, Wilson County, TX

Title: Farm workers in California's Central Valley struggling to find work
Description: Farm workers in the Central Valley were struggling to find work and pay their bills as the month of April passes, and farm work does not begin as usual.  By now, weeding and the laying of irrigation lines usually begins and farmers normally begin planting tomatoes and melons, but many fields lay fallow because there is not enough water to produce crops.  In March, the unemployment rate in Mendota was 37 percent, but the mayor fears that it may rise as high as 50 percent due to the lack of water and work for the farm hands.  The owner of Pappas Family Farms has cut back production because there is less water, meaning he’ll need fewer workers.  He intends to remove 30 percent of his almond trees.The chairman and chief executive officer of Harris Farms, a beef producer in Fresno County,  said less lettuce, broccoli and onions were planted this year for lack of water.  He may have to cut up to 70 percent of his workforce, or 1,100 positions, because he lacks the water to keep crops growing and workers employed.  Fewer customers were frequenting businesses in Mendota since they have precious little money to spend.  Business owners were hurting from the decline in revenue.  A bakery owner worried that she’ll have trouble helping her daughter pay for tuition.  A café owner had to let two of his five employees go and can no longer afford to put in a new air conditioning system.Some farm workers and their families were moving away in search of better employment opportunities.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), April 28, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Central Texas wheat not doing well; rangeland, pastures in worst condition since 2009
Description: Small grain fields were plowed under or harvested for forage in Central Texas because drought prevented them from producing harvestable grain.  Recent rains improved soil moisture, rangeland and some crops, but more was needed to fill stock ponds.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), June 10, 2014The best wheat fields in Central Texas were anticipated to yield 35 bushels per acre, but drought and freeze damage is expected to drop the yield some.  Rangeland has not been in such poor condition since 2009.  Clay soils were powder dry.Corn and sorghum need rain soon if they are to produce a crop.  Farmers were baling oats, wheat and rye grass for hay with the expectation that drought would persist through the summer.  Stock pond water was low.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014

Title: The shortage of hay in East Texas and persistent drought has kept hay prices steady
Description: The shortage of hay in East Texas and persistent drought has kept hay prices steady.  Low soil moisture was low in the region, due to dry, windy conditions.  North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014

Title: Pastures in the Coastal Bend of Texas were deteriorating from the lack of rain
Description: Coastal Bend pastures remained in good to poor condition, despite rain in recent weeks.  In Fayette County, rangeland was in poor to very poor condition, and topsoil moisture was low.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), June 10, 2014Pastures in the Coastal Bend of Texas were deteriorating from the lack of rain, and stock water tanks were going dry.  Producers were selling calves earlier than usual because pastures were in poor shape.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014

Title: Dry, windy, dusty conditions worrying farmers in the South Plains of Texas
Description: Wind, blowing dirt and the continued absence of rain in the South Plains of Texas worried crop producers.  Some farmers were planning to plant irrigated cotton in the next few weeks, but there would be no dryland cotton without substantial rain in the very near future.  A big dust storm blew out sunflowers in Hale County.Pastures in Swisher County were not producing enough vegetation to feed many cattle and were starting to show leaf curl and other signs of moisture stress.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health

Title: Persistent drought in Rolling Plains of Texas, forcing herd sellouts, water shortages, restrictions
Description: The sky in the Rolling Plains of Texas had a brown tint most of the week of April 28 through May 4 as strong winds blew the dry, dusty soil.  Farmers were cutting their small grains for hay.  Cotton growers were waiting for rain before planting.  In the southwestern part of the Rolling Plains, some ranchers were looking at the prospect of having to sell their entire herd.  Just as farmers and ranchers were struggling to cope with drought, municipal water users in towns were enduring water restrictions and shortages.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Wheeler County, TX

Title: The wells of roughly two dozen homeowners north of Lubbock, Texas run dry when cotton farmers irrigate their crops
Description: The wells of roughly two dozen homeowners north of Lubbock run dry when cotton farmers irrigate their crops.  This has been a recurring event during irrigation lasting for weeks or months since drought took hold in the region years ago.  Regional water supplies in general were low, but years of drought have drawn down groundwater levels to the point that shallow wells produce little to nothing when deep wells are in use.Another resident who still has water, worries that he too may be out of water soon because his neighbor irrigates so much.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 27, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Lubbock County, TX

Title: Fire restrictions on U.S. Bureau of Land Management land in western Arizona, southeastern California
Description: Fire restrictions were lifted on Aug. 22 for public lands in the Yuma area administered by the Bureau of Land Management, due to recent rainfall.  Yuma Sun.com (Yuma Daily Sun) (Ariz.), Aug. 21, 2014Fire restrictions took effect on 5.4 million acres of land in western Arizona and southeastern California along the Colorado River on April 25.   the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) Colorado River District  enacted the fire restrictions to protect public and natural resources. “Due to the drought conditions throughout the state, we have very dry vegetation in the area that will become fuel for wildfires as temperatures continue to rise and humidity falls,” said Fire Management Officer Michael Trent. “The restrictions will continue until conditions warrant the lifting of the restrictions.”It is forbidden to build, maintain, attend or use a fire, campfire, charcoal, coal, or wood stove.  Campfires and charcoal are permitted in developed recreation sites or improved sites where agency-built fire rings or grills are provided. Smoking may only be done in an enclosed vehicle or building.  Fireworks, welding and such activities that create sparks or have an open flame were prohibited.Yuma Sun.com (Yuma Daily Sun) (Ariz.), April 22, 2014
Places: La Paz County, AZ, Mohave County, AZ, Yuma County, AZ, Imperial County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Increased river flows near Sacramento, California to aid fish, delta water standards, downstream water supplies
Description: The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation began releasing even more water from Nimbus Dam to push salty water from the San Francisco Bay out of the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta since it provides water to 23 million Californians and 3 million acres of cultivated land.  The flow was increased from 2,000 cubic feet per second to 2,500 cfs.  Unusually high tides in the forecast will increase the likelihood of salinity intrusion.Keeping water with high salinity out of the Delta is urgent because it takes weeks to months to flush the salt out and return the salinity to acceptable levels.  State law also requires that salinity be controlled for the benefit of water users to take water straight from the Delta.The California Department of Water Resources began releasing more water from Oroville Reservoir on the Feather River late in the week of June 9 to lower the salinity.  The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation increased releases from Keswick Reservoir on the Sacramento River also to bring the Delta salinity down.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 18, 2014The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation is boosting flows from the Folsom and Nimbus dams on the American River to help salmon and steelhead make their way down the river.  At 9 p.m. on April 23, the flow will begin to increase from its present rate of 500 cubic feet per second to 1,500 cfs by 11 p.m. and will continue at that rate through early on the morning of April 25, when the flow will be reduced to 800 cfs.  The flow will remain at 800 cfs until further notice to provide water for various demands, such as maintaining adequate river temperature, Delta water quality standards and downstream water supplies.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 22, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Parks and Recreation cut its water use in parks in Kern County, California
Description: Kern County Parks and Recreation cut its water use in county parks by 20 percent about three months ago, due to drought, said the director of parks and recreation.  Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), July 23, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: East Bay Municipal Utility District diverting water from Sacramento River in California
Description: Water from the Sacramento River began pouring into San Pablo Reservoir on May 1.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), April 30, 2014The East Bay Municipal Utility District’s board of directors all voted in favor of diverting water from the Freeport Regional Water Project on the Sacramento River for its customers in Alameda and Contra Costa counties.  EBMUD usually gets most of its water from its own reservoir and pipeline system on the Mokelumne River, but snowmelt in the river’s watershed was predicted to fall below 500,000 acre-feet, at which point EBMUD may use the separate diversion pumps at Freeport.  EBMUD intends to withdraw 16,000 acre-feet in May and June at a cost of about $8 million.  The district has an annual diversion limit of 133,000 acre-feet or 165,000 acre-feet in a three year period.  Sacramento County has also been using some of its diversion capacity at Freeport to meet its water demand.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 22, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: Dry wells causing hardships in California's San Joaquin Valley
Description: A man on a fixed income lost his water supply in April 2014, but had it restored through the help of a neighbor, federal funding and assistance from Visalia-based nonprofit, Self-Help Enterprises.  Hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of people in the San Joaquin Valley have dry wells as farmers adjusted to the lack of irrigation water by pumping well water, causing the water table to drop dramatically.  The situation may very well be much worse this coming summer.  Many people with dry wells turn to large water tanks using small pump motors to send water into their homes.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), March 9, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: More dead and dying bats than usual are being found in Northern California
Description: More dead and dying bats than usual are being found in Northern California.  Bats feed on aquatic insects and insects that spend a portion of their lives in water, stated the founder of Northern California Bats.  Drought may have reduced the insect population to the extent that bats cannot find enough insects to eat because fewer agricultural fields were irrigated or flooded, providing a water source for the insects. One News Page (Los Angeles, Calif.), April 17, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Butte County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Del Norte County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Inyo County, CA, Kings County, CA, Lake County, CA, Lassen County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Merced County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Mono County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Drought exposed truck in Lake Granbury in Hood County, Texas, explaining disappearance of woman nearly 35 years ago
Description: The drought-depleted level of Lake Granbury exposed a pickup truck containing the skeletal remains of a woman last seen nearly 35 years ago when she vanished after an argument with her husband, who has also since died.The pickup was located about 15 feet from the normal shoreline and would have been in 15 to 16 feet of murky water if the lake were full.  The location of the truck was not near a roadway, suggesting to law enforcement that foul play was involved and that this was not the result of an accident.  The Hood County sheriff said that the investigation into the woman’s death will continue.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 19, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Hood County, TX

Title: Insects thriving during drought in Wichita Falls, Texas
Description: Ticks were more of a problem than usual in Wichita Falls because drought offers ideal conditions for ticks’ eggs to hatch.  Other insects, such as roaches, ants, fleas and mosquitoes, also seem to be thriving during drought.Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), April 17, 2014
Places: Wichita County, TX, Wichita Falls, TX

Title: California produce shortage felt at foodbanks, relief on the way
Description: The California Department of Social Services announced that shipments of food assistance will be provided to Amador, Butte, Colusa, Fresno, Glenn, Kern, Kings, Lake, Lassen, Madera, Merced, Modoc, Monterey, San Benito, San Joaquin, Santa Cruz, Sierra, Siskiyou, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tehama, Tulare, Yolo and Yuba counties because these counties have high unemployment rates and a high proportion of agricultural workers.  The first shipment of five $5 million installments of aid will provide prepackaged boxes of nutritionally balanced, nonperishable food in early May.  KION-TV CBS 46 (Salinas, Calif.), April 22, 2014Foodbanks in California were feeling the pinch of drought, due to less produce being grown in the state and fewer produce donations coming their way.   Foodbanks must vie against others in the food industry for basic items like onions, potatoes, carrots and corn.The Foodbank of Santa Barbara said they were getting more requests for produce from local groups serving children and needed cash donations to be able to help those in need.KEYT-TV ABC 3 Santa Barbara (Calif.), April 16, 2014

Title: More water conservation for Korbel Champagne Cellars in Sonoma County, California
Description: Korbel Champagne Cellars chose to strive for greater water conservation by replacing some annuals with perennials, adding more compost to some beds, planting more drought-tolerant species and cutting back on “color” plantings.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), April 15, 2014
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Consumption advisory for Lubbock, Texas
Description: A consumption advisory was issued for Lubbock because one of its water sources, Lake Alan Henry in Garza County, held less than 65 percent of capacity.  The lake was created 20 years ago at an expense of $245 million.  The lake lost about 4 billion gallons to evaporation in 2011, according to the Lubbock Avalanche-Journal.My San Antonio.com (Texas), April 15, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Garza County, TX, Lubbock, TX

Title: Farmer in Madera County, California protects his investment by buying drilling rig
Description: A farmer near Chowchilla in the Central Valley purchased a drilling rig at a cost of $1 million to make sure he has water this summer.  "It's like an insurance policy," said the farmer. "You have to do something to protect your investment."At least two other farmers have done the same.  A licensed driller urged the farmer to buy the drilling rig.  The farmer put down a $150,000 deposit and will pay the remaining $850,000 when the rig arrives.  The farmer will use the rig as he needs to drill wells, and the licensed driller will use it on neighboring farms to cover some of the money spent on the drilling rig.Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 13, 2014
Places: Madera County, CA

Title: California well drillers very busy
Description: A well driller based in Lancaster said that his mid-sized business with three rigs has jobs booked out for 15 months.  His crew dug a 1,840 foot well near Bakersfield recently.  Three upcoming wells will reach depths of roughly 2,000 feet.  Farmers are desperate for water because they know none is coming from state or federal suppliers.  Buying water on the market costs three to four times what it used to cost.Another well driller based in Gilroy and president of the California Groundwater Association said that he thinks farmers were talking to several drillers to see who could do the job the soonest.His crews work 24 hours days for weeks, and he appreciates the business, especially because jobs were scarce about two years ago.  Workers willing to work such long hours are hard to find, says the driller.  He fears that the excessive drilling in the Central Valley could lead to a shortage of steel casings, prompting him to order such supplies by the truckload.Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 13, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Lancaster, CA, Madera County, CA, Gilroy, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Ranchers in the Rolling Plains of Texas tried to protect pastures  by rotating cattle to avoid overgrazing
Description: Ranchers in the Rolling Plains of Texas tried to protect pastures  by rotating cattle to avoid overgrazing, but it did not help much.  While farmers had prepared fields for spring planting, high winds led to blowouts and the need to go over the plowed ground again.  Several counties had burn bans.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 13, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions
Places: Archer County, TX, Baylor County, TX, Childress County, TX, Clay County, TX, Cottle County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Foard County, TX, Hardeman County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Jack County, TX, Kent County, TX, King County, TX, Knox County, TX, Montague County, TX, Motley County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Parker County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Stonewall County, TX, Throckmorton County, TX, Wichita County, TX, Wilbarger County, TX, Wise County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Stage 4 pumping restrictions for groundwater permit holders in the San Antonio Pool of the Edwards Aquifer Authority in Texas
Description: The Edwards Aquifer Authority entered stage IV restrictions, an unprecedented move requiring a 40 percent reduction in pumping from the aquifer.  The increase in restrictions was triggered by the 10-day well average falling below 630 feet above sea level.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Aug. 12, 2014The J-17 monitoring well in Bexar County fell to 629.6 feet above sea level on Aug. 6.  If the well remains at or below 630 feet above sea level, it will trigger stage IV restrictions in the Edwards Aquifer Authority’s critical period plan, requiring a 40 percent reduction in pumping.  The Edwards Aquifer was 13.4 feet lower than one year ago and fell nearly 10 feet in the last two weeks.  At Comal Springs, the water flowed at 101 cubic feet per second on Aug. 6 and may lead to stage IV restrictions if the flow drops below 100 cubic feet per second.My San Antonio.com (Texas), Aug. 6, 2014The Edwards Aquifer Authority (EAA) declared Stage 3 pumping reductions for users within the San Antonio Pool. Stage 3 of the EAA’s drought plan requires Edwards groundwater permit holders in Bexar and Medina counties, and parts of Atascosa, Caldwell, Comal, Guadalupe and Hays counties to reduce their annual authorized pumping by 35 percent. The EAA declared Stage 3 based on declining water level readings at the J17 index well in Bexar County. On April 10, the 10-day average dropped below the Stage 3 trigger of 640 feet above sea level. Stage 3 will remain in effect as long as the water level of the monitoring well stays below this threshold. The San Antonio Pool was previously in Stage 3 from December 16, 2013 – January 3 of this year. Edwards Aquifer Authority (San Antonio, Texas), April 10, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Atascosa County, TX, Bexar County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Comal County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hays County, TX, Medina County, TX

Title: No showers at Lake Isabella in Kern County, California
Description: Showers were not available at any camps around Lake Isabella, due to water conservation measures.  Lake Isabella was at 2,535 feet in elevation and 10 percent of capacity.Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 9, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: Farmers in the Klamath Reclamation Project in southern Oregon, northern California to be short of water
Description: An operations plan released by the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation stated that there was only 61 percent of the water needed for full irrigation for the 1,200 farms in the Klamath Reclamation Project.  This will be the third consecutive year that Klamath farmers will receive less than their contracted amounts.  The executive director of the Klamath Water Users Association said that it will be difficult to meet water demand this year, even after contracts paying farmers not to plant and groundwater pumping.  Wildlife refuges for waterfowl on the Pacific Flyway, too, will be short of water this year.Snowpack was 31 percent of normal, while precipitation was 75 percent of normal, according to the bureau.  Everett Herald (Wash.), April 9, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Klamath County, OR

Title: Val Verde County, Texas, livestock requires extra feed and water
Description: Extreme drought, no grasses, sparse vegetation, much less than normal. Requires extra feed and water for stock and wildlife.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Comstock 29.7 NW on 5/7/2014
Places: Val Verde County, TX

Title: Farm family in Matagorda County, Texas growing corn instead of rice
Description: A Matagorda County farm family that usually grows rice has switched to 700 acres of corn this year because the Lower Colorado River Authority was not providing water for rice growers for the third consecutive year.  Corn provides about half  as much income per acre as rice does, but the family needs to grow some crop to have an income.  The family has returned two of three combine harvesters that they leased from a dealership.  Three combines were needed in 2011 to harvest the rice crop, but the lack of irrigation water since 2012 means that one combine can easily harvest any small amount of rice they might be able to grow.  The patriarch of the family lays awake at night, worrying about the future of the farm, his sons and grandsons because there isn’t as much money in corn as there is in rice.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), April 6, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Matagorda County, TX

Title: Hay suppliers in Central Texas have no hay to sell
Description: The Feed Station, a livestock supply store just west of Oak Hill, began carrying pelletized packaged hay because the hay suppliers in Central Texas have no hay to sell, due to the drought.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 6, 2014
Places: Bandera County, TX, Bastrop County, TX, Bell County, TX, Bexar County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Bosque County, TX, Brazos County, TX, Burleson County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Comal County, TX, Comanche County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Falls County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Gonzales County, TX, Grimes County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hamilton County, TX, Hays County, TX, Hill County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Kerr County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Lee County, TX, Leon County, TX, Limestone County, TX, Llano County, TX, Madison County, TX, Mason County, TX, McLennan County, TX, Milam County, TX, Mills County, TX, Robertson County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Travis County, TX, Oak Hill, TX, Washington County, TX, Williamson County, TX, Wilson County, TX

Title: High hay prices in Burnet County, Texas
Description: Grasses were dead in Burnet County after a dry, cold winter.  Hay prices have risen from $85 per bale to $100, said an agriculture and natural resources extension agent for Burnet County.  Horse-quality hay rose from $100 in 2011 to $145 at present.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 6, 2014
Places: Burnet County, TX

Title: San Joaquin River Restoration Program still underway, despite drought
Description: The San Joaquin River Restoration Program, a project designed to restore a 60-mile length of the river and revive  the salmon population, continues despite the drought.  Federal biologists have gained valuable information about spawning conditions in an area where no salmon have lived for nearly 60 years.  If the program ended immediately, the biologists say that hundreds of young fish would die.  The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation has not released water for river restoration in more than one year, due to drought.  In spite of the smaller flows, the young salmon have survived on water intended for farmers, including an unusually large release in 2014 from a reservoir north of Fresno to provide water for growers deprived of usual allocations from the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta.Given the severity of the drought, farmers would like the project to be reevaluated in the context of other priorities.  The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 27, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Madera County, CA

Title: Tuolomne County, California, water restrictions, can't water lawns, trees dying
Description: County wide utility district announced major cut backs of 40%.   Residents can't water lawns this summer.  Increased tree mortality in Stanislaus National Forest.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Tuolumne City 2.0 N on 5/7/2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Mosquito season early in Napa County, California
Description: Drought was partially responsible for the early arrival of mosquito season and abundance of mosquitoes in Napa County.  Warm weather and pools of stagnant water—present after March’s rains—are key ingredients for mosquito breeding, which led more residents than usual to call Napa County’s Mosquito Abatement District about the pests.Napa Valley Register (Calif.), April 22, 2014
Places: Napa County, CA

Title: Farmers' water connections sealed in Terra Bella Irrigation District in Tulare County, California
Description: The Terra Bella Irrigation District (TBIG) notified its 600 farmers that they will receive no irrigation water this year for the first time in the district’s history because the district will not likely get any water from the federally-operated Friant-Kern canal.  The main crops in this area are citrus and pistachio trees—crops that cannot be left unwatered without substantial loss.  Water meters were sealed by the TBIG last month and tagged with a notice that says, “No irrigation water is available this year. Illegal use of irrigation water is subject to penalties. Your meter has been sealed.”  Those who cut the seal will be fined $10,000, but the irrigation district manager expects the fine will not deter some farmers.  “I’ve heard rumors that it may be worth paying the penalties to keep your trees alive, so we’ll see how it works,” said the district manager.  The district provides water to a $100 million citrus crop, and farmers, desperate to get water, have brought checks totaling $4 million to the district office to purchase water on their behalf.  The manager has not been able to find any water to purchase so far.The town of Terra Bella expects to receive half of the usual water supply from the Friant-Kern canal.  KQED Public Media (San Francisco, Calif.), April 8, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tulare County, CA, Terra Bella, CA

Title: Water shortage in the North Coast of California exacerbated by marijuana growers
Description: Rivers in the North Coast of California are being tapped by marijuana growers who need excessive amounts of water to irrigate their crop, exacerbating a water shortage brought on by drought.  California is the most popular state in the nation to grow pot in U.S. forests, and pot plants consume up to 6 gallons of water daily.Rep. Mike Thompson, a California Democrat and 13 other members of the U.S. House of Representatives from California would like to give the Drug Enforcement Administration $3 million to eradicate large pot operations in public forests, partly because drought makes every drop of water precious and also to simply put an end to the illegal operations.  The marijuana growers often steal water to irrigate their crop.Boise Idaho Statesman (Idaho), March 27, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Del Norte County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Trinity County, CA

Title: Ongoing drought brought about the proliferation of tumbleweeds in southeastern Colorado, parts of New Mexico and the Texas panhandle
Description: Ongoing drought brought about the proliferation of tumbleweeds in southeastern Colorado, parts of New Mexico and the Texas panhandle.  Rainfall in September 2013 spurred the growth of the Russian thistles, which grew well with little moisture in places where much of the native vegetation was sparse or had died from the drought.  There were also fewer cattle in many areas as drought led ranchers to sell livestock, leaving fewer ruminants to nibble on the Russian thistle shoots.  The tumbleweeds are abundant in many areas, blocking roads and drainage culverts and piling up against fences and homes.In Fountain, Colorado, just southeast of Colorado Springs, a windstorm blew an incredible number of tumbleweeds into town, building mounds more than 10 feet high that residents strove to rake together and bag to get rid of them.An older couple in Clovis, New Mexico was trapped in their home in January when it became engulfed in tumbleweeds.  "I looked out the window to see why it got so dark all of a sudden, and they were over 12-feet high, blocking my front and back doors," the man said. "We couldn't get out."A neighbor managed to dig through and get into the garage to free the couple.Tumbleweeds have been an ongoing problem in Crowley County, New Mexico where they continue to make travel on some roads very difficult.Baltimore Sun (Md.), March 27, 2014
Places: Alamosa County, CO, Baca County, CO, Bent County, CO, Cheyenne County, CO, Costilla County, CO, Crowley County, CO, Custer County, CO, El Paso County, CO, Elbert County, CO, Fremont County, CO, Huerfano County, CO, Kiowa County, CO, Kit Carson County, CO, Las Animas County, CO, Lincoln County, CO, Otero County, CO, Prowers County, CO, Pueblo County, CO, New Mexico, Clovis, NM, Armstrong County, TX, Bailey County, TX, Borden County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Castro County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Wheeler County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: Dryland wheat in West Central Texas was deteriorating; rangeland in bad shape
Description: The dry, windy and warm conditions continued in West Central Texas, elevating the fire danger as temperatures rose into the triple digits.  Wheat remained in very poor condition, with most of it being grazed.  A small portion of the wheat crop was to be harvested, but yields will likely be very low.  Low subsoil moisture will probably delay cotton planting in coming weeks.  The drought kept farmers from planting summer annuals because seed was too expensive to gamble that rain will fall to water the crop.  Ranchers continued to feed their livestock as some rangeland and pasture manifesting signs of moisture stress.  Water supplies were on the decline.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014The growth and development of all small grains in West Central Texas was limited by warm, dry and windy conditions, and some fields were already a total loss.  Other wheat fields were very short with spotty stands and were in poor to fair condition.  Stock tank levels continued to decline and were presently a problem for some farmers.  Heavy supplemental feeding continued for all livestock.The fire danger increased with the dry, windy conditions.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 13, 2014Dryland wheat in West Central Texas was deteriorating and manifested signs of drought stress.  Rangeland and pastures were in poor condition and were also deteriorating.  Soil moisture was very low, and extreme fire danger was increasing.  Drovers Cattle Network (Lenexa, Kan.), March 26, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coke County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Concho County, TX, Fisher County, TX, Irion County, TX, Jones County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Runnels County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Shackelford County, TX, Sterling County, TX, Taylor County, TX, Tom Green County, TX

Title: Dry winter killed much vegetation in pastures in Central Texas
Description: The dry winter killed much vegetation in pastures in Central Texas.  Producers continued culling cattle, due to ongoing drought.  Poor moisture reserves did not encourage good corn germination, leaving spotty stands. Drovers Cattle Network (Lenexa, Kan.), March 26, 2014
Places: Bell County, TX, Bosque County, TX, Comanche County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Eastland County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Erath County, TX, Falls County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Hamilton County, TX, Hill County, TX, Hood County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Leon County, TX, Limestone County, TX, McLennan County, TX, Milam County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Robertson County, TX, Somervell County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Stock water tanks were low in South Texas as dry conditions persist, pastures deteriorating
Description: Drought caused South Texas pastures to deteriorate, and soil moisture was short to very short throughout the region.  The fire threat remained high with all of the dry vegetation.Atascosa County ranchers bought hay for supplemental feeding, and McMullen County ranchers also continued supplemental feeding.  In Webb County, ranchers were holding off on restocking cattle and livestock until the rangeland recovers.  Stock tank water levels were low.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014Stock water tanks were low in South Texas as dry conditions persist.  Soil moisture was short to very short in the northern portion of South Texas.  Rangeland and pastures were in fair condition as spring greening begins.  Cattle body condition scores in some places were slipping.   Forage production in Jim Wells County was better than it had been, but more rain and warm temperatures were needed to boost forage growth.  The wheat yield in the county was in question due to a lack of rain early in its growing period.Forage in Webb County has not recovered from previous drought, prompting producers to sell some cattle until the forage is healthier.Drovers Cattle Network (Lenexa, Kan.), March 26, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Atascosa County, TX, Brooks County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Dimmit County, TX, Duval County, TX, Frio County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Jim Hogg County, TX, Jim Wells County, TX, Kenedy County, TX, Kleberg County, TX, La Salle County, TX, Live Oak County, TX, Maverick County, TX, McMullen County, TX, Starr County, TX, Webb County, TX, Willacy County, TX, Zapata County, TX, Zavala County, TX

Title: Fields in the Rolling Plains of Texas were so dry that they were difficult to till
Description: Fields in the Rolling Plains of Texas were so dry that they were difficult to till.  Pastures were in need of moisture to promote summer grass growth and grazing for livestock.  Stock water tanks were low or dry, and lakes and ponds also need rainfall.  Several counties in the Rolling Plains had burn bans in effect.Drovers Cattle Network (Lenexa, Kan.), March 26, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Dry conditions hurt the condition of winter wheat in Ochiltree County, Texas
Description: Dry conditions hurt the condition of winter wheat in Ochiltree County, Texas.Drovers Cattle Network (Lenexa, Kan.), March 26, 2014

Title: Winter wheat in the South Plains of Texas was hampered by drought
Description: Winter wheat in the South Plains of Texas was stifled by drought.  Livestock needed to be fed weekly because pastures did not provide enough for cattle.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 13, 2014.Winter wheat in the South Plains of Texas was hampered by drought, and some plant diseases were present.  Numerous people held the same sentiment that current conditions were reminiscent of the Dust Bowl days.Drovers Cattle Network (Lenexa, Kan.), March 26, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health
