Title: Low soil moisture hindered Texas Panhandle farmers who were preparing their fields, some fields a total loss
Description: Cattle on the range in the Texas Panhandle needed supplemental feed because there was not enough vegetation growing to sustain the cattle.  Ranchers sold cattle if they did not have wheat for the cattle to graze.  Soil moisture was short to very short.  Winter wheat was in fair to very poor condition.  Some Ochiltree County farmers have crop insurance adjusters to assess their fields.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014Windblown soil erosion was a problem throughout the Texas Panhandle where drought conditions were worse than in other parts of the state.  Dryland wheat growers in Wheeler County have brought in crop insurance adjusters to witness the devastation caused by drought, said the AgriLife Extension agent for the county.  Even irrigated wheat manifested signs of drought damage.Wildfires charred roughly 10,000 acres in Lipscomb County over the past three weeks, according to the AgriLife Extension agent in the county.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 13, 2014.Low soil moisture hindered Texas Panhandle farmers who were preparing their fields for the upcoming growing season.  High winds further depleted soil moisture.  Drovers Cattle Network (Lenexa, Kan.), March 26, 2014
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Wheeler County, TX

Title: Supply of untreated water cut off for certain property owners in Santa Clara County, California
Description: Ninety-nine property owners in Santa Clara County received letters from the Santa Clara Valley Water District notifying them that those who get untreated water from creeks and pipelines will be cut off entirely from those sources on May 1.  The 99 property owners include 32 farmers, seven golf courses, some homeowners and others, who collectively use 3,477 acre-feet or about 1 percent of the total water use.  Some farmers are particularly frustrated with the notice and feel that they must bear an undue burden.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 25, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: Thirty million young Chinook salmon catching a ride to the ocean in California
Description: Thirty million young Chinook salmon were being trucked from a federal fish hatchery in Anderson to San Pablo Bay, 180 miles to the south to be released because drought has left the water in the Sacramento River and its tributaries too warm and shallow for the fish to make the trip on their own.  Four to seven trucks will transport the fish to the ocean on 22 days during the next two and a half months until 12 million juvenile fish from the federal hatchery and 18 million from four state hatcheries are in the ocean.  The state usually hauls some of its fish to the ocean, but this year the tab will be about three times higher than usual.  Expenses are expected to reach about $150,000 for truck rental and fuel.Bloomberg.com (New York, N.Y.), March 25, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Record coho salmon migration in Marin County, California
Description: Despite the drought, nearly 20,000 coho salmon migrated out of Lagunitas Creek to the ocean in Marin County.  This was the largest salmon migration recorded in Lagunitas Creek since scientists began estimating fish numbers in 2006.  The previous record was 11,000 coho in 2012.The number of fish was surprising because the lower water levels cut into the number of fish able to reproduce by laying eggs in creeks and tributaries along the Central California coast.The juveniles would normally swim into the lower reaches of the Lagunitas Creek in late fall and winter, but were prevented from doing so by drought and low water flows.  The lower part of Lagunitas Creek can support around 7,000 to 11,000 coho, so the fish that remained upstream and the fish present in the lower stretches of Lagunitas Creek resulted in an overall larger coho population.Fisheries biologists counted just 206 salmon egg clusters, or redds, in the Lagunitas watershed this year, in comparison with the 20-year average of 250 redds.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), June 24, 2014
Places: Marin County, CA

Title: Customers of California American Water in Placer and Sacramento counties were urged to voluntarily curb their water use by 20 percent
Description: Customers of California American Water in Placer and Sacramento counties were urged to voluntarily curb their water use by 20 percent.  The voluntary program was issued in accordance with the Governor’s emergency drought declaration and California Public Utilities Commission’s Rule 14.1, which urges residents to limit non-essential uses of water.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 24, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: Planted crop acreage remained lower than usual in south Texas
Description: Planted crop acreage remained lower than usual in south Texas as the area struggles with drought and Mexico’s failure to comply with the 1944 water treaty, under which it owes the U.S. 860,000 acre-feet which it must deliver by October 2015.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), March 24, 2014
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Seasonal firefighters for Mendocino National Forest in California trained early
Description: About 150 seasonal firefighters for the Mendocino National Forest trained for the upcoming fire season about two months early as dry conditions drove the need for early preparation.  The yearly training usually happens in early May.  Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), March 23, 2014
Places: Mendocino County, CA

Title: Drought and climate change threaten the existence of the federally endangered Amargosa vole east of Death Valley National Park in California
Description: Drought and climate change are threatening the existence of the federally endangered Amargosa vole, which lives in wetlands east of Death Valley National Park.  There are thought to be just 200 such voles.Los Angeles Times, March 23, 2014
Places: Inyo County, CA

Title: Eighty-seven percent of dryland wheat crop in the High Plains and Rolling Plains of Texas rated in fair to very poor conditions
Description: Eighty-seven percent of the dryland wheat crop in the High Plains and Rolling Plains of Texas was rated in fair to very poor conditions as dry weather takes a toll on the crop, according to Dr. Travis Miller, an AgriLife Extension agronomist and Texas A&M University soil and crop sciences associate department head.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), March 23, 2014

Title: Water releases reduced from Anderson Dam in Santa Clara County, California
Description: The Santa Clara Valley Water District reduced water releases from Anderson Dam from 14 cubic feet per second to just 9 cfs, due to drought, according to the district spokesman.  With less water, Coyote Creek has nearly dried up, leaving fish to die in muddy pools. San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 23, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: The Santa Clara Valley Water District in California informed seven cities and companies that they would receive just 80 percent of their requested treated drinking water through the end of the year
Description: The Santa Clara Valley Water District informed seven cities and companies that they would receive just 80 percent of their requested treated drinking water through the end of the year.  Roughly 1.5 million people in San Jose, Mountain View, Sunnyvale, Cupertino, Milpitas and Santa Clara will be affected by the 20 percent cuts.  These communities may resort to groundwater pumping, urging residents to conserve and using other water supplies to compensate for getting less water from the SCVWD.A spokesman for the San Jose Water Company responded by stating that they will pump more groundwater from the 100 or so wells throughout the county and will strongly urge water conservation.  The SJWC has devised new rules for outdoor watering and days on which people may water, but at present were not fining violators of those rules.Only about 25,000 acre-feet of water will be put back into Santa Clara County’s underground aquifers this year, a reduction of 75 percent as the area endures drought.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 25, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA, Cupertino, CA, Milpitas, CA, Mountain View, CA, San Jose, CA, Santa Clara, CA, Sunnyvale, CA

Title: Water prices rising in Fresno County, California
Description: Water prices were skyrocketing by the week as one Fresno County grower discovered after selling extra water for $1,500 an acre-foot about a month ago.  Very recently someone offered him $2,500 per acre-foot.  The arrival of investors, who grow crops requiring more water, were driving up water prices as supply decreases, which is threatening the survival of long term resident farmers growing traditional crops.  The resident farmers cannot afford high priced water.The New York Times, April 20, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Landowners in the Imperial Irrigation District in southern California being paid to fallow land
Description: Landowners in the Imperial Irrigation District were being paid to fallow land as the district cedes more water to urban areas in San Diego County and the Coachella Valley.  Drought and the 2003 Quantification Settlement Agreement, which changes the way the Colorado River is divvied up, led the district to find ways to free up water for urban use.  While landowners receive up to $750 per acre to fallow land and tenant farmers who rent the land often pay an average of $300 per acre to rent, landowners find it more lucrative to fallow the land, leaving tenant farmers without an income.  Also, as the land is fallowed, other jobs are lost, creating an economic ripple through the community.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), March 17, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, San Diego County, CA

Title: The San Francisco Public Utilities Commission is preparing to use water from Lake Eleanor and Cherry Reservoir
Description: The San Francisco Public Utilities Commission is preparing to use water from Lake Eleanor and Cherry Reservoir, which have been used for hydropower and to deliver water to several districts.  To prepare those water bodies to provide drinking water to San Francisco, the SFPUC must shore up a dam damaged by the Rim Fire in 2013 and repair an aqueduct not used in more than 20 years.  The PUC aims to have the new system in operation by Oct. 1.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 16, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Francisco County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Ventura County, California, poor drinking water quality, water restrictions
Description: The last six months have brought only 1.13" of rain to my area.  This area is the Boy Scout Camp Road area of Lockwood Valley in North-East Ventura County. The impact is tremendous to my property and to the wildlife.  Several varieties of wildflowers never germinated this year, or if they did, there were no blooms: penstemons (wild snapdragons), lupins, clover, goldenrod, rattlesnake weed, bladder pods, cat tails, and domestic daffodils and tulips and iris didn't sprout or bloom.  The canyon/scrub oaks produced no acorns this year, the manzanita produced no nuts.  Oddly, the pinion pines produced a very small amount of viable nuts.  I now believe that the pinions are on a two to four year cycle of nut production, and it's the quantity of nuts produced that is dependent on precipitation.  More small gray fox (kit fox?) were killed on roads last fall, than I have ever seen in the past 14 years living in this area.  Rabbit numbers have reduced tremendously, and even the coyotes are hunting in other areas, since we hear their howls rarely now.  Scrub jays and stellar jays rarely visit my property now.  My property is along the northern edge of the Day Fire's devastation, and there is still very little vegetation found in the burned out areas, despite the fact that it has been eight years since the Day Fire.  Tiny pine trees and seedlings have all perished.  There are no more one to three year old pine trees on my property.  The vegetation is so sparse that very little of my property has ground cover now.  I used to have at least some grasses (dead or alive) that provided erosion control on the exposed areas.  Now, I fear that heavy rainfall will erode most of my exposed topsoil.  Since there has been almost no regeneration of the forest destroyed by the Day Fire, it's clear that this danger exists for most of the forest land between Piru and Lockwood Valley.  About 1/3 to 1/2 of the trees killed by the day fires, but those left standing remain standing.  The fallen trees roots are termite ridden.  That seems to be the only insect thriving, other than bark beetles.  There were very very few wasps, gnats, dragonflies, butterflies, flies, june bugs and similar beetles, but no difference in scorpions, and similar desert insects.  This summer, the cicadas emerged and their chirps were deafening in the forest, but this only lasted a few weeks, then it was silent again.  There was an extreme number of bark beetles on my property last fall and this spring, and I worry that my pinions will be successfully attacked by their swarms.  In some areas of Lockwood Valley, near the TXI Plant, and along Cuddy Valley and Frazier Park's south facing mountain sides, very large sections of pinions have died.  In LV, as much as 1/3 to 1/2 of these forest areas are now dead.  This will be devastating to the wildlife and will enhance erosion in these areas in future years.  Many of the poplars planted by residents have died, seemingly by drought and insects.  They are not drought resistant.  Jeffery pines (lodgepole?) appear to be as vulnerable as the pinions.  Even the manzanita are dying, as well as a small number of juniper.  To put it bluntly, things are looking grim.  This area is transforming into a desert region, it seems.  I don't know the amount the local well water has dropped, but will find out and enter that info as well.  Extreme water conservation measures are being used.  The water on my property is unsuitable for irrigation, or drinking.  I must haul in drinking water, and I don't irrigate.  I rely on local plants for landscaping, and precipitation for irrigation.  Sadly, most perennial wild flowering plants have completely died.  The flowering plants that remain are navarretia (an annual), scarlet bugles, and two different species of sage.   That's all that remains on my property.  I hope that I will still have viable seeds of the now gone plants to germinate once good precipitation returns.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Frazier Park 10.7 WSW on 9/14/2014
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Ventura County, CA

Title: Uncertain water supply delaying camping reservations at Camp Mather in Tuolumne County, California
Description: A comprehensive assessment of the Camp Mather water system revealed water supplies were safe and reliable.  Potential visitors will soon be notified of summer cabin assignments.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 28, 2014.San Francisco’s parks officials have put the reservation process on hold for Camp Mather in the Sierra because it is not clear that there will be enough water for campers this summer.  Camp Mather’s water source is a creek about 2.6 miles from the camp, but water flow is below normal, due to drought.  In addition, last year’s Rim Fire damaged a water line to the camp.  People who have requested camping spots were notified by mail that water supplies must be evaluated before reservations can be made.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 14, 2014
Places: Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Water releases into and from the Rio Grande River for the irrigation season in southern New Mexico and El Paso, Texas delayed
Description: Water releases into and from the Rio Grande River for the irrigation season in southern New Mexico and El Paso, Texas were delayed from a typical March start to June 1, due to ongoing drought, said the president and CEO of El Paso Water Utilities Co.  All parties in New Mexico; El Paso, Texas and Mexico agreed with a June 1 start date.Drought in 2013 also led to delayed water releases beginning on June 1.El Paso Times (Texas), March 13, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Dona Ana County, NM, Sierra County, NM, El Paso County, TX

Title: Many counties in the Texas Panhandle banned outdoor burning
Description: Many counties in the Texas Panhandle banned outdoor burning, due to the ongoing dry, windy and warm conditions.  Counties on the northern and southern edges of the panhandle, such as Dallam, Hartley, Sherman, Hansford, Ochiltree, Lipscomb, Collingsworth, Hall, Briscoe and Swisher do not have burn bans.Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), March 12, 2014

Title: Wildlife encroaching for food onto Yolo County, California farmland
Description: An organic farm in Yolo County has had more problems than usual with wildlife, such as deer and wild pigs, encroaching onto farmland in search of food.  The farmers are spending more money on fencing to keep wildlife out and expect to spend $20,000 on fencing this year.  Also due to the drought, the farm has planted fewer water intensive crops like corn and melons, which will limit produce variety at farmers markets.Denver Post (Colo.), March 12, 2014
Places: Yolo County, CA

Title: Abundance of tumbleweeds in Texas Panhandle
Description: The abundance of tumbleweeds was causing problems for Randall County residents, prompting county officials to remind the public that the burn ban also applies to annoying tumbleweeds.  People were urged to crush them and put them in the trash, haul them to landfills or shred them with a mower when the humidity exceeds 15 percent.Tumbleweeds were also “terrorizing” the better part of the Texas Panhandle as drought allowed tumbleweeds to thrive while other vegetation did not.  Southeastern Colorado was also trying to get a handle on a bumper crop of tumbleweeds.Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), March 12, 2014

Title: The California Department of Water Resources holding off on temporary dams in three channels of the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta
Description: The February and March precipitation postponed the need to install rock barriers in the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta to prevent saltwater intrusion.  Washington Post (D.C.), April 19, 2014The California Department of Water Resources is striving to quickly install temporary dams at a cost of $25 million in three channels of the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta to reduce seawater intrusion from the San Francisco Bay and guard water quality.  Having the barriers in place would eliminate or reduce the need for water releases from reservoirs to improve water quality in the Delta.  The project manager said they were hurrying to get needed permits, alert property owners who would be affected by the dams and have the dams installed as soon as May 1.  The temporary dam plan still must be approved by the State Water Resources Control Board, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the National Marine Fisheries Service.The dams would consist of 24-inch rocks at the entrance to the False River near Oakley, just west of Franks Tract and at Sutter and Steamboat sloughs on the Sacramento River near Courtland.  The rock dams would remain in place through November, when they would be removed and possibly used again next year if the drought continues.Water for more than 25 million people and 3 million acres of farmland comes from the Delta, including supplies for the Santa Clara Valley Water District, which serves 1.8 million customers, the Contra Costa Water District, which serves 500,000 customers and the Metropolitan Water District, serving 19 million people in southern California.  This barrier method was also used in the 1976-77 drought to keep salty water from moving upstream.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 12, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Contra Costa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Solano County, CA

Title: Dust storm rolled across West Texas
Description: A wall of dust up to 1,000 feet tall and 200 miles wide rolled across West Texas and New Mexico on the evening of March 112, as drought continues to impact the region.  Strong winds from a cold front stirred up the dust, reducing visibility to roughly one mile in Lubbock and to zero in Muleshoe and Friona.  The dust storm started in Amarillo and stretched from the New Mexico border east to Post.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), March 12, 2014

Title: California state and federal wildlife officials presented a plan to transport hatchery-raised salmon to the sea
Description: California state and federal wildlife officials presented a plan to transport hatchery-raised salmon to the sea by tanker truck in the event that the Sacramento River and its tributaries become too warm and shallow for the fish to survive.  Salmon are usually released from the Coleman National Fish Hatchery on Battle Creek in April and May.Similar measures were undertaken during the 1991-92 drought to help the salmon reach the Pacific Ocean. Fresno Bee (Calif.), March 11, 2014
Places: Contra Costa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Solano County, CA

Title: Hydropower production down in central Texas
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority has generated less hydropower from its six dams as drought reduces the amount of water flowing in the Colorado River.  In early 2014, the LCRA produced roughly one-third of the hydropower it generated in 2011.  The executive manager of water operations at the LCRA said that water levels could drop too low to turn the generators within several years.Of the power produced by the LCRA from power plants and hydropower, less than 6 percent comes from the dams on the Colorado River, whereas most of its power previously came from hydropower prior to the mid-1960s.  Water managers do not often use the generators to their full potential and only use the generators when water is being released downstream for other purposes.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), March 10, 2014
Places: Austin County, TX, Bastrop County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Colorado County, TX, DeWitt County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Gonzales County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Lavaca County, TX, Lee County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Mills County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Travis County, TX, Waller County, TX, Washington County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Fewer farmers selling at City Farmers’ Market in Civic Center in San Francisco
Description: Drought and production challenges were keeping five or six small family farmers from bringing in fresh produce to sell at the City Farmers’ Market in Civic Center. Farmers are wary and anxious, hoping to have enough water to continue growing crops, but unsure, wondering what the summer holds in store. A grower of alfalfa and broccoli sprouts, pumpkins and Christmas trees has begun planting sprouts closer together and watering less frequently than he used to do.  He does not have any extra water for a personal garden and must be frugal with water while washing sprouts because the creek which supplies all of his water is drying up quickly.  He is worried and praying for rain.Another farmer in Merced who stopped bringing produce to the market was able to plant only one crop, instead of double-cropping.  In addition, he is only planting half of his 60 acres while he waits for the pump and pipes in his well to be replaced.  The water level has dropped considerably.He is also installing drip irrigation lines to conserve water .San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), May 2, 2014 and June 6, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Merced County, CA, San Francisco, CA, San Mateo County, CA

Title: Tehama-Colusa Canal Authority in northern Californiaspent $30 million to acquire water when the Central Valley Project had none to deliver
Description: The Tehama-Colusa Canal Authority spent $30 million to acquire water from the Glenn-Colusa Irrigation District, Reclamation District 108, Conaway Ranch, Sycamore Water District and others at a price of $400 to $450 per acre-foot after receiving zero percent of its allocation from the federal Central Valley Project.  Of the district’s 150,000 acres in four counties, just 70,000 acres received irrigation water to keep trees and vineyards alive, while the remaining acres were left idle.Almond growers in Tehama County have drilled deep new wells costing $150,000 to $200,000 apiece in some instances to compensate for the lack of federal water.  One almond grower runs his pumps around the clock to get as much as he can because his wells are not producing much water.  Farmers in Butte County have found economical ways to get water.  Electricity is roughly half price on weekends, so farmers choose to irrigate when it’s cheaper.  Diesel pumps are also used instead of electric ones to keep costs down.  Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Aug. 28, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Tehama County, CA

Title: Triple the usual number of salmon released on Sacramento River near Redding, California to compensate for 95 percent salmon mortality in 2014
Description: Ninety-five percent of the winter-run chinook eggs, hatchlings and juvenile salmon in the Sacramento River perished this year, like in 2014, due to the warm, drought-depleted Sacramento River and its tributaries, announced the National Marine Fisheries Service.  The fish would typically return in three years to spawn, but with two consecutive years’ worth of salmon dying, this wild run could be nearly extinct and will require careful monitoring and protection in 2016.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Oct. 29, 2015Three times as many as usual or about 600,000 Chinook salmon will be released into the Sacramento River below Keswick Dam by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.  Warm water allowed a massive fish die-off to occur in 2014 when about 95 percent of the salmon eggs and newly hatched fish died.  Winter-run salmon need water temperatures of 60 degrees or less for successful spawning. Shasta Lake, from which the water is released, has fallen to its second lowest level, putting the reservoir at 42 percent of capacity.  The relatively small quantity of water warms more than if the lake were larger and deeper, and lacks a pool of colder water that is drawn upon for spawning season.  Only 5 percent of the juvenile salmon survived in 2014, compared with a typical survival rate of about 27 percent, said a spokeswoman for the State Department of Fish and Wildlife.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Jan. 28, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Fewer young steelhead trout moving down the Napa River in California
Description: Fewer young steelhead trout were moving down the Napa River to the ocean as measured by an annual count of the native fish.  Biologists and volunteers with the Napa County Resource Conservation District counted just 31 steelhead smolts and no young Chinook salmon between March and June, for the lowest number in six years.  Drought has reduced the flow of the Napa River, making it difficult for the fish to make it down the river.  In 2009, biologists found 119 steehead trout caught in the rotary screw trap; in 2010, a record 242 steelhead were caught; and in 2013, the number of steelhead caught was 77.Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Aug. 3, 2014
Places: Napa County, CA

Title: Electric bills rose for Pacific Gas and Electric Co. customers in California
Description: Pacific Gas and Electric Co., serving much of California from Eureka in the north to Bakersfield in the south, upped its electric rates 1.5 percent to compensate for less cheap energy from hydropower production, due to drought.  The rate increase took effect prior to March 2014.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 6, 2015
Places: Alameda County, CA, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Butte County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Inyo County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Lake County, CA, Lassen County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Merced County, CA, Mono County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Roseville, CA, Plumas County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Sacramento, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company held back water during the spring of 2014 and generated less hydropower in California
Description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company held back water during the spring of 2014 and generated less hydropower, with the expectation that the water would be used for electricity production during the summer when demand for power would be higher.The California Energy Commission estimated that hydroelectric production in the Sierra Nevada in 2014 will be roughly half the production in 2010, which was a normal hydroelectric year.  Powerhouses along 16 rivers in the Sierra region generated about 31.7 million megawatt-hours of electricity in 2010, but in 2014, these powerhouses are expected to produce just 17 million MWh, according to the energy commission's deputy director for strategic planning.The Helms hydroelectric powerhouse, northeast of Fresno, has the capacity to recycle water and reuse it to generate more electricity, a very valuable quality during drought.  When the plant is not producing power, the turbines can turn backwards to pump the water back uphill into storage for later use.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Aug. 4, 2014
Places: Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mono County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Drought limited number of Chinook salmon returning to California rivers
Description: Six million fewer fall-run Chinook salmon were produced at the federal Coleman National Fish Hatchery for release into Battle Creek in the spring of 2018, half of the usual production of 12 million fish.  Past years of drought, notably 2014 and 2015, led biologists to truck juvenile salmon to the Delta because rivers were warm and shallow rather than cold, roiling rivers of stormwater runoff that protect the fish.  Transporting the fish resulted in fewer fish being able to return on their own to the fishery to spawn as returns of spring- and winter-run salmon born during drought were some of the lowest on record.  Chinook salmon spend two to three years in the Pacific Ocean before they swim back upriver to lay their eggs and perish, completing their life cycle.  The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Dec. 26, 2017
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: California Department of Water Resources sending water to Lake Perris rather than Castaic Lake
Description: The California Department of Water Resources is rerouting 30,000 acre-feet of water that was intended for Castaic Lake in Los Angeles County and sending it to Lake Perris in Riverside County.  Both lakes are popular with boaters and anglers, and were intended to store drinking water moved via the State Water Project.  The Metropolitan Water District  can access 65,000 acre-feet of “flexible storage” water from Lake Perris, but must replace the water within five years.  The agency used about 35,000 acre-feet in February and March, said Metropolitan’s assistant general manager and chief operating officer, but has never needed to use the full 65,000 acre-feet until this year.Metropolitan considered draining Lake Perris, but consultations with the DWR led to the alternative of redirecting the water intended for Castaic Lake.  The water will go directly to a water treatment plant in Riverside.  Castaic Lake, operated by the Los Angeles County department of parks and recreation, was already depleted enough that swim beaches will not be used this summer, resulting in a revenue loss of about $230,000 in 2014.  Trailered boats may not be launched on the lower lake, due to low water levels.  Castaic also holds 153,000 acre-feet of flexible storage that it plans to use in May, June, September and October, according to the deputy director for the State Water Project.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 13, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Riverside County, CA

Title: Wildflowers are few and far between in southern California
Description: Wildflowers were few and far between in southern California because not enough precipitation has fallen to encourage the plants’ growth.  Jim Bremmer, publisher of DesertUSA.com for the past 15 years, does not remember a season as poor as this for wildflower viewing.  Other wildflower enthusiasts agree that the season is lousy, but dwarfed flowers can be found if one is willing to hunt for them.The Antelope Valley California Poppy Reserve near Lancaster is mostly devoid of poppies, but does have a few plants that managed to produce a bloom.  The hills remained mostly brown as the area has received less than 10 percent of its average precipitation.The Joshua Tree National Park has fewer mustard plants, an invasive annual that crowds out native flora and fuels wildfires.  A botanist for the park credits the drought with the reduced number of the mustard plants.The annual ground flowers were nowhere to be found at the Anza-Forrego Desert State Park in San Diego County, stated a park volunteer.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Feb. 27, 2014
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA

Title: Chiquita moving agricultural production to Southeastern U.S.
Description: Chiquita is moving production to the Southeast U.S. while its growing regions in Yuma, Ariz., California’s Salinas Valley and Mexico are parched.  Dry conditions hurt the production of iceberg lettuce and other salad ingredients.The Charlotte Observer (N.C.), Feb. 27, 2014
Places: Yuma County, AZ, Monterey County, CA

Title: Woodward Reservoir in Stanislaus County, California to remain at low level
Description: The South San Joaquin Irrigation District board of directors voted to leave the Woodward Reservoir in Stanislaus County lower than normal, which would effectively close the reservoir for public recreation.  While the SSJID has senior water rights on the Stanislaus River, the district prefers to conserve water in the event that drought drags on into 2015.  The SSJID will save up to 9,691 acre-feet of water that would be lost to evaporation and seepage if it does not fill the reservoir, but will review the issue in April.The SSJID serves water customers in Tracy, Manteca and Lathrop.Stockton Record (Calif.), Feb. 27, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Lathrop, CA, Manteca, CA, Tracy, CA, Stanislaus County, CA

Title: Mandatory 25 percent water conservation in San Juan Water District near Sacramento, California
Description: The San Juan Water District imposed a stage 3 water warning, bringing mandatory water use restrictions of 25 percent as Folsom Lake continued to drop.  Pavement and buildings may not be washed, and restaurants must only serve water if the customer requests it.  The San Juan Water District provides water for roughly 265,000 people in Granite Bay, parts of Roseville and Folsom, and unincorporated portions of Sacramento County.  Water agencies in Citrus Heights, Orangevale and Fair Oaks also receive water from the SJWD and have taken steps to guard the water supply in Folsom Lake.Fair Oaks Water District began using wells rather than drawing water from Folsom Lake.  Other agencies were also striving to conserve water.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 28, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Roseville, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Citrus Heights, CA, Fair Oaks, CA, Folsom, CA, Orangevale, CA, Granite Hills, CA

Title: Texas rice growers on Lower Colorado River to go without water for third year
Description: While rice farmers on the Lower Colorado River did not expect to get water, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality sealed their fate by postponing a decision on trigger levels for releasing water from lakes Travis and Buchanan.  This is the third straight year without water for rice growers.KXAN-TV NBC 36 Austin (Texas), Feb. 26, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Llano County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: East Bay Municipal Utility District in California purchasing second emergency supply
Description: The East Bay Municipal Utility District board chose to act on an option to purchase up to 20,000 acre-feet of water from the Placer County Water Agency.  EBMUD will spend $8 million on the expenditure, $1.5 million for the water and $6.5 million to pump the water from the Sacramento area.  EBMUD also has a contract to purchase water from the Sacramento River from the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Feb. 26, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Placer County, CA

Title: The Santa Clara Valley Water District in California asked its customers to use 20 percent less water
Description: In response to the Santa Clara Valley Water District’s request for cutting water use by 20 percent, its customers in Palo Alto and Mountain View curbed their water use by 17 percent, while the countywide reduction in water use was 12 percent.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), July 21, 2014The city of Milpitas did not like Santa Clara Valley Water District’s plan to reduce water delivery to 80 percent of normal, with city staffers pushing for a flat out denial of the water district’s recommendations.  After the Santa Clara Valley Water District representatives met with City of Milpitas staffers on April 23, Milpitas staffers accepted the district’s plan to curb water use by 20 percent.Milpitas water authorities will monitor water use and, if necessary, adopt water restrictions and penalties to encourage compliance with the district’s 80-percent water delivery schedule. San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 6, 2014The Santa Clara Valley Water District asked its customers to use 20 percent less water to keep groundwater levels from falling to near critical levels.  The groundwater level may be just above the critical stage at the start of 2015 if drought persists.The Santa Clara Valley Water District provides water to 13 water retailers, serving 1.8 million people in Santa Clara County.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Feb. 25, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: San Diego, California, water conservation requested
Description: Orange County has a Drought Task Force, has made a proclamation and requesting 10% water conservation. Metropolitan Water District asking for 20% voluntary water conservation. DM Consensus: No change.
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The California Department of Water Resources was selling $165.3 million worth of bonds
Description: The California Department of Water Resources was selling $165.3 million worth of bonds to finance a reservoir expansion east of Los Angeles and the construction of pipelines connecting with suburbs in San Bernardino County.Drought has little bearing on the creditworthiness of the California Department of Water Resources, said Moody’s Investors Service in a Feb. 14 report.  The 29 local agencies that purchase water from the state must pay whether or not they receive water.Washington Post (D.C.), Feb. 24, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA, Butte County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Napa County, CA, Orange County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Yuba City, CA, Tulare County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Nine thousand acres of land unplanted near Coalinga, California
Description: Nine thousands acres of vegetables near Coalinga, including 3,000 acres of lettuce were not planted due to the water shortage, stated the executive vice president of Harris Farms in Coalinga.  The forced fallowing of the acres normally devoted to lettuce will result in the loss of 72 million heads of lettuce and 700,000 hours of work for field workers.One thousand acres of almonds may soon be next for removal as the farm cuts back on water needs where possible.  Insects infest unwatered almond trees and spread into nearby fields, so the trees cannot be ignored for a season with the hope that they might survive.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 24, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA, Coalinga, CA

Title: Orchard removal company in Ripon, California very busy
Description: The high number of trees being removed due to drought has driven up business by 75 percent, said a crew leader for an orchard and vineyard removal service based in Ripon.  Although this time of year typically isn’t very busy, they presently have very full days of work removing orchards.The abundance of wood chips from almond trees is used by California power plants that burn the chips as bio fuel.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 24, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA

Title: Allergy season began two months early in the Central Valley of California, may last longer than usual
Description: Pollens counts typical of April were already present in February as drought drove up pollen levels in the Central Valley.  The allergy season may also last longer than usual as drought causes grasses and trees to pollinate longer.Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 17, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Drought alert for customers of West Basin Municipal Water District in Los Angeles County, California
Description: The West Basin Municipal Water District board of directors declared a drought alert, urging its water customers to adopt water conservation measures and meet the governor’s goal of reducing water use by 20 percent.  The West Basin Municipal Water District provides water for nearly one million people in Los Angeles County.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), March 4, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Almond growers in Fresno County, California ripping out trees
Description: Almond growers in Fresno County were at the mercy of the dry weather and severely depleted water supplies and were having acres of almond trees torn out because the trees cannot survive without water.  An almond grower in Firebaugh took out 20 percent of his 5,000 acres of almonds and hopes that he does not have to remove more trees.  The orchard removal crew pulling out his trees says that drought has boosted their business considerably.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 24, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: California farmers expect to receive 5 percent from State Water Project
Description: Water districts and farmers in California will get up to 5 percent of requested amounts of water from the State Water Project, said the Department of Water Resources.  The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation bumped up allocations for water agencies in the Sacramento Valley from 40 percent to 75 percent, while water customers relying on federal water south of the delta still will not receive any water.  February and March storms brought enough precipitation to allow the water providers to offer some water rather than none, as had been previously forecast. Although the state has upped its water allotment, Mark Cowin, the director of the California Department of Water Resources, asked suppliers not to take the water before Sept. 1.  Washington Post (D.C.), April 19, 2014Water delivery estimates for the Central Valley Project remained at zero percent.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 9, 2014The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation announced that there was not enough water in the Central Valley Project to deliver water to farmers, while communities and wildlife get just a fraction of their contracted amounts after a third dry winter.In 2013, Central Valley farmers received 20 percent of contracted amounts.ABC News, Feb. 21, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: USDA adjusted standards for certified organic beef production to allow for drought challenges in California
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture began allowing producers of certified organic beef and other ruminants to graze the animals on grass for less than 120 days, as used to be the policy, in counties that received a primary disaster declaration due to drought.  All counties in California qualify, except Riverside, San Diego, Imperial and San Francisco counties.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Feb. 21, 2014

Title: Groups oppose Crystal Geyser's plans to draw water from aquifer in Siskiyou County, California
Description: Mount Shasta residents, environmentalists and Native American tribes are opposed to Crystal Geyser’s plans to draw water from the Big Springs Aquifer at the base of the Mount Shasta, fearing that Siskiyou County’s wells and aquifers could become depleted.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Feb. 19, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Siskiyou County, CA

Title: Tehama County, California, lack of forage for animals, hay prices increasing
Description: Despite 3 inches of rain in February the hills and fields are still brown.   Normally, February in California is green, with hints of wild flowers.   The horse pastures are still barren, no forage is available for them.   Buying hay is an adventure, the line of waiting trucks and trailers is a mile long.   The price of hay is going up.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Red Bluff 5.1 NNW on 2/17/2014
Places: Tehama County, CA

Title: Lady Gaga to do a public service announcement encouraging water conservation in California
Description: In exchange for use of the Neptune Pool at Hearst Castle near San Simeon, Lady Gaga agreed to donate a quarter of a million dollars to castle maintenance and repair, to promote the castle and water conservation on social media and also to make a water conservation public service announcement.   Gov. Jerry Brown wrote Lady Gaga a letter of thanks for the aid and assistance she provided to the state park and beyond.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 14, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA, San Simeon, CA

Title: Salt accumulation in soil of strawberry fields in Southern California
Description: The lack of rain has led to salt buildup in strawberry fields in the Salinas in Monterey County, Watsonville in Santa Cruz County and near Oxnard in Ventura County, stated the director of berry operations for Naturipe Berry Growers Inc., Salinas, Calif.The Packer (Lenexa, Kan.), Feb. 13, 2014
Places: Monterey County, CA, Salinas, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Watsonville, CA, Ventura County, CA, Oxnard, CA

Title: Some California ski resorts in the Sierra finally received enough snow to open for the winter
Description: Some ski resorts in the Sierra finally received enough snow to open for the winter.  Dodge Ridge and Badger Pass in Tuolumne County opened for the season on Feb. 12 after recent snowfall.  Tahoe Donner opened on Feb. 14 with limited terrain.Mount Shasta Ski Park in Siskiyou County remained closed initially due to drought, but then due to rain.  Heavenly Mountain Ski Resort at South Lake Tahoe still had some lifts and runs closed as drought made snow scarce.  One week ago, skiers had access to 271 acres of the 4,800 acres at the resort, but recent snowfall brought the number of acres in use to 2,240.  At Northstar at Tahoe Ski Area in Nevada County, 13 of 20 lifts were running and 70 of 97 runs were in use.The Kirkwood Ski Resort in Alpine County had 8 of 15 lifts operating for access to 49 of 86 runs.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Feb. 13, 2014
Places: Alpine County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: The Metropolitan Water District allotted more money to its conservation rebate program, approved water supply alert
Description: Metropolitan Water District allotted another $20 million to its previous budget of $20 million for its conservation rebate program because district officials expect a surge in demand for rebates for items such as rain barrels, lawn replacement rebates and soil moisture sensors.  The MWD board also approved a water supply alert, requesting its member agencies in Riverside and San Bernardino counties and southern California to voluntarily implement and enforce ordinances that limit outdoor irrigation, prohibit runoff and other similar measures.The MWD provides water for 19 million people and gets its water from the State Water Project and the Colorado River.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Feb. 11, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Fire chief in Kern County, California held press conference early
Description: The Kern County fire chief held a press conference which would usually be held mid-May, but the ongoing drought prompted him to have the press conference three months early in mid-February.  The fire chief noted that the 2013 fire season never ended and bled over into 2014.  Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), Feb. 11, 2014
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: The East Bay Municipal Utility District in California urged its customers to cut water use by 10 percent
Description: The East Bay Municipal Utility District has asked its customers to voluntarily trim their water use by 10 percent.  EBMUD serves 1.3 million people in Alameda and Contra Costa counties.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Feb. 12, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA

Title: Caltrans has begun to conserve water by curbing the irrigation of highway landscaping in California
Description: Caltrans has begun to conserve water by curbing the irrigation of highway landscaping in California and especially in severe water shortage areas including parts of Kern, Fresno, Madera, Mariposa, Amador, Mendocino, Nevada, Placer and Santa Cruz counties, plus the cities of Healdsburg and Cloverdale in Sonoma County.  The irrigation cutbacks range from 50 to 100 percent.  Caltrans typically uses 12 to 13 billion gallons of water annually to irrigate highway vegetation and aims to pull that back to about 6 billion gallons in 2014.Caltrans is also assessing and repairing irrigation systems, increasing the use of recycled water and putting off all non-essential highway planting.  Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), Feb. 11, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Amador County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Cloverdale, CA, Healdsburg, CA

Title: California water providers, well repairers and well drillers are experiencing unprecedented demand for their services as drought limits water supplies
Description: California water providers, well repairers and well drillers are experiencing unprecedented demand for their services as drought limits water supplies in the state.  Rain for Rent, a water management firm in Bakersfield, helps irrigation districts move massive amounts of water to thirsty areas, installs pumps for groundwater wells and installs temporary irrigation systems in fields that usually rely on rainwater.  The firm was running out of parts, due to the flood of orders, and farmers are looking to keep the temporary irrigation systems in place longer than usual.Advanced Water Well Services, based in Madera, has extended their workweek from five days to six as demand to restore wells climbs.  Well drillers are in very high demand and often have long waiting lists of up to six months in some places.  As farmers have larger pumps installed, they sometimes need upgrades to deliver more energy, placing more demand on power companies to perform the upgrades, with a wait time for that service.A drip irrigation maker has a backlog of several months as farmers anticipate a huge shortfall in moisture this winter.  Los Angeles Times, Feb. 11, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Kern County, CA, Bakersfield, CA, Madera County, CA, Madera, CA, San Diego County, CA, El Cajon, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tulare, CA

Title: Steelhead salmon unable to reach ocean from Carmel River in Monterey County, California
Description: Steelhead salmon in the Carmel River ought to be swimming to the ocean, but dry stretches have prevented them from doing so, according to the general manager of the Monterey Peninsula Water Management District.  Washington Post (D.C.), Feb. 10, 2014
Places: Monterey County, CA

Title: The fire chief  in Kern County, California trying to get some seasonal fire crews organized and operational early this year
Description: The Kern County fire chief is trying to get some seasonal fire crews organized and operational early this year, due to drought and the abundance of dry fuels.   "We have the potential for a catastrophic fire year," the fire chief said.Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), Feb. 10, 2014
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: Cantaloupe grower near Firebaugh, California plans to leave 500 to 700 acres of his 2,000 acres unplanted
Description: A cantaloupe grower near Firebaugh plans to leave 500 to 700 acres of his 2,000 acres unplanted in 2014 because he does not have enough irrigation water to produce a crop.  Without cantaloupes to harvest in July—usually about 650,000 boxes of regular and organic cantaloupe, worth about $3 million—he won’t have to hire a few hundred workers to harvest the produce.He is planning to use what precious water he banked in the San Luis Reservoir to water his almond and cherry trees to keep them alive.Washington Post (D.C.), Feb. 10, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Wildlife entering developed areas in the Bay Area, California
Description: Drought is taking a toll on wildlife in the Bay Area, where more animals are entering developed areas for water.  Wildcare, a wildlife rescue and rehabilitation center based in San Rafael, has received numerous calls from people concerned about wildlife and asking how they can help the animals.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Feb. 9, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, San Rafael, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Grape grower in Alameda County, California trimmed his vines more, waters more
Description: A grape grower in the Livermore Valley trimmed his 6,000 vines more than usual to reduce their need for water.  He also waters them every two weeks, instead of every three months as he did previously, to give them plenty of moisture to draw on when warmer weather arrives.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Feb. 6, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA

Title: Farmers in Butte County, California irrigated to moisten the soil profile
Description: Butte County farmers irrigated to moisten the soil profile, which was extraordinarily dry, until February storms moved through and brought precipitation, said Joe Connell, University of California farm adviser.  It is very rare to irrigate in the winter.Any farmer hoping to have a well drilled before the growing season has little chance of getting a drilling crew because most drillers are booked for months as the demand for water skyrockets during drought.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), March 6, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA

Title: Zone 7 Water Agency in California hurrying to drill two new wells
Description: The Zone 7 Water Agency was quickening the pace of its plans to drill two new wells, knowing that it will receive no water from the State Water Project.  The district usually receives 85 percent of its water from the SWP.  Nevertheless, Zone 7 says it has enough water to serve its customers this summer.  The district provides water for Livermore, San Ramon, Dublin and Pleasanton.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Feb. 6, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Dublin, CA, Livermore, CA, Pleasanton, CA, San Ramon, CA

Title: The Buena Vista Water Storage District in Kern County, California received auction bid of $1,350 per acre-foot for water
Description: The Buena Vista Water Storage District in Kern County put 12,000 acre-feet of stored water up for auction to local growers.  The minimum bid was set at $600 per acre-foot.  The district received 50 bids, with the highest at $1,350 per acre-foot for 300 acre-feet at a total cost of $405,000.  Nearly 20 of the bids offered $1,000 or more for each acre-foot.  The bids altogether showed a need for more than 63,000 acre-feet of water.  Proceeds from the auction will be used to pay for a land fallowing program in the district which will compensate farmers with $400 per acre to lessen demand on the aquifer.  The district hopes to fallow 4,000 to 5,000 acres using the program.  Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), Feb. 5, 2014
Places: Kern County, CA, Buttonwillow, CA

Title: Drought severity in California led El Dorado Irrigation District board to skip to stage 2 water warning
Description: The El Dorado Irrigation District Board leaped over a stage 1 water alert and started with a stage 2 water warning, asking customers to voluntarily reduce their water use by 30 percent.  The board will consider adding a drought surcharge and making voluntary water restrictions mandatory during its March 10 meeting.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 5, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Dorado County, CA

Title: Some California grape growers were purchasing crop insurance for the first time
Description: Some California grape growers were purchasing crop insurance for the first time this year as drought looks to devastate the grape crop unless more precipitation falls.Dryland grape growers are the envy of growers who irrigate their grapes to get a larger crop.InsuranceNewsNet.com (Camp Hill, Penn.), Feb. 3, 2014

Title: California officials bracing for a wave of high unemployment in the rural towns in the Central Valley

Rick Palermo of Community Food Bank in Fresno was scoping out locations for handing out food in Mendota, Firebaugh and other small communities.  During the dry spell in 2009, unemployment rates were very high in the Central Valley.Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), Feb. 2, 2014

Title: Water conservation at 18 percent in Sacramento region
Description: Water customers in the Sacramento area trimmed water use by 18 percent from February through May, in comparison with the last two years, according to the Regional Water Authority.The El Dorado Irrigation District, serving customers from El Dorado Hills to Pollock Pines, saw water conservation of just 6 percent, despite calls for 30 percent conservation.  During most of April, water use was higher than the three year average.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 16, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: The California Water Resources Control Board passed an emergency ruling limiting Delta water diversions
Description: The California Water Resources Control Board passed an emergency ruling on Jan. 31, limiting Delta water diversions to 1,500 cubic feet per second or less and waiving some water-quality rules in the estuary as historic drought gripped the state.  The limited diversions are to be used with “health and safety” purposes in mind, or for urban water needs, not for agriculture.  On Feb. 7, the SWRCB amended the rule to say that water diversions could exceed 1,500 cfs to use the precious storm water runoff, providing that normal water-quality rules were met. Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 11, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Contra Costa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Solano County, CA

Title: Extreme water shortage in Cambria, California
Description: The Cambria Community Services District declared an extreme water shortage in January and got a fast-tracked county permit to construct a $9.13 million water treatment plant along San Simeon Creek to stretch the water supply.  Water customers cut their water consumption by 40 percent, but dropping well levels meant the community needed to do more to bolster its aquifer.  Cambria also gets water from Santa Rosa Creek, but both San Simeon and Santa Rosa were alarmingly low.Los Angeles Times, Nov. 4, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA, Cambria Pines, CA

Title: Voluntary water conservation of 10 percent urged in San Francisco, California
Description: The San Francisco Public Utilities Commission asked its water customers in January 2014 to voluntarily curb their water use by 10 percent.  The agency is preparing for a worst-case scenario and is striving to stretch the water supply.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 16, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Francisco County, CA

Title: The California Department of Fish and Wildlife closed some rivers and streams in Monterey, Santa Cruz and Santa Clara counties to fishing
Description: The California Fish and Game Commission unanimously voted to close the American and Russian rivers to fishing through April 30 and extend closures on hundreds of smaller coastal streams because low water levels were adversely affecting spawning and fish survival.  The low water also exposes the fishes’ egg nests, or redds, which may be trampled by anglers.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 6, 2014 and June 18, 2014The California Department of Fish and Wildlife closed some rivers and streams in Monterey, Santa Cruz and Santa Clara counties to fishing to protect salmon and steelhead populations while river flows are low.  The CDFW is also considering additional river closures, including sections of the American River and Russian River.“We fully understand the impact these closures will have on California anglers and the businesses related to fishing in California, and we really feel for them,” said the director of the CDFW.  “However the science is clear. Two-thirds of the wettest part of winter is now behind us and conditions are looking increasingly grim. Under these extreme drought conditions, it is prudent to conserve and protect as many adult fish as possible to help ensure the future of fishing in California.”Californian Online - Salinas, Jan. 30, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Farmers across California were planting fewer crops and selling livestock in anticipation of continued drought and poor water allocations
Description: Farmers across California were planting fewer crops and selling livestock in anticipation of continued drought and poor water allocations.  Lost revenue in 2014 from farming and agriculture-related businesses like processing and trucking could come to $5 billion, according to estimates by the 300-member California Farm Water Coalition, a Sacramento-based group of farmers, water district managers and farm-related businesses.  Farmers may leave up to 500,000 acres unplanted, which is 12 percent of the principal crops grown in 2013, because they will not have sufficient water to bring the crop to harvest, according to Mike Wade, executive director of the California Farm Water Coalition.A farmer in Stanislaus County chose to plant less corn and alfalfa and sell some dairy cows to avoid having to purchase grain to feed the animals because he may lose as much as two-thirds of his usual allotment of irrigation water this year.  The farmer dislikes the reductions he has to make because he says the cuts will affect his farm through 2015.A dairyman in Turlock sold roughly a dozen replacement cattle from his herd of 900 Holstein cows to reduce his need for feed and water for his main milking herd.  The animals were sold about 16 months earlier than the dairyman would have liked because he anticipates his corn and oat crops grown for feed not doing well, given that irrigation water supplies will likely be scarce.Bend Bulletin (Ore.), Jan. 30, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Stanislaus County, CA, Turlock, CA

Title: Wine grape vines budding early in Sonoma and Napa counties in California
Description: Wine grape vines in Sonoma and Napa counties were budding early, indicating that drought could lead to a smaller grape crop.  The crops were also at an earlier risk for frost as the dry weather triggered early growth.  San Francisco Business Times (Calif.), Jan. 29, 2014
Places: Napa County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Drought threatening California's livestock producers’ ability to meet organic production guidelines
Description: Drought is threatening Sonoma County’s livestock producers’ ability to meet organic production guidelines because cattle must graze on pasture for at least 120 days and to receive a minimum of 30 percent of their feed from pasture.  Water supplies were also running low.Ag Alert (Sacramento, Calif.), Jan. 29, 2014

Description: Frustrated residents around Lake Texoma feel that too much water is being taken from the lake for hydropower generation, and the low lake levels hurt the area’s economy.KGOU-FM (Norman, Okla.), Jan. 28, 2014

Title: The Santa Clara Valley Water District planned to vote on whether to adopt additional water conservation measures
Description: The Santa Clara Valley Water District planned to vote on whether to institute a “preliminary water use reduction target” and whether to spend $500,000 to broaden their public outreach campaign and expand water conservation rebate programs to encourage water conservation at a Jan. 28 meeting.  Because the district is a wholesale water provider, any voluntary water conservation request will be at the discretion of the water retailers, which sell water to 1.8 million customers.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Jan. 26, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Clara County, CA

Title: California water systems with 60 to 120 days' worth of water left
Description: The California State Water Resources Control Board has 14 communities on the “critical water systems” list and were having water brought in for residents.  Some communities that have been on or were still on the list include Parkwood in Madera County, Montague in Siskiyou County, Arroyo Seco Resort in Monterey County, Lake Berryessa Resort in Napa and Woodside RV Park in Mendocino County.Los Angeles Times, Sept. 25, 2014The California Department of Public Health revised downward the number of communities with less than two months’ worth of water left to three.  Montague in Siskiyou County, the Redwood Valley County Water District in Mendocino County and a 55-person apartment complex in Mariposa County were in danger of running out of water within two months.Rains have improved situations for some communities, such as Willits, which has two full reservoirs rather than nearly empty ones as was the case in February.  The town’s main concern has shifted to fire danger.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 25, 2014The California Department of Public Health listed 17 communities that have 60 to 120 days’ worth of drinking water remaining.  The water systems are located in Amador, Fresno, Kern, Madera, Mariposa, Mendocino, Nevada, Placer, Santa Cruz and Sonoma counties and range in size from serving just 39 people to 11,000 people.  The state health department checked with the more than 3,000 water agencies in the state to assess the status of the systems and will revise their list of communities with water shortages weekly.State health officials were also consulting with the state Office of Emergency Services and the Federal Emergency Management Agency to provide assistance when it is needed, such as trucking in water, handing out emergency funds for new wells or connecting struggling systems to neighboring water systems.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Jan. 28, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Gold prospectors were taking advantage of low river levels in Placer County, California to look for gold
Description: The proprietor of a mining store in Auburn stated that drought and the interest in panning for gold has increased business at the store by 20 to 25 percent.Fresno Bee (Calif.), March 27, 2014Gold prospectors were taking advantage of low river levels in Placer County to look for gold along river banks that have not been dry in more than 100 years. A man panning for gold along the Bear River in Colfax found a chip of gold about one-fourth the size of a pea.A seller of mining supplies in Auburn reported that business was up 10 percent recently with the low water levels and interest in finding gold.ABC News, Jan. 27, 2014
Places: Placer County, CA, Auburn, CA, Colfax, CA

Title: Water belonging to San Joaquin Valley farmers in California being eyed by feds
Description: The water in the San Luis Reservoir is safe from the Bureau of Reclamation, which decided to leave the water alone, but whether the bureau will tap the water in Millerton Lake is still in question.Merced Sun-Star (Calif.), Jan. 30, 2014Some farmers in the San Joaquin Valley wisely set aside some water from the Central Valley Project in 2013 for 2014, in case the drought continued.  Roughly 340,000 acre-feet of water, which belongs to the farmers since they paid for it, is stored by the Bureau of Reclamation in the San Luis Reservoir in Merced County and a lesser amount is held in Millerton Lake in Fresno County.  Farmers now worry that federal officials may take that water, which, unfortunately for the farmers, is legal.  Federal officials have not ruled out taking water in the San Luis Reservoir that is intended for irrigating crops in the San Joaquin Valley.  The Bureau of Reclamation has yet to announce its initial water allocations, but will in late February.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Jan. 27, 2014

Title: Ongoing drought keeps ban on outdoor burning in many Texas panhandle counties

According to the Texas A&M Forest Service, counties with bans include Armstrong, Childress, Deaf Smith, Donley, Hemphill, Hutchinson, Moore, Parmer, Randall, Roberts and Wheeler.Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), Jan. 27, 2014

Title: Dryland winter wheat in Texas panhandle threatened by dry conditions
Description: Dryland wheat growers in Wheeler County brought in crop insurance adjusters to witness the devastation caused by drought, said the AgriLife Extension agent for the county.  Even irrigated wheat manifested signs of drought damage.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 13, 2014.Winter wheat in the Texas panhandle was struggling and needs moisture.  Texas A&M AgriLife Research wheat breeder Jackie Rudd and AgriLife Extension small grains specialist Clark Neely said that the dry conditions are a major problem for the winter wheat and may kill the dryland wheat if there isn’t precipitation soon.Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), Jan. 27, 2014

Title: Many California ranchers were selling livestock
Description: Many California ranchers were selling livestock because drought has dried up pastures and water supplies.  An auction in Aromas usually isn’t busy in January, but has been humming with activity as livestock producers bring in hungry cattle that they cannot afford to feed.  An auction house co-owner in Aromas said that weekly sales have been 800 to 1,000 animals weekly, far above the January average of 100 to 150 animals weekly.One cattle rancher in his 70s near Hollister sold more than 160 cows and calves at auction in Aromas in the past two weeks and intends to sell another 100 head, if not more.  Hay is too costly to purchase to feed his livestock, and the water supplies on his land were going dry, but the lack of food and water on his land for the livestock may drive him to sell the rest of the herd.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Jan. 27, 2014
Places: California, Monterey County, CA, San Benito County, CA

Title: Wildfires burning in typically moister parts of California
Description: The wildfire danger is high in California, leading to fires in typically wet parts of the state.  The Red Fire charred 333 acres in Humboldt County in early January, while the Soda Fire has scorched about 735 acres in the Sequoia National Forest at elevations above 7,500 feet, elevations that are usually deep in snow in January.  The state Department of Forestry and Fire Protection hired enough firefighters to staff 26 engines in northern California, due to the drought, said Cal Fire director Ken Pimlott.  Most fire engine crews are usually on seasonal furlough during the winter, but the fire danger prompted the additional staffing, despite the time of year.  “The vegetation conditions are extremely dry statewide,” said Pimlott. “I’ve been a firefighter for 30 years and I talk to all of our peers, and no one can remember when we’ve had these kind of conditions statewide and had this level of activity. It’s a situation to take very seriously.”Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Jan. 23, 2014

Title: Horse owners in California struggling to feed horses when grass does not grow
Description: A horse owner in Sanger made the painful decision to sell some of his horses because there has been no rainfall to make winter grasses grow and hay is too expensive.  The horses have lost some weight, and the sale can no longer be postponed.A horse rescue next door has been overwhelmed with horses as many other horse owners also can no longer afford hay for their horses.  People call two to three times weekly, looking to find a place to leave their horses, in contrast to the two to four such calls that used to come monthly.  KBZK-TV Bozeman 7 (Mont.), Jan. 23, 2014
