Title: The Sierra Salmon Alliance encouraged the California Department of Fish and Wildlife to close the American River around Sacramento, California
Description: The Sierra Salmon Alliance encouraged the California Department of Fish and Wildlife to close the American River around Sacramento to guard steelhead and salmon against fishing pressure as drought reduces the flow of the river.  The co-founder of the Sierra Salmon Alliance expressed concern that fishermen may have an easier time catching spawning steelhead with reduced water flows narrowing the river.  Fishermen may also inadvertently crush Chinook salmon eggs underfoot, making it better to close the river to fishing as was done during the 1977 drought. Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Jan. 9, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: Agencies met to discuss water transfers and drought preparedness in Sacramento, California
Description: Representatives from the California State Board of Food and Agriculture, the Department of Water Resources and the State Water Resources Control Board met to discuss water transfers and drought preparedness in Sacramento on Jan. 7.  The drought is expected to cause many farmers to fallow lands or overpump groundwater in 2014.Central Valley Business Times (Stockton, Calif.), Dec. 30, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Amador County, CA, Butte County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, Colusa County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Lake County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, Sacramento, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Solano County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Ongoing drought emergency in Santa Barbara County, California
Description: The Santa Barbara County Board of Supervisors unanimously chose to adopt a resolution again ratifying the county's proclamation of a local emergency due to persistent drought.  The resolution has been renewed every 30 days since it was initially ratified in January 2014.  Lake Cachuma was at 32 percent of capacity on Sept. 17, 2018.  Santa Barbara Independent (Calif.), Oct. 13, 2018
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Barbara County, CA

Title: Flows from Folsom Dam near Sacramento, California will be reduced in stages from 1,100 cubic feet per second to 500 cfs to conserve water
Description: Flows from Folsom Dam will be reduced in stages from 1,100 cubic feet per second to 500 cfs to conserve water.  Some Chinook salmon eggs are expected to be exposed and die.  The flow reduction occurred ahead of the steelhead spawning season so they will not be harmed by reduced flows.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Jan. 7, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: Drought emergency in Mendocino County, California
Description: Mendocino County officials declared a drought emergency on Jan. 7 after a historically dry 2013, becoming the first county in California to do so on account of the drought.  Lake Mendocino was at 37 percent of capacity in early February 2014.  Willits in Mendocino County was one of the 17 communities identified as having 60 to 120 days’ worth of water left in their reservoir.  Consequently, water restrictions are severe—outdoor watering and car washing are not permitted, residents were ordered to slash water use and restaurants must only serve water if a customer requests it.  One resident expressed worry about the water situation, "We're very concerned. If we totally run out of water, what are we going to do? Go to another community?  It's frightening."San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Feb. 6, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Mendocino County, CA, Willits, CA

Title: Ranchers continued hauling water for livestock in Tarrant County, Texas
Description: Ranchers near Saginaw attested that they were still hauling water for livestock because there was no water in stock tanks.  Some grass did grow in 2013, which was more than could be said for the past couple of years.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Jan. 5, 2014
Places: Tarrant County, TX

Title: Little snow has fallen in the Lake Tahoe area of California, leading ski resorts to close, recreationists to find alternative activities
Description: The six chairlifts at Donner Ski Ranch were not running, and the lodge was closed because there was too little snow on the ground.  Soda Springs ski area and two cross-country areas, Royal Gorge and Tahoe XC were also closed.The Sugar Bowl ski resort was open, but only about 25 of the 100 runs were useable.  Fewer skiers were visiting with the thin snowpack, so the parking lot was relatively empty.  Only one restaurant and lodge was open, and just one of the four cash registers was in use.  The spokesman for the Sugar Bowl said that they will continue with the snowmaking operations to improve the runs that were currently open.  The ski patrol was also out with hockey sticks to slap rocks off the trail.Some small number of visitors who made their reservations months ago continued to trickle through, but resort managers and staff worried about the trickle drying up.  In a couple of weeks, there may be far fewer visitors.  Young people have been laid off from their jobs at the ski resorts because there were not enough customers, due to the low snowfall.  Royal Gorge just closed Jan. 7, but will reopen when the area gets a foot of snow.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Jan. 8, 2014.Little snow has fallen in the Lake Tahoe area, leading recreationists to do more mountain biking, hiking, beach walking and sunbathing than skiing.  The mountains are largely brown, ski resorts are not fully open and the dry winter is taking a toll on local businesses’ bottom line.  Even Donner Summit has only thin patches of snow and the Donner Ski Ranch was empty.  A few skiers made their way downhill, despite the rocks and bare dirt.The lack of snow cut into business at most resorts and equipment rental shops, but many people who had planned their vacations months ago were making the best of it and skiing anyway.  The ski and board repairs needed after hitting rocks were beneficial for the local shops.  A bicycle rental shop in Truckee was busy, although the activity is not usually popular in January.  Sales of chai Manhattans were down at a bar in Homewood, given the poor snow conditions at the Homewood Mountain Ski Resort.  Some vacationers have chosen to go home early, due to the lack of snow, stated a bartender.  Las Vegas Sun (Nev.), Jan. 4, 2014
Categories: Business & Industry, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Truckee, CA, Placer County, CA, Tahoe City, CA

Title: Number of Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta fish drop precipitously during California drought
Description: Populations of five species of fish in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta dropped dramatically during the past year of drought when freshwater flows failed to support their habitat.  The affected fish include the Delta smelt, longfin smelt, American shad, threadfin shad and striped bass.  Delta smelt numbers nosedived to record lows in the fall fish survey.  Water diversions for humans and pollution, habitat loss and invasive species also affect fish counts.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Jan. 14, 2015
Places: Contra Costa County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Solano County, CA

Title: Dry winter meant grape vines needed irrigation near Temecula, California
Description: The dry winter led Temecula wineries to water their dormant grape vines, during a time of year when seasonal precipitation usually meets the vines’ water needs.  No one can remember ever needing to water during the winter like this.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), July 22, 2014
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Pool demolition in Los Angeles County, California
Description: A pool demolition company was thriving in Southern California as numerous homeowners opted to get rid of their pools.  From 2010 to 2012, Los Angeles County issued fewer than 21 permits during a single year, but since then, 53 permits were pulled in 2013, 55 permits pulled in 2014 and more than 60 permits pulled in 2015.Long Beach Gazettes (Calif.), April 9, 2016
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Long Beach, CA

Title: Many days of blowing dirt in South Plains of Texas
Description: The South Plains of Texas has endured 29 days of blowing dirt since the start of 2014, with more such days forecast.  During the same period in 2013, there were only 14 days of blowing dirt.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014
Places: Bailey County, TX, Borden County, TX, Castro County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: High demand for well drilling permits in San Mateo County, California
Description: The number of well drilling permits in San Mateo County was nearly twice the number in 2014 as in 2013, according to county records.  A well driller from Santa Cruz reported that this was the busiest he had been in decades.  He was doing his best to get through the jobs to help the next person needing water and saw numerous water trucks making deliveries.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Nov. 16, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Mateo County, CA

Title: Cotton, well production down in Texas' Rolling Plains
Description: Cotton production in Texas’ Rolling Plains in 2015 was down to about one-quarter to one-half of that of an average year.  The gin manager of the Rhineland gin said that he expected this year’s bale count to be about 26,650, in comparison with years prior to the drought when average production ranged from 50,000 to 100,000 bales.  Cotton production was down because intense drought caused farmers to draw heavily from their irrigation wells, and well production has not yet recovered to pre-drought levels.Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Jan. 19, 2016
Places: Baylor County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Knox County, TX

Title: Drought and the olive fruit fly reduced the California olive harvest by about one-third
Description: Drought and the olive fruit fly reduced the California olive harvest by about one-third in 2014.  The harvest began about a week earlier than usual.  Low humidity in December, related to the drought, allowed temperatures to fall and freeze many of the buds.  An olive grower in Marin County imported organic extra virgin olive oil from Italy to be sure to have enough for all of their customers.  The grower’s 18,000 Tuscan olive trees were pruned severely last winter to reduce water needs and were expected to have a lighter yield.  The ranch’s estate oils can be purchased only online this year, instead of in stores, due to the smaller crop.Some small-scale olive growers in the Seka Hills in the Capay Valley did not produce enough olives to bring them in for milling.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Oct. 24, 2014
Places: California, Butte County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Kings County, CA, Marin County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Low cotton prices, low cotton production hurting farmers in the Big Country of Texas
Description: Low prices for cotton and reduced cotton production due to drought has hurt farmers significantly in the Big Country of Texas.  A cotton ginner reported that most of the cotton in the region was shredded because cotton production was so low.  With less cotton to gin, the gin brought in fewer workers, who will certainly miss the paycheck.  KTAB TV 32 & KRBC TV 9 (Abilene, Texas), Dec. 16, 2014
Places: Brown County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coke County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Comanche County, TX, Eastland County, TX, Erath County, TX, Fisher County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Howard County, TX, Jones County, TX, Kent County, TX, Knox County, TX, Mills County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Runnels County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Shackelford County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Stonewall County, TX, Taylor County, TX, Throckmorton County, TX

Title: Sonoma County, California, reduction in hydroelectric power, squirrels not hibernating, ranchers feeding livestock due to lack of grass
Description: Calendar year 2013 is the lowest annual rainfall I've ever recorded in 39 years living here. So far no rainfall in 2014.Hydroelectric power minimal or rationed.Some neighbors completely out of water. Vegetation showing signs of stress. Squirrels not hibernating. Red flag warnings issued in January. Water stored in reservoirs nearly depleted. Mendocino county issued drought warning. Extended cold damaged water systems and plants.Ranchers feeding livestock due to lack of grass.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Cazadero 6.9 WNW on 1/8/2014
Categories: Agriculture, Energy, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Water use in the Coachella Valley of California
Description: The amount of groundwater pumped in the Coachella Valley decreased only 0.8 percent during the first eight months of this year, compared to last year’s water use.  Water conservation improved over the last five years, but has remained steady since 2011.  Groundwater use between January and August rose by 3.9 percent over 2010.  More water has been pumped from the Coachella Valley aquifer than has returned to the ground, leaving the water table declining.Although water use by customers of the Desert Water Agency was down 10 percent and 11 percent in August and September, water use rose 0.7 percent in October, compared to last year’s figures.Some of the state’s lowest water rates can be found in Coachella Valley, and some of the highest per capita water use also exists there, showed data from the State Water Resources Control Board.  The Myoma Dunes Mutual Water Company, serving 6,000 people in Bermuda Dunes and vicinity, had a per capita water use of 521 gallons daily in October, nearly five times the state average of 109 gallons daily.  Average per capita use for the Coachella Valley Water District and the Desert Water Agency was 337 gallons per day and 322 gallons per day, respectively.  Those water agencies assert that the volume used was high due to the presence of winter residents who are not counted among the population served by the water districts.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Dec. 4, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Wild black bear activity high in Yosemite National Park in California
Description: Wild black bears have been stirring up trouble in Yosemite National Park this year, likely due to drought reducing the amount of berries and other bear foods available. Accounts of bears entering campgrounds and parking lots for food have risen 35 percent, compared to last year, for the second increase of this nature during the last three straight dry years. Rangers have been working hard to warn visitors about securing food, toothpaste and sunscreen so bears cannot access the items.There were 120 bear incidents in 2013, and 154 so far this year.ABC News, Oct. 25, 2014
Places: Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Crops, livestock continue to be affected by drought in Young County, Texas
Description: Drought is persistent in Young County.  High temperatures and strong winds continue to impact farmers and ranchers across the county.  The few rains that have fallen have been followed by consistent winds as high as 30 mph.  Municipalities have instituted drought restrictions limiting water usage, and lake levels are below 50% capacity and livestock tanks are virtually empty.  Ranchers continue to cull herds since the native and improved grasses are still not growing at a rate that will sustain livestock.  Because the winter wheat crop progressed faster than normal rates due to the early rise in temperatures, the crop headed out before maturity; the subsequent occurrence of some below-freezing nights and hail led to a failure of almost 80% of the crop.   Very few farmers are choosing to plant spring hay crops because of the drought conditions.From a USDA employee in Graham, Texas, on May 16, 2014.
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Limited water supplies for the Turlock Irrigation District in California
Description: Drought led to reduced irrigation supplies in the Turlock Irrigation District in 2014 when farmers received just 20 inches of water.The Ceres Courier (Turlock, Calif.), March 24, 2021
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Stanislaus County, CA

Title: Low stream flows prevented coho salmon from reaching native streams in California until late January
Description: All coastal California creeks from the Golden Gate to Monterey Bay were blocked by sandbars, due to drought and low flow, until late January and February.  Not many coho were able to get to their native streams.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), June 24, 2014
Places: Monterey County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA

Title: Baby squirrels, other wildlife need food in Northern California
Description: Numerous hungry baby squirrels were falling out of their nests in parts of Northern California as they sought food.  Wildlife experts say this is just one more way years of drought are hurting wildlife.  The Gold Country Wildlife Rescue, a nonprofit volunteer organization in Loomis, has been overwhelmed with orphaned baby squirrels and experienced an increase of 120 percent in the number of baby squirrels needing care.  In 2013, they took in 1,800 baby squirrels, but so far in 2014, they have received more than 2,200 baby squirrels.Other animals, too, have been on the move in search of food and water.  More bears and deer have been struck and killed by vehicles on mountain highways, according to the California Department of Fish and Wildlife.  The director of the California Department of Transportation said that there were an “unprecedented” 23 collisions between animals and drivers on Highway 50 and Interstate 80 in Northern California.  Mating season and wildfire-damaged vegetation have also caused animals to travel further to find food.  More deer have been killed this year than in 2013, according to the California Roadkill Observation System.  The co-director of the Road Ecology Center said that drought was probably the reason more deer have died this year.Drivers are cautioned to be on watch for wildlife near the road.Los Angeles Times, Nov. 25, 2014
Places: Alameda County, CA, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Butte County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Del Norte County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Inyo County, CA, Kings County, CA, Lake County, CA, Lassen County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Merced County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Mono County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Persistent drought affecting farmers, water supplies in Young County, Texas
Description: Drought remains persistent in Young County.  July rains did bring temporary relief to farmers and ranchers in the area, but a rise in temperatures and consistent winds have dramatically reduced soil moisture, leaving grass growth stagnant and top soil dry and powdery.  Row crop farmers are already considering whether or not planting of winter wheat will make a viable crop.  The City of Graham has announced emergency Stage 5 water restrictions and that lake levels are so low that bulk water sales have been suspended.  Lake Graham has less than 365 days left of water for public use; this restriction affects rural Young County and the cities of Graham, Bryson, Throckmorton and Newcastle.From an FSA employee in Graham, Texas, on August 5, 2014.
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Young County, TX

Title: More vegetation fires than usual in Napa County, California
Description: Napa County has seen 13 vegetation fires in January and February 2014, compared to only two such fires in the same time period in 2013, said the CalFire/Napa County fire captain.  She explained the uptick in fires by saying, “We’re in a severe drought.”Napa Valley Register (Calif.), March 12, 2014
Places: Napa County, CA

Title: Demand for well drilling permits up considerably in Central Valley of California
Description: The demand for water-well permits remained high in Fresno County where 414 permits were issued to farms from the start of the year through July 21, more than twice the number from last year when 179 permits were issued between the start of 2013 and July 2013.In Tulare County, farmers were eager to drill wells, too.  County officials issued 476 permits during the first half of the year, in comparison with the more than 335 permits issued during 2013.  Washington Post, Aug. 1, 2014Well drillers in the Central Valley are very busy as farmers eagerly have wells drilled to provide water for their crops since state and federal water suppliers were offering no water for many farmers this year.  Some well drillers are booked out to one year, so high is the demand for water.  Fresno County officials issued 256 new well permits for agricultural and domestic use in the first three months of 2014, which is more than double the number of permits issued by this time last year.The number of permits to dig agricultural wells in Tulare County tripled to 245.Similarly in Kern County, the number of wells for agricultural use more than quadrupled to 63.Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 13, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Black bears active in Reno, Nevada, Lake Tahoe
Description: More black bears than usual visited Reno in search of a meal in 2014,  the second busiest year in terms of black bear activity and encroachment into residential areas.  The Nevada Department of Wildlife had gotten more than 500 bear complaints by November.  The lack of berries, grasses and other natural foods for bears was scarce in the woods as the area coped with its third straight year of drought.  Productive fruit trees in the foothills attracted lots of hungry bears, and urban ponds and other water sources provided a welcome drink.  Numerous bears followed the Truckee River right into downtown Reno.The Department of Wildlife in 2014 relocated, euthanized or recovered (after being hit by vehicles) 70 bears.Reno Gazette-Journal (Nev.), Nov. 7, 2014Black bears caused a commotion in Reno as they wandered into residential areas looking for food.  The drought dried up natural food sources for the bruins, leaving them to look elsewhere for a meal as they ate roughly 30,000 calories daily in preparation for hibernation.  Hungry bears were also very active in the Lake Tahoe area.CBS (New York), Oct. 22, 2014
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV, Reno, NV

Title: Recreation affected by low level of Folsom Lake, California
Description: Sailboat owners were savoring their time on Folsom Lake, knowing that the receding water level will cut short the sailing season this year.  During this year’s Camellia Cup, fewer large sailboats entered as fewer sailors braved the shallow waters.  The commodore of the Folsom Lake Yacht Club said that a lot of people who own large boats opted to crew on smaller boats while the lake is low.  It was challenging to launch a large keeled boat even at the low water ramp.  “By the time you get it in the water, you’re worn out before you can go sailing,” said the owner of an Olson 25.The water elevation was 421.36 feet for the race, or 55 percent of capacity, according to the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation.  Back in January, the lake elevation was 370 feet, said the owner of a Lido 14, and on Feb. 6, the water elevation was 357.06 feet, by the state Department of Water Resources’ measure.  Low water levels in January and February kept sailors from training for the Camellia Cup.The low water level also affected powerboat owners, water skiers and water boarders because a speed limit of 5 mph is imposed on all water craft when the lake level falls below 400 feet.In addition, fewer people have become members of the Folsom Lake Yacht Club, due to the low water level.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 27, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: Impending water rate hike for Desert Water Agency in Palm Springs, California
Description: The Desert Water Agency Board of Directors unanimously approved a rate hike which could result in a nearly 80 percent increase to its customers’ water bills over the next four years if all subsequent rate hikes are approved.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Dec. 15, 2016The Desert Water Agency was soon to vote on a rate hike which would lead to an increase of nearly 80 percent over the next four years.  DWA officials say the rate hike was needed to cover the utility company’s operational costs and to replace severely aging water lines responsible for hundreds of water leaks just this year.  DWA’s spokeswoman explained that the drought also contributed to the need for the rate increase because customers used less water, decreasing revenue, while the costs of operating the water service have not gone down.  During the fiscal years 2014-2015 and 2015-2016, DWA lost about $7.6 million.Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Nov. 28, 2016
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA, Cathedral City, CA, Palm Springs, CA

Title: Farmers in the El Paso's Lower Valley in Texas received less than 40 percent of full allotments
Description: Farmers in the El Paso's Lower Valley had a hard year in 2014 and received just 18 acre-inches, rather than their four acre-feet allotments.  Farmers with pecan trees, which cannot go without water, were in particularly dire straits because they had to find water for their orchards.  A Tornillo pecan grower was hoping and praying for water to sustain his trees and said he would be in serious trouble without water.The general manager of the El Paso County Water Improvement District No. 1 said it was very difficult to tell farmers that little water was available for irrigation, especially since allocations in 2013 were a record low.  The meager ration was hardest for pecan growers who had little option but to get long-unused wells functioning again.  Well water quality is poor.  To add insult to injury, irrigators must pay annually for water from the Rio Grande River, even if they do not receive the water.  El Paso Times (Texas), Dec. 14, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Rush on well permits in Stanislaus County, California
Description: More than 500 new water well permits have been issued in Stanislaus County in 2014 as wells continue to go dry amid an historic drought.  More than 100 well permits were issued in October alone, according to county records, because word got out that future well permits may require that new wells would not cause “undesirable results” on groundwater, such as affecting a neighbor’s well.  Those who receive new well permits before Nov. 24 do not have to prove that the new well will not affect other nearby wells.  Most new wells were in the Oakdale area.Modesto Bee (Calif.), Nov. 23, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Stanislaus County, CA, Oakdale, CA

Title: Water quality changes create challenges for beer brewers in Escondido, California
Description: Beer brewers in Escondido noted the challenge that different water sources brought to the process of beer making during years of drought.  Water from the Colorado River and other water sources all require unique processing methods to make it suitable for brewing, but using treated wastewater takes away the variability and requires the addition of a few salts to make it perfect for brewing.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), March 20, 2017
Places: San Diego County, CA, Escondido, CA

Title: Pasture and forage affected in Bandera County, Texas
Description: Pasture grass and forage for cattle/calves is disappearing rapidly, resulting in extra expenses for hay and minerals to supplement feed for the livestock in order to keep the cows and their calves healthy.From Bandera County, Texas, on March 21, 2018
Places: Bandera County, TX

Title: California wine grape tonnage down in 2014
Description: Wine grape tonnage has been lower during years of drought, although grape quality is typically very good.  In Napa and Sonoma counties, the 2014 wine grape harvest tonnage was 11 percent lower than 2013.  In Alameda County, the 2014 wine grape harvest was 54 percent lower than 2013.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Sept. 1, 2015
Places: Alameda County, CA, Napa County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Drought hurting California almond growers
Description: The drought has presented serious challenges to California almond farmers who must find water for their trees and have resorted to drilling new wells, depending on salty groundwater or bulldozing trees.   The U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service and California agriculture officials sent surveys to 688 almond growers, 458 of whom filled out and returned the surveys.Survey results showed that almost 70 percent of almond growers have only groundwater to use for irrigation this year—no surface water or canal water.  Roughly 23 percent drilled new wells, an expensive option, while 32 percent improved existing wells.  Nearly 75 percent of almond growers are using groundwater with a higher salt content than is recommended for almond trees.  Growers often try to use groundwater and less salty surface water, but this year, there is no surface water to be had.  Salt can accumulate in almond trees and harm or kill them.  Almond trees suffering from salt build-up often see smaller nut size, reduced growth and the potential for smaller than usual crops in future years.  The U.S. Department of Agriculture forecast a 2.1 billion pound almond harvest in California this year, but the survey revealed that 9 percent of growers bulldozed trees for lack of water or suitable water.  Many almond growers cut back their acreage as well.  Growers with at least 600 acres reduced their operations by 17 percent.  Overall, California almond growers eliminated 38 percent of their acreage.  Almonds are one of the largest crops in California, covering 860,000 acres mostly in the San Joaquin Valley.  Almonds are the main crop in Fresno County, worth $1.1 billion in 2013.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Sept. 12, 2014
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Caruthers, CA, Glenn County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Solano County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Stanislaus County, California, wells running dry, ranchers feeding hay due to lack of grass
Description: My area has been experiencing very serious drought conditions since January 2013.  After two preceding dry years, the total rainfall here for calendar year 2013 was less than 4", compared to a normal of about 17".  Rainfall here is officially measured from July 1 to June 30 - so since 7/1/2013 we have had less than 2" of rain and none is in the forecast at least until early February.  Local newspaper reports that several residential wells have run dry and some of the larger almond orchards have installed numerous deep wells (500' or more) and the local newspaper says this is causing the water table to decline significantly, and in some areas is causing the ground to subside, especially in Merced County, 50 miles to my South.  Many ranchers in the area report they are feeding hay to cattle as there is not enough grass to sustain their herds.  The hills are still brown at a time of year when they are normally green.  The landscape looks more like it normally does in September than January.    The major reservoir that supplies our local irrigation district is only about 40% of capacity now, and snowpack in the mountains above it is reported to be only about 20% of normal for the date.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Knights Ferry 5.2 WSW on 1/22/2014
Places: Stanislaus County, CA

Title: Subsidence still occurring in California's San Joaquin Valley; California Department of Water Resources to strive for laws to limit pumping
Description: California officials intend to seek new laws to limit drilling because parts of the Central Valley were subsiding and threatening the canal system.  They would like the Legislature to give the state Department of Water Resources authority to designate zones where pumping is limited, stated Jeanine Jones, a California Department of Water Resources manager.Merced Sun-Star (Calif.), Feb. 9, 2017New NASA radar satellite maps prepared for the California Department of Water Resources indicated that land in the San Joaquin Valley continued to sink rapidly, endangering state and federal aqueducts and flood control structures.  “The rates of San Joaquin Valley subsidence documented since 2014 by NASA are troubling and unsustainable,” stated DWR Director William Croyle. “Subsidence has long plagued certain regions of California. But the current rates jeopardize infrastructure serving millions of people. Groundwater pumping now puts at risk the very system that brings water to the San Joaquin Valley. The situation is untenable.”A NASA report prepared in 2015 for the DWR showed record rates of subsidence in the San Joaquin Valley, notably near Chowchilla and Corcoran, where farmers drew groundwater heavily during drought.  KFRE & KMPH-TV Fox 26 & CW 59 (Fresno, Calif.), Feb. 8, 2017
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Record crop sales in California in 2014
Description: California farmers took in a record $53.5 billion in crop sales in 2014, despite a year of intense drought.  Higher costs for water and other expenses due to drought were greater than sales for some farmers, but clearly some farmers made significant profits and poured them back into almond trees, given the high price for almonds.  More expensive water and other drought-related expenses cost farmers $2 billion in 2014, according to the University of California Davis.Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Feb. 10, 2016
Places: California, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: California Chinook salmon surviving with help
Description: Most of the existing California Chinook salmon were products of state and federal agencies’ fish hatcheries and were trucked downstream to be released during the past years of drought, and would not have survived otherwise. Salmon grow, spawn and die in three-year cycles, making three consecutive years of drought challenges all the populations can stand before going extinct. During 2014 and 2015, millions of young salmon were raised in hatcheries to keep fall-run Chinook salmon thriving. Winter-run Chinook salmon received a federal listing in 2015 as one of the eight U.S. species most in danger of imminent extinction after drought depleted California’s rivers in 2014 and 2015, leaving river water too warm and low to sustain the fish.  Federal authorities announced intentions to formally review their management of key state waterways and reservoirs concerning the survival of native species.Associated Press (New York), Sept. 4, 2016
Places: California, Alameda County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Del Norte County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Orange County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Ventura County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Water restrictions in Sacramento County, California
Description: The Sacramento County Water Agency encouraged customers to curb water use by 20 percent to conserve water during the drought.  Officials in Folsom told residents to reduce their water use by 20 percent and to water outdoors no more than twice per week.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), Jan. 5, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sacramento County, CA

Title: The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection suspended burn permits in central coastal California
Description: The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection suspended burn permits in central coastal California, due to dry conditions and a high number of wildfires for this time of year.  Burn permit holders may not conduct burns in Alameda, Contra Costa, Santa Clara, San Mateo and Santa Cruz counties and parts of Stanislaus and San Joaquin counties.  San Mateo Daily Journal (Calif.), Dec. 31, 2013
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA

Title: Grass dried up for dairy cattle in Marin County, California
Description: An organic milk producer in Marshall began seeing drought effects in December 2013 when his grass dried up.  He expressed frustration in March 2014, noting that the pasture still offered nothing for the cattle.  The producer worries about increased costs and that alternative feed will affect the quality of the cows’ milk.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 20, 2014
Places: Marin County, CA

Title: Only two boat ramps open at Lake Oroville in northern California
Description: Low water at Lake Oroville caused the closing of all boat ramps, except the lower spillway boat ramp, stage two and the Bidwell Canyon Boat Launch stage three ramp.  The ramp at Lime Saddle closed on Dec. 30, but the marina remains open.  The Foreman Creek Lake Access is open for those who can carry their kayaks, canoes or small fishing boats to the water.Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Jan. 23, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA

Title: Litigation over water rights in Coachella Valley in Southern California
Description: In 2013, the Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians sued the Coachella Valley Water District and the Desert Water Agency for water rights, saying that the water providers were taking too much water from the aquifer beneath the Coachella Valley.  The lawsuit arose as drought continued to deplete already scarce water resources in the state and was one among several legal disputes taking place in California.  Los Angeles Times, March 31, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Covers for water pits save money and water for hydraulic fracturer in eastern Permian Basin in Texas
Description: A hydraulic fracking company based in Oklahoma City began experimenting in 2013 with the use of pit covers to reduce water lost to evaporation.  With drought being an ongoing concern, hydraulic frackers, which typically use 4 million gallons of water per well, strive to conserve and protect their water supplies.  Although covers can cost from $150,000 to $350,000, businesses can recover the cost after two to four months of use, according to a senior superintendent for Devon Energy Corp.’s operations in the east Permian Basin area in Texas.  Devon uses covers on 24 of its 39 waters pits there.  In the long run, the covers can result in savings of millions of dollars and millions of gallons of water.  NewsOK.com (Oklahoma City, Okla.), Sept. 16, 2014
Places: Oklahoma City, OK, Borden County, TX, Crockett County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Garza County, TX, Glasscock County, TX, Howard County, TX, Irion County, TX, Kent County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Martin County, TX, Midland County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Reagan County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Sterling County, TX, Tom Green County, TX, Upton County, TX

Title: Aerial firefighters remained on alert in California
Description: Aerial firefighters remained on alert in California during what is normally the state’s wet season since dry warm weather has prolonged the fire season.  Rogers Helicopters, based in Fresno, got an exclusive contract extension from the U.S. Forest Service (USFS) for the use of a Bell 212 helicopter, which was stationed in Santa Maria from Dec. 24 through Jan. 6 and then on a day-by-day basis thereafter.  A Portland-based helicopter business was also offering its services to Cal Fire and USFS.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Jan. 8, 2014
Places: Monterey County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA

Title: Yuba County, California, farmers needing to irrigate crops
Description: Have received much below normal rainfall so far this winter. Began irrigating my walnut orchard this week to keep soil moisture up for young trees. This is not a normal occurrence in my area. Have also noted other farmers in my region irrigating in recent weeks.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Marysville 5.0 N on 12/23/2013
Places: Yuba County, CA

Title: California grass-fed beef producers struggling to stick with business model
Description: Marin Sun Farms, a 100 percent grass-fed beef producer, began feeding grain to the cattle several months ago because drought has severely limited the amount of grazing land in the area, according to the company’s founder.  If the company did not shift to feeding grain, for lack of pasture, the only alternative would have been to go out of business.  Without good rain in the next few months, most of their cattle will be eating grass, hay and grain, instead of just grass.A producer of organic grass-fed beef for the meat company, Belcampo, may truck 2,000 head of cattle to the Dakotas or Montana for the winter since there was inadequate grazing nearby.  The cost of scarce organic hay for the cattle is about $295 per ton, or 9 percent higher than last year, as numerous producers scramble to buy the hay.  The retail cost of the organic grass-fed beef rose by 10 percent as it became more costly and difficult to maintain the grass-fed business model, but the owner is determined to stick with it.  The owner of Eel River Organic Beef in Humboldt County has been selling cattle weighing 800 to 900 pounds, rather than 1,050 pounds because there isn’t enough grass to put the weight on the cattle.  He loses $200 to $300 per animal.  The financial loss hurts, but the owner is determined to save the brand.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Feb. 21, 2014
Places: Humboldt County, CA, Marin County, CA

Title: Ski resorts near Fresno, California suffering from lack of snow
Description: Less than two feet of snow has fallen at China Peak, allowing the ski resort to open only four of seven lifts and a few runs for about 12 percent of total operations.  Hardcore snowboarders were skiing anyway.Nearby at Badger Pass Ski Area, the Nordic Center opened on Dec. 20 for snowshoeing and cross-country skiing, but the lack of snow caused forced it to close a week later.  The bike rentals have been available to offer something for visitors to do since there was little snow and ice.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), Jan. 8, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA, Lakeshore, CA, Mariposa County, CA

Title: The Squaw Valley Ski Resort near Lake Tahoe partially open, snowpack improving
Description: The Squaw Valley Ski Resort received 10 inches of snow, enough to open more lifts and trails so that 15 of the 30 lifts and 32 of the 170 trails were open.  Drought and low snowfall has kept the ski resort only partially open this winter.  The snowpack in the Tahoe Basin was 25 percent of normal.Elko Daily Free Press (Nev.), Feb. 3, 2014
Places: Placer County, CA

Title: Meager snowfall kept trails, ski lifts closed at Heavenly Mountain Resort in California
Description: Additional snowfall allowed 15 more trails to open at Heavenly Mountain Resort on Feb. 1 as a welcome storm left about 2 feet of snow.  Thanks to the new snow, about 40 of the resort’s 97 trails and 24 of the 29 ski lifts were finally in use.  Low snowfall kept trails and lifts closed earlier in the season because the snowpack in the Tahoe Basin was 25 percent of normal.Elko Daily Free Press (Nev.), Feb. 3, 2014
Places: El Dorado County, CA

Title: West Bishop (California) wells, ponds drying up
Description: Shallow ground water wells, some that went down only 30 feet, have gone dry. Many water ditches and ponds in West Bishop had dried up this past summer. The Department of Water and Power believes it may be due to the lack of re-charge affecting the water table.From a NOAA employee in Las Vegas, Nevada, on December 28, 2013; http://www.sierrawave.net/27831/west-bishop-wells-run-dry/
Places: Inyo County, CA, West Bishop, CA

Title: The absence of wind and rain allowed particulate levels to climb in Sacramento and the San Joaquin Valley in California
Description: The absence of wind and rain allowed particulate levels to climb in Sacramento and the San Joaquin Valley, leading the Sacramento Metropolitan Air Quality Management District to issue no-burn warnings for Sacramento County on Dec. 16 and 17.  KCRA-TV NBC 3 Sacramento (Calif.), Dec. 16, 2013
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Pacific Gas & Electric received permission from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to cut releases from Lake Pillsbury into the Eel River in California
Description: Pacific Gas & Electric wants to reduce water releases from Scott Dam to the minimum level allowed in a critically dry year.  If the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approves the request, PG & E can limit releases to just 20 cubic feet per second from Scott Dam, 5 cfs to the East Branch of the Russian River, and 25 cfs to the Eel River below Cape Horn Dam.Ukiah Daily Journal (Calif.), Jan. 16, 2014Pacific Gas & Electric received permission from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to cut releases from Lake Pillsbury into the Eel River from 100 cubic feet per second to just 20 cfs through the end of January 2014 to conserve water.  PG & E may also cut the flow of water through a tunnel from Pillsbury Lake through a power turbine and into the Russian River above Lake Mendocino from 35 cfs to only 5 cfs, withholding valuable recharge water for Lake Mendocino.  Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), Dec. 15, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Lake County, CA, Mendocino County, CA

Title: Big Sur fire in Monterey County, California
Description: The Big Sur fire had scorched 1 1/3 square miles through the evening of Dec. 18 and was 74 percent contained, according to the U.S Forest Service.  St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Mo.), Dec. 19, 2013A late fall wildfire consumed a little over a square mile and more than a dozen homes in Los Padres National Forest in the Big Sur region and led to the evacuation of roughly 100 people.  Twenty-two buildings were destroyed, including 14 or so homes, but no injuries were reported.  While Big Sur averaged nearly 45 inches of rain between 1981 and 2010, only 7 inches of rain have fallen in 2013 for just 16 percent of normal precipitation.  Las Vegas Sun (Nev.), Dec. 18, 2013
Places: Monterey County, CA

Title: Thirty-two communities or water systems in south Texas have restrictions on water use
Description: Thirty-two cities or water suppliers in the Rio Grande Valley were under voluntary or mandatory water restrictions, due to low reservoirs.  Restrictions were in effect for seven public water suppliers In Cameron County, 13 in Hidalgo County, six in Starr County, four in Zapata County and two in Willacy County.  There are emergency restrictions in three public water systems, indicating a water supply  that could be exhausted in 45 to 180 days.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Dec. 15, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: The Sonoma County Water Agency in California began to reduce flows from Lake Mendocino into the Russian River
Description: The Sonoma County Water Agency began to reduce flows from Lake Mendocino into the Russian River in recent days and has permission to reduce flows to 75 cubic feet per second.  The district intends to request permission from the State Water Resources Control Board to reduce flows further.  Lake Mendocino contained about 30 percent of capacity, and the Russian River flowed at 115 cfs at Healdsburg on Dec. 13. Less than 8 inches of rain have fallen in Santa Rosa since the start of the year, although normal rainfall is about 33 inches.  Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), Dec. 15, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Mendocino County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Many ranchers in San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties, California are on the verge of running out of cattle feed
Description: Many ranchers in San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties are on the verge of running out of cattle feed and may need to think about selling since the lack of rain has left pastures brown.  One rancher, who owns a livestock trading company, estimated that there were 50 percent fewer cattle in San Luis Obispo County as ranchers culled cattle for lack of pasture, for a potential loss of $50 million in annual revenue.Hay and alfalfa prices were 30 percent higher than they were two years ago.  KSBY-TV San Luis Obispo (Calif.), Dec. 11, 2013
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA

Title: Grazing land in Butte County, California was brown from the lack of rain
Description: Grazing land in Butte County was brown from the lack of rain and did not offer the grazing that can normally be found in the valley during the winter.  Ranchers may need to purchase expensive feed for their cattle.  Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Dec. 11, 2013
Places: Butte County, CA

Title: Hay supplies have been low in Texas after years of drought
Description: Hay supplies have been low in Texas after years of drought, but hay growers in McLennan County finally had a good hay season this fall.  A Texas AgriLife extension agent noted that Bermuda grass production was down, presumably due to drought-stressed roots.  Hay prices were still somewhat high in Texas, and supplies were selling out quickly.  Hay and Forage Grower (Minneapolis, Minn.), Dec. 10, 2013
Places: McLennan County, TX

Title: 11th consecutive “Spare the Air” alert in the Bay Area, California
Description: The Bay Area Air Quality Management District issued the 11th consecutive “Spare the Air” alert on Dec. 18, setting a record for consecutive days with poor air quality.  On Spare the Air days, it is illegal to burn wood, manufactured logs or other solid fuels indoors or outside in Alameda, Contra Costa, Marin, Napa, San Francisco, San Mateo, Santa Clara and parts of Solano and Sonoma counties.  The lack of wind and rain has allowed the concentration of particulate matter in the air to climb.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Dec. 17, 2013
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Low water makes boat ramps unusable at Indian Valley Lake in Lake County, California
Description: Boat ramps were not useable at Indian Valley Lake due to low water levels.  The reservoir was more than 100 feet low.  Lakeport Lake County Record-Bee (Calif.), Dec. 4, 2013
Places: Lake County, CA

Title: Humboldt County, California, wells going dry
Description: Many neighbors here on Kneeland Mountain are experiencing their water wells going dry, especially shallow or ground water wells.  We are lucky as our well is at 218 feet and seems to be producing normally.  The water delivery service here has been very busy filling tanks.  Pete Caminata, who services many of the water wells on Kneeland says he has quite a few clients who are in trouble.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Kneeland 0.4 NNW on 1/23/2014
Places: Humboldt County, CA

Title: Ranchers in Sonoma County, California buying hay, selling livestock
Description: Sonoma County ranchers were beginning buy and feed hay early and sell livestock because there was little to no grass for the animals to graze on, as there normally is at this time of year.  Some stock ponds were drying up, and may force some ranchers to haul water.A sheep rancher planted grass seed into dry soil and saw little of it germinate.  He purchased hay for his sheep since the grass largely failed to grow when the sheep would normally have plenty of grass to eat.  He has sold some of the weaker sheep and was planning to sell up to a third of his 400 ewes.  A cattle rancher with roughly 300 cattle northwest of Calistoga reported that a spring which she relies upon for domestic water went dry.  She pays $175 every week and a half to have more water trucked to her home.  Her pastures were brown and nearly barren, leading her to feed her cattle twice the amount of hay she would normally feed in early December.  Her pastures are usually green in mid-November.  A Valley Ford neighbor was also feeding more hay to his livestock than usual, due to the lack of grass.A rancher with roughly 1,600 cattle near Two Rock was feeding hay also because he has no grass for the livestock.  He worries about how much longer his ponds will hold out for the cattle.  Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), Dec. 2, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Calistoga, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Some residents on the North Coast of California are preparing for a dry year by purchasing water storage tanks
Description: Some residents on the North Coast of California are preparing for a dry year by purchasing water storage tanks.  Sales of water storage tanks at a home improvement store in Ukiah rose 50 percent in December, compared to the previous year.  Water conservations effort picked up considerably in May and June 2013.Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), Jan. 12, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Mendocino County, CA, Ukiah, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Santa Rosa, CA

Title: Groundwater, well levels remain low in Monterey County, California
Description: Two Monterey County reservoirs were dried up by drought in 2013 and have not fully recharged, leaving area groundwater levels and wells levels lower than usual, attested the chief executive of Braga Fresh Family Farms.The New York Times, April 20, 2014
Places: Monterey County, CA, Salinas, CA

Title: El Dorado County, California, ski area closing due to lack of snow
Description: Absolutely zero snow at this reporting station. Very odd for March. Usually we have 4 to 6 feet on the ground. The local ski area is closing this weekend ending dozens of jobs. Mountain biking is already picking up.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Tahoma .5 S on 3/18/2014
Places: El Dorado County, CA

Title: Drought exacerbated air quality issues in the San Joaquin Valley in California
Description: The San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District cannot achieve a key federal air standard after the unusually dry 2013-14 winter brought a lengthy episode of stagnant air and high levels of soot and other microscopic debris.  The district’s governing board has requested that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency postpone the deadline until 2019.Fresno Bee (Calif.), Sept. 27, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Coho salmon possibly extinct in Muir Woods in Marin County, California
Description: Coho salmon that typically swim up Redwood Creek into Muir Woods did not appear in 2014 and may be nearing extinction.  No salmon eggs were found in Muir Woods this past winter, and no baby coho were seen this summer.  Biologists thought the 2014 generation was extinct, but that suspicion had not yet been confirmed.  Officials blamed decades of environmental pollution, habitat degradation and drought for the fishes’ disappearance.  To preserve the genetically unique coho population, 105 juvenile were taken from the creek and moved to a hatchery in August.  The coho should have already migrated to the ocean by August, but low water levels may have prevented the fish from getting to the ocean.The spawning run is anticipated to be dismal this winter, as well.  Fewer than 10 fish returned to spawn in five of the past seven years, excluding 2014.  Just eight spawning coho were seen in Redwood Creek in 2011 and 2013.  The 8.9-square-mile Redwood Creek watershed is the historic home of the southernmost continually returning natural population of coho salmon in the Western United States.The Bulletin (Bend, Ore.), Nov. 30, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Marin County, CA

Title: Rancher in Bailey County, Texas sold most of his cattle herd
Description: A Bailey County rancher sold 290 cattle and kept only 85 cattle from his herd as drought prevented pasture and corn from growing well.    High feed prices made profit nearly nonexistent.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Nov. 30, 2013
Places: Bailey County, TX

Title: Siskiyou County, California low stream flow reduces power supply
Description: This is the first winter since we built this place in 1995 that we haven't had any pelton wheel supplied power from our intermittent stream. The stream is usually flowing by late October to late November. There are no mushrooms to speak of, either.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Forks of Salmon 1.0 NW on 12/28/2013
Places: Siskiyou County, CA

Title: Drought task force met in Butte County, California
Description: The Butte County Drought Task Force met in November as severe drought persisted in the region.  Groundwater measurements in six wells were at historical lows.  Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Dec. 4, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Oroville, CA

Title: Site around water intake cleared out to allow continued pumping for Olney, Texas
Description: The area around the water intake in Lake Cooper was dug out and deepened to allow Olney, Texas to continue to withdraw water from Lake Cooper, which held 24 percent of its capacity on Nov. 21.  Water from Lake Olney can be used if or when there was no longer enough water in Lake Cooper, but water from Lake Olney contains more silt, making it more expensive and difficult to treat.  Olney still gets water from Lake Kickapoo, just as Wichita Falls does.  Wichita Falls was at stage 4 drought restrictions because its primary water supplies fell to less than 30 percent of capacity.  Olney Enterprise (Texas), Nov. 27, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Young County, TX, Olney, TX

Title: Drought reduces the amount of wetlands in the San Joaquin Valley in California
Description: Drought reduces the amount of wetlands in the San Joaquin Valley because the dry ground soaks up water, shrinking the spatial extent of the wetlands, stated a recreation planner for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.  The refuges receive 100 percent of their requested water even in drought years because a 1992 environmental reform law, the Central Valley Project Improvement Act, gives refuges a higher priority than some farm water.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), Nov. 24, 2013
Places: Merced County, CA

Title: Matagorda Bay, Texas suffering from drought, lack of fresh water inflows
Description: Years of drought and reduced fresh water inflows to Matagorda Bay have allowed the salinity of the bay to climb to unhealthy levels for oysters, shrimp and other aquatic life, reducing their populations.  The lack of fresh water also has limited the bird population at Matagorda Bay, the birding capital of North America.One oysterman stated that this daily hauls were just one-third of the amount of oysters he used to catch prior to the 2011 drought, forcing him to downsize his seafood shops and oyster processing.  Texas Public Radio (San Antonio, Texas), Nov. 20, 2013
Categories: Business & Industry, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Matagorda County, TX

Title: The California Department of Water Resources announced its initial water allocation
Description: Water districts and farmers in California will get up to 5 percent of requested amounts of water from the State Water Project, said the Department of Water Resources.  The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation bumped up allocations for water agencies in the Sacramento Valley from 40 percent to 75 percent, while water customers relying on federal water south of the delta still will not receive any water.  February and March storms brought enough precipitation to allow the water providers to offer some water rather than none, as had been previously forecast. Although the state has upped its water allotment, Mark Cowin, the director of the California Department of Water Resources, asked suppliers not to take the water before Sept. 1.  Washington Post (D.C.), April 19, 2014Water delivery estimates for the State Water Project remain zero percent.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 9, 2014The Jan. 30 snow survey revealed a snowpack of 12 percent of normal, leading the State Water Project to revise its previous water allocation estimate to zero percent.  If this comes to pass, it will be the first time the SWP has not been able to provide any water.  Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), Feb. 2, 2014The California Department of Water Resources announced its initial water allocation of a 5 percent delivery of requested water, based on present reservoir levels.  Water allocations often start low and increase throughout the winter as storms bring snow that eventually fills reservoirs.  Lake Oroville, the largest reservoir belonging to the State Water Project, held just 41 percent of capacity, with a historical average of 66 percent.  The State Water Project provides water to about 25 million Californians via 24 municipal water agencies and to farmers in the southern San Joaquin Valley through five water agencies.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com) (Calif.), Nov. 21, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Alameda County, CA, Butte County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Napa County, CA, Orange County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Yuba City, CA, Tulare County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Cattle ranchers in Butte County, California moved their livestock out of the county earlier than usual because drought caused pasture lands to deteriorate
Description: Butte County cattle ranchers moved their livestock out of Butte County earlier than usual because drought caused pasture lands to deteriorate.  Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), Nov. 19, 2013
Places: Butte County, CA

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority board in central Texas approved an emergency plan allowing them to keep 1.1 million acre-feet of water in the Highland Lakes
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority board approved a plan that would allow them to keep 1.1 million acre-feet of water in the Highland Lakes before sharing water with downstream users.  Previously, Lake Buchanan and Lake Travis had to contain at least 850,000 acre-feet, or 42 percent of capacity, before water would be released, but persistent drought made the board realize that the lakes needed additional time to recover from drought.  The Texas Board of Environmental Quality must approve the plan before it takes effect.Since lakes Buchanan and Travis were at 36 percent of capacity, it seems unlikely the lakes will fill enough to allow rice farmers to receive irrigation water in 2014 for the third consecutive year.  The lack of irrigation water may be the death knell for many rice farmers who were desperately hoping for irrigation water this year.  Matagorda Bay also relies on the Highland Lakes for fresh water inflows to reduce the bay’s salinity for oyster beds and fisheries.The emergency plan also requires municipal water customers to restrict water use.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Nov. 19, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Llano County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Cal Fire officials have kept fire season staffing in San Mateo County through Nov. 25, due to ongoing dangerous fire conditions
Description: Cal Fire officials have kept fire season staffing in San Mateo County through Nov. 25, due to ongoing dangerous fire conditions.  The cost of maintaining readiness to fight fires longer than originally planned is $126,000.  The Division Chief Angela Bernheisel also noted that the fire season staffing could be kept longer if conditions warrant.  SFExaminer.com (Calif.), Nov. 18, 2013
Places: San Mateo County, CA

Title: The mayor of Del Rio strongly opposed a proposed plan to move water from the Edwards-Trinity aquifer in Val Verde County to San Antonio, Texas
Description: The mayor of Del Rio strongly opposed a proposed plan to move water from the Edwards-Trinity aquifer in Val Verde County to San Antonio by 2018.  The V.V. Water Co. proposed to pipe sufficient water to supply 150,000 households yearly, but the mayor feels that such a water transaction would shortchange San Felipe springs, the Del Rio community and the region.  People opposing the proposed plan noted that there was not enough water to recharge the aquifer when rainfall was less than 80 percent of average and that springs and creeks in Val Verde County were presently dry.San Antonio officials are looking at bringing in water from other areas to reduce their drain on the Edwards Aquifer.  My San Antonio.com (Texas), Nov. 18, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Antonio, TX, Val Verde County, TX

Title: Drought hampered the sugar cane crop in south Texas
Description: Drought hampered the sugar cane crop in south Texas, where farmers were hesitant to plant for lack of irrigation water.  Mill experts anticipate the sugar cane crop to be roughly 125,000 tons, or about 17 percent lower than the average harvest of 150,000 tons, for a loss of about $10.5 million.    The president and CEO of RGV Sugar Growers said that it is hard to break even with depressed sugar prices.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Nov. 17, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Tehama County, California, higher energy bill
Description: Energy bill is noticeably higher because of a lack of rain.   Still using well pump/irrigation system to water lawns, shrubs and pasture.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Red Bluff 5.1 NNW on 1/4/2014
Places: Tehama County, CA

Title: Fewer monarch butterflies passing through Texas this fall
Description: Two years of drought and habitat destruction in the Midwest have drastically limited the number of butterflies returning to Mexico to overwinter this year.  A master naturalist and entomology specialist in Victoria, Texas said that of the 300 million monarch butterflies that left Mexico this spring, just 60 million butterflies, or 20 percent of the original butterflies’ progeny, will return to Mexico in the fall.A Texas A&M butterfly expert noted that the number of monarchs leaving Mexico last spring was low, contributing to the small number of butterflies this year.  He heard that there were so few monarchs in Canada that an annual monarch count was cancelled this fall.  Victoria Advocate (Texas), Nov. 11, 2013
Places: Texas, Victoria County, TX

Title: Lake Texoma entered Drought Level 2
Description: Lake Texoma entered Drought Level 2 on Nov. 6 when the lake receded to 612 feet, or 77 percent of conservation pool storage.  The lake’s recreational users are urged to be cautious about shallow areas and submerged hazards.  One boat ramp in Lakeside Public Use area closed, due to low water levels.   Inflows to the lake have been 23 percent of average this year.  North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), Nov. 6, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bryan County, OK, Johnston County, OK, Marshall County, OK, Cooke County, TX, Grayson County, TX

Title: 784 dry domestic wells in Tulare County, California; portable showers coming
Description: Some domestic wells in Tulare County have been dry for as long as one year.  The Tulare County Office of Emergency Services is aware of 784 dry wells in the county and is working out how best to help.  Portable showers will be set up within two weeks.The county would like funds from the recently passed water bond to pay for long-term projects, but those may not reach completion for three to five years.KFSN-TV ABC 30 Frenso/Visalia (Calif.), Nov. 7, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tulare County, CA

Title: The faithful in eastern New Mexico and West Texas had a second day of prayer to give thanks for the rain
Description: The faithful in eastern New Mexico and West Texas had a second day of prayer to give thanks for the rain that has fallen and ameliorated drought in the region.  A Clovis man helped organize the days of prayer and thinks the precipitation that lessened the drought is a “true miracle.”  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Nov. 3, 2013
