Title: California ski resorts closed weeks early
Description: California ski resorts closed weeks early because there was too little snow for winter sports.  The California Ski Industry Assn. reported that there were just 4.9 million ski visits, in comparison with the five-year average of 6.8 million.  Mammoth Mountain, California’s highest elevation, saw 10 percent fewer skiers and snowboarders than the previous winter season.  At the San Bernardino Mountains in Southern California, resorts at Bear Mountain and Snow Summit reported a roughly 20 percent reduction in skiers from the previous season.Los Angeles Times, June 17, 2014
Categories: Business & Industry, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Kern County, CA

Title: Air pollution worsened in California
Description: Air pollution in California has been worse this past year, due to heat and extreme drought.  The drought has led to more temperature inversions, holding pollution near the ground.  Last winter, the San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District saw the worst air pollution in more than 10 years.  During the first week of November 2014, air quality took a dive.Chronic exposure to smog has contributed to thousands of premature deaths each year in California, largely from heart attacks and cardiovascular disease.  Los Angeles Times, Nov. 10, 2014
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Uptick in fire activity in Santa Cruz County, California led Cal Fire to keep extra crew, all-terrain engines on hand during wet season
Description: The increase in the number of wildfires in Santa Cruz County in November and December rose from an average of four or five to 31 fires.The uptick in wildfire activity led Cal Fire on Dec. 28 to begin keeping extra crews and all-terrain engines on hand.  Two fire crews are staffed in Ben Lomond, whereas there are usually none during the wet season.  Santa Cruz Sentinel (Calif.), Dec. 28, 2013
Places: Santa Cruz County, CA

Title: Drought worsened winter air quality in California
Description: Drought and stagnant air combined to push air-quality regulators in the Bay Area of California to issue 30 Spare the Air alerts, or poor air quality advisories, to alert the public when the amount of particulate matter in the air is approaching or is at unhealthy levels.  Spare the Air alerts also result in bans on residential burning.  The only other winter season with as many Spare the Air alerts occurred during the 2006-07 season.The Bay Area district fielded a record number of 5,091 telephoned complaints about neighbors illegally burning.  The district issued 267 citations. The San Joaquin Valley had 66 days with poor air quality, compared to 52 last year.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 7, 2014
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Merced County, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority proposed unprecedented measures to keep water in the depleted Highland Lakes in central Texas
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority has proposed unprecedented measures to keep water in the depleted Highland Lakes in central Texas to allow the lakes to recover from years of drought.LCRA authorities recommend limiting releases for threatened river species, requiring curbs on outdoor watering in Central Texas cities and making it easier to withhold water from rice farmers near the Gulf Coast.  The LCRA wants to increase the amount of water that must be contained in the Highland Lakes before water is released for rice farmers.  Most rice farmers have not received water for the past two years.Lake Travis and Lake Buchanan are part of the Highland Lakes.  The Texas Tribune (Austin, Texas), Nov. 1, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Groundwater becoming depleted in the Central Valley of California
Description: Groundwater is becoming depleted in the Central Valley, forcing farmers to deepen their wells to reach water, or plant crops requiring less water.  The possibility of receiving no irrigation water in 2014 also has many growers preparing their wells for use.  Fresno County was the third largest tomato grower in the state of California, but ranked fifth in 2012 as farmers plant fewer tomatoes, which require a lot of water to grow.  Some well drillers have many jobs lined up and are booked until mid- summer 2014.  KMPH Fox 26 (Fresno, Calif.), Nov. 1, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: The mild, dry weather in the Napa Valley in California has been a boon for the tourist industry
Description: The mild, dry weather in the Napa Valley during what is normally the wet season, has been a boon for the tourist industry because there have been more nice days.  A tasting room manager for Judd’s Hill Winery said they were able to use outdoor space and patio with the warm, dry days.  The owner of Napa Valley Balloons, Inc. also was thrilled for the warm, dry days that permitted more flights than usual for January.  The president and CEO of Visit Napa Valley stated that “anecdotally it seems we are benefiting from Lake Tahoe not having meaningful amounts of snow,”  even though there is no direct evidence linking warm winter weather in Napa Valley to increased tourism.  Hotel occupancy rates in November were strong, and will likely be similar in December and January.More visitors rode the Napa Valley Wine Trolley in January when he originally had only one date booked for the trolley.  Toward the end of December, people began expressing interest in riding the trolley, leading the general manager of the trolley to add additional dates.A personal culinary gardener said that although the weather allowed her to work in her clients’ gardens more, none of the cover crops were growing, and some clients were displeased with large water bills.Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Feb. 2, 2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Napa County, CA

Title: Snow drought ruined 13-14 ski season for resorts in California, Nevada and Arizona
Description: Skier visits to resorts in California, Nevada and Arizona dropped by 27.8 percent during the 2013-2014 season, according to data from the National Ski Areas Association.  Drought left slopes without the needed snow to draw winter sports enthusiasts.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), March 29, 2015
Places: Arizona, California, San Bernardino County, CA, Nevada

Title: Drought and higher salinity in Lavaca and San Antonio bays on the Texas Gulf Coast have cut oyster harvests by half
Description: Drought and higher salinity in Lavaca and San Antonio bays have cut oyster harvests by half, according to a seafood merchant in Port Lavaca.  He reported that oyster harvests since the season began on Nov. 1 have been about 50 percent of usual.  His seafood company usually sends three to four trucks out daily to transport oysters across the country, but has sent only two trucks per day.The business owner explained, “A lot of the oysters are dead.  We did get some rain later this summer, but it might have been too little too late for a lot of the oysters."The warmer, saltier water benefits oysters’ natural predators, such as the oyster drill, which is a snail that feeds on the oysters, and dermo disease, a parasite that kills oysters.  Once the drought ends and freshwater inflows to the bays resume, the oysters should recover in about two years, said the upper coast regional director for the coastal fishers division of Texas Parks and Wildlife Department.  Victoria Advocate (Texas), Nov. 25, 2013
Categories: Business & Industry, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Calhoun County, TX, Port Lavaca, TX, Refugio County, TX

Title: Drought drove down hay production in northern California
Description: Drought drove down hay production in northern California, forcing ranchers to purchase feed for their livestock.  A USDA Farm Service Agency executive officer in Humboldt County stated that feed production in Humboldt County was 70 percent less than usual. A rancher reported that four wells went dry on his property in Del Norte County.  Eureka Times-Standard (Calif.), Oct. 24, 2013
Places: Del Norte County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Trinity County, CA

Title: Officials with the Metropolitan Water District in southern California announced plans to draw water from stored reserves to meet demand in 2014
Description: Officials with the Metropolitan Water District announced plans to draw water from stored reserves to dodge mandatory cutbacks in 2014 as drought reduces the flow of the Colorado River and two years of dry winters in Sierra Nevada leave water supplies low.  “After two consecutive dry years, the state project reservoirs that buffer California’s water supplies are getting low, leaving us no choice but to forecast reduced state supply allocations,” said the director of California’s Department of Water Resources. “A wet winter could increase those projections, but we need to be cautious, given last year’s early rains gave way to record-dry conditions.”  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Oct. 15, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California expects to receive less water from the state Department of Water Resources in 2014
Description: The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California expects to receive less water from the state Department of Water Resources in 2014 if drought lingers in the state.  MWD is a consortium of 26 cities and water districts that provides drinking water to nearly 19 million people in parts of Los Angeles, Orange, San Diego, Riverside, San Bernardino and Ventura counties.  KCAL-TV Los Angeles (Calif.), Oct. 14, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Bermudagrass hay production has nearly ended in east-central Texas because the region has received little rain since early July
Description: Bermudagrass hay production has nearly ended in east-central Texas because the region has received little rain since early July, said a Cherokee County ag agent.  Many farmers got a normal first cutting of hay, but the second was not even 75 percent of a normal cutting, he said.  Since then, very little hay has grown.  Many east-central Texas farmers grow hay for their livestock and sell any extra, but may not have enough for their own herd this winter.Hay was being shipped in from Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi.  Hay and Forage Grower (Minneapolis, Minn.), Oct. 5, 2013
Places: Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Anderson County, TX, Angelina County, TX, Bell County, TX, Bosque County, TX, Brazoria County, TX, Brazos County, TX, Burleson County, TX, Chambers County, TX, Cherokee County, TX, Comanche County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Eastland County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Erath County, TX, Falls County, TX, Fort Bend County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Galveston County, TX, Gregg County, TX, Grimes County, TX, Hamilton County, TX, Hardin County, TX, Harris County, TX, Harrison County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Hill County, TX, Hood County, TX, Houston County, TX, Jasper County, TX, Jefferson County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Lee County, TX, Leon County, TX, Liberty County, TX, Limestone County, TX, Madison County, TX, Marion County, TX, McLennan County, TX, Milam County, TX, Montgomery County, TX, Nacogdoches County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Newton County, TX, Orange County, TX, Panola County, TX, Polk County, TX, Robertson County, TX, Rusk County, TX, Sabine County, TX, San Augustine County, TX, San Jacinto County, TX, Shelby County, TX, Smith County, TX, Somervell County, TX, Trinity County, TX, Tyler County, TX, Upshur County, TX, Walker County, TX, Waller County, TX, Williamson County, TX, Wood County, TX

Title: U.S. Bureau of Reclamation okay to release water for salmon
Description: The Westlands Water District and the San Luis & Delta-Mendota Water Authority in the San Joaquin Valley sued the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation for reservoir releases made to benefit salmon in Northern California’s Klamath River during drought in 2013.  U.S. District Judge Lawrence O’Neill in Fresno gave his ruling on Oct. 1, 2014, saying that Reclamation did not violate the law by making the special reservoir release, but he did note that the agency needed to cite a better legal authority than a 1955 law authorizing the government diversion of water to maintain a minimum flow in the Trinity River to sustain fish and wildlife.The Westlands Water District and the San Luis & Delta-Mendota Water Authority wanted the water to go to farmers in the San Joaquin Valley rather than to fish.Eugene Register-Guard (Ore.), Oct. 2, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Trinity County, CA

Title: Trinity County, California, fish unable to migrate due to low water, high fire danger, low lake levels make boating difficult
Description: I have two benchmarks in Brown's Creek, Douglas City, California.  One is from June 2013, the other from November 2012.  The creek is about .25" above the June benchmark.  Salmon and steelhead are unable to migrate in a normal fashion.  Debris and leaves are everywhere in the drainage as no scouring has occurred in a few years.  The ground is very dry just below the surface.  Fire danger is high; there is a fire in Lassen National Park right now.  California just experienced the driest year on record, 2013.  Trinity Lake is incredibly low, many boat ramps are inaccessible.  All this is on the heels of two successive low water years.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Douglas City 2.4 SW on 1/4/2014
Places: Trinity County, CA

Title: Water supply nearly depleted for the North Central Texas Municipal Water Authority
Description: Water users in the North Central Texas Municipal Water Authority were asked to reduce their water use by 25 percent in 2013.Miller’s Creek Reservoir, the water authority’s main supply, was at 7.8 percent of capacity in October 2014.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Oct. 27, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Haskell County, TX, Knox County, TX, Stonewall County, TX

Title: Drought’s impact on Lake Travis near Austin, Texas led a second restaurant to close
Description: The Gnarly Gar, a floating restaurant on Lake Travis, announced that its last day of business would be on Sept. 29, due to the low level of the lake.  The restaurant might reopen if the lake refills.  At the end of September, Lake Travis was about 43 feet below average, giving patrons a walk of nearly 1,000 feet from the parking lot to the restaurant.Earlier in September, another restaurant, Carlos’N Charlie’s closed, due to drought’s impact on Lake Travis.  KXAN-TV NBC 36 Austin (Texas), Sept. 24, 2013
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Wildlife, water supplies and fire danger affected by drought in Southern California
Description: Groundwater levels are expected to continue their decline; wildfire concerns remain high; and wildlife will continue to descend from the mountains in search of water as drought persists in southwestern California.  KEYT-TV ABC 3 Santa Barbara (Calif.), Sept. 24, 2013
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Drought closing dairies in Archer County, Texas
Description: The Windthorst/Scotland area had more than 90 dairies 15 years ago, but drought has driven most of those dairies out of business until just 38 dairies remain at present.  The lack of water and grass has forced the remaining dairy owners to lay off employees or drill new wells in an effort to hang on until rain returns.  KAUZ-TV CBS 6 Wichita Falls (Texas), Sept. 19, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Archer County, TX

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority board requested that the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality exempt the LCRA from releasing water from the Highland Lakes
Description: The rising levels of lakes Buchanan and Travis persuaded the Lower Colorado River Authority to release water downstream for the benefit of Matagorda Bay, where salinity levels were high because little freshwater has flowed into the bay.  The LCRA had previously requested permission to withhold the water for the bay.  Lakes Buchanan and Travis were at 34 percent of capacity and rising.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Oct. 16, 2013The Lower Colorado River Authority board requested that the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality exempt the LCRA from releasing water from the Highland Lakes, northwest of Austin, to Matagorda Bay to reduce salinity in the bay.  The high salinity is harming wildlife.The Highland Lakes had a combined total storage of 638,000 acre-feet and was about 32 percent of capacity on Sept. 18.  In a matter of weeks, the lakes are expected to fall below a total storage of 30 percent, thereby meeting the criteria for the area being in a worse drought than during the late 1940s through the late 1950s.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 18, 2013
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Llano County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: San Luis Obispo County, California, low well levels
Description: Our well began having difficulty recovering around this time.  We have an extensive garden and livestock.  We have had to reduce the size and scope of our vegetables due to lack of water.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Santa Margarita 8.9 ESE on 1/27/2014
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: Drought eliminated about 95 percent of the grass used for grazing in Ventura County, California
Description: Drought eliminated about 95 percent of the grass used for grazing in Ventura County just northwest of Los Angeles, forcing ranchers to sell livestock.  One rancher noted that grass growth was about one-sixth of its normal height, more sparse than usual and fed his cattle for just two weeks although he can usually leave the cattle on the grass for six weeks.  TradingCharts (Chicago, Illinois), Sept. 6, 2013
Places: Ventura County, CA

Title: Communities along Lake Travis in central Texas out of water
Description: Mud clogged the only water supply line for Ridge Harbor on the edge of Lake Travis, forcing the small community to have water transported in for a few days.  KXAN-TV NBC 36 Austin (Texas), Sept. 6, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX

Title: Cracks in foundation due to watering restrictions, dry pastures, Tarrant County, Texas
Description: Thing have deteriorated since my last report. Not only are stock tanks & ponds are either completely dry, or the deeper ones are nearly dry. Tree loss is significant. I have lost half of a 25 year old live oak, and have a tree service coming this morning to give me a definitive diagnosis and prognosis for this tree. Lost a red oak planted last fall, and a few outlying shrubs are gone. There are mature trees showing damage or are dead around the neighborhood. Because of watering restrictions, I'm just trying to save my foundation, although I see a crack where it was worked on before, and the trees and plants closest to the house. And of course, the oaks. The pasture is dry, and the horses my neighbor has bee grazing have been taken off. The ground cracks are trip hazards. Need beneficial rain, but none in the forecast. Got 0.39" in August. My water bill and electric bill are up. Lake levels continue to go down all over North Texas.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Haslet 2.2 S on 9/5/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Energy, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tarrant County, TX

Title: The Brazos River Basin  in Texas in stage 1 water restrictions
Description: The Brazos River Basin was in stage 1 water restrictions as water levels in its reservoirs continued to decline, due to ongoing drought.  Lake Granbury hit a new low at 64 percent of capacity during the first week of September and was 7.3 feet low.  Possum Kingdom Lake was 73 percent of capacity, or 10 feet below normal.  “I would say the upper part of our basin upstream of Possum Kingdom it's in the same category as the drought of the ‘50s,” stated Brad Brunett, water services manager for the Brazos River Authority.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Sept. 3, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Austin County, TX, Bailey County, TX, Baylor County, TX, Bell County, TX, Bosque County, TX, Brazoria County, TX, Brazos County, TX, Burleson County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Castro County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Comanche County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Eastland County, TX, Erath County, TX, Falls County, TX, Fisher County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Fort Bend County, TX, Garza County, TX, Grimes County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hamilton County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Hill County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Hood County, TX, Jack County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Jones County, TX, Kent County, TX, King County, TX, Knox County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Lee County, TX, Limestone County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, McLennan County, TX, Milam County, TX, Mills County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Parker County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Robertson County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Shackelford County, TX, Somervell County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Stonewall County, TX, Taylor County, TX, Throckmorton County, TX, Waller County, TX, Washington County, TX, Williamson County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Popular restaurant on Lake Travis near Austin, Texas to close
Description: Years of drought and the very low level of Lake Travis finally forced Carlos' n Charlie's, a popular restaurant on the lake, to close.  Austin Business Journal (Texas), Aug. 20, 2013
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Despite the ongoing drought, California almond growers in the Blue Diamond cooperative had a record annual revenue of $1.5 billion
Description: Despite the ongoing drought, California almond growers in the Blue Diamond cooperative had a record annual revenue of $1.5 billion with its 2013 crop, 25 percent more than the 2012 crop.  Years of drought is expected to hold steady or lower production from the almond trees, in comparison with last year’s harvest of 2 billion pounds.“We need a good winter rain this next year to begin the process of reviving almond trees,” said the president and CEO of Blue Diamond Growers. Even with normal rain, he explained, UC Davis research indicates that a complete revival of California’s drought-stressed almond orchards could take three years.Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Nov. 19, 2014
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Solano County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Victoria, Texas in stage 3 water restrictions, other area rivers dwindling
Description: Victoria entered stage 3 water restrictions when the flow of the Guadalupe River fell below 200 cubic feet per second.  Rainfall in Victoria amounted to 17.57 inches since the start of the year, more than 11 inches below normal.  The flow of the Guadalupe River was 145 cfs on Sept. 18.Other area rivers were also diminished by drought.  The Lavaca River was not flowing in Lavaca County; the Navidad River was barely flowing in Jackson County; and the Guadalupe River was flowing at 188 cubic feet per second at Cuero (DeWitt County), down from the annual flow rate of 919 cfs, or just over 20 percent of normal.  Victoria Advocate (Texas), Sept. 18, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: DeWitt County, TX, Jackson County, TX, Lavaca County, TX, Victoria County, TX, Victoria, TX

Title: Grass growth decimated in Yuba County, California
Description: Researchers at the University of California’s Sierra Foothill Research and Extension Service found that just 40 pounds of grass grew per acre from September through the end of December.  Normal grass growth for that time period is about 500 pounds per acre.Capital Public Radio (Sacramento, Calif.), Jan. 27, 2014
Places: Yuba County, CA

Title: Dozens of wells dried up in the northern part of San Luis Obispo County, California
Description: Dozens of wells have dried up in the northern part of San Luis Obispo County, frustrating residents who blame vineyards’ water use for the dry wells.  The water level in parts of the county fell by at least 70 feet since 1997, due to drought and growing agricultural and urban demand.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Sept. 1, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: Drought damaged grazing land, hindered grass production in San Joaquin County, California
Description: San Joaquin County’s agricultural commissioner requested and received a formal disaster declaration due to drought damage to grazing lands.  Little precipitation fell after December 2012 and did not provide enough moisture for grass production.  He also noted that the past two seasons in a row of below normal rainfall has hindered the recovery of pastures.  TradingCharts (Chicago, Ill.), Aug. 31, 2013
Places: San Joaquin County, CA

Title: The San Juan Water District in Granite Bay, California issued a report stating that water intakes at Folsom Reservoir will be above the water line within months if current weather trends do not change
Description: The San Juan Water District, serving 265,000 customers in Granite Bay and parts of Roseville, Folsom and Orangevale, issued a report stating that water intakes at Folsom Reservoir will be above the water line in April or May if current weather trends do not change.  The water district began encouraging its customers to conserve water since August 2013.  The board will hear recommendations for more stringent water restrictions at its upcoming meeting.  Sacramento Bee (California), Jan. 5, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Placer County, CA, Roseville, CA, Folsom, CA, Orangevale, CA

Title: Nine thousand ducks died from avian botulism at the Tule Lake National Wildlife Refuge near Tule Lake, California
Description: Roughly nine thousand ducks died from avian botulism at the Tule Lake National Wildlife Refuge near Tule Lake, California, due to overcrowding, which facilitates the spread of disease.  The nearby Lower Klamath National Wildlife Refuge was nearly dry because water shortages in the Klamath Basin meant that the refuge received no water this summer, leading the ducks to congregate at Tule Lake marshes.  Medford Mail Tribune (Ore.), Aug. 29, 2013
Places: Siskiyou County, CA, Klamath County, OR

Title: Central Texas offered no native flowering plants on which hummingbirds feed during their annual migration
Description: Central Texas offered no native flowering plants on which hummingbirds feed during their annual migration south to Mexico and Central America, reported the president of the Arroyo Colorado Audubon Society after a recent trip.  She urges people to put out feeders for the hummingbirds to help the creatures on their long journey south.  The hummingbirds will benefit from the food, and the people will benefit next year and in following years when the hummingbirds return on their migrations and bring offspring with them.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Aug. 25, 2013
Places: Bell County, TX, Bosque County, TX, Comanche County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Eastland County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Erath County, TX, Falls County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Hamilton County, TX, Hill County, TX, Hood County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Leon County, TX, Limestone County, TX, McLennan County, TX, Milam County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Robertson County, TX, Somervell County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: San Jacinto County, Texas, dry grass a fire danger
Description: The drought impact on my property is severe. My pond has not been full enough to support any life for several years. Some frogs reached maturity this spring, but there is very little water in it now. The water is stagnant & lifeless. The grass in my fields is dry, dead, & a fire danger. Rain is desperately needed.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Coldspring 4.3 SSW on 8/24/2013
Places: San Jacinto County, TX

Title: Comal County, Texas, livestock desperate for moisture, no grass in pasture
Description: Water levels in the Edwards aquifer continue to drop. The main spring in New Braunfels has quit flowing. There is no more green grass in the pasture. In fact the cattle fight over the watermelon and cantaloupe rinds when we throw them over the fence. You know things are desperate when we start looking to the Gulf of Mexico for hurricane relief! I estimate we have about 10 more feet of aquifer before our well begins to suck air. At present, the aquifer level drops between half a foot and a full foot each day.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #New Braunfels 5.9 NW on 8/24/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Comal County, TX

Title: Homeowner reaching last of stored water in Humboldt County, California
Description: We are into the last of our stored water, have cut off the garden, and expect to run out of water before the rains. I take a bath in three inches of water, and double-use any cooking or shower water I can, for flushing, plants, etc. If we buy water it will be $580 for 3200 gallons.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Redway 4.8 WNW on 8/23/2013
Places: Humboldt County, CA

Title: Drought affecting wells, trees in Foard County, Texas; Stage 4 drought in effect
Description: We have no pond water for stock. We had 4" of rain in July and have some grass, but still no water. The drought has also killed many trees in our area and continues to affect our local water system. Generally we have about 25' of water in our wells at the first of August and this year we have 7' of water. We are in Stage 4 drought and would probably be out of water but we purchase water from the City of Crowell (they have water from Lake Greenbelt in Clarendon).CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Crowell 10.5 E on 8/23/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Foard County, TX

Title: Pool water to replenish duck pond in Midland, Texas
Description: Water from the Dough Russell Pool will be transported to Wadley Barron Park’s duck pond once chlorine levels in the water have dissipated.  Wells were drilled to replenish the duck pond, but the wells were not productive enough.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com) (Calif.), Aug. 23, 2013
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Midland County, TX

Title: Low water table and well, Medina County, Texas
Description: Our community well is in the Cow Creek formation and is 1200' deep.  The pump was at the 350' depth but on 8/22 the water table dropped below that point.  The pump had to be lowered 125' to get back into a stable water pool.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Mico 5.0 E on 8/29/2013
Places: Medina County, TX

Title: Wildflowers affected by drought in Ventura County, California
Description: Drought conditions have progressed this year to the extent that many common flowering wild plants didn't flower this year.  There were no lupins at all, nor any wild clover, nightshade, maricopa lily, morning glories, five o'clocks, or goldenrod, and very few penstemons (wild snapdragons) and  navaretia.  The scarlet bugles seem unaffected.  The local sage seems to be suffering and many branches on a bush are dying.  There was very little pine pollen this year, when usually the cars get a strong yellow dust.  However, this year the pollen wasn't evident.  There don't appear to be many acorns either, but there is an abundance of wasp galls.  The grass was very sparse and only a few inches tall, barely necessary to cut for fire control.  On the good side of this, there was little grass affected by the blight (the seeds eaten away by a black mold that becomes a black powder when weed-whacked).  There has been no water flowing in the local creek since spring 2012.  Very little of the bunch grass went to seed this year, when usually there are massive amounts of this seed everywhere.  Nearly all of this grass has turned completely brown, and appears dead.  Usually the base of this grass retains some green color, but not this year.  I rely on this grass and the sage for erosion control.   My hillsides had very little growth this spring, and heavy rains this winter would easily bring serious erosion.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Frazier Park 10.7 WSW on 8/22/2013
Places: Ventura County, CA

Title: The Rim Fire burned dry timber, brush in and near Yosemite National Forest in California
Description: The Rim Fire, which blackened more than 400 square miles, burned so intensely over a 60 square mile area that all trees and vegetation were dead.  Researchers say that drought and aridity related to climate change have increased the intensity of wildfires this year.  New York Times (N.Y.), Sept. 18, 2013The Rim Fire burned its way into record books as California’s fourth largest wildfire in history at 348 square miles on Sept. 1.  A spokesman with the U.S. Forest Service stated that $60 million in state and federal funds have been spent fighting the fire.  The blaze was 40 percent contained, but still moving to the northeast.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Sept. 1, 2013The Rim Fire burning in Yosemite National Park has kept away tourists, who would normally pour into the park over the Labor Day weekend.  The fire consumed about 315 square miles, but less than one-fourth of that was in Yosemite.  Trust.org (New York, N.Y.), Aug. 30, 2013The Rim Fire blackened 301 square miles, destroyed 111 structures, including 11 homes and threatened groves of sequoia trees.  Atlanta Journal-Constitution (Ga.), Aug. 28, 2013The Rim Fire charred more than 230 square miles and at least 23 structures and showered ash over the reservoir that provides most of San Francisco’s water.  Firefighters were striving to protect the reservoir, the hydroelectric transmission lines and other utility facilities.  Washington Post (D.C.), Aug. 25, 2013The Rim Fire continued to burn more than 200 square miles in and near Yosemite National Park since the fire began Aug. 17 in a remote canyon in the Stanislaus National Forest.  Firefighters were trying to protect stands of giant sequoia trees, which are some of the oldest and largest living things on the planet.  The blaze became so large, burning through dry timber and brush, that it generated its own weather, making the fire even more difficult to manage.  The fire moved toward the Hetch Hetchy reservoir, the main water and power supply for San Francisco's municipal buildings, the international airport and San Francisco General Hospital.  The San Francisco Public Utilities Commission closed tow hydro-electric stations that use water from the reservoir and turned off power to more than 12 miles of lines.  New London Day (Conn.), Aug. 25, 2013
Places: Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Harsh weather decreases cotton production in West Texas

Title: Water to be diverted from lake, residents concerned about water supply in California
Description: The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation will be shifting water from Folsom Lake to Southern California, with the lake to drop to 376 feet by December 2013. The general manager of the San Juan Water District is not comfortable with the USBR draining the lake down to 300,000 acre-feet, which is 100,000 acre-feet lower than during the drought of 1976-77. A dry winter could leave Roseville, Folsom and Granite Bay with little water to spare next year.  Auburn Journal (CA), August 16, 2013

Title: Rivers dry and increased water restrictions in Texas

Title: Guadalupe River dry above Canyon Lake north of San Antonio, Texas
Description: A hydrologic technician with the U.S. Geological Survey searched for a section of the Guadalupe River near Spring Branch to measure the flow, but could not find water moving enough for his sensor to read, leaving him to estimate the flow.  The Guadalupe River was nearly dry above Canyon Lake just north of San Antonio for the third time in the last five years.  The historical median flow for Aug. 13 is 78 cubic feet per second.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 14, 2013
Places: Comal County, TX

Title: Water table dropping, affecting wells in Kendall County, Texas
Description: The falling level of the Trinity Aquifer level has forced many homeowners to have the pumps in their wells lowered or to have their wells drilled deeper to keep the water flowing in their pipes.  The number of calls to a well drilling business in Boerne has gone up, stated the secretary, as people try to get the water back on in their homes.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 14, 2013

Title: Stretches of dry river not helpful for kayakers and canoeists at the Guadalupe River State Park in Comal County, Texas

An employee at the campsite said that the river was drying up quickly.   Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 14, 2013
Places: Comal County, TX

Title: Stage three drought restrictions took effect in the Cow Creek Groundwater Conservation District in Kendall County, Texas
Description: Stage three drought restrictions took effect in the Cow Creek Groundwater Conservation District (CCGCD) with the goal of trimming water use by 30 percent.   The drought, the declining water table and the state of the Guadalupe River all factored in the CCGCD board’s decision to tighten water restrictions.  Monitoring wells that the CCGCD uses indicate that the Trinity Aquifer is lower than it has been in decades, said the general manager of the CCGCD.  It is 2 feet lower than in 2011 and 30 feet lower than in 2007.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 14, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: South Texans are frustrated with Mexico’s noncompliance with the 1944 treaty and were signing a petition to be sent to President Obama urging him to take action
Description: Mexico acknowledges its water debt of 380,000 acre-feet, but does not have the water to give to the U.S., due to drought.  Washington Post (D.C.), Sept. 8, 2014South Texans are frustrated with Mexico’s noncompliance with the 1944 treaty and were signing a petition to be sent to President Obama urging him to take action.  The Rio Grande Regional Water Authority has copies of the petition that people may sign.  Petition organizers aim to get Mexico to comply with the treaty requiring it to deliver 1.75 million acre-feet of water during a five-year cycle unless an extraordinary drought or problem with its hydraulics system prevents Mexico from sharing the water, said a spokeswoman for the U.S. sector of the International Boundary and Water Commission in El Paso.  In return, the U.S. must provide 1.5 million acre-feet from the Colorado River annually.  About one thousand signatures have been gathered, but petition organizers intend to collect 10,000 signatures.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Aug. 13, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Lower water levels facilitate trash removal along waterways in Santa Clara County, California

Title: Exceptional drought conditions and late freezes cut into the amount of certified wheat produced in southeastern Colorado, leading to reduced supplies of seed for the next planting
Description: Exceptional drought conditions and late freezes cut into the amount of certified wheat produced in southeastern Colorado, leading to reduced supplies of seed for the next planting.  The executive director of the Colorado Wheat Research Foundation, which works with the growers of certified seed varieties created by Colorado State University, said that supplies would be tight, but there should be sufficient supplies if farmers contact their dealers early.  Growers of certified seed in northeastern Colorado have received requests for seed from southeastern Colorado, western Kansas, and the panhandles of Nebraska, Oklahoma and Texas since production was low in those areas.  A certified seed grower near Haxtun in extreme northeastern Colorado reported that 70 percent of his seed was sold because his usual customers wanted to claim their seeds early, knowing that the wheat crop in the southeastern part of the state was below par.A certified seed grower in southeastern Colorado near Sheridan Lake harvested only one-fifth of his total acres this summer, but only half of that seed was of decent quality to sell.  The harvested acres yielded roughly one-third of the usual amount.  Altogether, he had about 6 to 7 percent of the wheat he had to sell last year.  He was trying to buy seed from northern Colorado, but will have to raise the price 20 to 30 percent to cover transportation costs.  Denver Post (Colo.), Aug. 6, 2013

Title: Drought leads to infectious bacteria growth in bodies of water, some pools shut down, Texas, Florida, and Arksas
Description: Heat and drought produce favorable conditions for the growth of the Naegleria fowleri amoeba, which can cause a deadly infection.  Most infections occur in southern states, with the most cases occurring in Texas, Florida, and Arkansas. Some pools were forced to shut down.  The Vindicator (TX), August 2, 2013

Title: Homeowner watering trees and grass daily in Harris County, Texas

Places: Harris County, TX

Title: Klamath tribal members in the upper Klamath Basin in Oregon eligible for aid from drought relief programs
Description: Klamath tribal members in the upper Klamath Basin who endured water shut-offs to their farms and ranchlands were eligible for assistance from drought relief programs from the Bureau of Reclamation.  The program is for tribal members holding allottee water rights dating back to 1864 on the tribe's former reservation—non-tribal farmers were not eligible.  Tribe members may receive $250 per acre.  Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), July 31, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Jackson County, OR, Klamath County, OR, Lake County, OR

Title: Burn bans in Brazos, Milam and Washington counties in Texas
Description: A 60-day burn ban was approved by the Brazos County Commissioners Court after a couple of grassfires burned, with one of them closing parts of Texas 6.  The Brazos County Emergency Management coordinator said that the five fire chiefs that he spoke with were in favor of the burn ban.  Milam and Washington counties also have bans on outdoor burning.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), July 31, 2013
Places: Brazos County, TX, Milam County, TX, Washington County, TX

Title: Kings River in California not flowing
Description: The Kings River, where people commonly float down the river to cool off, is seeing more use as an off-road trail this year since the river has gone dry.  Hanford Sentinel (Calif.), July 30, 2013
Places: Kings County, CA

Title: Not enough irrigation water to grow marijuana in Plumas National Forest in California
Description: A marijuana garden in the Plumas National Forest was abandoned, possibly due to a shortage of water, theorized the Butte County sheriff. Berkeley East Bay Express (Calif.), July 30, 2013
Places: Butte County, CA

Title: A mat of algae growing in the Colorado River in Bastrop, Texas
Description: A mat of algae is growing in the Colorado River along the June Hill Pape Riverwalk Trail in Bastrop.  The general manager of the Blue Bonnet Electric Cooperative said that no inflow in the river and plenty of nutrients in the water produce conditions conducive to the growth of the algae and weeds.  Some stretches of the river are impassable.  KHOU-TV CBS 11 Houston (Texas), July 28, 2013
Places: Bastrop County, TX

Title: Dry spring affected water volume, recreation on Russian River in Sonoma County, California
Description: A dry spring brought the Russian River to low levels not seen in decades, forcing canoeists above Healdsburg to drag their canoes in a couple of places.The owner of a business that offers kayak and canoe trips said, “I don't tell people it's business as usual. There's less river to paddle in, and in the river channels under the trees our clients have to duck a lot. And they hit sandbars. They have to get out more often.”  She noted that drought has affected her business and fears that another dry winter may drive her out of business.Water releases from Coyote Dam at Lake Mendocino near Ukiah rose 25 percent in late June to boost river flow.Near the Del Rio Woods Beach, a lifeguard reported that the river “is noticeably a lot lower and the water doesn't flow as much. This year it's really bad. This is definitely lower than usual.  There are still swim holes, just not as many”  Canoeing at Del Rio meant pushing off of gravel beds now and then.  One canoeist said, “There's not enough water to flow all the way.  I managed to prod it, dig it along.”  Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), July 28, 2013
Categories: Business & Industry, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Water levels extremely low at White River Lake in Texas
Description: Just one boat ramp is still open on White River Lake, while docks at the marina are yards from the water.  The marina owner wonders how long he can stay open with the low level of the lake driving away business.  He gets some revenue from the marina’s restaurant and uses his savings to pay bills.  GO San Angelo/San Angelo Standard Times (Texas), July 24, 2013
Places: Crosby County, TX

Title: Boat owners at Folsom Lake Marina  in California were told to remove their boats from berths by August 3
Description: Boat owners at Folsom Lake Marina were notified that they must remove their boats from their berths by August 3 because the lake level is receding.  The floating docks will be sitting on the lake bed by early August, and the lake storage will be approximately 412,000 acre-feet.  Normally boats do not need to be removed from their slips until October 1.  "We are dropping about three-quarters of a foot a day," said the marina's manager. "It hurts business all around. We've got a lot of restaurants that depend on the public coming out and using the lake. We've seen a big drop in day use."The Bureau of Reclamation expects that flow in the American River will fall to about 1,000 cubic feet per second—about one-third of the present flow—by October.  The level of Folsom Dam will likely drop to 241,000 acre-feet, or about 25 percent of capacity, in December.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 22, 2013
Categories: Business & Industry, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA

Title: The Mountain Fire burned in the parched San Jacinto Mountains in Riverside County, California
Description: The Mountain Fire blackened thousands of acres of pine forests and chaparral in the San Jacinto Mountains, driving thousands of residents from their homes in Idyllwild.  Firefighters blame drought and dense vegetation untouched by fire for decades for the intensity of the wildfire.  A fire behavior analyst from the Livermore-Pleasanton Fire Department working with an interagency team in the San Jacinto Mountains stated, “I haven’t seen a fire burn with this intensity this early in the fire season, probably in 30 years of firefighting,” and also noted that moisture levels in forest fuels was at historic lows in Southern California.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), July 21, 2013
Places: Riverside County, CA, Idyllwild, CA

Title: Comal County, Texas, allergy and asthma affecting people, deer having trouble finding food
Description: Our lawn crunches under our feet when we walk on it.  Deer have been eating almost everything that is green, even those plants they previously left alone.  Our air conditioner runs almost constantly which has caused a considerable increase in our electric bill.  Outside activities are limited to early morning and late evening.  Our family has been suffering from allergy and asthma symptoms with the dust in the area.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #New Braunfels 10.0 W on 8/24/2013
Places: Comal County, TX

Title: Low lake levels impacts fishing in Texas
Description: Lake Travis has hit a historical low and is not good for fishing anymore, especially since boaters can’t get their boats in the water.  KRGV-TV Channel 5 Weslaco (TX), July 18, 2013
Places: Burnet County, TX, Weslaco, TX

Title: Fire forces residents to evacuate town, damages area, California
Description: The Mountain Fire blackened more than 22,800 acres and forced more than 6,000 people to flee. A Forest Service spokeswoman said that the wind-driven blaze was burning in timber and shrub land that was exceedingly dry after the dry winter. It has cost $5.5 million to battle the fire, according to the U.S. Forest Service.  NBC (NY), California, July 18, 2013

Title: Irrigation water shut offs continue in Upper Klamath Basin in Oregon
Description: The Klamath Basin watermaster finished regulation in the last week and is monitoring stream flows to see that required minimum flows have been met.  He said that in the basin, only Crooked Creek was meeting required flows.  The amount of the required flow decreases on July 1 and August 1. Title: Crops and vegetation in the Coastal Bend of Texas were in need of rain
Description: Crops and vegetation in the Coastal Bend of Texas were in need of rain.  Poor yield potential and the need for livestock feed made farmers bale their corn and grain sorghum for hay.  Soil moisture was declining for the cotton crop, but farmers hoped that it would be sufficient.  Pasture condition deteriorated from drought and heat, leading livestock producers to give their cattle supplemental feed, while others moved their herds.  Many ponds held little or no water.  Trees bore signs of drought stress.  Hay yields were low where  there was enough hay to cut.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), July 16, 2013
