Title: The California Water Resources Control Board warned water rights holders in the Sacramento Valley that curtailments may be in the offing
Description: The California Water Resources Control Board warned water rights holders in the Sacramento Valley that curtailments may be in the offing, given the low runoff, if there isn’t more water conservation.  Even senior water rights holders could be affected by curtailment orders.  "This is really a heads-up for a potentially critical condition," said the assistant deputy director for water rights at the board.  The last time those with “riparian” and “pre-1914” water rights faced curtailments was during the 1976-77 drought.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 17, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Placer County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: The cotton crop in the Lower Rio Grande Valley in Texas is expected to be one of the region’s smallest
Description: The cotton crop in the Lower Rio Grande Valley is expected to be one of the region’s smallest since less acreage was planted, irrigation water was in short supply and the mild winter did not kill enough insects.  During the last three years, an average of 150,000 acres of cotton were planted in the Lower Rio Grande Valley, but this year, a Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service cotton integrated pest management entomologist said  that about 80,000 acres of cotton were planted.  The lack of moisture has slowed plant growth even where farmers irrigated before and since planting.  In some fields in Willacy County, the cotton never came up.  High Plains Journal (Dodge City, Kansas), July 15, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Drought leads to tree loss in Wilbarger (Texas) County cemetary
Description: Cracked earth at this station has been repaired for the most part with the 1.84" of rain in this event. Ant mounds are appearing as the fire ants dig out. Will treat with organic product. Vegetation has greened up and is actively growing again. No unusual threat of grass/brush fires in the immediate area. Air conditioner use has been down due to the unseasonably cool temps. Cities in Tarrant and surrounding counties have been spraying for mosquitoes for several weeks in order to head off the threat of West Nile Virus infections, which caused significant morbidity and mortality last year. Stagnant water collections will be a problem again after this rain event. Only rain directly over area lakes helped replenish low lake levels by a few inches. No significant watershed runoff occurred, as most moisture was soaked up by the thirsty soil.I made a road trip to Vernon, TX, in Wilbarger County last Wednesday. Since there is apparently no reporting station for CoCoCaHS in that area, I shall report my observations. My main objective for the trip was to check the family burial plots in Eastview Memorial Cemetery, and it was evident when driving in the gate that they have had a tremendous loss of trees in the old section. Cemetery personnel reported to me that no significant rain had fallen in the last 3 years, and that they had lost many trees, including the old cedars that had existed nearly 100 years. Cedar trees are prevalent in old cemeteries in that part of Texas because of their drought and disease resistance.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Haslet 2.2 S on 7/21/2013
Places: Wilbarger County, TX

Title: Irrigation water deliveries at an end on the Lower Rio Grande River in New Mexico
Description: Elephant Butte and Caballo lakes held just 3 and 2 percent of capacity, respectively, at the end of the irrigation season, which was cut short, due to low water levels.  Heavy rains sent 29,400 acre-feet of water into Elephant Butte and 25,200 acre-feet into Caballo Lake, bringing the storages in those lakes to 6 and 17 percent of capacity, as of Sept. 17.  The influx of water to the reservoirs was a godsend, but is far from guaranteeing a good irrigation season next year.  El Paso Times (Texas), Sept. 17, 2013Irrigation water from the Elephant Butte Reservoir began flowing on June 1 and will end on July 14, making this the shortest irrigation season ever for the district.  The reservoir is at 3.1 percent of capacity, lower than it has been in 40 years.  Growers received just 6 percent of a full allotment.  ABQJournal Online (Albuquerque, N .M.) July 9, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sierra County, NM, El Paso County, TX

Title: High number of applications for well permits in Santa Barbara County, California
Description: Twenty-eight applications for new well drilling permits were received in Santa Barbara County in the first quarter of the 2014-15 fiscal year, which would lead to about 120 new applications for the year if the trend continues.  The average number of well permit applications during a normal year is around 50.  The county received 165 applications during the 2013-14 fiscal year.Santa Maria Sun (Calif.), Oct. 16, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Santa Barbara County, CA

Title: Hard, dry ground causing problems for producer installing fences; mesquite and locust trees affected in Navarro County, Texas
Description: I use rotational grazing with electric fences. In trying to put the step-in posts down I have to look for either a crack in the ground or use a hammer to drive it in. Normally you step on it and shift a little weight.Cracks are becoming more numerous, wider and deeper. Even the mesquite is showing the effects with lots of dead limbs. Loosing locust trees as well (not a bad thing).CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Blooming Grove 2.4 SW on 7/10/2013
Places: Navarro County, TX

Title: High demand for well drilling in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas
Description: Low irrigation supplies led more farmers in the Rio Grande Valley to have wells drilled on their land.  One sod farmer refers to the two wells he had drilled as “insurance.”  The wells cost more than $30,000 and each produce about 200 gallons per minute.  A well driller from McAllen said that he has a lot of customers wanting to have wells drilled since irrigation supplies are not satisfying people’s water needs.  In other cases, people want to water their lawns, but municipal water is expensive.  KRGV.com reported that the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation listed more than 2,000 wells as being registered in the Valley.  KRGV-TV Channel 5 Weslaco (Texas), July 4, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Hidalgo County, TX

Title: Drought allows oyster farmer in Marin County, California to work more days
Description: A Marin County oyster farmer credits the drought with allowing him to harvest oysters more and having to stop less frequently when rains wash unwanted bacteria into the bay.  He normally has about 90 days per year when he cannot work, but drought has cut the number down to about 30 days when runoff keeps him from harvesting oysters.San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), July 3, 2014
Places: Marin County, CA

Title: Burn ban in the unincorporated parts of Travis County, Texas
Description: Travis County Commissioners Court approved a burn ban in the unincorporated parts of the county, due to drought and the elevated fire danger.  The ban was not related to the use of fireworks and remained in effect through July 30.  The Travis County fire marshal urged people to attend a public fireworks display and to forgo private fireworks in the interest of safety.
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Water company in southern Kern County, California needed water in summer 2013
Description: The Lake of the Woods Mutual Water Co. needed to truck in water during the summer of 2013, stated an unpaid volunteer who works for the water company.  The water company serves about 400 connections in the southern mountains near Frazier Park.The Lake of the Woods Mutual Water Co. is again in crisis, stated the volunteer, and may need infusions of water during the summer of 2014, too.Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), Feb. 24, 2014
Places: Kern County, CA

Title: Grasshopper population booming in Navarro, Henderson and Lampasas counties in Texas
Description: Dry conditions in July through the fall of 2012 led to an increase in the grasshopper population in June 2013, stated an AgriLife Extension entomologist in Dallas.  During the July through the fall period, grasshoppers put their eggs half an inch to two inches below the soil surface.  Moisture encourages the growth of fungus and other diseases, which limit the eggs’ survival, so during dry times, as in 2012, the eggs survive, leading to a healthy grasshopper population the following summer.  AgriLife Extension agents verified the presence of abundant grasshoppers in Navarro, Henderson and Lampasas counties.  Grasshoppers are affecting hay production in Navarro County.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), June 30, 2013
Places: Brazos County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Navarro County, TX

Title: Drought improved Lake Tahoe's clarity
Description: Average water clarity at Lake Tahoe increased to nearly 78 feet in 2014, up from more than 70 feet in 2013.   During drought, there is less stormwater runoff to cloud the lake water.The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Aug. 25, 2015
Places: El Dorado County, CA, Placer County, CA, Carson City, NV, Douglas County, NV, Washoe County, NV

Title: Fewer people purchase annual and boat passes in San Luis Obispo County, California
Description: The number of annual passes and boat passes sold between July 2013 and February 2014 slumped 43 percent, compared to the previous year, said San Luis Obispo County parks officials.  The declining water level also brought about a decline in visitors.San Luis Obispo County Tribune (Calif.), March 28, 2014
Categories: Business & Industry, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: Stage 1 drought restrictions end for Tarrant Regional Water District in Texas
Description: Stage 1 drought restrictions ended for the Tarrant Regional Water District on May 18 after being enacted nearly two years prior.  Recent rainfall brought the levels of the Richland-Chambers and Cedar Creek reservoirs to more than 100 percent of capacity; Eagle Mountain Lake was full and its floodgates were open slightly to  send water downstream to Lake Worth, which was at 84 percent of capacity, according to the water district’s community and government relations director.  The stage 1 drought restrictions took effect in June 2013 and could not end until the lake levels rose to 95 percent of capacity.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), May 12, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Denton County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Jack County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Parker County, TX, Tarrant County, TX, Wise County, TX

Title: The hot, dry conditions prompted the U.S. Forest Service to lengthen the hours of staffing during the day in the Angeles National Forest in California
Description: The hot, dry conditions prompted the U.S. Forest Service to lengthen the hours of staffing during the day in the Angeles National Forest through at least July 1.  A park spokesperson said that park staff will be on high alert on July 4 to take quick action against any fires that might pop up and also said that campgrounds could close early on July 4.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), June 27, 2013
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: Burn ban in Ector County, Texas
Description: Ector County commissioners extended the current burn ban, which took effect on June 24, by another 30 days because the Keetch-Byram Drought Index was 654 on Sept. 23.  Odessa American (Texas), Sept. 23, 2013 and Oct. 27, 2013Ector County commissioners adopted a burn ban for the county as the Keetch-Byram Drought Index (KBDI) rose to an average of 574, where a minimum KBDI value of zero represents very moist conditions and a maximum value of 800 indicates the driest conditions.  The sale and use of fireworks is unaffected by the burn ban.  Odessa American (Texas), June 24, 2013
Places: Ector County, TX

Title: Producer cannot fertilize hay meadows because of lack of rain; grass for cattle going fast in Victoria County, Texas
Description: Still no rain, 9.00 in. below normal. Heat is almost not bearable around 2:00 pm. Grass for cattle is going fast. Have not fertilized hay meadows this year because of no rain. May be just as well, it would not have paid off without water. To the east, Houston area and beyond, good rains; to the north, San Antonio area last week got downpours, also to the west, Corpus Christi area last week got good rains, maybe not enough. I guess the old saying, we will get it when we need it, will have to be good enough for now.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Inez 1.1 SSE on 6/22/2013
Places: Victoria County, TX, Inez, TX

Title: Livestock producer going out of business because of lack of grass in Kern County, California
Description: A nearby neighbor who raises grass-fed cattle for beef has informed us that he is going out of business, at least for now, because of the lack of grass!Lake of the Woods, 3 miles west of Frazier Park, is having severe water problems.  They are not allowed to water their gardens for fear of not having enough household water.  Lawns are drying up.  They are considering digging very expensive deeper wells but they don't have the money.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Frazier Park 0.6 WNW on 6/22/2013
Places: Kern County, CA, Frazier Park, CA

Title: Fuel dryness unusual for June in Mariposa County, California
Description: The reports from our recent area brush/grass/tree fire indicate that the "fuel" dryness is unusual, more like August than June.  It could have been a bad fire--that is, worse, but the weather cooled off, and they threw a lot of personnel into fighting it.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Mariposa 3.7 NNW on 6/21/2013
Places: Mariposa County, CA, Midpines, CA

Title: Zebral mussel encroachment reported in 2 Tarrant County (Texas) lakes; water restrictions reported in some cities
Description: Yard grass/pasture have greened and are actively growing. Ground cracks have filled in except for the widest ones. All this noted after nice rains on 6/9-10 and 6/18. Mowing the yard weekly again, and the pasture needs it again to  prevent weeds and mesquites. Keeping pasture borders mowed low although fire danger is not great now.Tarrant County lakes remain low by 3 or more feet, with Bridgeport reported at -18 feet. Reports of zebra mussel encroachment in 2 lakes to the north affect municipal water supplies. Haslet is in Stage 1 Water Restrictions, but other cities are already in Stage 3.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Haslet 2.2 S on 6/21/2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tarrant County, TX, Haslet, TX

Title: Loose livestock causing problems in DeWitt County, Texas
Description: Loose livestock have taken up more than 150 hours of sheriff’s deputies’ time during the last two months as the animals amble to roadways to graze.  Precipitation runs off of roads, greening up the vegetation along the roads, which draws livestock.  A number of accidents involving livestock has been reported in recent months, but another problem with the livestock is the high volume of phone calls about loose livestock that keeps deputies from other responsibilities.  KAVU & KUNU-TV Crossroads (Texas), Aug. 20, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health
Places: DeWitt County, TX

Title: Campfire restrictions in San Bernardino National Forest in California
Description: Dry conditions in the San Bernardino National Forest prompted warnings to visitors to keep vehicles on paved roads, be especially careful with open fires and extinguish cigarettes in ashtrays rather than throwing them out of car windows.  Violators may be fined up to $10,000 or face six months imprisonment.  Campfires are permitted at developed camp sites and within fire rings and camp stoves.  KCBQ (San Diego, Calif.), June 21, 2013
Places: Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Second year of drastically limited water supplies for rice farmers along the Lower Colorado River in Texas resulted in 30 percent reduction in rice acres
Description: The second year of drastically limited water supplies for rice farmers along the Lower Colorado River and cooler temperatures have resulted in a 30 percent reduction in rice acres in Texas, according to Dr. Ted Wilson with the Texas AgriLife Research Center in Beaumont.  About 10 percent of the crop has shown grain development, whereas last year at the time, 19 percent of the crop was developing grains.  The cost of rice will increase in grocery stores since rice production is down.  The lack of irrigation water pushed some rice farmers out of the business, while others have decided to try growing soybeans for the first time.  Texas Public Radio (San Antonio, Texas), June 19, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Colorado County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Low water levels causing bad smell in drinking water in Montague County, Texas
Description: We have had some good rains lately but still not enough to get the lake in Montague County where it needs to be or even close. The drinking water has a bad smell due to the low level. With the temps. being so high there is still a threat of grass fires.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Bowie 0.5 WSW on 6/12/2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Montague County, TX, Bowie, TX

Title: Wheat in poor condition in Childress County, Texas; eastern Colorado and Dakotas
Description: Wheat in Childress County, Texas was in such poor condition that much of it was grazed or baled, stated a custom harvester from Goodland, Kansas who has been in the business for 23 years.  This was one of the worst years for the area with yields of 5 to 10 bushels per acre.  He also noted that eastern Colorado did not get a good stand and the Dakotas did not have enough moisture to germinate their winter wheat.  Salina Journal & Salina.com (Kan.), June 11, 2013
Places: Baca County, CO, Bent County, CO, Cheyenne County, CO, Crowley County, CO, Kiowa County, CO, Kit Carson County, CO, Las Animas County, CO, Lincoln County, CO, Logan County, CO, Morgan County, CO, Otero County, CO, Phillips County, CO, Prowers County, CO, Sedgwick County, CO, Washington County, CO, Yuma County, CO, North Dakota, South Dakota, Childress County, TX

Title: Some fireworks banned in Ector County, Texas
Description: Rockets with sticks and missiles with fins were banned during the Fourth of July holiday in Ector County on June 10 by Ector County commissioners.  Although commissioners discussed a burn ban, consensus was that a ban was not needed.  Odessa American (Texas), June 11, 2013
Places: Ector County, TX

Title: Irrigation shutoffs in Klamath Reclamation Project in southern Oregon, northern California
Description: The chairman for the Klamath Tribes and the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation commissioner announced calls on water rights for rivers flowing into Upper Klamath Lake, which may leave up to 58,000 acres without irrigation water by the bureau’s calculations.  The tribes have the oldest water rights and want to maintain adequate flows in the Wood, Williamson, Sprague and Sycan rivers for fish, such as the endangered suckers and redband tout.  The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation uses its water for the Klamath Reclamation Project, an irrigation project supplying water for 225,000 acres straddling the Oregon-California border, and for wildlife refuges that support migrating waterfowl.  The local water master, working for the Oregon Department of Water Resources (ODWR), must begin checking river flows and notifying those with junior water rights to stop pumps and close headgates on diversion dams until the bureau’s and tribes’ water rights are met.  It may take several weeks to make all notifications to increase river flow.  The ODWR has three teams of two people each to visit junior water rights holders and shut off water.  The sheriff will be notified of the teams’ whereabouts at all times for the teams’ safety.  The suspension of junior water rights will continue through the summer as flows in the river fall.  One Klamath County commissioner warned that violence could easily accompany these calls on water rights.  A rancher stated that the irrigation shutoffs will bring economic disaster because livestock producers will not be able to feed their herds.  One rancher worries about where to find decent pasture for her cattle and sent some to family ranches.  They will need to begin purchasing hay in roughly six weeks.  It would cost an estimated $27 million to feed hay to the more than 70,000 cattle on lands affected by the calls.  Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), June 11, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Del Norte County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Jackson County, OR, Klamath County, OR, Lake County, OR

Title: The Hathaway fire charred at least 2,372 acres in the Banning Pass in southern California
Description: The Hathaway fire burned 2,372 acres through the evening of June 11 and was 30 percent contained, according to the U.S. Forest Service’s Inciweb website.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), June 11, 2013The Hathaway fire charred at least 1,650 acres on the Morongo Indian Reservation north of Banning since June 9.  The fire, which was 25 percent contained on the evening of June 10, was burning through heavy chaparral and drought-and bark beetle-damaged timber.  The South Coast Air Quality Management District  issued a smoke advisory for people in northern parts of the Banning Pass and around Big Bear Lake to alert them to deteriorating air quality.  Officials hope that the fire might be completely contained by the end of June.  When the fire began, the region was in severe drought, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor released June 6, 2013.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), June 10, 2013
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Cutbacks in deliveries from Rio Grande River for farmers in El Paso, County, Texas and Mexico
Description: Farmers receiving water from the El Paso County Water Improvement District No. 1 will receive a record low allotment of 6 acre-inches, according to the general manager.  The El Paso Improvement Water District No. 1 usually gets 370,000 acre-feet from the Rio Grande, but will get only 60,000 acre-feet in 2013.  El Paso Water Utilities usually gets 60,000 acre-feet, but will get just 6,448 acre-feet this year.  Juárez irrigators in Mexico normally receive 60,000 acre-feet, but will get a meager 3,300 acre-feet in 2013.  Drought prompted El Paso Water Utilities to drill new wells, upgrade existing wells, build new pipelines to transfer water more efficiently from its well fields and boost production at the desalination plant.  The Elephant Butte reservoir in Sierra County, New Mexico holds just over 10 percent of capacity with 235,000 acre-feet in storage.  The water level is 92 feet below the dam spillway.  El Paso Times (Texas), June 7, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Dona Ana County, NM, Sierra County, NM, El Paso County, TX

Title: Drought reduced carrying capacity on ranch in Texas Panhandle
Description: Drought has forced the JA Ranch to destock to protect the pastures and will force them to cull more cattle if drought continues.  Calves weigh 100 to 150 pounds, which is less than normal.  AgWeb.com (Mexico, Mo.), June 7, 2013
Places: Armstrong County, TX

Title: Irrigators in the Klamath Irrigation District in Oregon and California to receive two-thirds of normal water delivery
Description: More groundwater is being pumped in the Klamath Irrigation District and fields were left fallow to compensate for water allocations that are about two-thirds of normal.  Peak snowfall was about 68 percent of average, and rainfall has been about 50 percent of normal.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 6, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Del Norte County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Jackson County, OR, Klamath County, OR, Lake County, OR

Title: The Powerhouse wildfire burned at least 25,000 acres north of Los Angeles, California
Description: The Powerhouse wildfire near Lake Hughes, north of L.A., burned 25,000 acres, including six houses by the evening of June 2.  At least 1,000 other homes were threatened by the fire, which prompted the evacuation of more than 2,000 people.  The wildfire was 20 percent contained and may not be brought under control for a week, officials said.  High temperatures and wind variability have driven the fire in an area that the U.S. Drought Monitor characterizes as being in severe drought.  New York Times (N.Y.), June 3, 2013
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: County judge in El Paso County, Texas seeking ban on all fireworks through the Fourth of July
Description: Drought and the elevated fire danger led County Judge Escobar to make a declaration of local disaster, valid for one week, and to request that county commissioners prohibit the sale and use of all fireworks in the unincorporated parts of El Paso County.  The governor and the El Paso Commissioners Court must approve the disaster declaration to extend it through July 5.  "Part of our challenge is that the drought has been ongoing for El Paso. It's not like we had a relief. We have had year after year of drought, the situation gets more severe as more time passes," said the county judge.  The Texas A&M Forest Service found the Keetch-Byram Drought Index to be 730 in El Paso and expects the KBDI to rise to 737 in the next two weeks.  If the disaster declaration is extended, this would be the third year that fireworks have been banned in unincorporated parts of El Paso County.  The area manager of TNT Fireworks opposes the potential fireworks ban, saying that the fireworks industry has lost millions of dollars in sales because the county has not allowed fireworks in unincorporated parts of the county in recent years, and has forced him personally to find other sources of income.  El Paso Times (Texas), June 2, 2013
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: El Paso County, TX, El Paso, TX

Title: Steelhead salmon rescued from dry Carmel River in Monterey County, California
Description: A 13-mile dry stretch of the Carmel River forced the rescue of steelhead salmon from the river in the summer of 2013 and relocating them to better parts of the river.  Washington Post (D.C.), Feb. 10, 2014
Places: Monterey County, CA

Title: Lavaca County, Texas, lowered water table, dry pastures, reduced hay yield
Description: I run a small plant nursery and daily watering of everything is taking its toll on our well. Water table seems to have dropped. We have never really recovered from the drought of several years ago. We had some spring rain this year, but not enough to really soak the soil or fill local wells and tanks. Now that we have had no rain for just several weeks, the pastures are crisp and dry. Local farmers harvested one, at the most two, cuts of hay this season.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Hallettsville 8.0 N on 6/28/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Lavaca County, TX

Title: Ninety-five percent of California beaches received grades of A or B for water quality during the summer of 2013
Description: Ninety-five percent of California beaches received grades of A or B for water quality during the summer of 2013 when there was little rain to wash pollutants to the sea.  This represents a 2 percent improvement over 2012, according to the annual Beach Report Card by Heal the Bay, an environmental group.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), May 22, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Del Norte County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Orange County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Temporary pumps in use, outdoor watering prohibited around White River Lake in Texas
Description: Two temporary floating pumps are pulling water out of White River Lake and sending it to the treatment plant on the lake’s shore since the permanent pumps cannot be used with the lake so low.  In May, the White River Lake district imposed severe watering restrictions that prohibited outdoor watering.  White River Lake provides water for about 10,000 people.  GO San Angelo/San Angelo Standard Times (Texas), July 24, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Crosby County, TX

Title: Many California farmers producing more, using less water with drip-tape
Description: Drought and limited water allocations pushed California farmers to seek more efficient ways to irrigate their crops.  Some farmers plant crops that need less water, store excess water in groundwater reserves during wetter years, try growing genetically altered crops that lose less water through evapotranspiration, leave land fallow or use drip-tape to direct water where it can be better used with less water waste.  Roughly one-third of the 9.4 million acres of irrigated land in California is irrigated with drip-tape to conserve water.  In addition, yields are higher using drip-tape than they are with other irrigation methods.  A grower northwest of Visalia estimated that he uses 20 to 40 percent less water with drip-tape.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), May 30, 2013
Places: California, Tulare County, CA

Title: Farmers in Hidalgo County, Texas selling their farmland due to drought, meager water supplies
Description: Farmers in Hidalgo County have resorted to selling their agricultural land because the drought and meager water supplies make it nearly impossible to turn a profit.  A real estate broker noted that many farmers were putting their land up for sale and some were putting the money into certificates of deposit at the bank because the interest earned is comparable to profits from farming.  A farmer selling agricultural land near Mercedes commented on how difficult it will be to sell land he farmed for a long time.  KRGV-TV Channel 5 Weslaco (Texas), May 28, 2013
Places: Hidalgo County, TX

Title: Hudspeth County, Texas, early sale of livestock, insufficient food for livestock
Description: .063 Total rain so far this year!  Grass is dying out in places!  Fewer mesquite beans this year.  Sage brush is still trying to grow.  Livestock has been moved to market and remainder having to be supplemented more than usual.  Deer herd has moved into alfalfa field to survive.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Salt Flat 10.7 NE on 5/28/2013
Places: Hudspeth County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Wichita County, Texas
Description: Wichita County commissioners instituted a burn ban on May 28 because the Keetch-Byram Drought Index is high; fuel for wildfires is abundant; winds are strong; and water supplies for firefighting are dwindling.  Outdoor burning is banned in unincorporated parts of the county.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), May 29, 2013
Places: Wichita County, TX

Title: A wildfire in the Los Padres National Forest in California charred 2.8 square miles
Description: A wildfire in the Los Padres National Forest charred 2.8 square miles of parched chaparral, oak and pine, leading to evacuations of about 50 cabins, vacation rentals and homes.  The blaze claimed two vehicles and a U.S. Forest Service garage.  The Santa Barbara County fire captain said, “There's a lot of dry vegetation in its path.  It's still spring — it's not even summer — and it's burning like it's August or September."  The fire was 10 percent contained on May 28.  Washington Post (D.C.), May 27, 2013
Places: Santa Barbara County, CA

Title: Aerial fireworks banned in El Paso County, Texas
Description: El Paso County Commissioners banned the sale and use of aerial fireworks in unincorporated parts of the county, due to the drought and high fire danger.  The county judge plans to request a total ban on fireworks on June 3.  El Paso Times (Texas), May 21, 2013
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Grass growing on the exposed bed of Lake Bridgeport, north of Fort Worth, Texas
Description: Grass is growing on the exposed bed of Lake Bridgeport, which is 16.75 feet low.  The low level of the lake and others that hold supplies for Tarrant Regional Water District may lead to water restrictions in a few weeks when the district’s lakes fall to 75 percent of capacity.  The lakes were at 76 percent of capacity on May 14.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), May 14, 2013
Places: Wise County, TX

Title: Lower waters bring early sightings of herons seeking fish in Mendocino County, California
Description: Started watering vegetable garden and flowers in April this year, instead of June. Cahto Creek and other area creeks are extremely low, though still flowing.  Earlier sightings of herons - who take advantage of lower waters to fish.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Laytonville 1.1 SW on 5/13/2013
Places: Mendocino County, CA, Laytonville, CA

Title: Low lake levels affecting fishing and boating in Montague County, Texas; drinking water quality deteriorating
Description: May 11, 2013: The drought in Montague County since fall (2012) has lowered the lake levels to where boats are sitting on dirt...docks seem to be getting brittle due to their dryness. The regular fishing spots are dry and the mold has grown totally over the farm ponds that now just have water in the bottom area. Our drinking water over the last two months (March, April into May 2013) has a bad smell & is getting worse. We are boiling water & using filtering pitchers for drinking water.  Most grass & trees are green but brown grass is starting to show more over the last month. So far the fishing & boating recreation has been affected & the boating safety due to low water levels which bring the underwater trees, old wood decking etc. closer to the surface for boats to run into. The farm fields seem to be a bit dry at this time but not overdry so we still hope to get in fruits & veggies.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Bowie 0.5 WSW on 5/11/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Montague County, TX, Bowie, TX

Title: Homeowner irrigating permanent plantings, pine trees dying in Mariposa County, California
Description: Who knows when this started.  It is continuing from last year--hardly any rain to speak of this spring.  We have had to irrigate permanent plantings,  and pine trees are dying, as they did last year.  The grass is very low, and the snow pack in the high country, from which farmers and all others get their water, is very far from normal.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Mariposa 3.7 NNW on 5/11/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Mariposa County, CA, Midpines, CA

Title: Trees dying, homeowner watering landscaping plants in Fannin County, Texas
Description: We have been in a drought in North Texas for over 3 years; it has killed several of our pecan trees and a lot of shallow root trees. We have dead trees all along FM 1206.We have gotten some rain during the early spring but it just quit about 3 weeks ago. All the fronts that come through the rain goes south of us. I am watering garden and flowers and fruit trees to keep them alive. We have 2 katopa trees in our yard that are over 100 years and both of them have died.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Savoy 5.3 NNE on 5/11/2013
Places: Fannin County, TX

Title: Drought, late freezes slow crop growth, delay opening of farmers markets in Vernon and Wichita Falls, Texas
Description: Drought and late freezes have delayed fruit and vegetable production and the opening of the farmers market in Vernon and Wichita Falls.  The farmers market in Vernon will delay its opening to June 1st instead of mid-May, while the farmers market in Wichita Falls will open on May 21 rather than on May 7.  KFDX-TV NBC 3 (Wichita Falls, Texas), May 7, 2013
Places: Wichita County, TX, Wichita Falls, TX, Wilbarger County, TX, Vernon, TX

Title: Dry fuels feed Ventura County, California, wildfire
Description: Dry fuels and low relative humidity led to a wildfire that has burned at least 10,000 acres and damaged 15 houses, 5 commercial properties, and 15 outbuildings in Ventura County, California. For more information: http://ktla.com/2013/05/03/brush-fire-burning-off-101-in-camarillo/#axzz2SFXol2SDFrom a NOAA employee in Hanford, California, on May 2, 2013.The Springs fire with flames 20 feet high drove thousands from their homes on the morning of May 2 and charred more than 6,500 acres in the span of a few hours.  Several RVs, some out buildings and some agricultural structures were destroyed by the fire. The dry winter and spring months have set the region up for a bad fire season as the vegetation reaches levels of dryness not normally seen until later in the year.   Los Angeles Times (Calif.), May 2, 2013.The Springs Fire had consumed more than 28,000 acres of rugged, brush-covered terrain by late in the afternoon on May 3 and was 20 percent contained, according to Cal Fire.  Clarksville Leaf-Chronicle (Tenn.), May 3, 2013.A 44-square-mile wildfire in the western Santa Monica Mountains was 80 percent contained after rains helped bring the fire under control.  The fire consumed more than 85 percent of the 22 square-mile Point Mugu State Park.  Bellingham Herald (Wash.), May 6, 2013
Places: Ventura County, CA, Camarillo, CA

Title: Cal Fire officials to begin hiring and training firemen in northern California a month ahead of schedule
Description: The dry, windy  conditions prompted Cal Fire officials to begin hiring and training firemen in northern California in early May, a month ahead of schedule.  Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), May 2, 2013
Places: Alameda County, CA, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Butte County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Del Norte County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Inyo County, CA, Kings County, CA, Lake County, CA, Lassen County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Merced County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Mono County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Rio Grande Regional Water Authority in Texas attempting to draw attention to water situation with Mexico
Description: The board members of the Rio Grande Regional Water Authority voted to use all available funds in the budget to organize and execute a media blitz to show the public and Congress that Mexico is disregarding the water treaty and is violating the treaty by constructing dams to withhold more water.  Meanwhile, the Rio Grande Valley in deep south Texas is headed toward an agricultural disaster for lack of water.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), May 1, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Threat of Valley fever requires relocation of high-risk inmates from prisons in the San Joaquin Valley in California
Description: Thousands of high-risk inmates must be removed from the Avenal and Coalinga prisons in the San Joaquin Valley, due to the increasing incidence of Valley fever, caused by an airborne fungus.  The order is complicated by the fact that California prisons are already overcrowded and the Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation is to reduce the state prison population by 9,000 inmates by December 2013.Valley fever cases are highest in Arizona (70 percent of cases) and California (25 percent), according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.  Most incidences of Valley fever occur in the central San Joaquin Valley, with the highest rates of illness at the Avenal and Coalinga prisons, where the disease contributed to the deaths of 24 inmates between 2006 and 2011.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 29, 2013
Places: Fresno County, CA, Coalinga, CA, Kings County, CA, Avenal, CA

Title: Cotton farmers in the Rio Grande Valley in South Texas planted about half as much cotton as usual, due to drought, lack of irrigation water
Description: Farmers in the Rio Grande Valley planted an estimated 80,000 acres of cotton, down from the average 150,000 acres planted the last three years, due to drought and the lack of irrigation water.  Between 2004 and 2006, an average of 220,000 acres were planted in cotton in this area.  Most of the cotton in the dryland fields did not emerge from lack of moisture.  In some fields with irrigation, crop growth was slow despite preplant irrigation and a second irrigation.  The slow growth allows ample opportunity for pests to damage the crop, and insect pressure is expected to be more intense than usual this year, partly due to the lack of rain and irrigation water.  SeedQuest (Oakland, California), April 26, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Utility poles fires cause power disruption in Cameron, Willacy and Hidalgo counties in south Texas
Description: More than 2,200 electric customers in Cameron County, 631 customers in Willacy County and 621 in Hidalgo County lost power on April 24 from fires atop utility poles.  The fires occur when rain moistens accumulated dust and debris atop the utility poles, and allows it to conduct electricity, igniting the wooden poles.  KGBT-TV CBS 4 Harlingen (Texas), April 24, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: The International Boundary and Water Commission releasing water from Amistad and Falcon reservoirs on the Rio Grande River to provide more water to the Lower Rio Grande Valley in Texas and also to Mex
Description: The International Boundary and Water Commission is releasing water from Amistad and Falcon reservoirs on the Rio Grande River to provide more water to the Lower Rio Grande Valley in Texas and also to Mexico.  The water releases from Amistad Lake will likely drop the level near a record low of 1,058 feet set in August 1998.  Amistad and Falcon reservoirs were at 34.7 percent of capacity as of April 22.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 23, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Brownsville, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Val Verde County, TX, Willacy County, TX, Zapata County, TX

Title: Fewer pollinators and flowering plants in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas
Description: There are fewer pollinators and flowering plants in the Rio Grande Valley, due to drought, stated a park naturalist.  He also noted that all wildlife is adversely affected by the drought if plants are not doing well.  The pollinators should return when drought abates.  KRGV-TV Channel 5 Weslaco (Texas), April 23, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Description: Drought and cool temperatures slowed crop development in the Coastal Bend of Texas.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), April 30, 2013

Title: Some cow and calf producers in the Texas Panhandle finally liquidating their herds
Description: Some cow and calf producers in the Texas Panhandle held on as long as they could and were finally liquidating their herds.  Most rangeland and pastures were in very poor to poor condition.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), April 30, 2013

Title: Fewer livestock to graze wheat in Rolling Plains of Texas
Description: A late freeze damaged much wheat in the Rolling Plains of Texas.  Since drought led many producers to sell livestock, there were fewer cattle in the region to graze on the wheat.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), April 30, 2013

Title: Livestock producers in Southwest Texas offered supplemental feed to their livestock and were selling cattle
Description: Livestock producers in Southwest Texas offered supplemental feed to their livestock and were selling cattle.  More rain was needed to boost rangeland production for the summer months.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), April 30, 2013

Title: Dry conditions drove cattle producers in West Central Texas to continue selling cattle
Description: Dry conditions drove cattle producers in West Central Texas to continue selling cattle as rangeland and pastures were in very poor condition.  Low soil moisture and cool temperatures hampered grass growth.  Increasing temperatures and drought will soon end the growth of cool season grasses and forbs.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), April 30, 2013

Title: Drought continues to affect parts of South Texas
Description: Drought continues to affect parts of South Texas.  Cattle body condition scores In McMullen County were fair to poor and were deteriorating.  The majority of the row crops in Jim Wells County did not establish a stand.  Livestock producers in Webb County were burning the spines off prickly pear cactus for the cattle to eat.  Crop producers in Cameron County did not have adequate supplies of irrigation water.  Spring-planted dryland grain and cotton in Hidalgo County was decimated by drought, but fields with irrigation did better.  Crops in Willacy County failed without rainfall.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), April 30, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Jim Wells County, TX, McMullen County, TX, Webb County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Many cotton growers in the South Plains of Texas pre-watered their fields
Description: Many cotton growers in the South Plains of Texas pre-watered their fields in advance of cotton planting, but the outlook for the crop is poor.  Livestock producers continued to offer supplemental feeding to their cattle.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), April 30, 2013
Places: Bailey County, TX, Borden County, TX, Castro County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: Few wildflowers blooming in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas
Description: The Rio Grande Valley has very few wildflowers to admire this year since drought has left most of the seeds dormant.  An outdoor journalist who travels the Valley said, “This is the worst I have ever seen it this time of year here in Deep South Texas. We might have to wait until next year for wildflowers in the Valley.”  Normally, fields full of bluebonnets, Western primrose and other flowers would be in bloom at this time of year.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 22, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority began releasing water from the Highland Lakes to provide sufficient water for the threatened blue sucker
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority began releasing water from the Highland Lakes to provide sufficient water for the threatened blue sucker fish, which will be spawning over the next four weeks.  Spring rains below Austin usually bring enough water for spawning, which occurs on gravel-bottomed stretches of the Colorado River between Eagle Lake and Bastrop, but drought has reduced the flow.  The LCRA may release about 20,000 acre-feet of water during the next four weeks.  As of April 22, the combined storage in lakes Buchanan and Travis was 40 percent.  Low water levels in the Highland Lakes led to a second year of irrigation water being denied to rice farmers along the lower part of the Colorado River.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 22, 2013
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Llano County, TX, Travis County, TX

Title: Cal Fire began deploying fire crews ahead of schedule in SoCal
Description: Cal Fire began deploying fire crews ahead of schedule since dry conditions have resulted in greater fire danger and more fires than usual early in the year.   Brush in the hills of Los Angeles has dried out more quickly than usual; Ventura County firefighters say the arid conditions resemble that of June or July; and the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection has responded to 150 more fires in 2013 than it had by this time last year.  Southern California is on track to have its fourth driest year since 1877.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), April 19, 2013
Places: Imperial County, CA, Kern County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Drought leaves Antelope Valley California Poppy Reserve barren
Description: Drought prevented orange poppies from flourishing in the Antelope Valley California Poppy Reserve this year.  Instead, the area looks like a “brown shag rug” and, consequently, has not drawn many visitors.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), April 19, 2013
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: Trees still weakened from drought near Abilene, Texas were suffering from more disease problems than usual
Description: Trees still weakened from drought in the Abilene area were suffering from more disease problems than usual, noted a tree specialist.  Hypoxylon canker, a fungus that affects wounded or weakened trees, has been found among mainly red and post oaks.  The tree specialist anticipates that the drought weary trees will suffer from more insect infestations than usual in the near future.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 17, 2013
Places: Taylor County, TX

Title: Only 10 percent of the grain sorghum in Nueces County, Texas germinated
Description: Only 10 percent of the grain sorghum in Nueces County has germinated and is not expected to last long without rain.  The county has gotten just 2.5 inches of rain in the last six months, the least amount for this period since 1961.  KRIS-TV Corpus Christi (Texas), April 16, 2013
Places: Nueces County, TX

Title: Joshua trees in southern California, southern Nevada and western Arizona blooming abundantly
Description: Drought conditions may be the reason Joshua trees in Joshua Tree National Park and parts of Nevada and Arizona are producing abundant blossoms, desert ecologists think, as the area undergoes two years of drought.  Many other plant species demonstrate a greater effort at reproduction during drought to ensure the species survives.  Palm Springs Desert Sun (Calif.), April 10, 2013
Places: La Paz County, AZ, Maricopa County, AZ, Mohave County, AZ, Yuma County, AZ, Inyo County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, Esmeralda County, NV, Nye County, NV

Title: Water restrictions continued in Cameron County, Texas; purple martins affected
Description: Continued water restrictions, lots of dead grass leading to blowing dirt and impacting air quality.  Plus so far it seems it is affecting how many purple Martins are returning; the count is down in my area about 80%, Some farmers can irrigate, but others can't. One city is reporting deteriorating water quality.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Brownsville 6.4 WNW on 4/8/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Brownsville, TX

Title: Concho County, Texas, producer has to clean air filter every day
Description: I had a producer who is in the center of Concho County (part that received the big rainfall last September 2012) [who said] that he has to blow out his air filter on his Honda Mule ATV each day after checking and feeding livestock. He has only the regular rangeland acreage of grass, mesquite and prickly pear so that indicates a huge photo to me of just how much grass cover has died and has been lost due to prolonged drought. Just had to pass it on since it was new way to me to explain drought. Submitted April 8, 2013, by Daniel J. Lange, CED, Concho-Menard County FSA
Places: Concho County, TX

Title: Dry conditions lead to water conservation measures, outside fire ban in Nueces County, Texas
Description: My island city has been dry for so long that grasses are being displaced by weeds, an outside fire ban is in effect, and the inland lakes require an area water conservation. All water usage is for health and necessity, drinking water is from grocery stores, convenience outlets.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Port Aransas 1.3 ENE on 4/6/2013
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Nueces County, TX

Title: Low level of Medina Lake in Texas offers clean-up opportunity
Description: The falling level of Medina Lake has exposed plenty of rusty 55-gallon drums, a Jeep, a hot tub and other debris.  Residents around the lake intend to take advantage of the low water level to clean up trash around Medina Lake just like they clean up Medina River each year.  One resident on the lake paid to have 52 exposed drums removed from the lake in 2012, but the receding water level has revealed another 30 drums.  The lake was at 6.5 percent of capacity.  San Antonio Express-News (Texas), April 5, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bandera County, TX, Medina County, TX

Title: Agriculture showing effects of continued drought in Young County, Texas
Description: Young County is still suffering the effects of numerous years worth of low rainfall, unseasonal high temperatures, very high winds and drought.  Ranchers in the area have been forced to suspend cattle-on-the-gain activities as well as reduce stocking rates by as much as 60-70% of normal. Native and improved pastures have seen very little growth of grass over the last 4 years and ranchers are facing a 1:140 cow-to-acre ratio to provide adequate nutrition along with their supplemental feeding regiment.  Fall-seeded row crops (wheat) usually provide significant fall grazing within the county, but due to lack of moisture, crop growth has been stifled and grazing acres have been cut short.  Ranchers have stated that if no significant rain comes in the next two months, cattle numbers will again take a dive.  Farmers are being forced to decide whether to gamble paying the cost of land preparation, seed, and fertilizer for the upcoming spring planting season in the case that rain continues to evade the county.  The burn ban has been reinstated, and red flag days have been common as the temperature rises.  Lakes levels are teetering at 50% and water usage for private as well as agricultural use is being limited.
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Communities in South Texas striving to conserve water and maintain steady flow in canal system
Description: Authorities in Rio Hondo have imposed water restrictions and will fine violators up to $200 as the city strives to conserve water.  Rio Hondo, San Benito and the East Rio Hondo Water Supply Corporation were considering purchasing water together to maintain a steady flow in the region’s canal system so customers would continue to receive water.  Officials for the San Benito irrigation district have warned that they may run out of water by the end of May, but were unsure how much water they may need to purchase to keep water moving in the canals because the water situation has never been so dire before now.   The further the cities are from the Rio Grande River, the more water they need to purchase.  The cities were also considering using treated water in the canals.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 1, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Rio Hondo, TX, San Benito, TX

Title: Desperation led ranchers in South Texas to burn the spines off prickly pear cactus to provide some nourishment for their livestock
Description: Desperation led ranchers in South Texas to burn the spines off prickly pear cactus to provide some nourishment and water for their livestock.  The cactus has little protein for the cattle, but ranchers can provide protein pellets, or range cubes, to sustain the livestock.  Ranchers also need an adequate supply of cactus, otherwise cattle will continue eating unburned cactus with spines, which hurt the animals’ mouths, leading to new problems.  Area ranchers were also transporting hay and water for their animals, stated an AgriLife Extension agent in Starr County.  He also noted that many area ranchers were in their late 60s and 70s, meaning that the timeframe for selling livestock, waiting for the drought to break,  rebuilding herds and recouping their investment might be out of reach for some ranchers, leaving them to hold on to their cattle rather than give in and sell.  SouthWest Farm Press (Texas), March 25, 2013
Places: Brooks County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Jim Hogg County, TX, Starr County, TX, Webb County, TX, Zapata County, TX

Title: Water restrictions instituted; homeowner chooses drought-tolerant and native plants in San Antonio, Texas
Description: Most rain barrels are empty; water rates have increased; water restrictions have been instituted for watering property. Collecting water at all faucet outlets; choosing drought tolerant or native plants to plant on property. Garden attracts variety of small animals due to diversity of vegetation and water features.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Terrell Hills 2.8 N on 3/22/2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bexar County, TX, San Antonio, TX

Title: California State Water Project water allocations reduced from an estimated 40 percent to 35 percent
Description: The last snow survey in California revealed just 17 percent of normal snowpack, said California Department of Water Resources (DWR).  Due to the slim snowpack, the DWR said that it may be able to provide just 35 percent of the requested water amounts from the State Water Project to the 29 agencies that buy water from the DWR.  Water allotments have not been so low since 2008.  The projected runoff from the Colorado River into Lake Powell is 44 percent and has been below normal for 11 of the last 14 years.  The limited water supply in California means that the state will have to use stored water from large reservoirs in southern California, such as Diamond Valley Lake, which contains 800,000 acre-feet of water.  KPBS-TV PBS San Diego (Calif.), May 3, 2013.The California Department of Water Resources announced that State Water Project water allocations were reduced from an estimated 40 percent to 35 percent since the average snowpack was 57 percent of normal for mid to late March.  Napa Valley Register (Calif.), March 27, 2013.
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: California ranchers have to feed, water cattle
Description: Poor rains during the spring left pastures rather dry and offering little for grazing this fall, said a University of California Cooperative Extension livestock and natural resources advisor for Yuba, Sutter and Butte counties.  Fall rains, too, have been disappointing, and did not promote much grass growth, leaving ranchers to buy dry feed and hay, although hay prices were high in California, due to poor production.  Stock water supplies were low also.A dryland cattle producer in Riverside and Tulare counties said that he began feeding hay in September and buys culled oranges, lemons, avocadoes and other fruit and vegetable byproducts to feed his cattle until he has better range for his cattle.  To conserve feed, he weaned his calves early and sold about 25 percent of his cows.  He had already culled 15 percent of his cattle in 2012 and sold all of his heifers during the last two years, leaving him no replacements.A San Joaquin County cattle producer moved his cattle to several properties to allow them to graze and stretch the feed.  He also sent some yearlings to feedlots early.  A cattle producer in Nevada County reported that drought has driven up his production costs, forcing him to leave his cattle on the range longer and buy more hay than usual.A Santa Cruz County cattle producer began feeding hay in September and hopes there will be adequate grass in January or February to feed the livestock because he’ll be out of feed by then.  He has thinned his herd by about 10 percent and purchased about 30 percent more hay.  Central Valley Business Times (Calif.), Dec. 4, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Butte County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Pollen count high in the San Joaquin Valley in California
Description: The warm, dry spring in the Fresno area prompted plants to ratchet up the pollen production, which is a survival mechanism many plants employ during drought.  As a result, many allergy sufferers were exceptionally miserable and will likely be for a while.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 8, 2013

Title: Marshes mostly dry in Lower Klamath National Wildlife Refuge in southern Oregon, northern California
Description: Very few birds visited the Lower Klamath National Wildlife Refuge because its marshes have mostly dried up for the earliest dry date in the last 70 years.  The refuge has not received water since March, leaving no water to draw migratory birds, despite being on the Pacific Flyway.  Indian tribes and agriculture have older water rights than the refuge does.  The manager of the Klamath refuge said that the park needs about 95,000 acre-feet of water to operate at full capacity, but often does not get the water it needs.  The refuge received 3,700 acre-feet in 2010 and 24,000 acre-feet in 2012.  Portland Oregonian, Hillsboro Argus, Oregon Live.com (Ore.), July 7, 2013
Places: Siskiyou County, CA, Klamath County, OR

Title: Texas rice farmers face second year without irrigation water
Description: Most rice farmers in Colorado, Wharton and Matagorda counties along the Lower Colorado River in Texas will not receive irrigation water for the second year in a row since lakes Travis and Buchanan did not hold more than 850,000 acre-feet as of March 1st.  This makes the second year in the history of the Lower Colorado River Authority that rice farmers will not get water.  The amount of water in the lakes was 823,551 acre-feet.  KTRK-TV ABC 13 Houston (Texas), March 1, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Texas Congressional members asking for the President to intervene in fulfillment of 1944 Water Treaty with Mexico
Description: A group of 35 Texas Congressional members sent a letter to President Obama, requesting that his administration intervene on Texas’ behalf concerning Mexico’s fulfillment of the 1944 Water Treaty.  The group is frustrated that Mexico has not regularly delivered water it owes the U.S. and wants the highest levels of the U.S. government to act on the matter since the issue has not been resolved by the International Boundary and Water Commission.The treaty states that Mexico has to deliver 1,750,000 acre-feet of water to the U.S. every five years.The Monitor (McAllen, Texas), Sept. A number of U.S. congressmen, are seeking President Obama’s involvement with the desperate water supply situation in South Texas and sent drought maps to show that Mexico was not in such dire drought that they could not release water into the Rio Grande River to provide relief to South Texas communities.  Congressmen signing the letter were U.S. Rep. Filemon Vela, D-Brownsville; Ruben Hinojosa, D-Mercedes; Henry Cuellar, D–Laredo; Pete Gallegos, D-Alpine, and Beto O’ Rourke, D-El Paso.  The governor of Texas has also requested intervention from the president.  The U.S. State Department and the U.S. International Boundary and Water Commission have not been able to persuade Mexico to release more water in addition to the inadequate amount that they have already released.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 11, 2013Mexico began releasing water from one reservoir into the Rio Grande River on April 5 and stated that one-third of the water was intended for the U.S.  Water from certain tributaries flowing into the Rio Grande River is also for the U.S., so South Texas will get additional water when Mexico receives rainfall.  U.S. Rep. Filemon Vela, D-Brownsville urged the U.S. government to push Mexico to release the water it owes the U.S. so South Texas municipalities and farmers get the water they desperately need.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 8, 2013Four congressmen from South Texas sent a letter on Feb. 14 to Eduardo Medina Mora, Mexico’s ambassador to the United States, and Edward Drusina, commissioner of the International Boundary and Water Commission urging them to assist with getting Mexico to deliver the water it owes, according to the 1944 Guadalupe Treaty.  Leaders of several border communities reported that drought and the depleted Rio Grande River were not providing enough water for municipal and agricultural use.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Feb. 14, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought-affected pastures in the Rolling Plains of Texas remained less productive
Description: Drought-affected pastures in the Rolling Plains of Texas remained less productive than they would normally be, and soil moisture was still low.  Some producers took the opportunity to clean out dirt tanks and ponds and reported no soil moisture lower than 2 feet.  There was not much grazing left with little moisture to sustain the wheat.  Ranchers have not restocked after recent drought conditions forced them to sell cattle and have no plans to do so anytime soon.  Native rangeland and pastures remained in poor to very poor condition.  Farmers were worried that soil moisture levels would fall by spring planting.  Strict water conservation was in effect for some Rolling Plains counties.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), Feb. 20, 2013

Title: Low water supplies in Rio Grande River basin force New Mexico farmers to wait until June or July for irrigation water
Description: The manager of the Elephant Butte Irrigation District stated that farmers would most likely not receive their water allotments until June or July, if water is even released at all, because Elephant Butte Lake only held 9 percent of capacity as of Jan. 30.  The third year of drought for the Rio Grande River has left snow pack low, the riverbed dry and the need for water high in southern New Mexico.  Farmers have pumped groundwater for irrigation in past years, but the water is salty, leading to an accumulation of salt in the soil, which harms crops.  Most of the region’s annual snowfall usually arrives in January, February and early March, so there is still hope for more snow to bolster the water supply.  As of Jan. 30, Elephant Butte Lake held 181,530 acre-feet of water, compared to 330,870 acre-feet last year at this time last year, according to U.S. Bureau of Reclamation records.  Caballo Reservoir contained 8,340 acre-feet on Jan. 30, down from the 14,770 acre-feet that it held one year ago.  Las Cruces Sun-News (N.M.), Feb. 4, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Dona Ana County, NM, Sierra County, NM, El Paso County, TX

Title: Burn ban in the unincorporated parts of Travis County, Texas
Description: A burn ban for the unincorporated portions of Travis County began on Jan. 29, due to the abundance of dry vegetation on the ground, given the ongoing drought.  Travis County commissioners unanimously voted to extend the burn ban through April 24.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), March 26, 2013
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Sonoma County, California, little vegetation for animals
Description: We live on land that is protected by a conservation easement that is intended to preserve natural open space. During a drought, the impacts to natural resources on this property reflect the effects on the broader ecosystem. As a retired wildlife biologist I notice the frogs and turles in our streams are concentrated around a few bedrock pools, which increases their vulnerability to predators. Herbivores are stressed as nutritious green feed is scarce. Trees, like buckeyes and blue oaks, which here in California are adapted to dry summers have already shown fall color and leaf drop, about a month or two early.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Geyserville 10.6 WNW on 8/25/2013
Places: Sonoma County, CA
