County, WY, Hot Springs County, WY, Johnson County, WY, Laramie County, WY, Lincoln County, WY, Natrona County, WY, Niobrara County, WY, Park County, WY, Platte County, WY, Sheridan County, WY, Sublette County, WY, Sweetwater County, WY, Teton County, WY, Uinta County, WY, Washakie County, WY, Weston County, WY

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority board members voted to deny rice farmers irrigation water if the combined storage of Lakes Travis and Buchanan is less than 850,000 acre-feet on March 1, 2013
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority board members voted to deny rice farmers irrigation water if the combined storage of Lakes Travis and Buchanan is less than 850,000 acre-feet on March 1, 2013.  The lakes held roughly 825,000 acre-feet in early January and were not likely to fill much more before the March 1 deadline.  The LCRA voted in November to withhold irrigation water if the combined lake storage was less than 775,000 acre-feet, but opted to reconsider that threshold since November and December brought little precipitation.   If rice farmers get no water again this year, it would be the second year since the lakes were constructed in the 1940s that no irrigation water was provided.  Victoria Advocate (Texas), Jan. 8, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Llano County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Cotton growers in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas planted only 88,772 acres of cotton in 2013 and harvested just 38,348 acres
Description: Cotton growers in the Rio Grande Valley, or Cameron, Hidalgo, Starr and Willacy counties, planted only 88,772 acres of cotton in 2013 and harvested just 38,348 acres, according to the Texas Boll weevil eradication Foundation.  Of the 43 percent of cotton that was harvested, most of that was on irrigated land, said an agricultural economist with Texas A&M AgriLife Research and Extension Center at Weslaco.  The remainder was hurt by drought and not worth harvesting.  SeedQuest (Oakland, Calif.), Dec. 19, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Grass growth, mustard crop decreased in Sonoma County, California
Description: Less grass growth in field. Mustard crop in garden 1/4 of what it was last year (mustard is turned under in spring as green manure).  Additional pumping of well water for garden and decorative plants.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Sebastopol 3.7 WSW on 4/5/2013
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: More fires in the San Mateo-Santa Cruz Cal Fire unit in 2013 than in previous year
Description: The San Mateo-Santa Cruz Cal Fire unit has responded to 344 fires that charred 152 acres in 2013, which was considerably higher than fire statistics from 2012 when 296 blazes burned about 33 acres.  So far, 2013 has been one of the driest years on record in California.  SFExaminer.com (Calif.), Nov. 18, 2013
Places: San Mateo County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA

Title: Low creek in Trinity County, California, has algae bloom on submerged sticks and rocks
Description: We've had below-normal rain and snow this season, after the big storms of late December.  Brown's Creek is just 2" above November benchmark low.  The snowpack is almost nonexistent.  Most residents along this watershed rely on it exclusively for water.  Fish migration/spawning will be affected by low water.  We're already seeing an algae bloom on submerged sticks and rocks.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Douglas City 2.4 SW on 4/7/2013
Places: Trinity County, CA

Title: Low power generation at Lake Texoma on Oklahoma/Texas border
Description: Power generation at Lake Texoma was lower in 2013 than it has ever been since hydroelectric power generation began on the lake in 1945.Herald Democrat (Sherman, Texas), Jan. 17, 2014
Places: Bryan County, OK, Johnston County, OK, Marshall County, OK, Cooke County, TX, Grayson County, TX

Title: Placer County, California, increased fire danger, ski resorts losing business
Description: The calendar year 2013 (which is not the water monitoring year) was the driest consecutive 12 months in recent memory. Major impact for my specific area is an elevated fire danger; marginal snow conditions at the ski resorts reducing the number of tourist & impacting revenue for lodging, restaurants, sporting goods retailers, chain installers, gas stations, tow truck operators, & the ski resorts; & me, personally, income from lack of overtime plowing snow. Normally I get out to ski 50 to 80 times a year.  As of 1/10/14 I have yet to go out.It is a boon for the California highway department as they are saving on all those wages, traction materials, repairs to road surface & guard rails, & maintenance to snow removal vehicles. Insurance companies will see a dramatic drop in claims based upon much less treacherous driving conditions. The highway patrol will also see a dramatic drop in citations due to those safer driving conditions. The locale that I am at the midpoint of the Sierra Nevada, at the crest. This is the "reservoir" of water for virtually the entire 35 million residents of the State of California. Without even a marginal supply of water, the monetary impact will be unimaginable. When it snows up at my location, it's raining in the lower elevations. And to think that 3 short years ago, I was reporting a snow depth in March of 2011 of over 250". Just give us 10% of that right now & we would be ecstatic.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Soda Springs 1.5 SSW on 1/11/2014
Places: Placer County, CA

Title: Wells going dry in San Diego County, California
Description: Groundwater levels in San Diego County dropped so much in 2013 that the county had the fifth most wells that were dug deeper.A residential well in Alpine went dry, forcing the owner to dig deeper to reach water again.The manager of a San Diego-area water well drilling business recommended that everyone pray for rain as water supplies above and below ground become depleted.ABC10 (San Diego, Calif.), May 5, 2014
Places: San Diego County, CA, Alpine, CA

Title: Drought closed marina and store at Santa Margarita Lake in San Luis Obispo County, California
Description: The Santa Margarita Lake Marina & Mini Mart plans to close on April 18 because drought drastically reduced the number of customers coming to the lake, which was at 37.6 percent of capacity.The marina store owner explained the reason for closing by saying, “I’ve had one customer this morning.  Three yesterday. This is spring break. Do you see anyone here?”The gross revenue in 2013 was $50,000, compared to a high of $140,000 in 2006.  He brought in $4,500 over Memorial Day weekend in 2013, which was less than half of the $11,000 he made on the same weekend in 2006.San Luis Obispo County Tribune (Calif.), March 28, 2014
Categories: Business & Industry, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: Tehama County, California agricultural losses from drought estimated at $6.9 million
Description: Drought cost Tehama County $6.9 million in agricultural losses in 2013.  Much of the damage is to 924,000 acres of rangeland for a 70 percent loss, amounting to roughly $6,145,000, a 50 percent loss in barley production at a value of roughly $275,000 and a 40 percent loss to the hay crop, costing an estimated $523,000.  Agricultural Commissioner, Rick Gurrola, sought a disaster declaration for Tehama County, where precipitation was about 20 percent of normal for the first half of 2013.  Red Bluff Daily News (Calif.), July 3, 2013
Places: Tehama County, CA

Title: Farmers in the Rio Grande Valley in Texas lost roughly half of the 90,000 acres of cotton planted in 2013
Description: Rio Grande Valley farmers lost roughly half of the 90,000 acres of cotton planted in 2013.  About half of the cotton is irrigated.  Roughly 60 percent of the 410,000 acres of grain sorghum planted in the Valley was destroyed by drought.  Eighty percent of the grain sorghum is grown without irrigation.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Sept. 1, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Drought, wildfire led to turtle die-off in Elizabeth Lake in Los Angeles County, California
Description: Nearly all of the turtles living in Elizabeth Lake in the Angeles National Forest in northern Los Angeles County died after wildfire and years of drought.  Scientists began studying the turtles in 2014 and noted that ash from wildfires hurt water quality, which was already poor, due to the drought.  YubaNet (Calif.), April 11, 2017
Places: Los Angeles County, CA

Title: Forest mortality rose 300 percent in California's Yosemite National Park
Description: Drought and an army of pine beetles increased forest mortality 300 percent in Yosemite National Park from 2013 to 2014, said federal officials.  Those large bands of dead trees may fuel an active fire season. Los Angeles Times, March 28, 2015
Places: Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Saltwater intrusion a greater problem for California's Salinas Valley amid drought
Description: Seawater intrusion went deeper into Salinas Valley’s underground water supply as groundwater levels dropped between 2013 and 2015 amid California’s years long drought.   Monterey County Herald (Calif.), July 11, 2017
Places: Monterey County, CA, Salinas, CA

Title: Thousands of Chinook salmon eggs and newly hatched salmon died in the Sacramento River in California this year
Description: Thousands of Chinook salmon eggs and newly hatched salmon died in the Sacramento River this year, due to lower water releases from Shasta and Keswick dams and little contribution from the river’s tributaries.  An environmental scientist with the California Department of Fish and Wildlife stated that 20 to 40 percent of the salmon nests were exposed when the river level fell in early November.  Water Environment Federation (Alexandria, Va.), Dec. 12, 2013
Places: Sacramento County, CA, Yolo County, CA

Title: Christmas trees in California growing slower amid drought
Description: Fewer big Christmas trees can be found in California after five years of below-normal precipitation, but tree growers were selling what they had.  A Christmas tree farmer in El Dorado County said demand exceeded supply, but that they would be open while they had trees to sell.  The growth of firs and other traditional Christmas trees has been slowed significantly by the meager rain and snowfall in recent years, so it takes longer to get a “full-sized” tree.  Drought has been particularly hard on Noble fir trees, with many of them bearing plenty of brown needles.  Silver tip firs, Douglas firs, white firs and native incense cedars have tolerated the scarce precipitation better.  Drought in 2013 and 2014 cost tree growers thousands of seedlings planted in those years.  In recent years, growers have begun buying water to keep the trees growing.  Raleigh News & Observer (N.C.), Dec. 5, 2016
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Drought sapped agricultural income in Bastrop County, Texas in 2013
Description: Drought sapped agricultural income in Bastrop County in 2013, said the county extension agent.  The county’s overall agricultural income was $47.5 million in 2013, in comparison with the normal annual income of $55 to $60 million.  Hay production was $13 million in 2013, down from $26 million in 2012.  Pasture conditions were very poor due to the lack of soil moisture.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), March 10, 2014
Places: Bastrop County, TX

Title: Hydropower generation down in central Texas
Description: Hydropower generation by the Lower Colorado River Authority was 69 percent lower in 2013 than in 2011, due to reduced flows from the Highland Lakes. Austin American-Statesman (Texas), May 23, 2014
Places: Burnet County, TX, Llano County, TX, Travis County, TX

Title: Atascosa County, Texas, lack of grass forces ranchers to sell cattle
Description: Soil moisture dried out from previous years lack of rainfall.  What little soil moisture there was evaporated quickly when this past summer' s 100-degree temperatures have arrived. Grass dried and turned crispy resulting in having to sell 2/3 of our cattle herd.  We run a grass-fed operation, so supplemental feed was not an option.   We are trying to learn and use drought mitigation techniques in order to quickly restock and resume operations.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Jourdanton 5.2 NNW on 10/2/2013
Places: Atascosa County, TX

Title: Sonoma County, California, dry streams cause stress to critters, low well water causes residents to conserve
Description: This has been a very dry end to our usual rainy season that runs from October to May, and a very dry start to the coming season which usually brings appreciable rain in October and November before peaking in December and January. Streams are dry, and frogs and turtles are clustered in a few bedrock pools and seeps. Wildlife like raccoons are coming to and digging around landscape plants that are on drip emitters. Our wells are only able to pump water for a few minutes out of each hour, so we are diligently conserving. We are exploring drilling an additional well.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Geyserville 10.6 WNW on 11/13/2013
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: The California State Water Project dropped its water allocations by 35 percent, due to below normal precipitation
Description: The California State Water Project dropped its water allocations by 35 percent, due to below normal precipitation between January and June 2013, which was the driest in the state’s recorded history.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Oct. 15, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Alameda County, CA, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Butte County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mono County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Orange County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Solano County, CA, Yuba City, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Many Monterey pines dead in Cambria Pines by the Sea, California
Description: Many of the tall Monterey pines in Cambria Pines by the Sea have succumbed to drought.  In 2013, one-quarter of the town’s trees died, and most of the remaining trees were brown and brittle.  Some of the trees have fallen over and others were felled for public safety.  Los Angeles Times, Nov. 4, 2014
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA, Cambria Pines, CA

Title: California almonds slightly smaller in 2013
Description: California produced 1.88 billion pounds of almonds in 2013, but the nuts were slightly smaller than usual because the water supplies were scarce in 2013.  The state endured its driest stretch in 90 years between January and May, dropping reservoir levels and limiting water allocations, according to the Bureau of Reclamation.  Lakeland Ledger (Fla.), Jan. 17, 2014
Places: Butte County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Solano County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Burn ban in Collin County, Texas
Description: Collin County commissioners instituted a 90-day outdoor burn ban, due to the elevated fire danger from drought.  Commissioners also prohibited the sale of fireworks with sticks and fins and the use of fireworks in unincorporated parts of the county.  Outdoor fires were also forbidden in the city of McKinney, while a hot work permit program began, requiring persons doing cutting or welding to get a free permit before starting their work.  Dallas Morning News (Texas), Dec. 13, 2012
Places: Collin County, TX, McKinney, TX

Title: Sen. Troy Fraser and Sen. Kirk Watson sent a letter to the Lower Colorado River Authority in central Texas, urging them not to release water to rice farmers
Description: Sen. Troy Fraser and Sen. Kirk Watson sent a letter to the Lower Colorado River Authority (LCRA), urging them not to release water to rice farmers.  The senators assert that giving water to the rice farmers would violate a court order and an agreement with the city of Austin.  The senators also intend to pursue legislation to prohibit future water releases for irrigation and would support legal action to prevent the LCRA from releasing the water to rice farmers in the spring.  The LCRA’s water management plan allows water releases for irrigation when lakes Travis and Buchanan are at 42 percent of capacity or greater, which is what the lakes hold as of Dec. 12.  If the state does not receive more rainfall next year than it did this year and rice farmers get irrigation water in 2013, the water left in lakes Travis and Buchanan may be about 33 percent in early 2014, according to some calculations.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Dec. 12, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Austin, TX, Wharton County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: The fire danger from drought in central Texas prompted two large fireworks vendors to choose to pull certain fireworks from shelves, some counties banned aerial fireworks
Description: The fire danger from drought in central Texas prompted commissioners in Hays, Bastrop, Blanco and Burnet counties to ban fireworks with sticks and fins, while two large fireworks vendors in the area decided not to sell fireworks with sticks and fins to keep the public safe during the Christmas-New Year’s holiday season.  County commissioners in Travis, Williamson and Caldwell county discussed partial fireworks bans, but did not pass them.  Counties must decide by Dec. 15 whether or not they want to ban certain fireworks.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Dec. 11, 2012
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Hays County, TX, Travis County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Hay thefts continue in many parts of the country because drought this summer prevented hay from growing well, driving hay prices higher
Description: Hay thefts continue in many parts of the country because drought this summer prevented hay from growing well, driving hay prices higher.  Three hay growers in Butte County, California have had hay stolen repeatedly from their fields, stated a Custom Hay operator.  Hay sells for more than $200 per ton in California.  In Tillman County, Oklahoma, the clever sheriff planted a GPS unit in a bale of hay located in a field where hay rustlers had already struck, hoping that they would strike again.  He managed to catch the thieves red-handed.  Grass hay prices in Kansas have nearly tripled from about $15 to $25 per bale to $65 to $75 for a bale.  Alfalfa prices rose from about $45 to $60 per bale to $140 to $150 per bale.  The Missouri Farm Bureau president stated that hay thieves were a problem in his state.  Sheriff’s deputies in Butler County, Kansas were patrolling county roads to stem hay thefts.  The Drought Impact Reporter previously noted that hay thefts were occurring in Missouri; New Mexico; Larimer County, Colorado; Butler County, Kansas; New Mexico; and Texas.  NPR (Washington, D.C.), Dec. 5, 2012
Places: Butte County, CA, Butler County, KS, Tillman County, OK

Title: The sale and use of fireworks with sticks and fins was banned in the unincorporated parts of Harris County, Texas
Description: The sale and use of fireworks with sticks and fins was banned in the unincorporated parts of Harris County by the Commissioners Court, due to dry conditions.  The Keetch-Byram Drought Index for the county on Dec. 2 averaged 575, which is also the trigger for prohibiting fireworks.  The season during which fireworks are often permitted extends from Dec. 20 to Jan. 1.  Other types of fireworks were still allowed, but all fireworks prohibited in the city of Houston.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Dec. 4, 2012
Places: Harris County, TX

Title: 30-day burn ban for Williamson County, Texas
Description: Williamson County commissioners voted in favor of a 30-day burn ban on Dec. 4.  The emergency management coordinator recounted how a controlled burn escaped containment the previous day to help commissioners understand the elevated fire danger.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Dec. 4, 2012
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: Voluntary water conservation urged in Killeen and Fort Hood, Texas
Description: Killeen water officials and Fort Hood authorities urged residents to begin conserving water voluntarily since the Bell County Water Control and Improvement District No. 1 was in stage 1 of its Drought Contingency Plan.  The Bell County water district receives water from the Brazos River Authority, which recently announced a stage 1 drought watch for the Lake Georgetown-Stillhouse Hollow subsystem.  Killeen Daily Herald (Texas), Dec. 4, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bell County, TX, Killeen, TX, Coryell County, TX

Title: Low lake levels in the Texoma region close many boat ramps
Description: "Lake Diversion, Kemp, Buffalo, Wichita, all those the boat ramps will be high and dry," stated an employee with the Texas Parks & Wildlife, as drought reduced water levels in those lakes.  The only open boat ramps at Lake Arrowhead were at the west end boat docking area.  Possum Kingdom has extended its boat ramps as the shoreline receded.  KAUZ-TV CBS 6 Wichita Falls (Texas), Dec. 3, 2012
Places: Archer County, TX, Baylor County, TX, Clay County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Wichita County, TX

Title: Thirty-four Texas counties received authorization to use Conservation Reserve Program land for emergency grazing in the fiscal year 2013
Description: Thirty-four Texas counties received authorization to use Conservation Reserve Program land for emergency grazing in the fiscal year 2013 to alleviate the drought-induced shortage of forage for livestock.  The counties are Armstrong, Bailey, Briscoe, Carson, Castro, Childress, Crosby, Dawson, Deaf Smith, Dickens, Donley, Floyd, Gray, Hale, Hardeman, Hemphill, Hockley, Kent, Lamb, Lipscomb, Lubbock, Nolan, Ochiltree, Oldham, Parmer, Potter, Randall, Roberts, Scurry, Sherman, Swisher, Terry, Wheeler and Yoakum.  To be eligible for emergency grazing, the CRP land must not have been hayed or grazed in the past two years.  Those who use eligible CRP land will get 25 percent less than the usual annual payment.  KVII-TV ABC 7 Amarillo (Texas), Dec. 3, 2012
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Bailey County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Castro County, TX, Childress County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Donley County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hardeman County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Kent County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Wheeler County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: Drought affecting sheep flock in Placer and Solano counties in California
Description: Because of the drought, we have reduced the size of our commercial sheep flock by 37% over the last year.  We have a lower lambing percentage this spring, and we're planning on selling all of our lambs at weaning (rather than finishing them on irrigated pasture).From a farmer/rancher in Auburn, California, on May 14, 2014
Places: Placer County, CA, Solano County, CA

Title: Stage 1 drought watch for the Lake Georgetown-Stillhouse Hollow subsystem in Texas
Description: The Brazos River Authority alerted water customers who are in the Lake Georgetown-Stillhouse Hollow subsystem that a stage 1 drought watch was in effect for the subsystem, meaning voluntary water conservation is requested.  Communities in the Lake Georgetown-Stillhouse Hollow subsystem include Round Rock, Georgetown, Lampasas, Kempner Liberty Hill and Harker Heights and others.  The water services manager for the Brazos River Authority explained that falling reservoir levels reached thresholds in the Drought Contingency Plan, prompting the issue of the stage 1 drought watch.  Killeen Daily Herald (Texas), Dec. 4, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bell County, TX, Harker Heights, TX, Killeen, TX, Coryell County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Kempner, TX, Lampasas, TX, Williamson County, TX, Georgetown, TX, Liberty Hill, TX, Round Rock, TX

Title: Some of the dryland wheat in the Panhandle, South Plains and the Rolling Plains of Texas has died or was withering from insufficient rainfall
Description: Some of the dryland wheat in the Panhandle, South Plains and the Rolling Plains has died or was withering from insufficient rainfall, stated AgriLife extension agents in Hansford County, Lipscomb County and Lubbock County.  The AgriLife extension agent for Wilbarger County said, “The lack of rain is really taking its toll on everything.  The wheat is really hurting, and cotton harvest is going to be short and fast. A lot of stocker cattle that were brought in are starting to leave the county.”  SouthWest Farm Press (Texas), Nov. 28, 2012
Places: Archer County, TX, Armstrong County, TX, Bailey County, TX, Baylor County, TX, Borden County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Castro County, TX, Childress County, TX, Clay County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Cottle County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Donley County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Foard County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hardeman County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Jack County, TX, Kent County, TX, King County, TX, Knox County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Montague County, TX, Moore County, TX, Motley County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Parker County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Stonewall County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Throckmorton County, TX, Wheeler County, TX, Wichita County, TX, Wilbarger County, TX, Wise County, TX, Yoakum County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Conditions dire for crops in Foard County, Texas; stock water reserves low
Description: Foard County continues to suffer from below-average moisture fall. Calendar year 2011 was the driest year in recorded history at only 9.37 inches (61% below normal) and though rains have come more frequently in 2012, conditions are currently dire for fall/winter small grain grazing and grain (our primary cash crop). Though all intended acres have been planted, with little or no Oct./Nov. moisture fall the crop may soon be lost. Little or no grazing has resulted from fall plantings. In addition, though the county received normal to above normal rainfall totals from May through September, stock water reserves are still dangerously low.From Jeff Peterson, Farm Service Agency, Crowell, Texas, on November 28, 2012
Places: Foard County, TX, Crowell, TX

Title: About a third of the cotton crop in Tom Green County, Texas not worth harvesting
Description: Roughly 30 percent of the cotton crop in Tom Green County was plowed under because it produced so little cotton, said a Monsanto representative for the area.  The irrigated cotton was average to below average as the land struggled to recover from drought last year.  KJTV-TV 34 Fox Lubbock (Texas), Nov. 26, 2012
Places: Tom Green County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Walker County, Texas
Description: The Walker County Commissioner’s Court enacted a 90-day burn ban for the county, due to the high fire danger and drought conditions.  The average Keetch-Byram Drought Index for Walker County was 537 on Nov. 28.  The county received 38 inches of precipitation so far in 2012, and is 6 inches behind average rainfall.  The Commissioner’s Court will reconvene on Dec. 10 to evaluate the need for a ban on New Year’s Eve fireworks.  The Houstonian (Texas), Nov. 29, 2012
Places: Walker County, TX

Title: Wheat in west central Texas exhibited signs of moisture stress
Description: Wheat in west central Texas exhibited signs of moisture stress as dry, windy conditions existed in the region.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), Nov. 20, 2012
Places: Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coke County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Concho County, TX, Fisher County, TX, Irion County, TX, Jones County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Runnels County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Shackelford County, TX, Sterling County, TX, Taylor County, TX, Tom Green County, TX

Title: Some wheat and oats on the Rolling Plains of Texas died
Description: Some wheat and oats on the Rolling Plains of Texas have died from the lack of moisture.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), Nov. 20, 2012
Places: Archer County, TX, Baylor County, TX, Childress County, TX, Clay County, TX, Cottle County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Foard County, TX, Hardeman County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Jack County, TX, Kent County, TX, King County, TX, Knox County, TX, Montague County, TX, Motley County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Parker County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Stonewall County, TX, Throckmorton County, TX, Wichita County, TX, Wilbarger County, TX, Wise County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Some livestock producers on the South Plains of Texas have begun to give their cattle supplemental feed
Description: Some livestock producers on the South Plains of Texas have begun to give their cattle supplemental feed.  Slow winter wheat growth, due to inadequate moisture, likely means that livestock will not be able to graze it unless the area receives rain soon.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), Nov. 20, 2012

Title: Burn ban in the unincorporated parts of Travis County, Texas

Title: Increased demand for new wells in the vicinity of Austin, Texas
Description: A well drilling business from Bee Cave has had increased demand for their services since the summer of 2011 and was finally catching up on the backlog of requests.  Many of the wells the business drills in Austin were for lawn watering because those wells were not affected by the city’s water restrictions.  Austin leaders passed an ordinance in October requiring homeowners to publicly register private wells in an effort to monitor water use from the northern edge of the Edwards Aquifer.  KEYE-TV We are Austin.com (Texas), Nov. 12, 2012
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Political pressure pushing the Lower Colorado River Authority in Texas toward curtailing water supplies to rice growers again
Description: Political pressure is pushing the Lower Colorado River Authority toward curtailing water supplies to rice growers, although the LCRA said last month that rice growers would not likely go a second year without irrigation water.  Austin and Travis County passed resolutions urging the LCRA to make an emergency request to curtail irrigation supplies to rice farmers in Colorado, Wharton and Matagorda counties.  Residents near lakes Travis and Buchanan have also petitioned to release less water downstream.  Rice production fell by 75 percent this year without irrigation water along the lower Colorado River.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 11, 2012

Title: Drought, land development reduced the supply of milkweed at Pismo State Beach Monarch Butterfly Grove in California
Description: Drought and land development have reduced the supply of milkweed at Pismo State Beach Monarch Butterfly Grove over the past five years.  As a result, fewer monarch butterflies, which feed on milkweed, were returning to Pismo Beach to mate during the fall and winter.   About 23,000 monarchs visited during the last butterfly season between October 2011 and February 2012.  In 1990, at least 200,000 butterflies wintered there.  Adobe Press (Calif.), Nov. 6, 2012
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: Pecan trees in central Texas still affected by drought
Description: Pecan trees in central Texas made more shells than the distressed trees could fill, according to a pecan grower in San Saba County.  The trees have heavy nut loads, but did not have the resources to produce plump pecans in some instances, lowering the overall quality of the pecans.   The 2011 drought stressed pecan trees in central Texas, killing a great number of them.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 6, 2012

Title: The decline of Lake Hemet in Riverside County, California
Description: The Lake Hemet Municipal Water District stopped drawing water from the lake in late 2012 as the volume of water fell to 50 percent of capacity.  In February 2014, the lakebed was exposed and overgrown with weeds since rains have not replenished the lake.  Paddleboats cannot be used in the lake while it is so shallow.Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Feb. 26, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Nursery owner watering stock almost daily in Lavaca County, Texas

Personally, I run a plant nursery and am needing to water all my stock almost daily, thus putting stress on our well.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Hallettsville 8.0 N on 12/14/2012

Places: Lavaca County, TX

Title: Drought devastated dryland cotton in the Texas Panhandle
Description: Drought devastated dryland cotton in Parmer and Bailey counties, according to a Texas Agri-Life specialist.  Overall, cotton production in those counties looks to be down 10 to 20 percent, but the actual shortfall will become apparent when the harvest is further along.  A cotton grower with a field east of Farwell anticipated a decrease in yield on his irrigated land from three bales per acre to just two bales this year.  His rainfed cotton will not even make one bale per acre.  In other years, he has gotten 5,000 to 6,000 bales from his 2,000 acres of land with some rainfed and some irrigated fields, but anticipated getting roughly 1,000 bales altogether this year.  Another cotton grower near Farwell has seen a wide range of yields on his irrigated land, noting that some fields will not be worth harvesting, while others ought to yield three bales per acre.  This farmer said, “The second year of the drought is that much more devastating due to less ground moisture. We've pumped our wells for two years now and don't have the well capacity in most places to pump the amount of water we need for the crops."  The general manager of Parmer County Cotton Growers reported that farmers brought in 40 percent less cotton for ginning this year, but said that hail took out about 20 percent of the acreage and that water was used on more lucrative crops, rather than cotton.  Clovis News Journal (N.M.), Oct. 31, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bailey County, TX, Parmer County, TX

Title: California poultry farm driven to bankruptcy as grain prices rise
Description: The rising price of grain pushed a poultry farm in California to file for bankruptcy.  The $1.8 million weekly expense for feed was too much for this farm that was founded in 1928 and houses 1.9 million turkeys and 600,000 chickens.  The poultry farm shelled out between $7 and $8 per bushel for corn and more than $500 per ton for soybean meal this year.  Soybean meal sold for about $300 per ton in the previous two years.  Wall Street Journal (N.Y.), Oct. 10, 2012
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Lumberjacks were cutting down salvageable dead and dying pine and hardwood trees in eastern Texas
Description: Lumberjacks were cutting down salvageable dead and dying pine and hardwood trees in eastern Texas after drought in 2011 killed or damaged millions of trees across the state.  The wood from the trees was less valuable and of poorer quality, but could still be used for pulpwood.  Hardwood trees, such as oaks, sweet gum and hickory, succumb slowly to drought’s effects, so it remained unclear how many of the trees were dying and how many might recover.  Last year the Texas Forest Service predicted that as many as 500 million trees statewide would die, due to drought.  Trading Charts, Sept. 16, 2012

Title: The level of Medina Lake near San Antonio, Texas fell to 13 percent of capacity
Description: The level of Medina Lake near San Antonio fell to 13 percent of capacity, causing problems for irrigators, business owners and fishermen.  Gates that allow irrigation water to leave the lake were closed to keep water in the lake, so irrigators were out of luck until rain refills the lake.  Merchants say that business had dropped 70 percent.  Launching a boat was difficult for boaters, too, because most docks were not on the water.  While the lake is low, people were taking advantage of the opportunity to do some repairs and pick up trash that would normally be submerged.  KEYE-TV We are Austin.com (Texas), Sept. 12, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Medina County, TX

Title: Hay production was down this year in the Texas-Oklahoma border region
Description: Hay production was down this year in the Texoma region because vegetation has not recovered from drought in 2011, according to a rancher in Durant.  More rainfall is needed to fill stock ponds.  KTEN (Denison, Texas), Sept. 6, 2012
Places: Atoka County, OK, Bryan County, OK, Carter County, OK, Coal County, OK, Johnston County, OK, Murray County, OK, Grayson County, TX

Title: Producer running out of hay for cattle in Denton County, Texas
Description: Drought conditions are worsening. We were hoping for rain to start the rye grass we planted in September, but only dirt and cracks cover our pasture. We will not have enough hay to feed our cattle this winter without rain. Used 9/1 as the start date when we started haying our cows. We have lost trees and grass due to more drought stress this year (drought last year also).CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Sanger 1.8 WSW on 12/4/2012
Places: Denton County, TX

Title: Producer feeding alfalfa and grain to goats in Edwards County, Texas
Description: I reported several small rain totals in August.  Since then it has only rained once.  Lots of morning dew but no real rainfall.  Everything is dead.  There is nothing for the goats to eat so I am having to purchase alfalfa and grain.  The ground is extremely dry.  Without a major change in the weather, spring is going to be a disaster. We had a little break from last year's extreme drought but it really never lifted and it appears 2013 will continue in drought if nothing changes fast.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Rocksprings 11.8 ENE on 12/5/2012
Places: Edwards County, TX

Title: Community's exotic game affected by dried springs and lakes; trees dying in Kerr County, Texas
Description: We raise (as a community) exotic game.  They are beginning to suffer as all the springs are dry and the "lake" is a puddle, and many of the animals are starting to eat the cedar leaves.  Of course, we also see acres of dead cedar and many live oaks that died in the last year from drought that are now beginning to drop their limbs.  Spanish Oaks are beginning to die again; we have lost many trees to lack of water and ensuing disease.  The good news?  Not many mosquitoes.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Kerrville 3.9 WSW on 8/18/2012
Places: Kerr County, TX

Title: Drought forces producer to sell cattle and goats in Sutton County, Texas

Places: Sutton County, TX

Title: Drought may have played a role in anthrax cases in Texas, Colorado
Description: Drought may have played a role in the anthrax deaths of more than 100 animals in Colorado and Texas in the past few weeks.  At least 60 cattle on three different ranches in Logan County, Colorado died.  Roughly 40 sheep died on a ranch near Mertzon, Texas in July.  Anthrax outbreaks are not uncommon west of the Mississippi River and often occur during drought when the anthrax bacteria generate more spores, which become airborne when the soil is disturbed.  Animals frequently come into contact with the spores by ingesting or inhaling them.  Livestock can die from the spores within hours.  Spores can remain viable for decades.  Humans can contract anthrax from infected livestock through a cut in the skin, but the disease is treatable with antibiotics if caught early.  Experts theorize that animals may be stressed by drought and more susceptible to illness.  Lincoln Journal Star (Neb.), Aug. 18, 2012
Places: Logan County, CO, Irion County, TX

Title: Fresno, California, low water levels lead to no rafting on rivers
Description: Very dry conditions across the Valley with little snow pack this past winter to feed the rivers, lakes, etc. Low levels exist at all the lakes in the Central Sierras. Watching out for newly exposed rocks is a major concern while going out fishing. People I know haven't been able to raft on the Merced River or the Kings River because of low water levels, too.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Clovis 2.9 N on 8/16/2012
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Fannin County, Texas, brown pastures, wilting pecan crop, lack of food for cattle
Description: We got .30 of rain day before yesterday but it did not even settle the dust.  Our pool is down about 75% and pasture is brown, good crop of pecans but they are starting to drop.  We drove around the pasture last night and it is bad.  We sold our cows a couple of years ago because of drought and it is a good thing because there is nothing to eat.  More trees are dying.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Savoy 5.3 NNE on 8/14/2012
Places: Fannin County, TX

Title: Producer cuts cattle herd to conserve hay and grazing in Medina County, Texas
Description: I've cut my cattle herd from 48 to 13 head to conserve the hay and grazing I have. If things don't change I will probably reduce further. The only thing saving this part of the country right now is the Eagle Ford Shale oil play and it appears to be getting bigger by the day.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Devine 0.4 S on 4/7/2013
Places: Medina County, TX, Devine, TX

Title: Yosemite Falls and other water falls in the Yosemite National Park in California temporarily dry
Description: Yosemite Falls stopped flowing after an arid winter and summer allowed the falls to run dry in July, which is months earlier than when they usually stop flowing.   Recent rains revived the Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls, Bridalveil and other waterfalls in Yosemite National Park.  The Merced River at the Happy Isles gauging station fell to less than 4 cubic feet per second in October, but did not rise much from the recent rain.  Merced Sun-Star (Calif.), Nov. 23, 2012
Places: Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Commissioners in Wichita County, Texas approved indefinite burn ban
Description: Wichita County commissioners approved an indefinite ban on outdoor burning, due to continuing dry conditions and low water levels.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), July 18, 2012
Places: Wichita County, TX

Title: Drought damaged the structural integrity of State Highway 130 in central Texas
Description: Drought damaged the structural integrity of State Highway 130 under construction from North Austin to Interstate 10.  Clay died out and shrank, leading to shifts in the soil beneath the asphalt and cracks in the road above.  The highway was still expected to open on time, despite the repair work.  KUT-FM 90.5 Austin (Texas), July 16, 2012 and Austin American-Statesman (Texas), July 16, 2012
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hays County, TX, Travis County, TX

Title: USDA Announces Streamlined Disaster Designation Process
Description: Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack July 11 announced a package of program improvements that will deliver faster and more flexible assistance to farmers and ranchers devastated by natural disasters. Vilsack announced three significant improvements to decades-old USDA programs and processes related to Secretarial disaster designations: a final rule that simplifies the process for Secretarial disaster designations and will result in a 40 percent reduction in processing time for most counties affected by disasters; a reduced interest rate for emergency loans that effectively lowers the current rate from 3.75 percent to 2.25 percent; and a payment reduction on Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) lands qualified for emergency haying and grazing in 2012, from 25 to 10 percent. ... The final rule for Secretarial disaster designations is amended as follows: 1) Nearly automatically qualifies a disaster county once it is categorized by the U.S. Drought Monitor as a severe drought for eight consecutive weeks during the growing season. Effective July 12, 1,016 primary counties in 26 states will be designated as natural disaster areas, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low interest emergency loans from USDA’s Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided eligibility requirements are met. 2) Streamlines the USDA Secretarial designation process, which is expected to provide better service to farmers and ranchers by reducing by approximately 40 percent the amount of time required for designating a disaster area. 3) Removes the requirement that a request for a disaster designation be initiated by a state governor or Indian tribal council, increasing the likelihood that counties will be covered. Indian tribal councils and governors may still submit a request for a designation, but it will not be required in order to initiate a disaster declaration. ... http://www.usda.gov/documents/disaster-fast-track-2012.pdf http://www.fsa.usda.gov/Internet/FSA_File/fast_trk_primary_contig_cos.pdfUSDA FSA press release, July 12, 2011

Title: Jim Wells County, Texas, milo crop yield below average, corn crop burned up, wildlife coming close to the house to drink
Description: Milo crop in area is averaging between 400 - 1100 lbs/acre.  Normal average is 3000 - 3500 lbs/acre.  Corn crop is burned up but harvest has not begun on the corn.  Drip watering to keep trees and shrubs alive.  Wildlife coming to water troughs near house to drink.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Orange Grove 3.3 NW on 7/11/2012
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Jim Wells County, TX

Title: Fire hazard increasing, livestock producer feeding hay in Smith County, Texas
Description: Lake levels are dropping at a rapid rate, which has affected the marketability of waterfront homes.  We are having to feed livestock our supply of winter hay as grass has dried to a point of non-growth and lack of protein.  Fire hazards are increasing and many burn bans have been issued in and around our area.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Whitehouse 1.2 SW on 8/19/2012
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Smith County, TX

Title: Fewer acres for rice in Matagorda County, Texas
Description: Land devoted to rice growing in Matagorda County dropped from 24,000 acres in 2011 to 1,500 in 2012, stated Haskell Simon, a representative from the rice-growing communities of the lower basin to the Lower Colorado River Authority.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), July 8, 2012
Places: Matagorda County, TX

Title: Farmer in Colorado County, Texas growing sesame seeds
Description: A Colorado County farmer switched from growing rice to growing less profitable sesame seeds because the crop required less water since the Lower Colorado River Authority was not delivering irrigation water for rice farmers.  The rice crop around Eagle Lake in Colorado County was down at least 75 percent, according to Tom Kallina, owner of Area Rice Marketing, which connects producers of rice with wholesale buyers. Austin American-Statesman (Texas), July 8, 2012
Places: Colorado County, TX

Title: Absence of rice forced alternative practices in Fort Bend County, Texas
Description: With little rice being grown in Colorado County, the owner of a calf-cow operation east of Eagle Lake had to purchase sack feed, costing $250 per ton, for his 60 head, which usually consume two to three tons a week.  He would usually feed them rice bran at just $150 per ton, which was not available this year, due to the drought and lack of irrigation water for growing rice. Austin American-Statesman (Texas), July 8, 2012
Places: Colorado County, TX, Fort Bend County, TX

Title: Outdoor burning, fireworks with sticks and fins banned in Hays County, Texas
Description: A Hays County judge issued an emergency order banning outdoor burning in the unincorporated parts of Hays County.  He also signed an emergency disaster declaration valid for seven days outlawing the use of fireworks with sticks and fins.  The judge consulted the fire marshal, who checks in with area fire chiefs to get their opinion on the fire danger and found support for the burn ban.  The Hays County Commissioners Court will revisit these issues at their next meeting on July 17.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), July 5, 2012
Places: Hays County, TX

Title: Floyd County, Texas, cotton crop doing poorly
Description: Not quite as bad as last year.  No grass, dryland cotton is fixing to give it up in a week.  No way to keep up on longer cotton.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #South Plains 2.0 ENE on 7/4/2012
Places: Floyd County, TX

Title: Fireworks vendors pull flying fireworks in Travis County, Texas
Description: Fireworks vendors in Travis County agreed to voluntarily remove some types of flying fireworks from their shelves, due to the increasing fire danger and dry conditions. Austin American-Statesman (Texas), July 4, 2012
Categories: Business & Industry, Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Partial ban on the sale of winged fireworks in Travis County, Texas
Description: Travis County officials implemented a partial ban on the sale of winged fireworks to reduce the likelihood of accidental fires, given that the area still endured moderate to severe drought.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), July 5, 2012
Places: Bexar County, TX

Title: Canyon, Texas, issues watering restrictions
Description: The city of Canyon, TX, has implemented mandatory water restrictions limiting watering to 3 days per week per household. Violators will be fined. This is stage 2 of the city's Drought Contingency Plan.From Nicholas Fenner, National Weather Service, Amarillo, Texas, on July 24, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Randall County, TX, Canyon, TX

Title: Brownsville, Texas, issues water restrictions for sprinkler systems
Description: On water restrictions for sprinkler systems, only 2 evenings a week.  Some resacas are dry. Birds flock to my bird bath that has a dripper.  But only when dripper is running.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Brownsville 6.4 WNW on 8/16/2012
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Brownsville, TX

Title: Grasses, weeds browning in Winkler County, Texas
Description: Weeds and grasses in Winkler County were starting to turn brown from the high temperatures and the lack of rain. Odessa American (Texas), June 20, 2012
Places: Winkler County, TX

Title: Wells low in Texas' Winter Garden
Description: The water tables were dropping in the Winter Garden area, leaving some of the wells to pump air, said Dr. Larry Stein, AgriLife Extension horticulturist specialist, Uvalde.  Rain was needed to refill rivers and reservoirs.Odessa American (Texas), June 20, 2012
Places: Dimmit County, TX, Frio County, TX, La Salle County, TX, Zavala County, TX

Title: Pastures suffering in Southwest Texas
Description: Pastures in Southwest Texas suffered from extreme heat and dry conditions.Odessa American (Texas), June 20, 2012
Places: Bandera County, TX, Bastrop County, TX, Bexar County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Comal County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Gonzales County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Kerr County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Kinney County, TX, Medina County, TX, Real County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Uvalde County, TX, Wilson County, TX

Title: Grazing conditions poor in Texas Panhandle
Description: Grazing conditions in the Panhandle remained poor from the dry conditions, but recent rainfall helped rangeland and pastures to begin to turn green.  Odessa American (Texas), June 20, 2012
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Wheeler County, TX

Title: Crops stressed in Texas' Coastal Bend, crops to be destroyed
Description: Crops in the Coastal Bend were severely moisture stressed.  Crop insurance companies were releasing many corn and sorghum fields to be destroyed, either by plowing or cutting for hay.  Cattle were stressed by the heat and the poor forage supply.  Odessa American (Texas), June 20, 2012
Places: Aransas County, TX, Austin County, TX, Bee County, TX, Calhoun County, TX, Colorado County, TX, DeWitt County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Goliad County, TX, Jackson County, TX, Karnes County, TX, Lavaca County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Nueces County, TX, Refugio County, TX, San Patricio County, TX, Victoria County, TX, Washington County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Denton County, Texas, forced to sell cattle due to drought
Description: No significant moisture since early June.  Large cracks are in the ground.  Sold all but four calves and one heifer in 2011 due to drought.  Planted rye grass 9/11 and have hay from that so we are ok with our five 'remnant' yearling herd.  They are eating the dead ryegrass we didn't mow or bale.  Watering trees, shrubs to keep them alive and container plants twice a day!  More hummingbirds this summer.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Sanger 1.8 WSW on 8/6/2012
Places: Denton County, TX

Title: Fireworks banned with disaster declaration in El Paso County, Texas
Description: An El Paso County judge declared a 60-hour disaster declaration banning the sale, use and possession of fireworks within the county with the hope that the governor will extend the declaration through July 5.  El Paso Times (Texas), June 13, 2012
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Rangeland, pasture deteriorating in South Texas
Description: Rangeland and pastures in South Texas continued to deteriorate amid high temperatures and poor rainfall.  Ranchers kept supplying supplemental feed or selling livestock.  In McMullen County, surface water was still short on many ranches, limiting pasture rotation and other grazing options.Odessa American (Texas), June 20, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Atascosa County, TX, Brooks County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Dimmit County, TX, Duval County, TX, Frio County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Jim Hogg County, TX, Jim Wells County, TX, Kenedy County, TX, Kleberg County, TX, La Salle County, TX, Live Oak County, TX, Maverick County, TX, McMullen County, TX, Starr County, TX, Webb County, TX, Willacy County, TX, Zapata County, TX, Zavala County, TX

Title: Less acreage farmed in Liberty, Chambers counties in Texas
Description: A rice and sorghum farmer with crops in Liberty and Chambers counties stated that he was farming less acreage because it was simply too dry.Houston Chronicle (Texas), June 7, 2012
Places: Chambers County, TX, Liberty County, TX

Title: Voluntary water conservation in Texas' Rio Grande Valley communities
Description: Seventeen water providers in the Rio Grande Valley were in “watch conditions,” indicating that water shortages were possible, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.  Two of the water providers were in Cameron County, 14 were in Hidalgo, and two were in Willacy County.  All providers urged customers to voluntarily conserve water.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), June 11, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: 2012 irrigation season on hold for users in Wichita County, Texas
Description: The Wichita County Water Improvement District No. 2 board of directors opted to end the 2012 irrigation season unless rain falls to increase the level of Lake Kemp and improve the water quality.  A water quality analysis done by the Wichita County USDA-Natural Resource Conservation Service found extremely high levels of electrical conductivity, high chloride and total dissolved solids levels, meaning the water was barely suitable for crop irrigation or for livestock consumption.  Lake Kemp was 36 percent of capacity on June 5.  About 300 to 400 agricultural users in central Wichita County are served by the irrigation district from mid-April through the end of October.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), June 6, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Wichita County, TX

Title: Forage grass growth reduced, water resources dwindling in Young County, Texas; ranchers providing supplemental feed and reducing herd size
Description: Young County is suffering from severe drought conditions.  A lack of rainfall, high winds and blistering temperatures have created a situation where water resources are lacking. Ranchers have been forced to reduce herd size due to lack of water, and continue to supplemental feed the livestock that remains.  Tanks, streams and creeks remain at low levels.  Many tanks that were cleaned out during last summer's extreme drought are dry again.  The lack of moisture has prevented growth of native and improved pasture as well as row crop production.  Forage grass (coastal) has had  reduced growth; by this time of year producers have normally made 2-3 cuttings of improved grasses for hay and this year producers have been lucky to get one cutting.  The extreme temperatures in the forecast do not show any improvement for the county.From a USDA employee in Graham, Texas, on August 1, 2012
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Water restrictions implemented in Young County, Texas; row crops and grass pastures less productive
Description: Drought is persistent in Young County.  High temperatures and strong winds continue to impact farmers and ranchers across the county.  Municipalities have implemented drought restrictions limiting water usage, and lake and storage tank levels remain low.  The small rains that have fallen have been accompanied by lightning which has caused several small fires.  As the dry conditions remain in the forecast we continue to see a loss of productivity in row crops and grass pastures.From an FSA employee in Graham, Texas, on August 13, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Water selling for $5,000 per acre-foot in San Bernardino County, California
Description: Several water purchases, in which the Mojave Water Agency had a part, were in the same price range as Hesperia’s water deal, in which the community paid $5,000 per acre-foot, said the watermaster services manager for the MWA.  Water prices have hovered around $4,700 to $5,000 per acre-foot since the latter half of 2012.Hesperia Star (Calif.), March 18, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Sonoma County, California, skinny deer, lots of fires
Description: Normal summer-dry season in north-coastal California is made a little dryer by somewhat below-normal winter precipitation, and a persistent hot, dry, high-pressure area to the east. This puts nutritional stress on herbivorous wildlife and deer I've been watching are showing ribs.  Stream flows are reduced, and returning salmonids this fall may be delayed or unable to pass barriers, either thermal or physical.  We are experiencing an active fire season, and low humidity and very high temperatures are making fire-fighting difficult. CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Geyserville 10.6 WNW on 8/14/2012
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Producer in Goliad County, Texas, reports hay cutting a total loss
Description: First hay cutting was a total loss, grass just didn't have enough rain to grow. With the heat it burned up. We have black soil, there was one crack in the ground 5 feet long and an inch and a half wide. 18 inches deep as close as we could measure.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Weser 1.9 NW on 8/16/2012
Places: Goliad County, TX

Title: Crops planted recently in Central Texas manifested signs of drought stress
Description: Corn, milo and haygrazer planted recently in Central Texas manifested signs of drought stress as rain failed to materialize.  Hay fields were green, but were not growing much.  Hay growers were pessimistic about getting a second cutting of hay.  Native-grass pastures have not recovered from last year’s drought.  El Paso Times (Texas), May 30, 2012

Producers with livestock continued to feed them hay, molasses and range cubes.  Surface water supplies were dry, leaving well water as the main source for livestock and wildlife in places. Title: Sorghum in the Coast Bend of Texas exhibited symptoms of drought stress
Description: Sorghum in the Coast Bend exhibited symptoms of drought stress.  Some sorghum growers opted to cut it for hay.  Many grain crops in the region were wilting from the dry conditions.  Most farmers growing corn and sorghum who have wells on their property were putting down pipe for furrow irrigation.  Many trees continued to die after last year’s drought. Title: Dryland cotton farmers in the Rolling Plains of Texas started to plant
Description: Dryland cotton farmers in the Rolling Plains started to plant, but there was not much hope for the crop.  Those fortunate enough to get a stand desperately needed rain to keep it alive.  Producers with irrigation watered for up to two weeks to get the cotton to come up.  Pastures needed more rainfall to meet grazing demands.  The elevated fire danger and memories of last year’s drought and wildfire has people on edge.  Odessa American (Texas), June 5, 2012

Title: Corn crop sparse, large trees dying, some cattle starving in Jim Wells County, Texas
Description: Corn crop is sparsely up with no rain since planting.  Crop should be 14-18" tall and it is struggling to be the 6" that it is.  Wind and sun have the leaves curled up trying to protect what little moisture the corn has.  Hot today - 93 expected for the high; sunshine as well.  Keeping trees alive is a great concern.  Large trees dying everywhere.  Cattle that are not being fed are starving - yep there is some of that (reported to county sheriff's department).  Topsoil blowing despite crop being up.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Orange Grove 3.3 NW on 4/9/2013
Places: Jim Wells County, TX

Title: All public boat ramps closed on Lake Travis in central Texas
Description: All public boat ramps on Lake Travis were closed, due to low water levels, which have effectively shortened the length of the lake from nearly 64 miles to 42 miles.  The lake is at 39 percent of capacity.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), May 22, 2013The only boat ramp open at Lake Travis was at Mansfield Dam since drought lowered the lake to 643 feet above sea level as of May 24.  The lake was nearly 30 feet below normal for May and more than 7 feet lower than last year at this time.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), May 24, 2012.
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Livestock producers in South Texas continued to give some supplemental feed to their animals
Description: Livestock producers in South Texas continued to give some supplemental feed to their animals, but pastures were improving, reducing the need for supplemental feeding.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), May 22, 2012

Title: Cotton planting delayed in areas without irrigation in the South Plains of Texas
Description: Cotton growers in the South Plains opted to plant cotton in irrigated areas and wait to plant in fields without irrigation capability because soil moisture was too low.  Rain did not come early enough to benefit winter wheat.  The range was still recovering since weeds had taken over many bare areas.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), May 22, 2012

Title: Not enough water to meet irrigation demand in the Klamath Basin in southern Oregon and northern California
Description: More irrigators were needed to sign up for a land-idling program to reduce the need for irrigation water in the Klamath Basin because there was not enough water to meet irrigation demand this season.  The Bureau of Reclamation estimated on May 22 that there would be a shortfall of about 70,000 acre-feet for the Klamath Reclamation Project over the summer.  Normally the project requires at least 400,000 acre-feet during a non-drought year.  Farmers may still enroll for the land-idling program with the Klamath Water and Power Agency through June 1.  Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), May 22, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Del Norte County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Jackson County, OR, Klamath County, OR, Lake County, OR

Title: Aerial fireworks banned in unincorporated El Paso County, Texas
Description: The sale and use of aerial fireworks was banned in the unincorporated parts of El Paso County during the Fourth of July season after county commissioners voted on the issue on May 21.  The ban became effective immediately.  El Paso Times (Texas), May 22, 2012
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Several lakes near Wichita Falls, Texas not stocked for years
Description: Recent rainfall eased drought in the Wichita Falls area, spurring the Texas Parks & Wildlife Department to restock lakes with a variety of fish.  The stocked lakes include Lake Arrowhead, Lake Kickapoo, Miller’s Creek Reservoir, Palo Pinto and Graham.  In previous years, drought left the lake levels very low and removed too much fish habitat to offer much hope for the fishes’ survival.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), May 20, 2015
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Archer County, TX, Clay County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Wichita County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Jim Wells County, Texas, cotton crop dead
Description: The cotton crop has been cut down and plowed under without trying to harvest.  Not enough on the bush to run the machines to gather the crops.  Dry with dust in the air quite often.  Sometimes very little wind in the area which is highly unusual living this close to the coast.  Showers in the area but showers have little impact when it is this dry. Title: Some farmers in the South Plains of Texas opted to wait for rain before planting
Description: Some farmers in the South Plains opted to wait for rain before planting because the soil was too dry.  Recent rainfall helped some pastures, but more moisture was needed.  Odessa American (Texas), May 15, 2012

Title: Burnet County, Texas, half of hay crop is dead
Description: We have never really recovered from last year's drought.  After getting rain this winter, rain has stopped.  Vegetation that was damaged from previous years has not recovered; hay field grass is about 50% dead and nothing is growing now.  Fire risk is high.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Marble Falls 2.7 SE on 8/12/2012
Places: Burnet County, TX

Title: Recent hot, dry weather in the Rolling Plains of Texas made producers anxious
Description: Recent hot, dry weather in the Rolling Plains made producers anxious about the possibility of another dry summer.  Pastures turned brown over the course of a few days.  Drought last summer and the absence of substantial rainfall this spring kept warm season grasses from greening up this spring.  Some cotton growers chose to wait on field preparation to reduce moisture soil loss.  Odessa American (Texas), May 1, 2012

Title: Drought, freeze killed many drought-tolerant plants in Big Bend National Park in West Texas
Description: Drought and a recent harsh freeze killed many desert plants in the Big Bend National Park, changing the landscape, according to a federal botanist.  Huge die-offs of creosote bush and lechuguilla occurred, while oak, madrone, piqon and juniper trees died also.  A cactus specialist stated that six to 12 species of cactus have died, too, and did not emerge and produce seeds as they should have done this spring.  It remains to be seen whether the die-offs will result in much soil erosion before vegetation recovers and what changes to the landscape might occur in the future.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), April 30, 2012
Places: Brewster County, TX

Title: Native wildflowers wilting along roadways in Cameron County, Texas
Description: I am noticing that the native wildflowers along the roadways are wilting from the lack of rain.  There are little bursts of dust storms acoss SR100.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Laguna Vista 1.2 NNW on 4/28/2012
Places: Cameron County, TX

Title: Burn bans, water restrictions in force across south central Texas
Description: Burn bans are in effect for 10 counties in south central Texas: Dimmit, Edwards, Frio, Karnes, Kinney, Maverick, Medina, Uvalde, Val Verde, and Zavala counties. Pastures declined from lack of rain. Streams and rivers were already low going into summer. Many trees will not recover from last year’s drought. In addition to live oaks and other oak trees dying, cedar trees have seen a die-off. In Sutton County, some cool-season vegetation was beginning to mature and turn brown. Cattle, sheep, and goat prices were high in Uvalde County where producers were trying to restock. Gillespie County reported some restocking, but high prices and lack of rain in the last 30 days slowed the process. Most producers in Kendall County have not restocked because of poor pasture conditions. The San Antonio Water System (SAWS) remains in stage 1 water restrictions. Stage 2 water restrictions will likely be implemented over the weekend or on April 30 as the level of the aquifer has fallen below 650 feet. Many communities across south central Texas have once again started to reinstate water restrictions because of the recent lack of rainfall and increased usage. Austin remains in stage 2 water restrictions and Kerrville and San Marcos are in stage 1 water restrictions. All cities continue to warn residents that stricter restrictions could return at any time if drier conditions develop. Locations that do not currently have mandatory restrictions continue to strongly promote year round water conservation. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Austin/San Antonio, Texas - April 27, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions
Places: Bexar County, TX, Dimmit County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Frio County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Hays County, TX, Karnes County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Kerr County, TX, Kinney County, TX, Maverick County, TX, Medina County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Uvalde County, TX, Val Verde County, TX, Zavala County, TX

Title: Burn bans in Young, Stephens and Eastland counties in Texas
Description: Outdoor burn bans continue for Young, Stephens, and Eastland counties. The Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association estimates that it may take more than 5 years to rebuild the Texas cattle industry. To foster the proper rebuilding of herds and help maintain the cattle infrastructure, the Texas Agrilife Extension Service has hosted educational programs throughout the state. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Dalls/Fort Worth, Texas - April 26, 2012
Places: Texas, Eastland County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Young County, TX

Description: As of April 26, the following west central Texas counties support a county wide outdoor burn ban: Irion, Schleicher, Sutton, Crockett, Coke, Nolan, Fisher, Concho, Menard, McCulloch, Coleman, Shackelford and Haskell.
