Title: Mariposa County officials requested that the state of California seek federal disaster status for the county
Description: Mariposa County officials requested that the state of California seek federal disaster status for the county’s ranchers who anticipate a difficult season.  Rain did not fall at the appropriate time to promote enough grass and forage growth for cattle, leaving livestock producers to purchase expensive hay.  Forage plants, such as vetch, clover and filaree, matured early and began to produce seeds, achieving 22 percent of normal growth, leaving producers with a forage loss of about $4.75 million in Mariposa County.  Grasses grew two to three inches on average, instead of a more normal growth of 12 to 14 inches.  Mariposa Gazette (Calif.), April 26, 2012
Places: Mariposa County, CA

Title: Dying trees create major fire hazard; outdoor burning prohibited in Bandera County, Texas
Description: Effect of early spring rains has vanished. Large cracks in ground spreading over wide areas. Trees, old and young, are dying, creating a major fire danger. No burning, no open flame, any activity making sparks is prohibited out-of-doors. This includes welding, slash pits, cleared brush, outdoor cooking, etc. Most of the trees in woods around the property are dead. Resources to combat fire are scarce to non-existent, doesn't matter much, as nothing will stop a fire here now. Everything is at risk with no relief in the forecast.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Bandera 3.9 E on 4/24/2012
Categories: Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions
Places: Bandera County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Ector County, Texas
Description: Ector County commissioners issued another burn ban for the county due to forecasted warm temperatures, meager rainfall and an impending emergency declaration by the governor.  Barbequing in a grill with an iron grate was permitted during this burn ban.  The Keetch-Byram Drought Index for the county was 603.  The previous burn ban ended about two months ago.  Odessa American (Texas), April 23, 2012
Places: Ector County, TX

Title: Hay fields at a standstill; cattle ponds dropping in Lavaca County, Texas
Description: Due to the lesser amount of rain in April our hay field grasses are at a standstill, and cattle ponds are dropping due to lack of runoff. Also have started seeing slight burning of native grasses in pastures due to 4-6 inches of top soil drying out.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Shiner 5.1 ESE on 4/22/2012
Places: Lavaca County, TX

Title: Burn bans, water restrictions in place in South Texas
Description: Burn bans are currently in effect for Zapata, Jim Hogg, Starr, Brooks, and Willacy counties. According to the United States Department of Agriculture and Texas Agrilife extension service agents, drought conditions continued across the area, keeping soil moisture levels short to very short. Sorghum showed signs of stress in Willacy County. Dry conditions prompted some corn, cotton and sorghum producers to irrigate. Several public water supply entities continue voluntary water conservation to avoid shortages or further restrictions, with a few entities requiring mild restrictions. One public water supply entity in Starr County continues severe restrictions. According to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ), 2 public water supply entities in Cameron County, 8 in Hidalgo County, 5 in Starr County, 3 in Zapata County and 2 in Willacy County are continuing water restrictions. Residents of Deep South Texas are urged to conserve water. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Brownsville, Texas - April 22, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Brooks County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Jim Hogg County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX, Zapata County, TX

Title: Coastal bermudagrass not growing well; producer preparing to irrigate hayfield in Atascosa County, Texas
Description: Preparing to irrigate field where we grow hay for cattle.  Coastal bermudagrass is not growing well.  Moisture deep in the soil is absent.  We have not gotten the rain that counties to our north and east and south have recently enjoyed.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Jourdanton 5.2 NNW on 4/19/2012
Places: Atascosa County, TX

Title: Ventura County, California, more bark beetles than ever before, fewer wildflowers blooming, fewer insects and reptiles
Description: There has been no rain, other than a trace on a few days, since mid April.  In addition, it was a very dry winter with very little snow compared to other winters.  Our Spring had short grass and about half the quantity of stalks.  The bunch grass was completely dried by mid June, when usually it's not dry until mid July.  The other grasses had gone to seed before June, when usually they go to seed by mid to late June.  There seemed to be not as much pine pollen this year, and I have seen many many more bark beetles everywhere this year than in years past.  In fact, this is the first year in 12 years that I have lived in this area where I saw more than just one or two bark beetles.  This year I have seen hundereds of bark beetles caught inside of boxes and buckets and in cracks and crevaces, in the dry rain gauge, etc.  I'm hoping that I don't lose any pinions to the beetles.  I have noticed that very, very few wildflowers bloomed this year, including the penstemons, lupins, mariposa lilies, maracopa poppies, and california poppies.  In regards to insects: there are much fewer yellow jackets, sweat flies, spiders, june beetles, and moths.  I haven't seen any wasps either, not the tiny ones on the oaks, or the bigger ones.  I haven't seen a scorpion or a jerusalem cricket.  It still sounds like there's lots of crickets at night time.  The dry spell along with the unusually hot May and June probably contributed to the early seeding of the grasses.  I can't say about the birds, because I stopped feeding them this spring.  I can't afford it right now.  I haven't seen any reptiles at all this spring or summer.  Not a lizard or snake.  Every year we see lots of lizards and a few snakes, but not this year.  Not a single reptile.  Hope that comment doesn't conjure up a rattler now....  The burned out forest (Day Fire in '06) is now six years later but after this dry spring and summer, it looks like the fire just happened a year or two ago.  Most of the burned trees are still standing.  No woodpeckers or flickers this year.  The creek bed (Lockwood Creek that crosses over Boy Scout Camp Rd), hasn't had water flowing in it for months.  No thistle plants, when usually I have one or two dozen of them.   This means that there are no humming birds either.  It's a very dry, lean year for plants, animals, and people.  This year it seems that most life forms have it real tough.  A nice thing for me is the competition between McDonalds and Jack-in-the-Box offering $1 large soft drinks.  That makes long drives much more pleasant.  I'm very worried about fires.  Last year the forest service had spotters along Lockwood Valley Road but possible budget cuts have prevented this from happening this year.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Frazier Park 10.7 WSW on 8/10/2012
Places: Ventura County, CA

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority lost $4.3 million in water sales
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority lost $4.3 million in water sales since most rice farmers along the Lower Colorado River did not receive irrigation water because upstream lakes were not full enough after a year of drought in 2011.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 18, 2012

Title: Wildfire awareness and preparation for Austin, Texas
Description: A “Wildfire Ready Austin” campaign began on April 16 to prepare area homeowners for the upcoming fire season.  Residents are encouraged to remove brush and mow grass to cut down on fuel and make an evacuation plan to be ready in the event that a wildfire would occur.  The Wild Land Task Force, which is a collaboration between the City of Austin, Travis County and others, created a “Ready, Set, Go” brochure to teach homeowners how to better prepare for wildfires.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 16, 2012
Places: Travis County, TX, Austin, TX

Title: Despite rainfall, mandatory water rationing remains in some parts of northwest Louisiana and northeast Texas
Description: Mandatory water rationing remains in effect for the south Caddo, north Desoto, Keatchie, and south Claiborne parishes in northwest Louisiana until further notice. Despite the above normal rainfall this winter, aquifer levels remain abnormally low. These cities in northeast Texas remain under a voluntary or a mild rationing of water until further notice: Pittsburg, Gladewater, White Oak, Marshall, Hallsville, Tyler, Nacogdoches, Melrose, San Augustine, Center, Hemphill, Bullard, Gilmer, and Huntington. Other smaller water systems across east Texas also remain under voluntary or a mild rationing of water until further notice as well. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Shreveport, Louisiana - April 13, 2012

Title: Producers drilling wells in South Plains of Texas
Description: A growing number of producers in the South Plains were drilling wells to have water for field preparation for spring planting.  Insurance adjusters assessed failed winter wheat in some counties.  Meager rains briefly helped pasture and rangeland, but more precipitation was badly needed.  Livestock producers continued to give supplemental feed to their animals.  Soil moisture in the Panhandle was ranked as very short to short in most areas, while most rangeland and pastures were very poor to poor.  Much of the wheat was in poor condition.  Odessa American (Texas), April 10, 2012

Title: Wheat in West Central Texas deteriorated from inadequate rainfall
Description: Wheat in West Central Texas deteriorated from inadequate rainfall and cotton farmers became more pessimistic about getting a crop.  As rangeland and pastures recovered from drought, weeds grew better than other vegetation and edged out warm season grasses, which emerged later than usual.  Bloat was still the greatest problem for livestock producers since clover was growing so thickly in pastures.  Soil moisture in the Panhandle was ranked as very short to short in most areas, while most rangeland and pastures were very poor to poor.  Much of the wheat was in poor condition.  Odessa American (Texas), April 10, 2012

Title: Fishermen catching big fish at O.H. Ivie Reservoir in Texas
Description: Fishermen caught some big fish at O.H. Ivie Reservoir recently as the dwindling lake crowded the fish into a smaller space.  An Abilene resident pulled a 13.36-pound largemouth bass out of the lake on April 6.  The bass was 27.5 inches long with a girth of 20 inches.  A man from Midland caught a 13.22-pound pure Florida bass that was 26.5 inches long with a girth of 20 inches.  A state parks spokesman said that the deepest parts of the lake were about 50 feet, but that the lake has a depth of 119 feet when it is at capacity.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), April 9, 2012
Places: Coleman County, TX, Concho County, TX, Runnels County, TX

Title: Irrigation districts in southern New Mexico, El Paso County in Texas and Mexico expected to receive 20 percent of their requested allotments
Description: Irrigation districts in southern New Mexico, El Paso County in Texas and Mexico expected to receive 20 percent of their requested allotments from the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation since snowpack in the Rio Grande river basin was below normal.  El Paso Times (Texas), April 6, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Dona Ana County, NM, Sierra County, NM, El Paso County, TX

Title: Dry conditions lead to poor kayaking in Sonoma County, California
Description: It has been a cool summer overall. Last year we had early rains, which destroyed a lot of the wine grape harvest, but had basically a drought year from then on. Now is harvest season again, and we have a forecast of showers starting tonight. So far the sky is clear. We'll see. Early rains destroy the harvest, but the area needs rain. Wine or survival? As a swimmer, I have noticed that the outdoor pools have been cool, which I hate.Kayaking has been poor due to dried up creeks and an unpredictable Russian River. Another dry year may have us conserving water.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Forestville 0.7 SW on 10/9/2012
Places: Sonoma County, CA, Forestville, CA

Title: Drought continues to affect agricultural producers in Young County, Texas
Description: Extreme drought continues to plague Young County.  There has been no measurable rainfall since December 2013.  Soil moisture is very low and has affected the grazing capacity of small grains as well as native and improved grasses.  High winds continue to increase the fire danger and deprive the soil and air of any potential moisture.  Tank and lake levels are very low and hauling water has become a necessity for livestock producers across the region.  There has been an exponential increase in interest for water well drilling as producers try to find an alternative source of water for livestock purposes.  Ranchers are continuing to reduce stocking rates due to insufficient grass and water.  Spring seeded acres had an unsuccessful growing season, and virtually no cotton or haygrazer was harvested this fall in Young County.   Planted acres of wheat dropped as row crop farmers continue to wait for rainfall.From a USDA employee in Graham, Texas, on January 27, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Ranchers, row crop farmers dealing with drought conditions in Young County, Texas
Description: Young County continues to suffer from drought conditions.  Recent rains have been of minimal benefit to agricultural producers.  Soil moisture remains very low and row crop farmers are suffering early losses to small grain crops.  There was very little growth on pasture acres during the spring months of 2012 and most residue on the ground is from the 2011 growing season and is of little nutritional value to livestock.  Ranchers are continuing to use supplemental feeding to maintain herds. Some ranchers have resorted to reducing normal stocking rates by up to 75% to accommodate for the loss of small grain grazing. Spraying has started for green bugs and weeds that are prevalent during drought conditions.From a USDA employee in Graham, Texas, on January 15, 2013
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Continued drought, low soil moisture and stock tank levels causing problems for agricultural producers in Young County, Texas
Description: Young County continues to suffer from drought conditions even with the recent rains having minimal benefits to agricultural producers.  The moisture in the soil remains very low, with wheat, oat and triticale crops  suffering from lack of rainfall.  Early losses to small grain crops are being reported.  Minimal growth continues on pasture acres during the spring months of 2013.  Most residue on the ground is from the 2011 growing season and is of little nutritional value to livestock.  Ranchers continue to supplemental feed to maintain herds and are still reducing stock rates. Producers are now having to make a difficult decision about whether to haul water or haul feed. Stock tank levels are at low levels or completely empty. Spraying has started for spider mites in the wheat.From a USDA employee in Graham, Texas, on April 4, 2013
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Wildfire activity rose in April in the Austin, Texas area
Description: The number of wildfires in Austin and Travis County climbed from just 29 calls in March to 87 calls in April.  The month of April was the second driest since records were kept, with just 0.22 inches of rain, according to the National Weather Service. Austin American-Statesman (Texas), May 1, 2012
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Jack County, Texas, agricultural producers facing continuing drought conditions
Description: Jack County continues to suffer from drought conditions as the producers have not been receiving the surrounding  recent rains.  Soil moisture is at an all-time low with wheat, oat and triticale crops suffering greatly from lack of rainfall.  Crop adjusters for crop insurance have been failing out wheat crops with early losses to small grain crops reported.  Pasture growth is minimal during the spring months of 2013.  Any ground residue left in pastures is from the 2011 growing season and is of little to no nutritional value. Producers are still reducing stock rates and are now having to make a difficult decision about whether to haul water or haul feed. Stock tank levels are at low levels or are empty.From a USDA employee in Graham, Texas, on April 4, 2013
Places: Jack County, TX

Title: Caldwell County, Texas, needed to buy supplemental feed for cattle, high cost
Description: We have had to buy hay and have started feeding hay to cattle.  We should not have to do so until November.  This means forage for cattle is minimal and our expenses are very high.  Also, we must supplement more water than usual.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Red Rock 5.4 SSW on 8/12/2012
Places: Caldwell County, TX

Title: Ranchers implementing supplemental feeding in Young County, Texas
Description: Drought conditions continue to impact the county.  Row crop producers continue to see the negative side effects of little to no rain on wheat growth.  Fall grazing of row crops has been virtually non-existent since the ground is either too dry and loose to keep the sprouts in the ground, or the seed has failed to sprout all together.  Water levels in stock tanks continue to drop as abnormally high temperatures and winds plague the area.  Native and improved grass pastures are still suffering, and many have not regenerated since the drought of 2011.  Ranchers have been forced to implement supplemental feeding since grass that is standing lacks any nutritional value.From an FSA employee in Graham, Texas, on December 19, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Many waterfowl perished from avian cholera in northern California, southern Oregon
Description: Drought contributed to the spread of avian cholera, leading to the deaths of approximately 10,000 snow geese, Ross’s geese, pintail ducks and other migrating waterfowl at the Lower Klamath and Tule Lake national wildlife refuges in northern California.  While some number of birds commonly die from avian cholera each year, the outbreak was much worse this year because a lack of water reduced the spatial extent of the marshes by half, crowding the birds into a smaller area.  The close proximity of the birds allowed the disease to spread more easily.  The refuge manager anticipated the deaths of 15,000 or so birds before the outbreak was over.   Water delivery to the refuges have resumed.   Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), March 30, 2012
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Siskiyou County, CA, Klamath County, OR

Title: Livestock producers in the Coastal Bend of Texas continued supplemental feeding as pastures recovered
Description: Coastal Bend livestock producers continued supplemental feeding as pastures recovered from overgrazing during drought in 2011.  There were fewer cattle in the region since many livestock were sold as drought dried up pastures and stock ponds.  El Paso Times (Texas), March 27, 2012
Places: Aransas County, TX, Austin County, TX, Bee County, TX, Calhoun County, TX, Colorado County, TX, DeWitt County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Goliad County, TX, Jackson County, TX, Karnes County, TX, Lavaca County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Nueces County, TX, Refugio County, TX, San Patricio County, TX, Victoria County, TX, Washington County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Some livestock producers in Ward County, Texas opted to send cattle elsewhere
Description: Some livestock producers in Ward County opted to send their cattle elsewhere because there was no hay and feed was expensive.  El Paso Times (Texas), March 27, 2012
Places: Ward County, TX

Title: Livestock producers in the Texas Panhandle continued to give supplemental feed to their cattle
Description: Livestock producers in the Panhandle continued to give supplemental feed to their cattle.  El Paso Times (Texas), March 27, 2012 and Odessa American (Texas), April 10, 2012.  Soil moisture in the Panhandle was ranked as very short to short in most areas, while most rangeland and pastures were very poor to poor.  Poor condition described wheat in much of the panhandle.  Odessa American (Texas), April 10, 2012
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Wheeler County, TX

Title: Some producers in the Rolling Plains of Texas were contemplating baling winter wheat
Description: Some Rolling Plains producers were contemplating baling winter wheat since hay supplies were depleted from drought in 2011.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), March 24, 2012
Places: Archer County, TX, Baylor County, TX, Childress County, TX, Clay County, TX, Cottle County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Foard County, TX, Hardeman County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Jack County, TX, Kent County, TX, King County, TX, Knox County, TX, Montague County, TX, Motley County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Parker County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Stonewall County, TX, Throckmorton County, TX, Wichita County, TX, Wilbarger County, TX, Wise County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Weeds growing better than grass in drought-stressed pastures in Harrison and Mason counties in Texas
Description: Stands of grass, thinned by drought, were being overtaken by weeds as rain returns to the area, according to AgriLife Extension agents in Harrison and Mason counties.  Small forbs also were growing well in Mason County.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), March 24, 2012
Places: Harrison County, TX, Mason County, TX

Title: Livestock producers in Presidio County, Texas still offering supplemental feed
Description: Livestock producers continued offering supplemental feed to their animals since pastures have not yet recovered from drought, according to the AgriLife Extension agent in Presidio County.  Unfortunately, poisonous green weeds have emerged in pastures.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), March 24, 2012
Places: Presidio County, TX

Title: Boat launch fees, permits suspended at Lake Meredith, Texas
Description: Lake Meredith boat launch fees and permits were suspended for the next three years, and possibly longer, as the projects funded by the fees have been completed.  Drought has also lowered visitation to the lake over the past few years.Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), March 23,  2015
Places: Hutchinson County, TX, Moore County, TX, Potter County, TX

Title: Anxiety over water supply in the Klamath River Basin in southern Oregon and northern California
Description: Klamath County commissioners made a drought declaration to pave the way for possible state and federal drought declarations and access to aid programs and pumping from emergency wells since there was insufficient water to satisfy farmers and coho salmon in the Klamath River Basin.  Meanwhile, officials in Humboldt County, California and the Hoopa Valley Tribe were seeking more water for salmon in the Trinity River because three times the highest recorded number of salmon was expected to spawn this season.   The executive director of the Klamath Water Users Association stated that farmers were in a bind, not knowing whether to plant crops or farm outside of the project, since farmers with junior water rights were cautioned by the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation that they may not receive irrigation water this growing season.  The decision on water allocation will not be made until April.  San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), March 21, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Del Norte County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Jackson County, OR, Klamath County, OR, Lake County, OR

Title: Drought emergency declaration in Marin County, California
Description: The Marin County Board of Supervisors declared a drought emergency in hopes of receiving state or federal aid if and when it becomes available.  Pasture grass production was down 50 percent from the lack of rain, increasing dairy ranchers' production costs.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), March 21, 2012
Places: Marin County, CA

Title: Water levels in Phantom Springs Cave in West Texas have fallen
Description: Water levels in Phantom Springs Cave have fallen, due to drought and irrigation, leaving the roots of plants in the cave dry and limiting the food supply for cave-dwelling creatures.  Some pools of water in the cave were shrinking, crowding fish into smaller areas, and would benefit from supplemental water to keep the fish alive.  A research team entering Phantom Springs Cave noted the presence of Comanche Springs Pupfish and Pecos Gambusia, two kinds of endangered species.  Phantom Springs Cave is closed to recreational exploration to protect the cave’s ecosystem.  Odessa Online (Texas), March 20, 2012
Places: Jeff Davis County, TX

Title: Corn crops curling leaves, trees stressed in Jim Wells County, Texas
Description: Corn crops are 'curling' their leaves trying to preserve the moisture that they currently have to maintain life.  There is no ground moisture to speak of and the dry wind and high temperatures are sapping what little moisture there is.  Some trees are stressing and dying - some have already been cut down due to the extreme drought of last year.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Orange Grove 3.3 NW on 4/25/2012
Places: Jim Wells County, TX

Title: Golden algae, increased salinity led to fish kills at Brady Creek Lake and the Clear Fork of the Brazos River in Texas
Description: Two fish kills, stemming from golden algae, occurred at Brady Creek Lake and the Clear Fork of the Brazos River, north of Hubbard Creek Lake, where the algae had not previously been detected.  The Clear Fork fish kill affected the stretch of the creek between FM 578 upstream to State Highway 183 north of Breckenridge.  Most of the dead fish were shad, drum and other nongame fish, but there were also many crappie, catfish and largemouth bass.  The algae proliferate in freshwater with high salt content, but are most commonly found in estuarine waters.  The Clear Fork fish kill was worrisome due to its proximity to Hubbard Creek Lake.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), March 17, 2012
Places: McCulloch County, TX, Shackelford County, TX, Stephens County, TX

Title: All public boat ramps closed on Lake Kemp in northern Texas
Description: All public boat ramps on Lake Kemp were closed, due to the low level of the lake, which was at 37 percent of capacity.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), March 16, 2012
Places: Baylor County, TX

Title: The Dundee State Fish Hatchery in northern Texas closed
Description: The Dundee State Fish Hatchery closed because Lake Kemp was too low to ensure adequate water for operation.  If the lake level were to decline by one foot, the hatchery would lose authorization for using lake water. Striped bass and hybrid striped bass were the main fish grown at the hatchery, which comprises 34 percent of the freshwater fish production capacity in Texas.  The bass will be raised at other fish hatcheries in the state.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), March 15, 2012
Places: Archer County, TX, Baylor County, TX, Wichita County, TX

Title: Drought allows airborne dust to remain in the air, worsening allergies in West Texas
Description: Plenty of airborne dust, in addition to pollen, was responsible for the early and severe start to the allergy season, according to an ear, nose and throat specialist in Abilene.  He asserts that drought has allowed the dust to remain in the air and continues to pose problems for allergy sufferers.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), March 15, 2012
Places: Taylor County, TX

Title: Program to provide hay for horses very popular in Abilene, Texas area
Description: The Great Bale Out, a program funded by a grant from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, served 51 applicants and 169 horses with 781 hay bales, according to the animal services manager with the city of Abilene.  Given the popularity of the program and the desperate need for hay, it was expected that all of the program’s funding would be exhausted soon.  There were also 46 applications that were not likely to be funded.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), March 12, 2012
Places: Taylor County, TX

Title: California resort still making snow
Description: Inadequate snowfall led the China Peak Mountain Resort to continue making snow through the winter, stated the marketing and retail manager.  Visitation was down by about 50 percent.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), March 11, 2012
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Kings County, California, declares drought emergency
Description: On March 6, 2012, Kings County declared a drought emergency. The county is concerned about declining groundwater supplies and the low snowpack amounts in the southern Sierra Nevada (less than 30 percent of normal). NWS - Drought Information Statement - San Joaquin Valley/Hanford, California - March 8, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kings County, CA

Title: Supplemental feeding, windblown soil erosion prevention in Texas Panhandle
Description: Livestock producers in the Panhandle continued to give their animals supplemental feed since rangeland and pastures were in poor to very poor condition.  Farmers and ranchers also strove to lessen windblown soil erosion.  Odessa American (Texas), March 6, 2012
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Wheeler County, TX

Title: Livestock producers on the South Plains of Texas continued to offer supplemental feed
Description: Livestock producers on the South Plains continued to give supplemental feed to their animals since winter wheat, pasture and rangeland all needed more moisture.  Odessa American (Texas), March 6, 2012 and El Paso Times (Texas), March 27, 2012
Places: Bailey County, TX, Borden County, TX, Castro County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: Livestock receiving supplemental feed, suffering bloating from wheat in Rolling Plains of Texas
Description: Livestock producers in parts of the Rolling Plains chose to let their animals graze wheat rather than harvest the wheat for grain later.  The immediate food source was more beneficial to some since pastures and rangeland have not yet recovered from drought.  Supplemental feeding continued to maintain cattle body condition and avoid additional culling.  Bloat was problematic for ranchers with livestock on wheat pasture.  Odessa American (Texas), March 6, 2012 and El Paso Times (Texas), March 27, 2012
Places: Archer County, TX, Baylor County, TX, Childress County, TX, Clay County, TX, Cottle County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Foard County, TX, Hardeman County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Jack County, TX, Kent County, TX, King County, TX, Knox County, TX, Montague County, TX, Motley County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Parker County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Stonewall County, TX, Throckmorton County, TX, Wichita County, TX, Wilbarger County, TX, Wise County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Bloat a problem for livestock producers in parts of Texas
Description: Drought and overgrazing increased forage loss in many places, allowing clover and other vegetation to regrow in greater than desired proportions.  High consumption of clover and winter wheat has led to problems with bloating and significant numbers of cattle deaths in some areas, such as Southwest Texas, Falls County and Clay County, where up to 10 percent of the cattle on some ranches have died from bloat.  Ranchers were buying bloat preventatives to reduce cattle deaths.  Odessa American (Texas), March 6, 2012 and El Paso Times (Texas), March 27, 2012
Places: Bailey County, TX, Borden County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Castro County, TX, Clay County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Falls County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: Water restrictions, burn bans continue to affect Deep South Texas
Description: Burn bans are in effect in much of Deep South Texas, with the exception of Cameron and Hidalgo counties. Residents are urged to refrain from conducting any outside burning activities. Range and pasture land remain in need of additional moisture. Ranchers continued to supplement with hay and protein. Several public water supply entities continue voluntary water conservation to avoid shortages or further restrictions, with a few entities requiring mild restrictions. One public water supply entity in Starr County continues severe restrictions. According to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ), 2 public water supply entities in Cameron County, 8 in Hidalgo County, 5 in Starr County, 3 in Zapata County and 2 in Willacy County are continuing water restrictions. Residents of Deep South Texas are urged to conserve water. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Brownsville, Texas - March 4, 2012
Places: Brooks County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Jim Hogg County, TX, Kenedy County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX, Zapata County, TX

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority revealed that rice farmers who depend on the Colorado River in southeast Texas will not get water
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority (LCRA) revealed that rice farmers who depend on the Colorado River in Colorado, Wharton and Matagorda counties will not get irrigation water this year because lakes Travis and Buchanan upstream contained too little water.  This is the first time that farmers in those counties will not receive water from the LCRA.  Lake Buchanan and Lake Travis held about 3,200 acre-feet of water, but needed to hold at least one billion gallons more before they would be sufficiently full for the LCRA to release water for irrigation.  A handful of farmers with senior water rights will still get a little bit of water.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), March 2, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Colorado County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: The Marin Municipal Water District in California drew about 140 acre-feet of water from the Phoenix Lake reservoir to bolster its water supply
Description: The Marin Municipal Water District drew about 140 acre-feet of water from the Phoenix Lake reservoir and transferred it to the Bon Tempe water treatment plant between March 2 and March 19.  Precipitation at nearby Lake Lagunitas was less than half of normal for the season.  Twin Cities Times (Novato, Calif.), March 7, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Marin County, CA

Title: Texas, Louisiana towns under various water restrictions
Description: Mandatory water rationing remains in effect for south Caddo, north Desoto, and south Claiborne parishes in northwest Louisiana until further notice. Mandatory water rationing also remains in effect for the city of Many, Louisiana, and for much of Sabine Parish, although levels at Toledo Bend Lake, the parish’s primary water supply, have gradually improved in the wake of above-normal rainfall across much of the watershed this winter (since December). The cities of Shreveport and Natchitoches, Louisiana, as well as Pittsburg, Gladewater, White Oak, Marshall, Hallsville, Tyler, Nacogdoches, Melrose, San Augustine, Center, Hemphill, Bullard, Gilmer, and Huntington in Texas remain under voluntary or a mild rationing of water until further notice. Other smaller water systems across east Texas and north Louisiana also remain under voluntary or a mild rationing of water until further notice as well. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Shreveport, Louisiana - March 2, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Caddo Parish, LA, Claiborne Parish, LA, De Soto Parish, LA, Natchitoches Parish, LA, Sabine Parish, LA, Angelina County, TX, Camp County, TX, Gregg County, TX, Harrison County, TX, Nacogdoches County, TX, Newton County, TX, Sabine County, TX, San Augustine County, TX, Shelby County, TX, Smith County, TX, Upshur County, TX

Title: Forage production reduced on Rita Blanca National Grasslands (Oklahoma and Texas), Kiowa National Grasslands (New Mexico)
Description: Reduced or no forage production on the Rita Blanca National Grasslands in OK and TX.  Of approximately 50 allotments in OK, only 4 are currently being grazed, and those with reduced numbers/season. In TX, over half of approximately 100 units are completely destocked this grazing season.  The ones that are being grazed are with reduced numbers and season. Significant reduction in forage production on the Kiowa NG in New Mexico.  Of the approximately 150 units, only about 1/3 are being grazed, w/ reduced numbers/season.From Angela Safranek, USDA Forest Service, Cibola National Forest, Kiowa and Rita Blanca National Grasslands, in Clayton, New Mexico, on July 12, 2012
Places: Colfax County, NM, Harding County, NM, Mora County, NM, Union County, NM, Cimarron County, OK, Dallam County, TX

Title: Whitewater rafting company in Fresno, California threatened by drought
Description: Four straight years of drought nearly put Kings River Expeditions, a commercial rafting company based in Fresno, out of business, but a Facebook post explaining how dire their financial situation had become brought back many guests and guides from the past to visit again.  The owner and manager of KRE explained in his post that the business averaged 1,500 customers per year during the past four years and had as few as 700 customers in 2015 when rafting ended before Memorial Day, due to low water on the Kings River.  It takes about 4,000 customers for the company to break even.  In short, the owner needed to see plenty of customers for the business to remain open.  In the two weeks following the Facebook post, they had 700 reservations for trips and the telephone keeps ringing.  In addition, the snowfall during the 2015-16 winter means that rafting should be possible through mid- to late July.Fresno Bee (Calif.), March 26, 2016
Categories: Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Whitewater rafting on hold amid drought on Kings River in California
Description: Zephyr Whitewater and Whitewater Voyages stopped river trips in 2012, due to low flows on the Kings River.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), March 26, 2016
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Native trees and bushes stressed in Aransas County, Texas
Description: Although areas north & south of us have gotten rain, we are still extremely dry. Ephemeral pond in yard is completely dry. Even native trees & bushes in yard are heat & drought stressed. They are being infested by pests such as mealybugs & aphids. The berries on native bushes such as American Beautyberry are very small compared to normal. We raise native plants for a non-profit sale in September & due to heat & drought they are doing poorly, even though we water every day.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Aransas Pass 6.1 NNW on 8/19/2012
Places: Aransas County, TX

Title: The Sonoma County Water Agency in California declared the Russian River to be in “critical” supply conditions
Description: The Sonoma County Water Agency declared the Russian River to be in “critical” supply conditions.  This designation allows more water to be stored in Lake Mendocino for municipal use and for release during the fall Chinook salmon migration.  Ukiah Daily Journal (Calif.), March 1, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Bird migrations varied from the norm as drought in Texas led birds to explore other options
Description: Bird migrations varied from the norm as drought in Texas led birds to explore other options this winter.  An annual bird count done in December revealed that there were far fewer songbirds, waterfowl, catbirds gnatcatchers, warblers and other migrating birds on the Texas Gulf Coast than usual.  Normally tens of thousands of birds winter there.  There were 61 percent fewer geese, compared to the 19-year average.  Populations of dabbling ducks were down 43 percent; diving ducks, 60 percent; and spoonbills 74 percent.  Ducks that winter in Texas kept flying south and were spending the winter in Belize in Central America. The Mad Island preserve on the coast had only 200 acres of wetlands since drought has shrunk the area of wetlands from its usual size of 1,100 acres.  Biologists wonder how the usual winter habitation might affect the birds’ wellbeing as they begin the return journey to their summer habitat and attempt to reproduce.  The Daily News (Texas), March 1, 2012
Places: Brazoria County, TX, Calhoun County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Chambers County, TX, Galveston County, TX, Harris County, TX, Jackson County, TX, Jefferson County, TX, Kenedy County, TX, Kleberg County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Nueces County, TX, Orange County, TX, Refugio County, TX, San Patricio County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Cattle producers were still feeding hay in parts of Texas
Description: Cattle producers were still feeding hay in Collin County, Navarro County and Victoria County, among other places around the state, according to AgriLife Extension agents.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Feb. 25, 2012
Places: Collin County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Victoria County, TX

Title: Drought inhibited growth of vegetation that could become fuel for wildfires in the Texas Panhandle
Description: Drought inhibited growth of vegetation that could become fuel for wildfires, according to a report from the Southwest Coordination Center’s office of predictive services and a senior forecaster and fire weather program leader for the Amarillo office of the National Weather Service.  The reduced fuel load could mean that wildfires will be less problematic in 2012 than they were in 2011.  Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), Feb. 25, 2012
Places: Potter County, TX

Title: Dust storm in Hall County, Texas, causes near-zero visibility, multi-vehicle accident
Description: The most significant weather event in the past month was a widespread high wind event on February 20. Extensive blowing dust developed both on and off the caprock as westerly winds sustained in excess of 40 mph with several gusts around 60 mph. The worst conditions occurred in eastern Hall County where near-zero visibility in a dust storm caused a multi-vehicle car accident and injured four persons. These high winds also damaged some winter wheat crops in the Rolling Plains. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Lubbock, Texas - February 23, 2012
Places: Hall County, TX

Title: Burn bans, water restrictions remain in south central Texas
Description: Burn bans are in effect for 11 counties in south central Texas: Dimmit, Edwards, Frio, Karnes, Kinney, Maverick, Medina, Real, Uvalde, Val Verde, and Zavala. Western areas have seen less rainfall so stock tanks there remain low or dry. The San Antonio Water System (SAWS) is currently in stage 1 water restrictions. Austin remains in stage 2 water restrictions and Kerrville remains stage 3 water restrictions. Locations that do not currently have mandatory restrictions continue to strongly promote year round water conservation.NWS - Drought Information Statement - Austin/San Antonio, Texas - February 23, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Antonio, TX, Dimmit County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Frio County, TX, Karnes County, TX, Kerrville, TX, Kinney County, TX, Maverick County, TX, Medina County, TX, Real County, TX, Austin, TX, Uvalde County, TX, Val Verde County, TX, Zavala County, TX

Title: Reduced water allocations in northern California
Description: Water districts in northern California that get water from the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation may get 75 percent of contracted water amounts for nonagricultural users and 30 percent for agricultural users, barring additional rain or snow fall this winter.  Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), Feb. 22, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Shasta County, CA, Tehama County, CA

Title: West Texas remains under outdoor burn ban
Description: As of February 21, all of West Texas remained under an outdoor burn ban except Ector and Midland counties. Supplemental feeding of livestock continued, and Presidio County reported hay supplies to be critical. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Midland/Odessa, Texas - February 21, 2012

Title: A rice farmer and crop sprayer in Wharton County, Texas strove to cut costs
Description: A rice farmer and crop sprayer in Wharton County strove to cut costs this year in anticipation of reduced irrigation water for growing rice.  He let one of his pilots go and cancelled a $50,000 per year insurance policy on one of his planes. His business normally sprays 15,000 acres, but expects to spray maybe 3,500 acres this year.  The owner was adapting his business and offering different services to remain profitable and avoid laying off employees.  San Diego Union-Tribune (Calif.), Feb. 21, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Wharton County, TX

Title: Houston Audubon is purchasing up to 18.5 million gallons of water to refill Clay Bottom Pond on the Texas Gulf Coast in preparation for the return of migrating birds
Description: Houston Audubon is purchasing up to 18.5 million gallons of water to refill Clay Bottom Pond in preparation for the return of migrating birds in late February.  Clay Bottom Pond normally covers 20 acres, but had dwindled to virtually nothing.  Without the water, it was feared that the birds might starve and die after their flight over the Gulf of Mexico.  A wide range of birds from snowy egrets to roseate spoonbills stop at the pond on their northward journey.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Feb. 20, 2012
Places: Chambers County, TX

Title: Birds in Texas have altered their migratory routes to avoid regions in drought
Description: Birds have altered their migratory routes to avoid regions in drought, according to a bird expert and associate director of conservation for the Nature Conservancy of Texas.  Cassin’s sparrow, a grayish brown songbird often found in the arid grasslands of West Texas, was observed in Arkansas this winter.  The bird has not been seen in Arkansas in previous winters.  Tens of thousands of snow geese wintered in northeast Texas rather than along the Gulf Coast.  Some critically endangered whooping cranes stayed in Nebraska for the winter instead of flying to San Antonio Bay on the Gulf Coast in Texas.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Feb. 20, 2012

Title: Farmers on the east side of the San Joaquin Valley in California were bracing for a difficult summer
Description: Farmers on the east side of the San Joaquin Valley were bracing for a difficult summer since snowfall has been about one-third of normal, meaning that farmers who rely on the San Joaquin River for water will not receive as much water as they need.  Farmers were restoring old wells, seeking to purchase water from neighbors and anticipating withdrawing water from underground water banks to eke through the summer.  They also hope for good storms in the next six weeks to deepen the snow pack and provide enough water for all activities.  This has been one of the driest winters in the past century.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), Feb. 20, 2012
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: New Mexico and Texas farmers who receive irrigation water from the Rio Grande River planning to plant fewer acres of cotton
Description: New Mexico and Texas farmers who receive irrigation water from the Rio Grande River were planning to plant fewer acres of cotton in the El Paso area because initial water allocations were just 6 inches per acre, compared to a full allotment in better years of 48 inches per acre.  Meager snowfall in New Mexico and Colorado was responsible for the drastically reduced allotment.  In addition, water deliveries are expected to begin in mid-May or early June, according to the general manager of El Paso County Water Improvement District No. 1, but deliveries normally begin in early March.  One cotton grower in the Lower Valley stated that cotton must be watered by April 5 or it won’t grow.  Consequently, he plans to plant just 340 of his 1,700 acres to cotton if water is not available in March.  Another cotton grower in the Lower Valley and Hudspeth County intends to plant 148 of his 950 acres with cotton.  Both growers expect to have to lay off employees unless they get more water soon and can plant more acres.  The Elephant Butte and Caballo reservoirs in southern New Mexico contained just 17 and 7 percent of capacity.  El Paso Times (Texas), Feb. 19, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Dona Ana County, NM, Sierra County, NM, El Paso County, TX

Title: Ranchers in northern California concerned about water, grass for their livestock

Stock ponds have not refilled because there has been little runoff.  The lack of snow has left grasses very dry.  Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), Feb. 13, 2012

Title: Olive grower irrigating weekly; rangeland grass scarce in Madera County, California
Description: Except for three days of recorded precip. in Jan 2012, there has been no rain since 11/30/12.  We are irrigating the trees and watering outside plants, and do not plan on purchasing any new plants unless the situation changes; local olive grower is irrigating weekly.  Local cattlemen are talking about selling off their cattle early; there is virtually no rangeland grass except for some growth under the trees.  Rain YTD is 5.01 out of approx 16 inches for a seasonal avg.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Yosemite Lakes 4.7 S on 2/8/2012

Title: Drought and fire killed nearly all of the Houston toads in eastern Texas
Description: Drought and fire killed nearly all of the Houston toads, but a few remain in Bastrop, Austin and Leon counties.  A biology professor from Texas State University who was heading up recovery efforts estimated that drought eliminated 80 percent of the toads and the wildfire on September 5, 2011 in Bastrop County ruined as much as 40 percent of the toads’ critical habitat.  The toads’ fragmented habitat and a fungus may also be contributing to the toads’ population decline.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 6, 2012
Places: Austin County, TX, Bastrop County, TX, Leon County, TX

Title: Burn bans, water restrictions continue in Deep South Texas
Description: Burn bans are in effect for all counties in Deep South Texas except Cameron, which has temporarily suspended its county ban. Residents are urged to refrain from conducting any outside burning activities. Rangeland and pastures remained in poor condition. Cattle body condition scores were poor to fair with most herds in poor condition. With stock tanks still low or completely dry and feed costs rising, ranchers were expecting to further cull herds. Some water districts in the Rio Grande Valley have started warning growers that water may run short next year if irrigation demands remain high. Several public water supply entities continue voluntary water conservation to avoid shortages or further restrictions, with a few entities requiring mild restrictions. One public water supply entity in Starr County continues severe restrictions. According to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ), 2 public water supply entities in Cameron County, 8 in Hidalgo County, 5 in Starr County, 3 in Zapata County and 2 in Willacy County are continuing water restrictions. Residents of Deep South Texas are urged to conserve water. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Brownsville, Texas - February 4, 2012
Places: Brooks County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Jim Hogg County, TX, Kenedy County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX, Zapata County, TX

Description: Wheat growers in the western part of the Rolling Plains waited to apply weed control and top-dressing until more rain came.  Ranchers continued to provide supplemental feed for the livestock.  Hay remained scarce, leading ranchers to purchase it from out of state.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Feb. 4, 2012

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority began trucking water to Spicewood Beach in Burnet County, Texas
Description: New wells and a small water treatment plant for Spicewood Beach have been constructed to supply the community with water after its wells went dry more than two years ago.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), June 22, 2014.  Spicewood Beach continued to receive water shipments because its well still was not producing enough water to supply the community.  KXAN-TV NBC 36 Austin (Texas), Sept. 6, 2013.The LCRA continued to truck water to Spicewood Beach and will likely have to continue to do so through the summer.  Since the level of Lake Travis affects the water level of the well supplying Spicewood Beach, an increase in the lake level from 626.82 feet above mean sea level on January 29 to 640.15 feet on April 17 meant that some water was able to be pumped from the well, but water deliveries continued.  Stage 4 water restrictions remained in effect.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 17, 2012.  The Lower Colorado River Authority began trucking water to Spicewood Beach on January 30 after the community’s well ran virtually dry.  The previous week, the LCRA alerted Spicewood Beach residents that water usage must be severely curtailed because the water level in the well was dropping rapidly.  By January 24, the water level in the well had fallen another 1.3 feet.  Stage 4 water restrictions took effect on January 24 and eliminated all outdoor watering.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 1, 2012.
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX

Title: Sales and rentals were far below normal at a ski shop in Big Bear Lake, California
Description: Sales and rentals were far below normal at a ski shop in Big Bear Lake, stated the shop owner.  Snowfall for January at Big Bear Lake was just 4 inches, compared to an average of 14.8 inches, according to the Western Regional Climate Center.  Twenty-five of the 26 runs were open at Snow Summit since one was closed for snowmaking.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Jan. 29, 2012
Categories: Business & Industry, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Bernardino County, CA, Big Bear Lake, CA

Title: Heifers sold for unusually high prices at the Fort Worth Stock Show in Texas
Description: Heifers sold for unusually high prices at the Fort Worth Stock Show, although steers normally command the highest prices.  One of the judges stated that he thought prices were 25 to 30 percent higher than the previous year.  Heifers were particularly valuable this year because they are “replacement females” or cows that have been bred or are set to breed for rebuilding herds.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Jan. 28, 2012
Places: Tarrant County, TX, Fort Worth, TX

Title: Voluntary water restrictions for Toledo Bend Reservoir in far eastern Texas
Description: The rising water level at Toledo Bend Reservoir led the Sabine River Authority of Texas to move from moderate to mild drought stage.  Water users were asked to voluntarily conserve water.  The reservoir was 162.92 feet above sea level on January 26, in comparison with the 164.27 feet last year at this time and fell to a record low of 159.42 feet on November 22, 2012, according to the Shreveport Times.  New Orleans Times-Picayune & Nola.com (La.), Jan. 28, 2012.  The Sabine River Authority of Texas announced that the Toledo Bend Reservoir was no longer in the mild drought stage as the water level reached 166.56 feet on March 6, 2012.  Shreveport Times (La.), March 6, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Newton County, TX, Sabine County, TX, Shelby County, TX

Title: Boat ramp closed at Possum Kingdom Lake in Texas
Description: The level of Possum Kingdom was about 9.5 feet below normal on January 25, according to the park superintendent.  One of the lake’s two boat ramps was closed due to the low water level.  Abilene Reporter News (Texas), Jan. 28, 2012
Places: Palo Pinto County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Farmer near Hemet, California replanted his wheat crop for lack of rain
Description: A farmer near Hemet had to replant his wheat crop because the seeds could not push through the crusty, dry soil.  Some of the wheat that did manage to emerge was growing slower than it normally does due to insufficient rainfall.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Jan. 30, 2012
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Supplemental feeding continuing in Far West Texas
Description: Livestock continued to receive supplemental feeding since rangeland was in poor condition. The body condition of many cows that had calves was deteriorating because they needed additional nutrition for lactation.  El Paso Times (Texas), Jan. 24, 2012

Title: Well providing water for Spicewood Beach, Texas expected to run dry within two to three weeks
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority requested that residents near Spicewood Beach "limit water use to absolutely necessary functions" because the well providing water for the 1,100 residents may be too low to supply water within two to three weeks.  The well provides water for the communities of Spicewood Beach, Lakeside Beach, Lake Oaks and Eagle Bluff.  The LCRA might deepen the present well or drill new ones, but first needs permission from the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality before taking emergency actions.  Another well along the upper reaches of Lake Travis went offline recently because the water table was too low.  The water level was 652.52 feet above mean sea level on June 20, 2011 and was 634.61 feet above mean sea level on January 20, 2012.  The area was in stage 3 water restrictions, but may move to stage 4 water restrictions, which prohibits all outdoor watering and additional water service, if the water table continued to fall.  Austin American Statesman (Texas), Jan. 23, 2012 and January 30, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX

Title: Sky turned brown from dust in West Texas
Description: Strong winds blew dust across the Big Country on January 22, turning the sky brown.  The winds increased the fire danger, given the existing drought conditions.  A senior forecaster for the National Weather Service in San Angelo stated, "The dust storm is really a factor of the dry weather pattern we've been in for close to 18 months now. The soil all across the western parts of the state is so dry that when we get these strong winds, it just picks it all up."  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Jan. 22, 2012

Title: Wildfires scorch patches of West Texas

Other fires were also reported in Snyder, Greenwood and Potter County, where a fire charred 4,000 acres on January 21.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Jan. 22, 2012

Title: Real County, Texas, wells almost going dry, low river levels

Title: Fire danger rising in Kern County, California

Title: Volunteer fire departments across Texas gearing up for another harsh wildfire season
Description: Volunteer fire departments across Texas were gearing up for another harsh wildfire season since drought was projected to persist for the state.  Unfortunately, state budget cuts eliminated millions of dollars’ worth of grants for volunteer fire departments, making the task of keeping communities safe an enormous challenge and one for which some departments feel unprepared.  A firefighter in Angelina County stated that his two tanker trucks were 25 and 30 years old and were both homemade.  The ages of the vehicles worries him and leaves him wondering if the vehicle is safe and can perform when needed.  A member of the Huntington VFD also expressed concern about the lack of appropriate equipment.  KTRE-TV ABC 9 (Lufkin, Texas), Jan. 18, 2012
Places: Texas, Angelina County, TX

Title: Pipeline under construction to connect Lake Ivie to Lake J.B. Thomas in West Texas
Description: A pipeline was under construction to connect Lake Ivie to Lake J.B. Thomas because Lake Thomas contained only enough water to last until April or May 2012, according to the Snyder city manager.  The pipeline ought to be finished in mid-February 2012.  The general manager of the Colorado River Municipal Water District revealed that Lake Ivie will be too low to be useful within a year if conditions do not change.  Both lakes are owned by the CRMWD. Title: Ranchers on the Rolling Plains of Texas continued to give livestock supplemental feed
Description: Rolling Plains ranchers continued to give livestock supplemental feed to keep their body condition from deteriorating and struggled to find any hay to purchase.  Overgrazed pastures have not yet recovered.  Bare fields not sown with cotton in 2011 and some wheat fields planted during the fall were blown out by strong winds.  Farmers resorted to listing their fields to reduce the likelihood of blow outs.  Odessa American (Texas), Jan. 18, 2012 and El Paso Times (Texas), Jan. 24, 2012

Title: Higher than normal volume of cattle sales in Fresno, California
Description: More cattle than usual were sold at the Fresno Livestock Commission, according to the owner.  She stated that the lack of grazing led some producers to sell.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), Jan. 18, 2012
Places: Fresno County, CA

Title: Ranchers in California's San Joaquin Valley sought alternate pastures, bought pricey hay
Description: Some farmers and ranchers had to move cattle to alternate pastures or purchase expensive hay because dry conditions have eliminated grass growth for livestock.  Hay was selling for about $300 per ton.  Some have also requested early water deliveries.  Fresno Bee (Calif.), Jan. 18, 2012

Title: Burn ban in Travis County, Texas
Description: Outdoor burning was banned in Travis County after county commissioners unanimously passed the ban on January 17.  The fire danger was rising due to dry vegetation with the expectation of warmer, drier weather and high winds in the near future.  The Travis County fire marshal attested that several controlled burns escaped containment in the past week.  The ban will expire on February 15 unless commissioners decide otherwise.  The county’s last burn ban ended on November 22, 2011.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Jan. 17, 2012
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Goat farmer in Flower Mound, Texas drove 120 miles round trip for hay
Description: A goat farmer in Flower Mound with a herd of 45 animals stated that she has to drive 120 miles round trip to get decent hay for her goats.  She also noted that she spends more than twice as much as she used to for hay.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Jan. 15, 2012
Places: Denton County, TX, Flower Mound, TX

Title: Dairy goat farmer in Midlothian, Texas sold most of herd due to high cost for hay
Description: A dairy goat farm in Midlothian sold 60 of its 80 goats because the owners could not afford the expensive hay for all of the animals.  A round bale of hay that used to cost $40 sells for $160.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Jan. 15, 2012
Places: Ellis County, TX, Midlothian, TX

Title: Higher salinity levels affect oyster beds, waterfowl in south Texas
Description: According to the Texas Forest Service, Victoria County has removed its burn ban. San Patricio County has reinstated its ban and the remainder of south Texas continues with burn bans. For Victoria County, household trash burning in a barrel will be allowed only if there is a screen on top consisting of holes no larger than 5/8 inch. The area around the barrel should be cleared down to the soil or gravel. All burning must be supervised with ready available means to control the fire. In addition, the Victoria County fire marshal’s office shall be notified of any acreage or pile burning. The city of Laredo officially remains under voluntary water restrictions. Although the city of Corpus Christi does not officially begin voluntary water restrictions until the combined system capacity falls to below 50 percent, residents are still encouraged to voluntarily conserve water. Residents in Victoria are also strongly encouraged to conserve. With grasses now dormant, residents should be not be watering their landscapes for growth, but only to maintain deep soil moisture. Thus, watering should be very infrequent, especially after recent rainfall. Also, lawns should be watered before 10 am or after 6 pm to reduce evaporation. Avoid runoff into sidewalks and streets, use a sprinkler that makes larger water droplets, and curtail watering time to less than 30 minutes. Additional locations within the HSA have maintained either mandatory or voluntary restrictions on their local public water systems (PWS): Aransas County: Sunset Bay (voluntary); Bee County: Blueberry Hills Waterworks (voluntary); Calhoun County: the city of Port Comfort (stage 1); Jim Wells County: English Acres (stage 3), Paisano Mobile Home Park (stage 3) and Loma Linda Water Supply (voluntary); Kleberg County: King Ranch Santa Gertrudis District (stage 1) and East Riviera (voluntary); Live Oak: Buckeye Knoll (stage 1), Old Marbach School WSC (voluntary); Nueces County: Nueces County WCID 3 (voluntary); Webb County: Mirando City WSC (voluntary) The drought has also affected the bays and estuaries, as salinity levels in these areas remain high. Because of the higher salinity levels, many oyster beds along the Texas Gulf Coast have been closed, which is affecting many businesses that rely on the industry. These closures were due to the red tide, largely caused by the lack of fresh water normally running into the Gulf. Recent testing shows that concentration is low to moderate. However, reports of dead fish washing up on shore continue. The annual migration of whooping cranes to the Texas coast is being threatened as the drought and red tide lessens the availability of freshwater and food. The lack of adequate feeding of the whooping cranes will make it a difficult and dangerous flight back to Canada as the cranes may become malnourished. Changes in winter migrations for towhees and sparrows have also been noticed. Typically, these birds reside in the western hill country and south Texas. However, due to scarcity of food in these areas, the birds have migrated farther north along the coast. The drought has also taken its toll across Texas, killing many trees (estimated in the millions) since 2010. Thousands of horses and donkeys have also been reported abandoned because of the high (and near record) cost of hay and other feed as well as the lower need for horses to monitor dwindling livestock. The Texas Crop and Weather Reports for January 4 and January 10 contained the following information: For the coastal bend district, supplemental feeding of cattle and importing hay continued. Many ponds remained dry and soil moisture was still below normal levels for spring planting. For western areas (considered part of the south district), stock tanks remained low. Supplemental feeding continued low forage supplies were low and rangelands and pastures were in poor condition. Overall, soil moisture levels were short to very short, with the exception of McMullen County being 50 to 60 percent adequate. Hay was in short supply and prices continue to increase. A high fire danger exists over areas generally west of Interstate 37. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Corpus Christi, Texas - January 12, 2012
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Aransas County, TX, Bee County, TX, Calhoun County, TX, Duval County, TX, Goliad County, TX, Jim Wells County, TX, Kleberg County, TX, La Salle County, TX, Live Oak County, TX, McMullen County, TX, Nueces County, TX, Refugio County, TX, San Patricio County, TX, Victoria County, TX, Webb County, TX

Title: Texas panhandle counties under burn ban; producers providing supplemental feed for cattle
Description: As of January 11, all Texas panhandle counties except Sherman, Hansford, Gray, Wheeler, Donley, and Collingsworth support a countywide outdoor burn ban. According to the Texas crop weather report issued January 10th by the Texas A&M agriculture program, the following agricultural impacts were noted across the Texas panhandle. Soil moisture continued to be mostly short to very short. The cotton harvest was almost complete. Winter wheat was in excellent to very poor condition, with most reporting poor to very poor. Producers were tilling fields in preparation for planting crops. Rangeland and pastures were in fair to very poor condition, with most reporting very poor. Livestock producers continued to provide supplemental feed for cattle on pasture. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Amarillo, Texas - January 11, 2012
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Castro County, TX, Childress County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Wheeler County, TX

Title: Whooping cranes survival jeopardized by drought along Texas Gulf Coast
Description: Marshes and estuaries on the Gulf Coast of Texas were too salty to support blue crabs and wolf berries, foods that are staples in the diet of whooping cranes, leading cranes lovers to worry about the birds’ survival this winter.  Because the birds usually walk around a one square mile area in search of water, it consumes valuable energy to fly to reach water sources that would normally be plentiful and within walking distance for the birds.  Reduced protein supplies from the dearth of blue crabs can diminish the likelihood of successful return to summer nesting grounds.  The manager of the Aransas National Wildlife Refuge where the birds winter noted that one bird died, and expressed concern that there was a death so early in the winter.  A skimmer boat captain who takes visitors to see the cranes worried that there was so little food for the birds, except dead fish.  USA Today, Jan. 9, 2012
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Aransas County, TX

Title: Burn bans, water restrictions in effect in Deep South Texas; producers providing supplemental feed to cattle
Description: Burn bans are in effect for all counties in Deep South Texas. Residents are urged to refrain from conducting any outside burning activities. Livestock producers continued to provide supplemental feed as forage supplies remained low, and rangeland and pastures were in poor condition. Of the 28 water districts in the Rio Grande valley, some have started warning growers that water may run short next year if irrigation demands remain high. Several public water supply entities continue voluntary water conservation to avoid shortages or further restrictions, with a few entities requiring mild restrictions. One public water supply entity in Starr County has initiated severe restrictions. According to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ), the number of water supply entities with restrictions is as follows: 2 in Cameron County, 8 in Hidalgo County, 4 in Starr County, 3 in Zapata County and 2 in Willacy County. Residents of Deep South Texas are urged to conserve water. NWS - Drought Information Statement - Brownsville, Texas - January 6, 2012
Places: Brooks County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Jim Hogg County, TX, Kenedy County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX, Zapata County, TX

Title: Marsh fires burned in Jefferson County, Texas
Description: Six fires flared up in exceedingly dry marshland and scorched several hundred acres of rural Jefferson County.  Strong winds also contributed to the fires.  Although the vegetation was dry, the marsh was still moist enough that fire trucks could not drive in to extinguish the fires, but had to wait for the fires to die down on their own.  KVUE (Austin, Texas), Jan. 2, 2012
Places: Jefferson County, TX

Title: Dominant species, carnivores struggled in California drought
Description: Due to drought in the Carrizo Plains of southern California between 2012 and 2015, dominant species suffered in the drought, while less dominant species benefited, found researchers from the University of Washington and the University of California, Berkeley.  Carnivores also struggled when their prey became scarce.EurekAlert! (Washington, D.C.), Aug. 20, 2018
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA

Title: Dry conditions in California cutting the carrying capacity of pastures and rangeland, prompting producers to thin their herds
Description: Dry conditions in California are cutting the carrying capacity of pastures and rangeland, prompting producers to thin their herds.  A cattle rancher east of Fresno compared his pasture to a parking lot because not enough rain has fallen for his grass to grow.  Further west in Mariposa, Merced and Madera counties, forage production was also down, noted a University of California Cooperative Extension livestock and natural resources farm advisor.  A livestock producer in Monterey County sold about two-thirds of his herd after enduring 2012 with just a third of normal rainfall and less than a third of average forage production.  A Napa County livestock producer had little forage in 2012, due to scant rainfall, and sold all of his cattle in January 2013 rather than struggle through another dry year.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), July 9, 2013
Places: Fresno County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA

Title: Loss of irrigation water in 2012 led to loss of 1,200 jobs in Colorado, Wharton and Matagorda counties in Texas
Description: More than 1,200 jobs ended in Colorado, Wharton and Matagorda counties in 2012 after the Lower Colorado River Authority withheld irrigation water from the rice farmers, according to a Texas A&M analysis released in April 2014.  Matagorda County suffered the most from the loss of irrigation water as 90 percent of its rice acreage was left unplanted that year in the first of three consecutive years of withheld irrigation water.  The direct value of rice production plummeted from $20.7 million to $2.4 million, according to the Texas A&M study.Related businesses also lost customers and income when rice farmers could not grow rice.  A crop duster went out of business, and a fuel supplier ended bulk fuel deliveries in Matagorda County.Houston Chronicle (Texas), April 6, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Colorado County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: California farmers pumping more water for crop irrigation amid a fourth year of drought
Description: California farmers were pumping more water for crop irrigation amid a fourth year of drought and were using hundreds of millions of dollars more electricity than normal to power the pumps.   The co-owner of a ranch northwest of Fresno reported that their power use was two and a half times higher than normal.  In response to the higher demand for electricity, utilities were building new transmission lines and substations to support the additional electricity.  In the Central Valley, farmers may use groundwater to meet more than 60 percent of their irrigation needs in 2015, one-third more than a normal year, said a senior researcher at the University of California at Davis Center for Watershed Sciences.  At that rate, electric bills would rise 77 percent, or $600 million, compared to a year with normal precipitation.  The amount of energy needed to pump groundwater was up 90 megawatt-hours, said the senior vice president of regulatory affairs for Southern California Edison Co., a subsidiary of Edison International.   The utility built the $190 million San Joaquin Cross Valley Loop transmission project in November to meet farmers’ increased need for electricity. Pacific Gas & Electric Co. has proposed a 230-kilovolt transmission line through the Central Valley where power demand for groundwater pumping rose about 40 percent over the average levels for 2008 to 2011.The Washington Post (D.C.), Sept. 3, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Energy, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Californians’ electric bills rose  $2.45 billion from 2012 to 2016
Description: Californians’ electric bills rose a collective $2.45 billion from 2012 to 2016 as drought sharply reduced the availability of cheap hydroelectricity, estimated the Pacific Institute, an Oakland water policy think tank.  In 2016, federal data showed that Californians spent nearly $39 million on electricity Peter Gleick, the study’s author and institute’s president emeritus, noted that the loss of hydropower caused environmental impacts too.  Carbon emissions from the state’s power plants increased 10 percent during the drought as utilities reverted to conventional sources like natural gas.The Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 26, 2017
