Title: A record number of Rio Grande Valley farmers have filed crop insurance claims because drought devastated crops and pastures in south Texas
Description: A record number of Rio Grande Valley farmers have filed crop insurance claims because drought devastated crops and pastures in south Texas again this year.  Hidalgo County farmers filed roughly $5 million in claims in 2012, and have filed claims for nearly $10 million this year.  KRGV-TV Channel 5 Weslaco (Texas), Nov. 5, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Twice the amount of idled farmland in California's Central Valley
Description: Persistent drought in California caused farmers to fallow 1.03 million acres of land in the Central Valley, amounting to about 15 percent of the 7 million acres of irrigated farmland in the Valley, found a study undertaken by NASA, in collaboration with the United States Department of Agriculture, the United States Geological Survey, and the California Department of Water Resources.  The amount of idled land was more than twice that left idle in 2011, the most recent year with a winter of average to above average precipitation statewide.  The biggest increases in idle acreage were seen along the west side of the San Joaquin Valley in Fresno, Kings and Kern counties."These datasets highlight the continuing impacts of the drought on agricultural communities in California, and identify regions in the state that have been particularly hard hit by water shortages.  At the same time, the data provide insights into regions of the state that have been more resilient to the drought and that have been able to sustain agricultural production despite the reductions in surface water supplies," said a senior research scientist at NASA’s Ames Research Center at Moffett Field in San Jose.Central Valley Business Times (Calif.), Oct. 26, 2015
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Water prices rising since Texas' 2011 drought
Description: Since Texas’ 2011 drought, the Lower Colorado River Authority's water prices have risen, increasing costs for crawfish farmers.  Rice farmers were also affected, with a number of them ceasing to grow rice.  The price of interruptible water, water that can be curtailed or shut off during drought, rose from $25 per acre-foot in 2011 to $39 per acre-foot in 2016, and to $63 per acre-foot in 2020.The number of contracted acreage has also fallen.  Because many costs are fixed, fewer units also means higher water prices.Victoria Advocate (Texas), Feb. 8, 2020
Places: Matagorda County, TX

Title: Irrigation deliveries began months early due to lack of rainfall in the San Joaquin Valley, California
Description: The Kings River Water District began its irrigation water deliveries in January.  The secretary-treasurer of the water district stated, “It is almost unheard of to be delivering water in January, but it has been so dry and we are getting requests for water.”  Fresno Bee (Calif.), Jan. 18, 2012
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kings County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Big Bear Lake in San Bernardino County, California low after years of drought
Description: The level of Big Bear Lake in San Bernardino County went from being full in 2012 to being 13.5 feet low on May 10, 2016.  Mike Stephenson, the general manager of Big Bear Municipal Water District, stated that the lake provides water for local ski resorts’ snowmaking guns.  Years of drought also have depleted the lake.Of the decline, the general manager said, “The last four years has seen the steepest line from full to 13-and-a-half feet down that I’ve seen in recorded history.  There is no steeper line in any of the graphs that I can find.”Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), May 10, 2016
Places: Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: California water restrictions also reduced spread of West Nile virus
Description: Water restrictions in California, which limited lawn watering, also reduced the number of shallow pools of water on lawns, thereby reducing spread of the mosquito-borne West Nile virus, according to research from UCLA and three other universities.  The number of mosquitoes was reduced by 44 percent in Los Angeles County and 39 percent in Orange County, thanks to the water restrictions, which extended from 2012 through 2016 amid the statewide drought.UCLA Newsroom (Los Angeles, Calif.), Feb. 16, 2021
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA

Title: Large water withdrawals in the Westlands Water District of Southern California
Description: Farmers in the Westlands Water District pumped 40 percent more groundwater than usual during the past few years, due to drought and cutbacks in the water supply.  The State Water Project provided just 5 percent of full allocations in 2014, while the state ordered thousands of water rights holders to stop drawing water in the watershed supplying the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta.  The New York Times, Feb. 14, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kings County, CA

Title: Number of mosquitoes carrying West Nile virus at an all-time high in California
Description: Nearly 800 Californians were infected with the West Nile virus in 2014, the worst outbreak in a decade.  Drought was blamed for the record number of cases, and 2015 is expected to bring more of the same.  The virus is mainly spread by mosquitoes that feed on infected birds and transmit the virus to humans.  Many people suffer no ill effects from the virus, while others become extremely sick and even die.When the California drought began in 2012, the number of West Nile virus cases rose to 479 from 158 the previous year.  In 2014, 798 cases were recorded, the highest number since 2005, said the California Department of Public Health.  Twenty-nine people died.  Experts attribute the elevated West Nile activity to stagnant water and water sources in populated areas bringing the virus closer to people.  The virus activity was most intense in Southern California, and especially in Orange County where 266 human cases were reported and the highest rate of infected mosquitoes was found. Water conservation measures prevented the county from flushing its underground storm drains where mosquitoes flourished.  The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 24, 2015The number of California mosquitoes infected with the West Nile virus has risen to record heights this year, according to the California Department of Public Health. Santa Clara County has been a hot spot for birds carrying the West Nile virus, with more than one-third of the total affected birds statewide being found there.  Health departments in Santa Clara, Alameda and Contra Costa counties have been taking measures to reduce the number mosquitoes with the West Nile virus since mosquitoes transmit the disease to birds. The Santa Clara County Vector Control District found that 1 in 20 mosquitoes were infected with the West Nile virus this summer.  Eighty of Alameda County’s 92 West Nile-positive birds were found in Livermore, leading health officials to pull out the stops to eradicate the mosquitoes.Throughout California, there have been 562 human cases of West Nile reported through Oct. 21, more than twice the count at this time in 2013.  Seventeen deaths have been related to the virus since the start of the year, compared with 15 deaths in all of 2013.  Five human cases leading to the neural-invasive type of complication were confirmed in Contra Costa County.  A dozen people in Santa Clara County contracted the virus, with four being hospitalized also with neural-invasive complications.Public health officials say the uptick in West Nile virus cases could be attributed to climate, the number and types of birds and mosquitoes in an area, birds’ immune systems and drought.San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), Oct. 19, 2014The number of mosquitoes carrying the West Nile virus was at an all-time high, said state health officials.  Since the start of the year, 181 cases of West Nile virus were reported to the California Department of Public Health, and eight people have died.  During the last week alone, 52 new cases were reported.  A state public health official said drought may be contributing to the spread of the virus via birds and mosquitoes. San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), Sept. 4, 2014
Places: California, Alameda County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA

Title: Drought reduced California's hydropower production
Description: The recent years of drought caused a significant lull in hydropower production, but the unusually snowy 2016-17 winter refilled reservoirs and promised to bring plenty of hydropower, possibly as much as 21 percent of the state’s total electricity output, according to the California Energy Commission.  Fifteen to 18 percent of California’s electricity generation typically comes from hydropower, according to Peter Gleick of the Pacific Institute, but during the drought, hydropower generation dropped to less than 10 percent on average.  The state turned to burning natural gas to make up the difference, driving up greenhouse gas emissions by 10 percent over what they would have been.  Burning natural gas also cost Californians $2.4 billion more than they would have paid if hydropower production had been near normal.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), March 20, 2017
Categories: Energy, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: California, Alameda County, CA, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Butte County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, Colusa County, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Del Norte County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Glenn County, CA, Humboldt County, CA, Imperial County, CA, Inyo County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Lake County, CA, Lassen County, CA, Los Angeles County, CA, Madera County, CA, Marin County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mendocino County, CA, Merced County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Mono County, CA, Monterey County, CA, Napa County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Orange County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Riverside County, CA, Sacramento County, CA, San Benito County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, San Luis Obispo County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, Santa Barbara County, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Santa Cruz County, CA, Shasta County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Sutter County, CA, Tehama County, CA, Trinity County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA, Ventura County, CA, Yolo County, CA, Yuba County, CA

Title: Second year of drought takes toll on trees, landscapes, cattle ponds in Madera County, California
Description: Short on water so we are re-evaluating how much is on a drip system. Replaced pump in well last week due to excessive iron deposits; water table seemed to be stable. This is the second year of a drought--11.98 inches of rain from 7/1/12-6/30/13 (60% of normal). Oak trees are visibly stressed; leaves are in a fall-like mode--also maple trees even though they are getting watered. The lawn is a disaster--days and days of temps at or above 100 are taking their toll.  Local cattle woman says their ponds are drying up--many are not putting in pasture due to lack of water. Even tar weed, which cattle won't apparently eat, isn't blooming as it normally does. Numerous local fires since April have emitted a lot of ash into the atmosphere; unknown whether this will have an impact on the fall/winter rains.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Yosemite Lakes 4.7 S on 7/24/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Madera County, CA

Title: Drought cost farmers in the Rio Grande Valley in Texas at least $6.9 million in crop losses in 2012
Description: Drought cost farmers in the Rio Grande Valley at least $6.9 million in crop losses in 2012, according to a report by the Natural Resources Defense Council.  In Cameron County, 43 percent of the crops were devastated by drought and heat, for $2.9 million in crop damage.  Thirty-one percent of the crops in Hidalgo County were lost to drought, for a cost of $3 million.  In Willacy County where all farmland is unirrigated, 88 percent of the crops were lost to drought, for a loss of $1 million.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Sept. 1, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Spate of well-drilling in San Joaquin Valley, California
Description: As drought persisted and water deliveries from the state and federal projects were slim, California farmers resorted to using groundwater to keep crops growing.  In the San Joaquin Valley in 2015, farmers dug about 2,500 new wells, the most in one year and five times the annual average for the previous 30 years, according to a Sacramento Bee analysis of state and local data.  From 2012 through 2015, San Joaquin Valley farmers dug more than 5,000 wells, more than were dug altogether during the previous 12 years.  Most of the new wells were in Fresno and Tulare counties, where officials issued an average of nearly 10 agricultural well permits each business day in 2015, although some of the permits were not used.  The permit-issuing pace has slowed in the first few months of 2016, but still remained higher than pre-drought levels.  There were plenty of drilling jobs lined up for a Fresno-based well driller, who expected to drill about 260 new wells in the San Joaquin Valley in 2016.  A recent well was sunk 1,200 feet in Poplar at a cost of $260,000, although just a few years ago, the average well depth was roughly 600 feet.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Sept. 25, 2016
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Fresno, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA, East Porterville, CA, Poplar, CA, Porterville, CA, Woodville, CA

Title: Drought-killed trees dropping in East Texas
Description: East Texas trees killed by drought in 2011 were dropping branches, taking down power lines and causing property damage.  KLTV ABC (Tyler, Texas), July 28, 2020
Places: Gregg County, TX

Title: Drought led towhees and sparrows to change their wintering habits in Texas
Description: Drought led towhees and sparrows to change their wintering habits in Texas this year.  Green-tailed towhees, which normally reside in western Hill Country and South Texas during the winter, were staying in the upper coastal regions from Brazoria and Harris counties through Jefferson and Montgomery counties.  The reason for their change of address was the summer drought, which eliminated all food sources in the Hill Country, according to the Hill Country Master Naturalist.  He stated, “I just did my first of three winter transects, and all the sparrow species were low.  There is absolutely no food out there for birds or mammals."  Spotted towhees, which usually winter in the Hill Country, were there in substantial numbers, but were also appearing in Lake Jackson, Galveston and Houston, which is unusual.  Many sparrows were flocking to coastal areas and Harris County this winter, but are normally found in Central Texas east to the Texas Blackland Prairie and up through the Great Plains.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Dec. 16, 2011
Places: Atascosa County, TX, Bell County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Brazoria County, TX, Brooks County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Chambers County, TX, Comal County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Crockett County, TX, Dimmit County, TX, Duval County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Frio County, TX, Galveston County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Harris County, TX, Hays County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Jefferson County, TX, Jim Hogg County, TX, Jim Wells County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Kenedy County, TX, Kerr County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Kleberg County, TX, La Salle County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Liberty County, TX, Live Oak County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Maverick County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, McMullen County, TX, Menard County, TX, Montgomery County, TX, Real County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Starr County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Val Verde County, TX, Webb County, TX, Willacy County, TX, Williamson County, TX, Zapata County, TX, Zavala County, TX

Title: Many ranchers near Sulphur Springs, Texas sold up to 50 percent of their livestock
Description: A part-time rancher near Sulphur Springs stated that many ranchers in his area sold up to 50 percent of their herds because they couldn’t keep all of the livestock during drought.  While good prices for the animals helped, many ranchers were really struggling financially.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Dec. 16, 2011
Places: Hopkins County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Ector County, Texas
Description: The Ector County judge voted in favor of keeping the county burn ban in effect to break the commissioners’ tie.  The present ban originally began in mid-December.  Odessa American (Texas), Jan. 23, 2012
Places: Ector County, TX

Title: Lack of snow affects ski areas in California and Oregon
Description: Mount Ashland Ski Area operating fewer days due to lack of natural snow. Mount Shasta and Willamette Pass Ski areas are not open, but plan to open between Dec 26 and Dec 31st- new snowfall dependent. Lodging and other services in these areas have lost substantial revenue (compared to normal) due to the dry December weather (and water year, thus far- since Sep 1st). Additionally, flows on waterways that are not regulated are down, which affects anadromous fish- where they can hide and go. Regulated waterways, such as the Rogue River regulated by Lost Creek Lake, have not been impacted yet.
Places: Siskiyou County, CA, Mount Shasta, CA, Jackson County, OR, Klamath County, OR

Title: Closure of oyster beds along Texas Gulf Coast affecting many businesses
Description: The closure of the coastal oyster beds has hurt the oyster industry, putting fishermen and oyster processers and shippers out of work and cutting into area businesses’ bottom lines.  Drought conditions and the absence of fresh water flowing into the Gulf promoted the growth of red tide, which makes the oysters harmful to those who eat them, and spread a parasite called “dermo” that kills oysters.  In Port Lavaca, the effects of the closure of the oyster beds touched many businesses from gas stations to equipment suppliers to eating establishments where fishermen would be spending money, but without oysters and work, there is no demand for such things.   An oyster transport company in San Leon trucks only four to five loads of Louisiana oysters instead of the ten truckloads of that it used to ship daily.  A seafood company reported that its business was off by 80 percent and noted that other seafood businesses in Port Lavaca were faring similarly.  The owner of a Port Lavaca hardware store revealed that the closure of the oyster beds cost him about $4,000 monthly or about 25 percent of his revenue from November through April.  A fisherman in Port Lavaca said that he spent $8,000 to improve his boat, but now has no income to support his wife and five children until the beds reopen.  A shellfish toxicologist for Texas A&M University-Galveston stated that a huge influx of fresh water into the Gulf was needed to remedy the red tide and dermo infestation.  USA Today, Dec. 14, 2011
Places: Brazoria County, TX, Calhoun County, TX, Port Lavaca, TX, Cameron County, TX, Chambers County, TX, Galveston County, TX, Harris County, TX, Jackson County, TX, Jefferson County, TX, Kenedy County, TX, Kleberg County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Nueces County, TX, Orange County, TX, Refugio County, TX, San Patricio County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: More road damage than usual in the vicinity of Austin, Texas
Description: The Austin District of the Texas Department of Transportation has been very busy dealing with more damage than usual to roads and attributes the increase to drought.  The soil becomes dry and contracts, leading to cracks and bumps in the road.  The Austin Department of Public Works has also received notification of new dips and depressions in the road that need repair.  There was no estimate of the cost for repairing the damage brought on by dry conditions.  KUT-FM 90.5 Austin (Texas), Dec. 12, 2011
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: County judge filed disaster declaration to prevent use of fireworks in Ector County, Texas
Description: The Ector County judge filed a 60-hour disaster declaration to prohibit fireworks in the county, due to dry conditions and elevated fire danger.  County commissioners lengthened the declaration and will send the declaration and extension to the governor for his approval and ban on fireworks through New Year’s Day.  Fireworks vendors strongly urged the commissioners to forego the ban, citing the hardship to him and his employees.  Odessa American (Texas), Dec. 12, 2011
Categories: Business & Industry, Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions
Places: Ector County, TX

Title: Stage 1 water restrictions took effect in Dallas, Texas
Description: Stage 1 water restrictions took effect in Dallas, portions of Dallas County and in Flower Mound and Lewisville in Denton County on December 12 and permit outdoor watering twice per week.  Normally water conservation would begin in Dallas when its reservoir capacity falls to 65 percent, but with drought expected to continue, city officials opted to enter stage 1 water restrictions when the reservoir capacity reached 75 percent.  The goal was to reduce water use by 5 percent.  Dallas Morning News (Texas), Nov. 15, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Dallas County, TX, Dallas, TX, Flower Mound, TX, Lewisville, TX

Title: Drought and heat devastated roughly half of a pecan orchard in southern Williamson County, Texas
Description: Drought and heat devastated roughly half of the 3,000 pecan trees in a pecan orchard in southern Williamson County.  The pecan harvest in Texas is anticipated to be 40 to 60 percent lower than last year.  While the normal annual production is around 75 million pounds, this year’s crop is estimated to be near 30 million pounds, due to drought and heat.  Country World News (Texas), Dec. 12, 2011
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality accepted stringent water curtailment plans from the Lower Colorado River Authority in Central Texas
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority received approval from the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality on their emergency plan that could deprive rice farmers of irrigation water in the upcoming growing season and on a pro rata water curtailment plan that could trim water deliveries to municipal and industrial water customers by 20 percent.   Irrigation supplies will be dependent upon the volume of water held in lakes Travis and Buchanan, which are the LCRA’s two primary reservoirs, on March 1.  If there is less than 850,000 acre-feet of water, rice farmers will receive no water for their crop.  If the volume held in lakes Travis and Buchanan was between 850,000 and 920,000 acre-feet, the LCRA will release as much as 125,000 acre-feet of water to rice farmers, which is substantially less than they normally receive.  If the lakes contain more than 920,000 acre-feet, the LCRA will distribute water as laid out in their water management plan.  As of December 7, the lakes held 741,000 acre-feet of water, which is 37 percent of capacity.  The lakes are expected to contain from 660,000 to 700,000 acre-feet on January 1, which does not bode well for rice farmers.  The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality also accepted a pro rata water curtailment plan from the LCRA that could trim water deliveries to municipal and industrial water customers by 20 percent.  The plan will take effect when the drought in Central Texas is recognized as being the worst drought ever to strike the region.  Some cities served by the LCRA include Austin, LaGrange, Wharton and Bay City.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Dec. 7, 2011
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Golf courses in the Reno, Nevada area enjoyed several weeks of winter play
Description: Dry conditions and delayed snowfall allowed golf courses in the Reno-Tahoe area to remain open many weeks later into the winter season than usual and entertain a record number of golfers.  Power carts were not in use at LakeRidge in Reno because the grass was very dry and dormant.  Despite the ban on power carts, a record number of rounds was played in December and January with 60 to 80 golfers coming through on some days.  LakeRidge elected to irrigate a few times, given the steady flow of players and absence of snow.  The head pro at Washoe golf course stated that 1,900 rounds were played there in January, in comparison to the 600 to 800 rounds played in an average year.  Roughly 2,000 rounds of golf were played at Old Brockway in King’s Beach between December 7, 2011 and January 17, 2012.  Prior to this winter, snowfall always closed Old Brockway for the winter by December 7.  Golf club rentals were much higher than usual.  The North Lake Tahoe Chamber of Commerce requested that golf courses stay open to give visitors an alternative to skiing since there was not enough snow.  Reno Gazette-Journal (Nev.), Feb. 20, 2012
Places: Placer County, CA, Washoe County, NV, Reno, NV

Title: Pecan production was just 10 percent of normal in the Taylor and Tom Green county area of Texas
Description: Pecan production was just 10 percent of normal in the Taylor and Tom Green county area, according to the Taylor County Extension agent.  He stated that many trees dropped their pecans to survive the drought.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Dec. 6, 2011
Places: Taylor County, TX, Tom Green County, TX

Title: Water intake pipe for Pendleton, Texas above the water level of Toledo Bend Reservoir
Description: The water intake pipe for Pendleton on the Toledo Bend Reservoir was above the water line, leaving the town without water.  The community has permission to use a barge to support a pipe to pump from a deeper area of the reservoir.  The cost for the emergency measure was $50,000.  This was the quickest solution to the town’s water crisis.  The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality stated that there were 11 communities in the state with water supplies expected to last six months or less.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Dec. 3, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sabine County, TX

Title: Subdivision near Austin, Texas relying on emergency water supply
Description: A subdivision of 230 homes near Austin spent roughly $10,000 to construct a barge to support a pipe over a lake that can supply water temporarily to the subdivision, according to a water supply company manager.  If the lake level falls six feet, the next option for the community will be to truck in water, which could drive monthly water bills up to about $300 per month from about $120.  It is hoped that there is about a years’ worth of water in the lake.  The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality stated that there were 11 communities in the state with water supplies expected to last six months or less.   Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Dec. 3, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: The Safe Haven Equine Rescue in Gilmer, Texas receives 20 to 40 calls weekly about abandoned horses and donkeys
Description: The Safe Haven Equine Rescue in Gilmer receives 20 to 40 calls weekly about abandoned horses and donkeys as many animal owners can no longer afford to feed their animals with hay so scarce and prices so high.  Before the drought, they received three or four calls weekly concerning animal abandonment.  Allentown Morning Call (Pa.), Dec. 3, 2011
Places: Upshur County, TX

Title: Water delivery to wildlife refuges in southern Oregon, northern California ended
Description: The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation stopped sending water to the Lower Klamath and Tule Lake national wildlife refuges because snowpack was down and inflows to Upper Klamath Lake were expected to be down also.  The bureau resumed water delivery to the refuges on March 17, 2012 at a rate of 100 cubic feet per second after the deaths of at least 10,000 migratory waterfowl from avian cholera.  The flow later rose to 250 cfs as more runoff was expected to fill Upper Klamath Lake.  Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), March 30, 2012
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Siskiyou County, CA, Klamath County, OR

Title: Low flows in Trinity River (Trinity County, California) delaying steelhead spawning
Description: With Trinity River flow as low as it is, migrating steelhead haven't gone as far upriver as they would.  Spawning is delayed in creeks and streams.  That may change next week, but how significantly remains to be seen.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Douglas City 2.4 SW on 1/14/2012
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Trinity County, CA

Title: Lack of snow hurting tourism and recreation in Inyo County, California
Description: 90% of our region's economy relies on tourism and recreation mostly in part to our local ski resorts. There has been minimal precipitation since mid-November and almost no snow accumulation in the mountains. Therefore skiers and winter tourists have not come. Many local communities are beginning to feel the effects of the lack of tourism. Ski resorts are on the brink of laying off all temporary employees and closing the ski resorts for the season (which stayed open until July of last year). If this trend continues, fire danger will be increasing soon as well.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Bishop 8.5 WSW on 1/6/2012
Categories: Business & Industry, Plants & Wildlife, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Inyo County, CA

Title: Livestock producers in North Texas continued to look for hay to purchase
Description: Livestock producers in North Texas continued to look for hay to purchase to sustain livestock through the winter and spring.  Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 29, 2011 and Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Feb. 4, 2012.  Livestock continued to receive supplemental feeding, but a recent rain may encourage grass growth and alleviate the need for supplemental feeding.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Feb. 4, 2012

Title: Tree farm south of Fort Worth, Texas lost 1,500 Christmas trees to drought
Description: The owner of a farm that grows Christmas trees south of Fort Worth stated that this summer’s drought killed 25 percent or 1,500 trees.  She purchased Frasier firs from North Carolina to have enough trees for her customers.  She has also planted trees from Arizona to have trees that tolerate drought better.  CBS, Nov. 29, 2011

Title: Supplemental feeding continued on Rolling Plains of Texas
Description: Livestock producers in the Rolling Plains continued to give their livestock supplemental feed as drought continued.  Winter pasture needed more rain to grow.  Cotton and dryland pecan yields were poor.  Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 29, 2011

Description: Ranchers in Southeast Texas continued to sell livestock rather than feed them through the winter since stock ponds held little water and pastures in poor condition.  Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 29, 2011

Title: Crop stalks being baled for feed in Deaf Smith County, Texas
Description: Farmers in Deaf Smith County continued to bale corn, grain sorghum and other crop stalks to have something to feed to livestock through the winter, according to the AgriLife Extension agent for the county.  He stated that ranchers were paying $80 to $100 for baled corn stalks in the field.  The cotton harvest was nearly complete with yields of 650 to 750 pounds per acre in some irrigated fields, due to drought during the growing season.  Dryland cotton was not harvestable.  Wheat needed rain or irrigation if it was to produce forage for stocker cattle.  Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 29, 2011

Title: Ranchers in Southwest Texas continued to give cattle supplemental feed
Description: Ranchers in Southwest Texas continued to give cattle supplemental feed and sell some or all of their herds since hay supplies remained short.  Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 29, 2011 and El Paso Times (Texas), Jan. 24, 2012

Title: Trees, vegetation dying in Far West Texas; some cattle dying from mesquite bean consumption
Description: Drought has devastated pastures, greasewood, some cedars on slopes and various other trees in Far West Texas.  The pecan harvest was poor due to the lack of rainfall.  Several ranchers whose cows were eating mesquite beans reported some cow deaths from eating too many beans, which can lead to impaction in the intestines and cause the rumen to stop functioning.  Mesquite beans are sometimes eaten when there is little else for the cattle to eat.  Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 29, 2011

Description: Livestock producers in South Texas continued giving their animals supplemental feed and looking for available hay because there was no grazing for the animals.  Producers also continued to sell animals.  Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 29, 2011

Title: North Texas Municipal Water District hastening the construction of a pipeline connecting Lake Texoma to a Lake Lavon water treatment plant
Description: The North Texas Municipal Water District was hastening the construction of a pipeline connecting Lake Texoma to a Lake Lavon water treatment plant.  Drought and the presence of zebra mussels since July 2009 prevented the NTMWD from drawing water from Lake Lavon.  The new pipeline will bring water from the lake straight to a Lake Lavon water treatment plant.  The district previously drew 28 percent of its water from Lake Lavon.  KXAS-TV NBC 5 Dallas - Fort Worth (Texas), Nov. 28, 2011
Places: Collin County, TX, Grayson County, TX

Title: Grape production a mere 25 percent of normal in Hays County, Texas
Description: A vintner near Dripping Springs said that his grape vines produced a mere 25 percent of his usual harvest of 60 tons.  Drought has recently demonstrated the importance of watering his vines during the months when the vines are dormant to keep them healthy and prepared for growth in the spring.  Statewide, grape production was expected to be about 4,450 tons this year, compared to 8,900 tons in 2010, as drought reduced the number of grape cluster and grape size, according to a viticulturist with the Texas AgriLife Extension Service in Lubbock.  Texas has about 400 vineyards covering roughly 3,400 acres mostly in West Texas and the High Plains.  Heat also caused grapes to mature sooner.  But on the bright side, drought caused the grapes to be sweeter, resulting in increased quality that will be remembered for years.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Nov. 27, 2011
Places: Hays County, TX

Title: Grape production just one-third of normal in Yoakum County, Texas
Description: A grape grower in Yoakum County stated that drought cut his grape harvest down to about 100 tons from his 115 acres of vines.  Last year the vines yielded 300 tons of grapes.  Statewide, grape production was expected to be about 4,450 tons this year, compared to 8,900 tons in 2010, as drought reduced the number of grape cluster and grape size, according to a viticulturist with the Texas AgriLife Extension Service in Lubbock.  Texas has about 400 vineyards covering roughly 3,400 acres mostly in West Texas and the High Plains.  Heat also caused grapes to mature sooner.  But on the bright side, drought caused the grapes to be sweeter, resulting in increased quality that will be remembered for years.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Nov. 27, 2011
Places: Yoakum County, TX

Title: Wildlife, grasses showing signs of stress in Sonoma County, California
Description: After an early start to the California water year in October, we have had a few moderate rain storms, well spaced, and winter annual grass growth has progressed well, but extremely low humidity and windy weather since Thanksgiving has begun to stress the grass, and tips are browning, which will affect grazing livestock and wildlife. As of the New Year, weather has remained extremely dry, and normally green hillsides have gone back to brown. Some deep-rooted perennial grasses are still green, but showing stress. A small watershed on my property has very reduced flow, and the fish are confined to a few bedrock pools. I observed one dead trout, indicating they are stressed.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Geyserville 10.6 WNW on 12/5/2011
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Christmas tree grower near Post, Texas lost more than half of her trees
Description: The owner of a Christmas tree farm reported that all 400 Leyland Cypress trees and 50 of the 400 Afghan evergreen trees died from heat and drought this year.  She intended to open her Christmas tree farm this season, but the hot, dry summer has forced her to wait another year until the trees are bigger.  Lake Wylie Pilot (S.C.), Nov. 25, 2011
Places: Garza County, TX

Title: Homeowner in Sonoma County, California, monitoring water usage, watering yard and garden
Description: I have had to water garden & yard (not typically required November - April).   I am now monitoring water usage because well is slow to refill holding tank (this is typically only required in late summer).CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Sebastopol 3.7 WSW on 1/9/2012
Places: Sonoma County, CA

Title: Firefighting resources in Riverside and San Bernardino counties in California being kept at summer levels
Description: Firefighting resources in Riverside and San Bernardino counties are being kept at summer levels.  Normally at this time of year, reductions in staffing and equipment are made, but the fire danger remains high, so the staffing reduction is being postponed.  Cal Fire records show that their Inland units have not transitioned to winter preparedness staffing since Nov. 21, 2011.  The U.S. Forest Service also has kept its staffing levels high in the San Bernardino National Forest and the Cleveland National Forest and continues to renew contracts for firefighting airplanes on a weekly basis.  Sixteen permanent full-time firefighters were hired to have more staff on hand after the seasonal firefighters leave. With the critically low level of moisture in vegetation, residents are urged to continue to keep vegetation 100 feet away from homes and take other precautions to fire-proof their homes and landscape as much as possible.  Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), Nov. 15, 2014
Places: Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: American Indian skull found at Lake Georgetown, north of Austin, Texas
Description: Fishermen at Lake Georgetown found an American Indian skull hundreds or thousands of years old as drought lowered the water level and revealed long-hidden artifacts.  The falling water levels of many Texas lakes have exposed a number of historical objects.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Nov. 20, 2011
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: Historical artifacts looted from Lake Whitney, south of Fort Worth, Texas
Description: Native American tools and fossils possibly thousands of years old were exposed by the low level of Lake Whitney, roughly 50 miles south of Fort Worth.  At least twenty-four looters were arrested for removing artifacts.  The Army Corps of Engineers was guarding the sites to prevent further looting.  The falling water levels of many Texas lakes have exposed a number of artifacts.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Nov. 20, 2011
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bosque County, TX, Hill County, TX

Title: Remnants of Bluffton, Texas visible again in Lake Buchanan
Description: The receding water line of Lake Buchanan revealed the grave of a young child, the concrete foundation of an old two-story hotel, scales from a cotton gin, a rusted tank and cement slabs from a gas station and general store from the long ago town of Bluffton.  A local historian learned that 389 graves were relocated when the dam construction began in 1931.  A number of ranches and prolific pecan trees were abandoned to the waters of Lake Buchanan.  The falling water levels of many Texas lakes have exposed a number of artifacts.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Nov. 20, 2011
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX, Llano County, TX

Title: Old church once submerged visible in Falcon Lake in South Texas
Description: A one hundred year old church emerged from the receding waters of Falcon Lake.  The falling water levels of many Texas lakes have exposed a number of artifacts.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Nov. 20, 2011
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Zapata County, TX

Title: Wildlife refuges in Texas Panhandle not drawing many migrating birds
Description: Drought in Texas and New Mexico has altered migrating birds’ flight paths as they sought areas with water and food.  The playas at the Buffalo Lake National Wildlife Refuge in Randall County were dry and hadn’t drawn many birds.  The situation was the same at Muleshoe National Wildlife Refuge in Bailey County, where only 27,000 birds had passed through the area.  The refuge manager stated, “I don't know where our birds are going.  It's not just the cranes, but the geese and the ducks. They had bumper crop years up in the potholes with lots of reproduction but there's nowhere for them to go."  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), Nov. 17, 2011
Places: Bailey County, TX, Randall County, TX

Title: More deer were feeding along Texas roads and being struck by vehicles
Description: More deer were feeding along Texas roads and being struck by vehicles for a couple of reasons.  Firstly, water sometimes collects in ditches, providing a source of water and encouraging the growth of vegetation, which draws deer to eat and drink.  Secondly, breeding season draws bucks in search of does and distracts them for exercising any caution they might normally possess near roads.  A game warden supervisor attested that most accidents within the past two weeks were connected to the breeding season, while many accidents prior to that were drought-related.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Nov. 17, 2011
Places: Wichita County, TX

Title: The lieutenant governor of Louisiana urged people to continue to visit the Toledo Bend Reservoir
Description: The lieutenant governor of Louisiana urged people to continue to visit the Toledo Bend Reservoir for fishing and other recreational activities, despite low water levels.  Recent dredging and stump removals have made navigation easier.  Boat ramps remained open at Pirate's Cove near Hornbeck, Circle Drive near Stanley, Buckeye Landing, Cypress Bend Park and Big Bass Marina, all near Many. Small boats can launch at Oak Ridge Park near Stanley, Toledo Bend Resort near Anacoco and Turtle Beach near Many.  Danbury News-Times (Conn.), Nov. 16, 2011
Places: De Soto Parish, LA, Sabine Parish, LA, Newton County, TX, Sabine County, TX, Shelby County, TX

Title: Some junior water rights suspended in Neches River Basin in eastern Texas
Description: Drought has depleted the flow of the Neches River in eastern Texas, prompting the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality to suspend the diversion rights of some junior water rights holders.  Those with water rights dated August 13, 1913 or later, term and temporary water rights permits were suspended.  In the interest of public health and safety, water rights for municipal uses and power generation were not affected.  Property owners along the river were still allowed to use river water for domestic and livestock uses.  In April, the TCEQ cautioned water permit holders that rights may be curtailed if drought continued to deplete water supplies.  Lufkin News (Texas), Nov. 16, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Anderson County, TX, Angelina County, TX, Cherokee County, TX, Hardin County, TX, Houston County, TX, Jasper County, TX, Jefferson County, TX, Orange County, TX, Polk County, TX, Trinity County, TX, Tyler County, TX

Title: Sesame yields down in the Coastal Bend region of Texas
Description: Drought limited the growth of sesame, a drought-tolerant crop grown in the Coastal Bend region of Texas.  The plant often grows to 3 to 5 feet in height and produces 500 to 1,200 pounds per acre in a non-irrigated setting.  Some test plots held plants that were just 2.2 feet tall and yielded only 255 pounds per acre on average.  SouthWest Farm Press, Nov. 15, 2011

Title: Farmers in the Rolling Plains of Texas stopped planting winter wheat
Description: Farmers in the Rolling Plains stopped planting winter wheat because the soil was too dry.  Livestock producers continued to give their livestock supplemental feed and cull their herds as drought continued.  Operators of large ranchers continued shipping cattle to better rangeland in other states.  The peanut and cotton yields were lower than producers had hoped.  Some cotton farmers whose crop didn’t fare well chose to plant wheat, but others were not optimistic enough to plant.  The danger of leaving fields fallow was the problem of blowing dust. Title: Donkey abandonments a problem in Navarro County, Texas
Description: Navarro County deputies rescued 40 donkeys and already had another 24 donkeys in need of a home.  The animals needed new homes because their previous owners could no longer afford hay since drought caused hay prices to increase dramatically.  About the donkey abandonments, the sheriff stated, “It's costing taxpayers a lot of money. This is a real problem."  Great Falls Tribune (Mont.), Nov. 7, 2011
Places: Navarro County, TX

Title: Horse rescue group in Argyle, Texas overwhelmed with animals
Description: Equine rescue groups in Texas were overwhelmed with abandoned and surrendered horses since many owners were unable to feed and care for their animals with the high price of hay.  A man with a horse rescue group in Argyle said that he has received 14 horses in the past two weeks and noted that law enforcement agencies, too, were coming across more animals than they could care for.  Great Falls Tribune (Mont.), Nov. 7, 2011
Places: Denton County, TX

Title: Rates rose at a boarding and riding stable in Mansfield, Texas
Description: The owner of a boarding and riding stable in Mansfield was forced to raise her boarding fees by $50 since the cost of hay has doubled.  She lost three customers over the increased boarding cost, but she has spent $20,000 on hay from Nebraska and Arkansas in the past two months, leaving her little choice but to raise rates.  To reduce her own expenses, she put 15 of her 30 horses up for sale.  Her mother has loaned her money to get her through this period of high hay prices.  Other horse owners were struggling too and tried to surrender their horses to her.  Great Falls Tribune (Mont.), Nov. 7, 2011
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Society & Public Health
Places: Tarrant County, TX

Title: Many abandoned horses in the vicinity of Fort Worth, Texas
Description: The Humane Society of North Texas in Fort Worth had 40 horses in their care and was receiving from 20 to 60 horses monthly since hay prices have skyrocketed.   A horse owner from Rendon had to give four show horses to the Humane Society because she could no longer afford to feed them.  The Humane Society gave her some hay to help feed the horses, but left the animals with their owner.  Equine rescue groups in Texas were overwhelmed with abandoned and surrendered horses since many owners were unable to feed and care for their animals with the high price of hay.  Great Falls Tribune (Mont.), Nov. 7, 2011
Places: Tarrant County, TX

Title: Donkey abandonments doubled in Johnson County, Texas
Description: The sheriff’s captain in Johnson County stated that they have 24 donkeys that were abandoned.  The number of abandoned donkeys was twice the number at this time last year because drought caused hay prices to climb dramatically.  Great Falls Tribune (Mont.), Nov. 7, 2011
Places: Johnson County, TX

Title: Low lake near Martins Mill, Texas revealed submerged vehicle, missing person
Description: Drought lowered the water level of a private lake near Martins Mill to reveal the top of a car which contained the body of a woman missing since July 2008.  Foul play was not suspected in the woman’s disappearance.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 8, 2011
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Van Zandt County, TX

Title: Peanut yield below average in Rolling Plains of Texas
Description: The peanut yield in the Rolling Plains was below average after a dry year.  Ranchers continued to cull cattle to manageable levels for the winter or opted to move cattle to leased pasture in other states.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Nov. 5, 2011

Title: More saltwater species found in Texas bays and estuaries
Description: Fishermen in Texas’ bays and estuaries were seeing more species that normally are found in the open sea as the salinities of the bays and estuaries rise, due to drought.  Some of the species recently seen include Spanish Mackerel, cow nose stingrays and lookdowns.  A fisherman at Sabine Lake even caught a blowfish.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Nov. 5, 2011

Title: Some Texas livestock producers were looking into the protein content of whole cotton plants
Description: Some Texas livestock producers were looking into the protein content of whole cotton plants since hay was so pricey and drought had reduced hay supplies.  An AgriLife Research nutritionist found that fresh whole cotton plants contained 13.3 percent crude protein and 62.4 percent total digestible nutrients and concluded that the plants could be a good source of supplemental energy.  A forage specialist also stressed that a sample of the cotton plant should be analyzed for nutritional value before being fed to livestock.  Bryan College Station Eagle (Texas), Nov. 3, 2011
Places: Brazos County, TX

Title: Thieves target different items in southeastern Texas during drought
Description: Thieves are targeting different items during the drought than they did prior to the drought.  Rather than steal cattle, which eat expensive hay or feed, thieves were taking more tractors, trailers, batteries, aluminum, copper, electrical pumps and diesel fuel.  A rancher near Stowell in southeastern Texas was robbed of 100 gallons of diesel fuel and some batteries for a loss of approximately $1,000.  Four riding saddles worth about $4,000 were stolen from a rancher in Richmond and were pawned.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Nov. 1, 2011
Places: Chambers County, TX, Stowell, TX, Fort Bend County, TX, Richmond, TX

Title: Open burning ban in El Paso County, Texas
Description: The Commissioners Count in El Paso implemented a 90-day ban on open burning in the unincorporated parts of the county because the persistent drought was forecast to continue.  The most recent burn ban for the county expired on August 8.  El Paso Times (Texas), Nov. 1, 2011
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Skier and snowboarder visits down in California
Description: The snow droughts of recent years have cut winter visitation to California ski resorts by about 30 percent during the last four years.  Resorts averaged about 7.4 million visitors during the 2010-2011 winter ski season, but have seen about 5.2 to 5.3 million visitors in subsequent years.Los Angeles Times, March 24, 2015Drought and below-normal snowpack kept skier and snowboarder visits down by 25 percent in the winter of 2013-14, compared to the 2012-13 winter. Snowpack in 2014 reached about 52 inches, the second lowest in 90 years, in California ski country near Lake Tahoe.New York Times, Nov. 23, 2014

Title: Denton County, Texas, farmer forced to sell cows
Description: We are in third year of drought. Our creek was completely dry over the winter 2012/2013 and that has never happened in the 21 years we have lived here. We had to sell a few more cows this spring so we are now down to three cows two calves and one steer that is going to be beef soon. No relief in sight.  More 100 degree weather predicted this week.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Sanger 1.8 WSW on 8/25/2013

Title: Planted winter acreage down in Winter Garden area of South Texas
Description: The amount of vegetables planted in Winter Garden, an area including Dimmit, Frio, La Salle and Zavala counties, fell by 22 percent this fall, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  The problem lay with limits on water use from Medina Lake so that growers must decide when to use their water most efficiently and lucratively.  Spring crops, such as corn and cotton, bring in more money than winter vegetables, leading some growers to wait until spring to plant.  Planted acreage in the Winter Garden area amounted to nearly 19,500 acres, compared to more than 24,800 acres in 2010.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Oct. 31, 2011
Places: Dimmit County, TX, Frio County, TX, La Salle County, TX, Zavala County, TX

Title: Animal abandonment rate high in Ellis County, Texas
Description: The sheriff’s office in Ellis County has collected 68 horses, donkeys and other animals as the owners fail to care for them.  In 2007, there were only 12 abandoned animals in the county.  The New York Times, Oct. 31, 2011
Places: Ellis County, TX

Title: The cost of a pound of Gulf Coast oysters rose by 35 percent during the past month, due to red tide algae
Description: The presence of red tide algae upped the cost of a pound of Gulf Coast oysters by 35 percent during the past month, stated the president of a seafood company in San Antonio. On October 26, Texas Department of State Health Services banned commercial and recreational oyster, clam and mussel harvesting, due to the possible health threat to humans from consuming tainted shellfish.  Consequently, one Houston restaurant owner had to look as far as Apalachicola, Florida for Gulf oysters.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Oct. 26, 2011

Title: Shellfish harvesting banned along Texas Gulf Coast
Description: Commercial and recreational oyster, clam and mussels harvesting were banned along the Gulf Coast by the Texas Department of State Health Services because the shellfish were tainted by an immense algae bloom that produced toxins that can be harmful to humans.  Drought and heat made the annual algae bloom worse than usual because the algae appreciate the warm, salty water.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Oct. 26, 2011.  Heavy rain reduced the salinity in most bays along the Texas coast, improving water quality, and allowing the ban on oyster harvesting to end.  The oyster harvest resumed in San Antonio Bay on January 27 and harvesting began in other coastal bays on February 16.  Matagorda Bay remained closed due to red tide.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), March 17, 2012

Title: Few boat ramps open on the Toledo Bend Reservoir on the Texas/Louisiana border
Description: Fewer visitors were coming to park sites along the Sabine River, lowering revenue for the Sabine River Authority.  Few boat ramps were still useable as the water level declined.  The boat ramps at Oak Ridge Park in south DeSoto Parish, Cypress Bend Resort Park in Sabine Parish and six additional private ramps remained open, but all other public and private boat launches were closed.  On October 22, Toledo Bend Reservoir reached a record low at just under 160 feet, covered 127,309 acres and contained roughly 2.6 million acre-feet.  When full, the reservoir spans more than 182,000 acres and contains 4.4 million acre-feet. Alexandria Town Talk (La.), Oct. 25, 2011
Categories: Business & Industry, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: De Soto Parish, LA, Sabine Parish, LA, Newton County, TX, Sabine County, TX, Shelby County, TX

Title: Bison leaving park in Houston, Texas for a ranch on the Oklahoma border
Description: The herd of 11 bison in Deussen Park in Houston was being moved to a 6,400 acre ranch in Hardeman County near the Oklahoma border since drought and other factors have made the park less hospitable for the animals.  Some of the grass and trees in their pen died from the lack of rain, leading park officials to purchase hay from Florida for the bison.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Oct. 25, 2011
Places: Hardeman County, TX, Houston, TX

Title: Some businesses suffer loss of revenue or close around Toledo Bend Reservoir on the Texas/Louisiana border
Description: The low level of Toledo Bend forced some businesses to close their doors, according to the Sabine Tourism Commission executive director.  Two marina motels in Texas and a bass marina in Louisiana have closed or were for sale.  Revenue declined by 45.5 percent for retail businesses in Texas and Louisiana around Toledo Bend, according to a survey conducted by the Sabine Chamber of Commerce office.  The Cypress Bend Conference Center and Resort reported lower interest and occupancy than in the past.  On October 22, Toledo Bend Reservoir reached a record low at just under 160 feet, covered 127,309 acres and contained roughly 2.6 million acre-feet.  When full, the reservoir spans more than 182,000 acres and contains 4.4 million acre-feet. Alexandria Town Talk (La.), Oct. 25, 2011
Places: De Soto Parish, LA, Sabine Parish, LA, Newton County, TX, Sabine County, TX, Shelby County, TX

Title: Business owners around Toledo Bend on the Texas/Louisiana border want stumps removed from depleted reservoir
Description: Dozens of business owners have asked the Sabine River Authority to revive a stump-cutting project to clear Toledo Bend of the obstacles because the unsightly stumps and low water levels were reducing the number of visitors to the lake.  On October 22, Toledo Bend Reservoir reached a record low at just under 160 feet, covered 127,309 acres and contained roughly 2.6 million acre-feet.  When full, the reservoir spans more than 182,000 acres and contains 4.4 million acre-feet. Alexandria Town Talk (La.), Oct. 25, 2011

Title: Worthless hay turning up in Titus County, Texas
Description: Ranchers in Titus County were purchasing hay that turned out to be worthless for feeding animals, according to an AgriLife Extension agent.  Stock ponds were very low.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Oct. 25, 2011
Places: Titus County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Taylor County, Texas
Description: Dry conditions and increasing fire danger led Taylor County Commissioners to impose a burn ban for the next three months unless the fire danger abates.  Local fire departments were in favor of the ban.  The last burn ban ended on October 9 after substantial rain eased the fire danger.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Oct. 25, 2011
Places: Taylor County, TX

Title: Bastrop County, Texas, less forage creates high expenses for cows
Description: Less forage which affects profit/loss and stocking rate.  Creates huge work load moving irrigation pipes and rotating cattle plus very expensive providing supplemental cattle food and hay.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Circle D-KC Estates 3.5 ESE on 6/10/2014
Places: Bastrop County, TX

Title: Cotton crop devastated in West Texas, Eastern New Mexico
Description: The cotton harvest in 2011 yielded half the amount of cotton that was produced last year, according to a cotton grower and a co-op general manager in Farwell, Texas.  The cotton farmer stated that he harvested two and a half bales per acre on his 200-acre farm in 2010, but only eked out one bale per acre this year.  Another way to look at it is to consider that about 60,000 acres were planted to cotton and harvested in 2010, but this year, maybe 20,000 acres were harvested.  It wasn’t possible to irrigate all of the cotton enough, forcing farmers to concentrate their irrigation efforts on a portion of their fields.  The co-op manager stated that drought devastated the cotton in Quay County, New Mexico.  Clovis Journal (N.M.), Oct. 21, 2011
Places: Curry County, NM, DeBaca County, NM, Quay County, NM, Roosevelt County, NM, Bailey County, TX, Castro County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Parmer County, TX

The 17 closed ramps were Mill Creek Spur 165 near Brookeland, Black Forest Ramp Black Forest Subdivision, Lakewood Ramp off FM 705, Driver's Subdivision Ramp off FM 226, Ayish Ramp FM 83 at Ayish Bayou Highway  59 Ramp, Cassells-Boykin Park at end of FM 3123, Harvey Creek Ramp end of FM 2390, Etoile East side of Lake at Texas 103, Townsend Park Ramp End of CR 2923, Marion Ferry end of FM 1669, Ralph MacAlister Texas 103 near FM 1274, Monterey end of FM 3124, Sandy Creek Park Forest Service Road 3333, Shirley Creek Marina end of FM 226, Ewing Park TX 103 at Angelina River, the two west lanes of the new ramp at Cassells-Boykin Park end of FM 3123 and the north ramps at Rayburn Park.  Boaters were urged to be cautious about using some of the remaining boat ramps.  The lake level was 164.40 feet above mean sea level.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Oct. 19, 2011

Title: Drought reduced the size of the pecan crop in central Texas
Description: Drought reduced the size of the pecan crop in central Texas, according to the owner of a pecan processing company.  He stated that the quality was fine, but the size of the nuts was smaller than usual.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Oct. 18, 2011

Title: Efforts underway to construct emergency water pipeline and raw water production facility for Colorado River Municipal Water District in West Texas
Description: Construction of a pipeline to carry water from Ward County to a raw water production facility in Big Spring was in the works to provide water for the Colorado River Municipal Water District.  The level of Lake Thomas fell too low to provide water in 2008 and Lake Spence became depleted in July, leaving Lake O.H. Ivie as the only remaining lake supplying the district.  It is anticipated that Lake O.H. Ivie will be effectively empty in December 2012.  Wells in Ward County and the raw water production facility were intended to be used only in emergency situations, which is where the CRMWD finds itself.  Construction began on the raw water production facility in July at a cost of $13 million, while the pipeline was expected to cost $140 million.  Odessa American (Texas), Oct. 18, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Robert Lee, TX, Millersview, TX, Odessa, TX, Big Spring, TX, Stanton, TX, Doole, TX, Midland, TX, Snyder, TX, Abilene, TX, San Angelo, TX, Ward County, TX, Grandfalls, TX, Pyote, TX

Title: Donkey rescue group in Miles, Texas at capacity
Description: The Peaceful Valley Donkey Rescue in Miles reached their maximum capacity of 450 animals and refused to take any more since so many horses and donkey have been abandoned lately.  They have already received 600 animals in 2011 and have a waiting list of 300 more in need of shelter.  The founder of the rescue group stated, “I think it will be a crisis this winter. I don't think it will just be abandonment. I can see hundreds of donkeys being shot by their owners this winter."  The problem stemmed from owners being unable to feed their animals since hay prices were so high.  Great Falls Tribune (Mont.), Nov. 7, 2011
Places: Runnels County, TX

Title: Enormous dust storm rolled across West Texas
Description: Farmers in West Texas were unable to implement soil conservation measures that they would normally practice to hold the soil in place, such as leaving plants in the field after harvest or planting cover crops, because drought prevented some farmers from planting.  It was believed that this was partly to blame for the enormous dust storm that rolled across West Texas on October 17.  A geology professor with the University of Texas at El Paso thinks that Texas’ drought may make dust storms more prevalent.  A spokesman for a regional group of cotton producers agreed that the absence of ground cover may have exacerbated the dust storm.  El Paso Times (Texas), Oct. 22, 2011

Title: Texas panhandle counties have burn bans in effect; livestock producers are feeding hay to cattle
Description: As of October 14th, all Texas panhandle counties were supporting a countywide outdoor burn ban.According to the Oct. 12 Texas crop weather report issued by Texas A&M, producers were continuing to plant winter wheat. In some instances, theywere irrigating the wheat in an attempt to speed up growth to provide grazing for cattle. Rangeland and pastures remained in very poor condition. Livestock producers continued feeding cattle and were bringing in more hay from out of the region for the winter months.Streamflows along the Canadian River are much below normal. Lake Meredith continues to set record low lake levels every day. On October 12th, the Canadian River Municipal water authority voted to stop using Lake Meredith as a source of drinking water after 40 years. The 11 member cities of the authority must now rely on wells for their water.

Title: Canadian River Municipal Water Authority in Texas Panhandle opted to stop using depleted Lake Meredith
Description: The Canadian River Municipal Water Authority was pumping from wells to conserve the water remaining in Lake Meredith during intense drought.  Water was temporarily drawn from the lake when water demand was higher.  After ending water withdrawals from the lake in 2011, pumping was resumed in 2014, but the lake still has not fully recovered from drought.Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), Jan. 14, 2015The Canadian River Municipal Water Authority decided on October 12 to stop using Lake Meredith as a water source because the water level of the lake has reached an historic low at 31 feet, according to the general manager.  This decision leaves the Ogallala Aquifer as the remaining water source.  Water from the Ogallala Aquifer was pumped into wells in Roberts County, which was then pumped to customers of the CRMWA.  The pipeline from Roberts County is not large enough to transport as much water as is needed during the summer months, which will likely lead to water restrictions during the summer.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Oct. 13, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Lamesa, TX, Pampa, TX, Plainview, TX, Levelland, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Borger, TX, Lubbock, TX, Slaton, TX, O'Donnell, TX, Tahoka, TX, Moore County, TX, Potter County, TX, Amarillo, TX, Brownfield, TX

Title: Low prices for cattle at auction in Lampasas, Texas
Description: Livestock at an auction in Lampasas sold for $1 per pound, compared to $1.70 last year as drought forced ranchers to part with their cattle for lack of affordable feed.  Some of the cattle had prickly pear cactus spines sticking from their cheeks and had legs coated with pale caliche mud, indicating that they were foraging in unusual places as they strove to find a little something to eat.  One rancher stated, “We can't get hay - we're feeding them stuff you wouldn't feed a goat," as hay cost twice what it used to and creek beds have gone dry.   The Macon Telegraph (Ga.), Oct. 11, 2011
Places: Lampasas County, TX

Title: Water table too low for adequate irrigation near Wichita Falls, Texas
Description: A well near Wichita Falls could not produce enough water to irrigate pecan trees with 2 inches of water every eight days and instead took 16 days to yield 2 inches of water.  The crop suffered.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Oct. 10, 2011
Places: Wichita County, TX

Title: Pecan crop suffered in Wichita Falls, Texas
Description: Some unirrigated pecan trees near Wichita Falls died from the lack of rain.  Other unirrigated trees managed to survive, but produced pecans the size of grapes. In comparison, the irrigated trees produced nuts about two inches in length.  Adequately watered trees yield pecans that are about 60 percent nut meat and 40 percent shell, but the dryland trees made pecans that were 40 percent nut meat and 60 percent shell.  This pecan farmer expects his total yield to be down by a third due to smaller nut size.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Oct. 10, 2011
Places: Wichita County, TX

Title: Drought affects garden in Travis County, Texas
Description: May have lost several trees and definitely have lost several landscape plants. Am a gardener, and try to grow food for personal supply and plants for pleasure. The garden failed to produce enough to sustain myself, much less store this year. Nothing in the garden or landscape reached the normal plant height this year, and most plants that would have been 7-10 feet tall either died or achieved a height of less than 2 feet. However, insect infestation and plant disease (other than drought impacts) were almost completely absent.
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Failed pumpkin crop in Texas Panhandle forced campus ministry in Wichita Falls, Texas to seek alternate fundraising activity
Description: A campus ministry in Wichita Falls must find another fundraising activity since the annual pumpkin sale cannot be held since there were so few pumpkins produced in the Texas Panhandle.  Last year, the group raised about $10,000 through its pumpkin sale.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Oct. 8, 2011

Title: Plans changed for proposed coal-fired power plant near Bay City, Texas
Description: Officials for a proposed coal-fired power plant near Bay City altered their plans for the cooling system and opted instead to construct a dry cooling system rather than a wet cooling system to reduce water use.  The wet cooling system that was originally intended for the power plant would require 8 trillion gallons annually, whereas the dry system would require just 978 million gallons of water each year.  Area farmers and ranchers vehemently opposed the power plant and its move to purchase water rights because drought has depleted water supplies to the extent that there may not be enough for all agricultural activities in 2012.  Drawbacks to using the dry cooling system are that it is more expensive than the wet system and would not allow the power plant to achieve its potential power generating capacity of 1,200 megawatts during the hottest summer months.  The plant will need 3,000 acre-feet of water yearly.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Oct. 6, 2011
Categories: Business & Industry, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Matagorda County, TX

Title: Insurance claims for $250 million in property damage after wildfire in Bastrop County, Texas
Description: Residents and business owners in Bastrop County filed 1,500 insurance claims for estimated property losses of $250 million in the wildfires that began on September 4, according to the Insurance Council of Texas.  Drought and high winds contributed to the wildfire that ravaged Bastrop County, burning more than 50 square miles, consuming at least 1,500 homes and killing two people.  Austin American Statesman (Texas), Oct. 5, 2011
Places: Bastrop County, TX

Description: Drought conditions and heat in West Texas reduced the size of pumpkins grown there.  The weight of the harvest was anticipated to be 40 to 50 percent smaller than usual, according to state agricultural officials.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Oct. 4, 2011
