Title: Brazos County, Texas fire departments prepare for busy fire season
Description: Drought contributed to increased fire activity in Brazos County, which is a concern for fire chiefs who do not have sufficient personnel and equipment to meet the challenge.  Drought conditions were not expected to improve soon and were anticipated to lead to a bad fire season.  To prepare for wildfire outbreaks, the fire departments in Brazos County were aiming to create a Wildland Strike Team with better communication between fire departments and increased mutual-aid response when wildfires occur.  Bryan-College station Eagle (Texas), July 3, 2011
Places: Brazos County, TX

Title: Sale and use of fireworks prohibited in Taylor County, Texas
Description: Fireworks sales and the use of fireworks were prohibited in Taylor County because the drought makes it too dangerous to risk starting a fire.  In addition, all violators of the law in rural parts of the county will be ticketed.  City ordinances forbid the possession or use of fireworks in Abilene.  The county already had a burn ban in effect.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), July 2, 2011
Places: Taylor County, TX

Title: Water users asked to voluntarily limit water use in Austin County, Texas
Description: Ranchers ponds have dried up; watering cattle have died drinking too much water; purchase of hay has begun; pastures and lawns are brown; local businesses are selling more processed cattle food; many ranchers are cutting their cattle herds; energy customers were asked beginning yesterday to limit energy use between 3-5 because of overloaded system; water users have been asked to voluntarily limit use of water especially for lawns and flowers; heat advisories began today for heat indexes above 105; white-tailed deer have been reported drinking from swimming pools; outdoor burn ban has been in effect for most of the year.
Categories: Agriculture, Energy, Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Austin County, TX

Title: Fireworks canceled in Williamson County, Texas
Description: Two Fourth of July fireworks displays were canceled at Dell Diamond, due to the drought and the burn ban. Austin American-Statesman (Texas), June 7, 2012
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: Drought, water restrictions keep nursery sales down in Lavaca County, Texas
Description: I run a small plant nursery in a rural area. While I seem to have enough water from my well to keep things watered, many of my customers are on water restriction, so my sales are down. The yard looks very sad with drooping vines on the fences, since I only use water for the nursery, the landscape, other than our fig tree, has to fend for itself. Our well is old and quite shallow- only about 80 ft. deep and has to also serve the home.
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Lavaca County, TX

Title: Bee keeper in south central Texas sustained bees with sugar water and pollen supplement
Description: A bee keeper with 130 hives at various locations in south central Texas provided sugar water and a pollen supplement because drought depleted most natural sources of nutrition in the region.  Despite his efforts to nourish the bees, roughly 30 percent of the colonies died.  Austin American Statesman (Texas), March 23, 2012
Places: Guadalupe County, TX, Seguin, TX, Travis County, TX, Sunset Valley, TX

Title: Delayed start to fireworks sales in Bastrop, Hays, Travis and Williamson counties in Texas
Description: Fireworks vendors in Travis, Williamson, Hays and Bastrop counties chose to begin fireworks sales on July 1 rather than on June 24 as state law permits.  The delayed start to the firework sales season reduces the length of time that fires may inadvertently started by fireworks.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), June 9, 2011
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Hays County, TX, Travis County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Edwards County, Texas, rancher facing losses
Description: Rain total at our ranch since Oct 1, 2010 is 2.32 inches. We are in the process of selling off our livestock as are many ranchers in our area. Drought is having a drastic effect on wildlife with the hottest months of the year coming up, many will not survive. Our water wells are all holding up OK, but have heard of several that are going dry & water table is falling off significantly. Monetary losses are difficult to determine, but are substantial. PRAY FOR RAIN!!!!CoCoRaHS Report from Rocksprings 8.5 WSW on 6/24/2011
Places: Ector County, TX

Title: Producers purchasing hay for horses in Denton County, Texas
Description: No precipitation in the last 30 days, combined with less than half of normal precipitation for the calendar year. Normally, we would not be feeding hay to our horses until the fall, when the grass stops growing. This year, we have had to purchase and feed hay that is being brought in to Texas from states to the west and north, which is very expensive. Horse hay prices have more than doubled in the last 2 months in N. TX.
Places: Denton County, TX

Title: Trees stressed, ponds drying up in Jack County, Texas
Description: It has been 49 days without rain - one day less than .01 hundredth was noticed, and more than 41 straight days with temperatures between 102 and 113. Today, I counted two Live Oaks, three Plums, and five Redbuds have all either dropped their leaves - or all their leaves are dead on the tree. This means severe shock from heat and lack of rainfall. All grasses are dead, dust devils roam every day over the plowed wheat fields, and all my neighbors have sold the majority of their cattle. My ponds have lost eleven to twelve feet of depth. Perhaps now would be a good time to hire a dozer, to dig out and enlarge my ponds to hold more water and raise the Conservation Depth Level that keeps the pond water from reaching 90+ degrees when oxygen depletion begins and aquatic life starts to fail. Whenever it rains again - my property drains rainfall from over 2000 acres - so if it rains 3.5 inches in one go - the ground saturates, and the water overflows two lakes north of me, and about a dozen other ponds that each overflows into another - until all that water meets from three directions and empties into my property into both of my ponds, and on into the Keechi Creek - that is a tributary of the Brazos River –meeting it 17 miles downstream - just below the Possum Kingdom Lake Dam. So - that is the only upside I can see from this drought - increase depth and area of my 3/4's dried ponds, and pray for better days of lower temperatures and rainfall.
Places: Jack County, TX

Title: Wichita County, Texas, bans fireworks, and municipal display is postponed
Description: Wichita County banned fireworks in 2011, and a few hours later, the city of Wichita Falls banned its planned municipal display. The city event is rescheduled for September. In an accompanying disaster declaration, the county said that drought created the possibility of large, fast-moving wildfire.Wichita Falls Times Record News, June 23, 2011
Places: Wichita County, TX

Title: El Paso, Texas, offers fireworks amnesty
Description: El Paso County authorities offered residents a week-long period of fireworks amnesty in which they could turn in fireworks. This comes after the county banned the sale, use and possession of fireworks. El Paso Times, June 23, 2011
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Rain helped contain fire in Grimes County, Texas
Description: Rain helped contain the Grimes County fire that had burned almost 5,300 acres and more than 70 homes and other buildings. A fire in Trinity and Polk counties that had burned more than 20,222 acres and two homes was 80 percent contained. The Texas Forest Service was battling 17 large fires that had consumed more than 145,000 acres. Austin-American Statesman, June 23, 2011
Places: Grimes County, TX, Polk County, TX, Trinity County, TX

Title: Rain helps end wildfire in Grimes County, Texas
Description: The Dyer Mill Fire in Grimes County had burned about 5,280 acres in and around Plantersville, Stoneham and Todd Mission, a lower estimate than the 6,100 provided earlier, because of better mapping technology. The fire was about 75 percent contained after the rain. The fire -- which most hurt the Millstone subdivision but also affected Pine Brook and Shadow Woods -- sparked Sunday at a barbecue on private property. It burned 30 homes, three businesses, and up to 35 more structures. Residents were being allowed back into their homes after being evacuated for a few days. More hot, dry weather was forecast.Bryan-College Station, Texas, Eagle, June 23, 2011
Places: Grimes County, TX

Title: Southeast Texas faces wildfire
Description: Wildfire in Grimes County, Texas had burned almost 5,300 acres and more than 70 homes and other buildings. Fire in Trinity and Polk counties had burned more than 20,222 acres and two homes. The Texas Forest Service was battling 17 large fires across 145,000 acres. A total of about 2,000 residents had been evacuated.  Austin-American Statesman, June 23, 2011
Places: Texas, Grimes County, TX, Houston, TX, Jasper County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Polk County, TX, Potter County, TX, Trinity County, TX, Walker County, TX, Waller County, TX

Title: Shifting soils necessitate frequent water pipe repairs in Guadalupe County, Texas
Description: The crack in the gumbo soil is now 42" deep. Was only 33" deep on 1 June. Have seen signs of 3 major repairs of water conduits within 1/2 mile of our place in the past week, due primarily to shifting soil. Our rural water supply system had a capital replacement project a few years ago, else there would be many more breaks now. In those days, the water pressure would go down to zero, everyone would call around to see if their water was also affected, we'd drive around to see where the break was, call it in, and wait for the water supplier to make the repair. Sometimes the water would be off for a couple hours. The capital replacement system has reduced the frequency of these incidents.CoCoRaHS Report from Marion 2.2 SSW on 6/15/2011
Places: Guadalupe County, TX

Title: Salt water barrier navigation lock closed to protect Houston, Texas water supply
Description: The salt water barrier navigation lock of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Galveston District’s Wallisville Lake Project was closed to prevent salt water from nearing the water intakes for Houston and Lake Anahuac.  Drought reduced the flow of the Trinity River to the extent that salt water was encroaching further upstream than normal.  The lock is opened hourly between 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. each day to permit boats to pass.  Digital Video and Imagery Distribution System (GA), June 15, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Chambers County, TX

Title: Workers put out small fire at Port Arthur Total refinery
Description: Drought appears to have been a contributing factor to a small grass fire at the Total Petrochemicals refinery in Port Arthur.Beaumont, Texas, Enterprise, June 14, 2011
Places: Jefferson County, TX

Title: Amarillo and county officials offer fireworks amnesty
Description: The city of Amarillo and Potter and Randall counties announced a fireworks amnesty program, offering to pick up and dispose of illegal fireworks. The announcement came a day after someone started a fire by launching fireworks. Fireworks are banned due to drought and heat.
Places: Amarillo, TX, Randall County, TX

Title: Trees dying in Harris County, Texas
Description: I copied this from the message board on the site I help administrate on.  It fits for most of our area. I am noticing the same in W. Houston. "Hey everyone - the situation is getting extremely dire for us. he Trees up here north of town are in a desperate situation. There are whole stands of pines now that have turned brown and are dying off. I've also seen a large number of oaks, especially white oaks, that are also turning completely brown. At the front of my neighborhood there is a tree buffer between some houses and the main road. The entire buffer (mostly pines with a few oaks) has now turned brown. I'm afraid the whole section will need to be chopped down.Un-irrigated shrubs are toast too."Of course the continuing triple digit temps aren't helping at all either. Many outlying communities already have water restrictions and I expect more and more to be added.CoCoRaHS Report from Spring Valley 2.7 NW on 6/14/2011
Places: Harris County, TX

Title: Williamson County, Texas, plans to ban sale of fireworks
Description: Fireworks will not be for sale during the Fourth of July in Williamson County because of the drought. Williamson County Judge Dan Gattis issued a disaster declaration on June 14, 2011, banning the sale of fireworks. The declaration would be in effect for 60 hours, and then it can be sent to Gov. Rick Perry, who can extend it up to 30 days.  Under state law, it is legal through July 4 to sell fireworks in counties but not within city limits. Austin-American Statesman, June 14, 2011
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: Texas Gov. Perry backed Travis County's fireworks ban until July 5
Description: Governor Rick Perry will consider Travis County’s order declaring a local state of disaster and banning the sale and use of any fireworks. Perry has indicated that he would grant an extension of the order until July 5, according to county staff.Austin-American Statesman, June 14, 2011
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Agriculture losses climb to $150 million in Rolling Plains of Texas
Description: The Rolling Plains region lost an estimated $150 million due to drought, according to a Texas Extension Agriculture economist.  Because agriculture losses translate to less spending in the local economy, the economist stated that the loss for the region was $500 million.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (TX), June 13, 2011
Places: Archer County, TX, Baylor County, TX, Childress County, TX, Clay County, TX, Cottle County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Foard County, TX, Hardeman County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Jack County, TX, Kent County, TX, King County, TX, Knox County, TX, Montague County, TX, Motley County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Parker County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Stonewall County, TX, Throckmorton County, TX, Wichita County, TX, Wilbarger County, TX, Wise County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Water companies in South Texas urging residents to reduce water use
Description: Water companies in South Texas were urging residents to reduce water use as supplies become depleted.  The need to conserve water presents a challenge for companies that drill for oil and gas using a process called hydraulic fracturing, which, in the Barnett Shale region, can require as much as 13 million gallons of water per well.  Washington Post (D.C.), June 13, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Drought reduced wheat yields in Wilbarger County, Texas despite irrigation
Description: Irrigated wheat yields were down, due to drought, stated the Wilbarger County agriculture agent.  He noted that farmers cut off the wheat heads for cattle feed and left the rest to hold the soil in place.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (TX), June 13, 2011
Places: Wilbarger County, TX

Title: Cotton producers in the Rolling Plains of Texas struggled to irrigate enough to be able to plant
Description: Cotton producers on the Rolling Plains of Texas struggled to irrigate enough to be able to plant.  Some cotton growers used light tillage called “scratching” to break the hard surface of the soil to permit the cotton plants to emerge more easily.  Other cotton growers had to replant their fields.  Blowing sand and soil erosion were still problems even in areas that had received rainfall recently.  Stock tanks were going dry, leaving little for livestock.  Ranchers continued to sell cattle.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (TX), June 11, 2011

Title: Drought, heat and winds slowed forage growth in North Texas
Description: Drought, heat and winds slowed forage growth in North Texas.  Early season hay harvests were a little below normal.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (TX), June 11, 2011

Description: Pastures in the Coastal Bend region were suffering from the heat and drought, forcing farmers to offer more supplemental feed for the livestock.  Sorghum matured more quickly than usual.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (TX), June 11, 2011

Title: Stocker cattle producers in Falls County, Texas transferred cattle to feedlots
Description: Stocker cattle producers in Falls County have transferred cattle to feedlots since pastures were very dry and hay production was much lower than usual, according to the AgriLife Extension agent for the county.  Corn, milo and cotton also exhibited symptoms of severe drought stress.  Odessa American (Texas), June 9, 2011
Places: Falls County, TX

Title: Fireworks outlawed in Potter and Randall counties in Texas
Description: Fireworks were outlawed in Potter and Randall counties as the drought made the use of fireworks too dangerous.  Violators of the fireworks ban in these counties will be arrested, stated the mayor of Amarillo.  Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), June 9, 2011

Places: Wood County, TX

Description: Tom Green County commissioners banned the use of  fireworks due to the drought.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), June 8, 2011
Places: Tom Green County, TX

Title: Chambers County, Texas rancher spent $5,600 to provide water for his livestock
Description: A rancher near Winnie spent about $5,600 to have a well deepened, to purchase a pump and tank and to have a power pole installed.  He needed to provide an alternate water source for his longhorn cattle after the stock tank went dry.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), June 8, 2011
Places: Chambers County, TX

Title: Drought spurred record cattle sales at Brazos Valley Livestock Commission in Texas
Description: The general manager of the Brazos Valley Livestock Commission stated that record numbers of livestock were sold there in April and May as ranchers sold animals at good prices rather than feed them.  The highest livestock sales totals occurred in past five months as some ranchers chose to quit ranching.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), June 8, 2011

Title: Fireworks with sticks and fins banned in Orange County, Texas
Description: The Orange County Commissioners Court has banned the sale and use of fireworks with sticks and fins in the unincorporated portions of the county.  Extreme drought conditions have increased the fire danger within the county.

Title: Several Texas panhandle counties enacted disaster declarations, sought extensions from governor
Description: Authorities in Potter, Carson and Armstrong counties adopted 60-hour disaster declarations to prevent the sale and use of fireworks.  It was hoped that the governor of Texas would extend the declarations through the July 4 holiday to reduce the likelihood of fires inadvertently set by fireworks.  Parmer and Hall county officials also sought an extension of county disaster declarations, with Hall County receiving an extension.  Strong winds, heat and drought have increased the fire danger in the region.
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Carson County, TX, Hall County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Potter County, TX, Amarillo, TX

Title: Forage growth in the Rolling Plains region of Texas was delayed
Description: Forage growth in the Rolling Plains region was delayed 14 to 28 days in response to drought and the cool spring.  Farmers were waiting for rain before planting cotton, but insurance deadlines may force them to plant without the rain.  Wheat yields were much lower than normal, leading some farmers to forgo the harvest.  Rain was desperately needed to fill stock tanks and to allow pastures to grow.  Some livestock producers were shipping cattle out because there was no pasture for them.   Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), June 4, 2011
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality

Description: Andrews County Commissioners chose to prohibit the sale and use of fireworks in the county through July 5, due to drought and the fire danger.  Odessa American Online (Texas), June 10, 2011
Places: Andrews County, TX

Title: Severe heat and drought affecting life in Johnson County, Texas
Description: Outdoor activities are restricted to the two hours after sunrise when at all possible, due to the ongoing 100+ degree streak. Lawn is dying, as spot watering is concentrated on saving fruit trees, shade trees and flowering shrubs for wildlife food and shelter. Small area of herbs and flowering plants that is watered regularly is continually uprooted by toads seeking damp shelter in the daytime hours. Entire purple martin colony has deserted their (metal) bird condo and departed. No mosquitoes. Stock tank is almost dry. Rabbits are desperate for green vegetation and will venture into a fenced yard with dogs to forage. Dairy cows in adjoining pasture yearn for greener grazing, will step THROUGH strands of barbed wire fence despite barbs to graze in what was my garden. Any hand-raised cows lumber to the fence whenever they see me with a watering can. Supplemental feeding of beehives has been necessary due to few flowering plants. Last of beehives died this past week, as the bees are not able to raise brood in temps > 102F and could not cool the hives sufficiently to survive. No moisture and clear skies require an expedition-size ice chest and 20 lbs. ice for every trip to the grocery store for perishibles. Increased gas use to run auto A/C continually. No kayaking in past two months due to low water levels in area rivers and lakes. No bicycling at all.
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Johnson County, TX

Title: Peach harvest in Gillespie County, Texas down slightly
Description: The peach harvest in Gillespie County was down slightly, due to drought, but the peaches were sweeter and richer in flavor, according to the president of the Hill Country Fruit Council.   Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), June 3, 2011
Places: Gillespie County, TX

Title: Drought limited the insect population around San Antonio, Texas
Description: Drought has limited the insect population, sharply reducing the number of orb webs in the San Antonio area since 2011.  San Antonio Express-News (Texas), Sept. 4, 2013
Places: Bexar County, TX

Title: Drought affecting birds, insects, plants, trees in Johnson County, Texas
Description: Single coastal hay crop has already been harvested (some years we get three cuttings) to reduce wildfire risk. The barn swallows I monitor for Cornell's NestWatch program are struggling to raise a single hatchling in their second clutch as flying insects have dropped with lack of green foliage. !@#$ grasshoppers are ravenous and concentrated on the only green left... in my vegetable garden. Tomatoes not fruiting due to excess heat. Large, deep cracks in black clay soil make it difficult to spot water fruit trees as water pours into cracks for 15 minutes before ground around tree roots begins to absorb water. Dogs must be carefully monitored while outdoors and walked on grass (not sizzling sidewalks) before 8:30 AM and after 8:00 PM to avoid heat exhaustion issues. Black labs are walking solar panels and only let out otherwise for five minutes or less. Fortunately we insulated our house to the max, chose energy efficient windows and built deep porches for shade from the afternoon sun, but have not been able to grow any additional shade!CoCoRaHS Report from Godley 2.6 NW on 7/4/2011
Places: Johnson County, TX

Title: Business good for windmill manufacturer, servicer in Texas
Description: Business was great for a windmill manufacturer and a windmill servicing business during the summer since ranchers desperately needed water for their cattle.  Gainesville Sun (Fla.), Oct. 27, 2011
Places: Claude, TX, Tom Green County, TX

Title: Natural beef producer near Cameron, Texas altered cattle diet during drought
Description: A rancher who raises pasture-fed cattle near Cameron stated that the drought has forced them to market their beef as “pasture-fed” rather than “grass-fed,” which was the way they formerly described their beef.  Grass in the pastures wasn’t growing, spurring them to feed their cattle hay, baled corn stalks and dehydrated alfalfa hay cubes.  They buy municipal water and drilled a new well since the ponds went dry.  The sale price of the specialty beef rose by 25 percent around June 1 due to the changes they’ve made to adapt to drought, but they’re striving to keep prices as low as possible for their customers.  The pasture-fed beef can be purchased at Village Foods, Stover Brothers Cafe and the Brazos Valley Farmer’s Market in Bryan and from the rancher’s website.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), Aug. 25, 2011
Places: Milam County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Drought diminished the Attwater prairie chicken population in Texas
Description: Drought diminished the Attwater prairie chicken population in Texas.  In 2010, there were just 110 birds, but drought last year further whittled that number down to 46 birds.  The manager of the Attwater Prairie Chicken National Wildlife Refuge noted that in 2011, there were no berries, insects or flowers for the birds to eat and that the refuge was “like a moonscape.”  Roughly 175 captive-bred birds are released into the wild each year in an effort to rebuild the population, but the survival rate hovers around 16 percent.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Sept. 5, 2012
Places: Colorado County, TX, Galveston County, TX, Goliad County, TX

Title: Christmas tree crop lost in Navarro County, Texas
Description: Although I put start date of impact as 1 June 2011, the drought really started in March when my location received only 0.14 of the normal 3.54 March average rain. April was near normal, May 50% of normal, and June was 75% of normal. HOWEVER, the June total was in one storm and its effectiveness in saving my crops was minimal. Since that rain in June, I have had 0.09 inches of rain through today 4 Sep 2011. Old established trees are losing their leaves, grasshoppers have taken to cutting skin of this year's limbs on my fruit trees to drink sap - (they had already stripped the leaves and fruit). My commercial crop of XMAS trees planted in Jan 11 are dead; my XMAS trees from Jan10 planting are about 50% dead. My black walnuts planted in Feb11 are dead; my pomegranates planted in Jan10 are 75% dead. These plants were hand watered but the roots could not take up water fast enough to keep the leaves/needles from burning. We have had 69 days above 100 and 91 days above 95 since 1 May11.
Places: Navarro County, TX

Title: Wichita Falls, Texas relied on Lake Kemp to reduce demand on other lakes
Description: Wichita Falls drew 20 percent of its water from Lake Kemp during the hot, dry summer of 2011 to reduce demand on Lake Arrowhead and Lake Kickapoo.  A reverse osmosis filtering system treated the brackish water from Lake Kemp and the less salty waters of Lake Arrowhead and Lake Kickapoo to make it potable for Wichita Falls.  Nearly a year later, Lake Kemp was 19 feet below capacity on May 21, 2012, while lakes Arrowhead and Kickapoo were at 54.5 and 48.8 percent of capacity.  Since Lake Kemp was about one third full, Wichita Falls was not drawing as much water from it.  If lakes Arrowhead and Kickapoo fall to 50 percent of capacity combined, stage two of the water restrictions will take effect.  The salinity of Lake Kemp has risen and become only marginally useable for irrigation.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), May 22, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Wichita County, TX

Title: Trees dying in Harrison County, Texas
Description: We have 20 acres...about half in pasture, half in forest. Every day now, I can see more trees turning brown...some have been dead looking for several weeks, but more and more are showing signs of dying...most are oaks, but I have maple, dogwood, pine, tupelo and elm all looking past coming back. Only sweet gum have not shown any signs of lack of water. (I would not save a sweet gum if I had a chance.) I water the trees near my home...oak, maple and tupelo, but some are still turning fall colors, going dormant to survive. The heat has been oppressive for over 60 days in Longview...over 100 degrees, many well over 100 according to the TV reports. Our 2 small ponds have dropped about 6 feet...one is spring fed, but it has dropped also.
Places: Harrison County, TX

Title: Drought affecting hay production in Titus County, Texas
Description: I work on a ranch. The drought has affected our hay production and now there is no grass for grazing. Therefore, we are having to use cubes and our hay in August. We are buying hay from outside sources and having it trucked in. The expense will greatly impact our business. Cattle prices are also going down due to the flood of cows being sold.
Places: Titus County, TX

Title: Countywide burn ban lengthened, fireworks with sticks and fins banned in Wichita County, Texas
Description: Wichita County Commissioners lengthened a countywide burn ban in unincorporated parts of the county for the next 90 days since drought and strong winds had boosted wildfire activity statewide.  Area fire departments favored an extension of the burn ban.  Commissioners also banned fireworks with sticks and fins to reduce the likelihood of additional wildfires.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), June 1, 2011
Places: Wichita County, TX

Title: Animals severely challenged by drought in southeast Texas
Description: Whitetail fawns were seen walking during the mid-afternoon, which is peculiar behavior that the observer attributed to drought, poor ground cover and forage and the poor condition of the doe.  Forbs, other vegetation, ground cover and insects were lacking to provide a good start for turkey and quail young.  Many hen Rio Grande turkeys did not try to nest, due to the poor conditions.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), May 29, 2011
Places: Colorado County, TX, Fayette County, TX

Title: Strong winds, heat, drought and outdoor cooking blamed for series of wildfires in southeastern Texas
Description: Strong winds, heat, drought and outdoor cooking were blamed for a series of wildfires over Memorial Day weekend.  Two of the larger fires were burning in Newton County and Jasper County, where 500 acres and 80 acres burned, respectively.  The fire in Newton County consumed two homes, while the Jasper County fire endangered 17 homes and forced the evacuation of 11 homes.  The blaze also threatened two airplane hangars, fuel tanks, a race track and 15 other structures.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), May 29, 2011
Places: Jasper County, TX, Newton County, TX

Title: Missiles and rockets banned in Ector County, Texas

In the past 40 years of ranching, he had not sold livestock due to drought, but given the dire circumstances, he called a buyer and prepared to sell. Los Angeles Times (Calif.), May 22, 2011

Title: Dust storms more common in West Texas
Description: Dust storms have become more common in West Texas, removing topsoil to the detriment of farmers and ranchers and leading to an increase in the incidence of respiratory distress, asthma attacks and more severe allergies, according to the Texas climatologist’s office.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), May 22, 2011

Title: A Scurry County, Texas rancher prepared to sell his livestock as pasture and water supplies for the animals dwindled
Description: A 79-year-old rancher near Fluvanna contacted a buyer for his cattle, although in his 40 years of ranching, he had never been forced to sell any cattle due to drought.  His pasture was dry and grazed down, leading him to purchase supplemental feed for the livestock, which were terribly thin and boney.  The cattle wear mud on their legs from wading into drying ponds and occasionally need to be rescued from the mud.  The rancher acknowledged that the dire situation with his livestock was depressing.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), May 22, 2011

Title: Bradford Pear Tree and St. Augustine Grass Drying Out Near Cedar Park, TX
Description: Only two 1+ inch days of rain so far this year. The leaves on a 10-year old Bradford pear have withered and are now on the ground. The arborist says that we will likely lose the tree. The St. Augustine grass is already going dormant, despite twice-weekly watering. CoCoRaHS report from Cedar Park 1.7 S on 5/21/2011
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: Twenty-seven Texas counties eligible for emergency grazing for 90 days on Conservation Reserve Program land

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 5/16/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Stephens County continues to be very dry.  This past week the county received from .17 inches to spots up to 1.0 inch of rain.  No running water occurred.  80% of the county received less than .2 inch of rainfall.  The county is still in a severe drought and crops that have been planted are not coming up.  Some rangeland has begun to grow a small amount of grass but the majority is still not growing.  Producers are still feeding hay in parts of the county.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Stephens County, TX

Title: Farmers selling livestock due to lack of forage on Rolling Plains of Texas
Description: Some ranchers on the Rolling Plains opted to sell cattle because there was insufficient pasture for the cattle to graze.  Some dryland farmers attempted to prepare their fields for planting, but discovered that the soil was too hard for the plow to break the soil.  It was too dry for farmers to plant Sudan grass also.

Title: High pumping led to mechanical failure in multiple wells in Carson County, Texas
Description: High pumping from Amarillo’s well fields in Carson County led to multiple mechanical failures, according to the director of utilities.  Fewer wells in operation resulted in a water supply problem and low water pressure, which prompted authorities to begin drawing from Lake Meredith again, despite the record low level of the lake.  Amarillo Globe News (Texas), June 5, 2011

Title: Rancher in Brazos and Burleson counties in Texas sold 70 cattle, due to absence of pasture and high cost of feeding
Description: A farmer sold 70 of the 300 cattle from a family ranch in Brazos and Burleson counties because there was no pasture and feeding the livestock was too expensive. Title: Horse owner feeding hay to horses in Kerr County, Texas

Title: Agriculture, Water Supply & Quality impact from Government submitted on 5/9/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Drought continues in Young County with high winds and over 100 degrees on 4/8/2011. Conditions are not improving with these weather patterns as the rains that are forecasted are not coming here in the county.  Supplemental feeding is increasing and the Spring rains have not happened as the norm. Grasses are in need of the moisture for ranges to continue the stocking rate that is needed to keep cattle herds.  With this week's weather predicted very hot, windy and dry, conditions will worsen.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Water Supply & Quality impact from Government submitted on 5/5/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Lake Colorado City went from 12.93 feet below full in December to 14.12 feet below last week.Lake Champion reservoir from 36.79 feet below full in December to 37.74 feet below last week.The City of Colorado City enacted emergency water conservation measures last year limiting the use of water which is from the city's well field east of Colorado City, and at this time production is being outpaced by usage as a result of decreased production from the field.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Mitchell County, TX

Title: Drought affecting water levels in Real County, Texas
Description: Drought continues, rivers running very low and in some cases drying up, area lake levels have significantly dropped, wide spread reporting of residential water wells drying up. Mesquite trees are starting to die.
Places: Real County, TX

Title: Increased wildlife sightings in residential areas near Marion, TX
Description: Wildlife are becoming desperate. Yesterday, two opossums came to a water trough in the front yard for water. Today, a raccoon did likewise. It's very unusual for such varmints to come this close to the house in broad daylight. The crack in the gumbo soil which measured 15" deep on 1 April is now 24" deep. (Report from CoCoRaHS Observer at Marion 2.2 SSW, submitted on 5/5/2011)
Places: Guadalupe County, TX

Title: Wells are drying up in Kendall County, Texas
Description: Area creeks have dried up. Major river (Guadalupe) stage is 1ft. and at 12cfs. South of here the river has dried up. Flows into large lake that the lake level is now dropping. Juniper is dying from lack of moisture. Many water wells are drying up as the water table falls. Watering landscape is not allowed. Heatwave is keeping people indoors and changing work hours for outdoor workers. No crops and selling animals. Wildlife dying off for lack of forage.CoCoRaHS Report from Boerne 8.5 NNW on 6/21/2011
Places: Kendall County, TX

Title: Visitation down at Possum Kingdom State Park in Texas after spring wildfire
Description: Roughly 1,300 acres of Possum Kingdom State Park burned in a wildfire in April 2011, causing $325,000 in damage to the park’s fencing, a rental cabin and some utility buildings, according to the park superintendent.  Park visitation levels remained at 50 percent or less in 2011, although visitors usually keep the park 85 to 90 percent full during the high season from May through August.  Only 300 acres of the park did not burn in the wildfire.  Abilene Reporter News (Texas), Jan. 28, 2012
Places: Palo Pinto County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Burnet County, Texas, low lake level, local resorts gone out of business
Description: We live at Lake Buchanan, Burnet County, Texas.  Lake level is down about 35 feet.  From our boat dock we cannot see the water.  I know of four resorts around the lake which have gone out of business. The land is dry, the green is gone except for deep rooted trees.  People here in rural Texas don't water their yards.  People are putting out feed and water for the wildlife.  We've had our land designated a wildlife habitat and put out 1200 to 1500 pounds of feed/seed a month for deer, rabbits, birds, foxes, raccoons, squirrels.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Burnet 8.4 WNW on 5/8/2014
Places: Burnet County, TX

Title: Dry wells and stock tanks cause livestock producers to haul water in Williamson County, Texas
Description: Our stock tank has turned into a dust bowl, the shallow well (30 feet) has been dry for the past three month, the deep well collapsed due to dry ground. We now have to haul water from another ranch which is on city water every other day (500 gallons) for us as well as for our cattle and horses. Wildlife traffic has tremendously increased around the house (visible tracks everywhere) due to water being in the cattle trough there. Trees are now showing definite signs of stress and some trees' leaves are turning yellow and falling off. Most weeds have not grown except for a few isolated grass burrs. Starting to look like desert around here. Grasses are brown and brittle and crumble under our feet.
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: Deer abandoning fawns, wildlife have little food or water in Bandera County, Texas
Description: Everything that depends on rain is dead or dying. Find no moisture when digging down 4 feet in soil. Have lost 3 old post oaks, two old live oaks, red buds, etc., just around the house. Local whitetail does have abandoned fawns, the adult deer sit in shade, immobile when approached. Wildlife have no food, no water left. Got a little rain last night, need a lot more, but there is nothing growing left to save.
Places: Bandera County, TX

Title: North Texas crops not growing, due to lack of rain
Description: Low soil moisture and strong winds prevented farmers in North Texas from planting pasture grasses, according to AgriLife Extension agents.  Corn, pasture grasses and wheat that had not received rain had ceased to grow.  Stands of ryegrass were shorter than they would usually be.  Meager hay supplies left livestock eating weeds.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), April 30, 2011

Title: Drought altered operational procedures for Toledo Bend Reservoir on the Texas/Louisiana border
Description: Water releases to satisfy downstream water needs from the Toledo Bend Reservoir since late April have allowed 2 ½ hours of hydropower generation every other day.  Worsening drought conditions led authorities to adjust the time frame of water releases to permit 3 hours of hydropower generation every other day, but the low water level has ended hydropower production capability.  The ongoing drought has led decision makers to make unprecedented adaptations to operational procedures to accommodate the low water levels and water needs downstream.  The Toledo Bend Reservoir is operated by the Sabine River Authority, the State of Louisiana and the Sabine River Authority of Texas.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Sept. 6, 2011
Places: De Soto Parish, LA, Sabine Parish, LA, Newton County, TX, Sabine County, TX, Shelby County, TX

Title: Barton Springs Edwards Aquifer district in central Texas entered stage 2 drought
Description: Water permit holders in the Barton Springs Edwards Aquifer district began receiving 20 percent less water after the board announced a stage 2 drought alarm for its 60,000 customers in Hays, Travis and Caldwell counties.  Water users were urged to reduce water use outdoors and to use less than 4,000 gallons of water per person monthly.  Austin American Statesman (Texas), April 30, 2011

Places: Caldwell County, TX, Hays County, TX, Travis County, TX

Title: No fireworks for Cinco de Mayo in Cameron County, Texas
Description: The Cameron County Fire Marshal won’t issue permits to sell fireworks for Cinco de Mayo because the fire risk was too high.  The county had a 14-day ban on outdoor burning, which had been renewed five times as dry conditions prompted officials to continue the ban.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 27, 2011

Title: Water demand for fighting wildfires straining already depleted surface water supplies in Taylor County, Texas
Description: Surface water supplies were depleted in Taylor County, but the prevalence of wildfires in the area has led to additional demands on the already scarce water supply, according to a Texas AgriLife Extension Agent for the county.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 26, 2011

Title: Agriculture, Water Supply & Quality, Society & Public Health impact from Government submitted on 4/26/2011
Description: From the Nolan County FSA: Nolan County has still not received any rainfall, the recent showers have been to the East and North. Conditions have only changed for the worse; the high temperatures and high winds have caused ground water to become critical in most of the county. Lake Santa Fe, which is a small in-town lake that the Country Club relies on for irrigation water, is almost dry. Many stock tanks are dry or at critical level. Wheat crop is now a total failure. Hay and milo cannot be planted due to dry conditions. It will be cotton planting time very shortly and it is so dry the land cannot be prepped for planting. We are getting another sand storm today as wind is out of the West where most of the county's crop land is located.Impact Source:  Government
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Nolan County, TX

Title: Open burning banned in Lower Colorado River Authority parks in Texas
Description: Drought conditions prompted Lower Colorado River Authority to issue more stringent fire restrictions in its 42 public parks.  Campfires and cooking fires fueled by charcoal, wood or other solid fuels, whether in fire rings or grills, are prohibited since many counties in which the parks are located have bans on outdoor burning.   Gas stoves, such as Coleman stoves, were still acceptable.   Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 25, 2011

Title: Local wildlife water source completely dry near La Grange, TX

Title: Two fire departments in Midland County, Texas receive gift of fire truck from Apache Corporation
Description: The Apache Corporation donated two fire trucks to the Northeast Midland County Volunteer Fire Department and the Greenwood Volunteer Fire Department to assist with firefighting efforts.  The mayor of Midland and fire chiefs of both fire departments expressed deep gratitude for the Ford F650 Diesel and the Ford F750 Diesel trucks since each unit had lost a fire truck recently.  The Apache office in Midland and corporate headquarters in Houston together donated $50,000 to the American Red Cross of Southwest Texas to assist people who had been affected by wildfires in West Texas.
Places: Midland County, TX

Title: Revenue shortfall of $65 million for San Francisco Public Utilities Commission
Description: Water sales were down $65 million for the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission, forcing them to consider a rate hike for their customers to increase revenue.  California was in the grip of drought for several years, prompting people to use less water and pay less on their water bills, leading to less revenue for utility companies.  San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), April 20, 2011
Places: Fremont, CA, Newark, CA, Union City, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Francisco, CA

Title: Farmers baled wheat for livestock in Wilbarger County, Texas
Description: Farmers in Wilbarger County were baling wheat that did not grow well, due to inadequate moisture, and intended to feed it to livestock.  Irrigation was necessary to prepare fields for planting peanuts.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), April 19, 2011
Places: Wilbarger County, TX

Title: Burn ban in the unincorporated portions of Harris County, Texas
Description: Harris County Commissioners Court unanimously approved a burn ban in unincorporated portions of the county for the next 90 days.  Campfires and open burning were prohibited, but enclosed burns that prevent flames and sparks from escaping and backyard grilling were permitted.  Harris County was in severe to extreme drought.   Houston Chronicle (Texas), April 19, 2011
Places: Harris County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Water Supply & Quality, Relief, Response & Restrictions impact from Government submitted on 4/19/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.So far we have had over 30 ranchers in the last 3 weeks file a notice of loss with us on pasture for drought, I have had several producers that are starting to cull cattle numbers as they are running out of grass and tank water. Most ranchers have other water sources for cattle so the grass is the big issue.  Bitter Creek spring that feeds lake Sweetwater and runs through several ranches has stopped flowing. I have had crop ins. adjusters in thisweek as they are appraising wheat crops and they report that virtually all wheat in the county is a disaster and only a very small portion will even be harvested. In some dry years our wheat is baled for feed when it is not goodenough to cut for grain, but this year producers say it is not tall enough or thick enough to bale.Hay grazer should be getting planted now in the county but none has been to my knowledge as 100% of it would not have enough moisture to come up.Impact Source:  Government
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Nolan County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Fire, Water Supply & Quality impact from Government submitted on 4/19/2011
Description: The following FSA report was submitted.Luckily we have avoided the major fire issues but we have had a few small ones.  The biggest was in the Cottonwood area towards Cross Plains and was about 300 to 400 acres.  One of our commissioners who was working the fire was in today and reported green fields burning.  The humidity has been so low there is just no moisture in anything.  Temperatures have been way above normal.  Last weekend the 9th and 10th we saw high in the 97 to 98 range.  They were not that hot this past weekend but still very warm.  Today we are expected to reach 100.  The combination of the high temperatures with the high winds is just taking any moisture we have and sucking right out of everything.  Rainfall.  Looking at the reports as reported to the NWS in San Angelo for the county were are 12% below normal for the month of March and 42% of normal year to date.  Add in very little rainfall for the majority of the County for the month of April and things are getting pretty rough aroundhere.  Recently we sent out letters to producers that potentially could have native and improved grass grazing losses due to drought.  Typically these letters do not get much response or at least a quick response.  This letter however did.  All are reporting bad conditions in the field.  Stock tank water is very low to almost non-existent in some areas.  Producers are still feeding hay and cubes to cattle when they would normally be ending that feeding process at this time of year due to having green grass to graze.  We havemany reporting selling livestock early typically due to lack of water but also lack of grass.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Callahan County, TX

Title: Ban on outdoor burning in El Paso County, Texas
Description: The El Paso County Commissioners Court adopted a ban on open burning in unincorporated portions of the county for the next 90 days.  Strong winds and an abundance of dry fuels on the ground prompted commissioners to act to prevent wildfires in the county.  El Paso Times (Texas), April 19, 2011.  The ban was extended another 90 days.  El Paso Times (Texas), May 8, 2012
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Edwards Aquifer Authority in central Texas entered Stage 1mandatory pumping restrictions
Description: The Edwards Aquifer Authority announced Stage 1 mandatory pumping restrictions for its municipal, irrigation and industrial water customers in Bexar, Medina, and portions of Atascosa, Caldwell, Comal, Guadalupe and Hays counties.  The trigger for Stage 1 occurs when the average water level of the J-17 index well falls below 660 feet above mean sea level over a ten day period.  The Edwards Aquifer provides water for 1.7 million people.  San Antonio Business Journal (Texas), April 18, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Atascosa County, TX, Bexar County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Comal County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hays County, TX, Medina County, TX

Title: Wildfire near Possum Kingdom Reservoir in Palo Pinto County, Texas burned many homes
Description: Wildfires near the Possum Kingdom Reservoir charred roughly 32,000 acres and at least 31 homes on April 17.  Residents of Strawn and Caddo were permitted to return to their homes on the evening of April 17, but evacuation orders remained in effect for those living on the east and south sides of the reservoir. Title: Three sizable wildfires burned in Wichita County, Texas
Description: Three sizable wildfires burned in Wichita County, devastating 20 homes in the vicinity of Iowa Park and eight homes in Wichita Falls.   People living in military housing near Sheppard Air Force Base in Wichita Falls evacuated for a couple of hours until the danger had passed and were allowed to return.  Syracuse Post-Standard & Syracuse.com (N.Y.), April 16, 2011
Places: Wichita County, TX

Title: Drought in Erath County, Texas, continues to affect producers
Description: 2011     Erath County, Texas  Rainfall in 2011 was many inches below normal (about 19 inches total for our property), resulting in poor forage for livestock and wildlife, hay harvests only 20% of normal, and the necessity of herd reduction for most livestock owners. Some sold out completely, others reduced herds drastically. (We sold 50% of our animals, others we know sold 80% or more.) This was done to reduce costs of feeding stock throughout the summer and winter, as the price of hay and feeds soared. Also impacting everyone was the sharply reduced amount of water available.  Our stock pond shrunk to almost dry, about 5% of its previous level, and many in the county lost all water, and sold out completely.  Streams dried up, and fish and turtles died in great numbers as the waters retreated to a few scummy pools.2012      Rainfall increased, but was several inches below normal.  Hay, corn, and livestock feed remained in short supply (ethanol induced?) and at greatly increased price.  Our hay crop was up to about 40% of previous years, but feed prices made everyone hesitant about increasing herd size.  Stock ponds came up, but only another 5-10 percent. Streams were flowing, but much lower than previous years.2013Rainfall at this location remains sparse (only 8.25 inches through April), and although pastures have greened up, they are not lush, only alive and growing slowly. Increasing livestock numbers seems chancy. Ponds are almost static; creeks are running, but slowly. Fish numbers appear somewhat increased, and nesting activity is still not up to previous years. Without rain, local conditions will become extreme quickly.    Erath County is still in extreme drought, and has not benefited from the increased rainfall that has touched other areas of the state.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Bluff Dale 3.7 SSE on 5/16/2013
Places: Erath County, TX

Title: Large number of fires burned in Harris County, Texas over weekend
Description: Harris County fire departments extinguished 78 fires over the weekend, according to records kept by the office of the fire marshal.  Harris County was in severe to extreme drought. Houston Chronicle (Texas), April 19, 2011
Places: Harris County, TX

Title: Wildfires in Tyler and Hardin counties in southeastern Texas burned 7,000 acres
Description: Wildfires in Tyler and Hardin counties charred roughly 7,000 acres in a heavily forested area near the Turkey Creek portion of the Big Thicket National Preserve.  Firefighters were trying to combat three fires roughly 15 miles north of Kountze.  One vehicle was destroyed.  12 News KBMT (Texas), April 18, 2011
Places: Hardin County, TX, Tyler County, TX

Title: Jefferson County, Texas residents urged to be careful with fire outdoors
Description: Jefferson County residents were urged by the Office of Emergency Management and local fire chiefs to be especially careful with fire outdoors because drought conditions elevated the fire danger.  An official burn ban was not in effect.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), April 15, 2011
Places: Jefferson County, TX

Title: Fire restrictions in the Sabine National Forest, Texas
Description: The forest supervisor for Sabine National Forest enacted fire restrictions which prohibit campfires not built in fire rings.  Campers may burn charcoal fires and campfires in fire rings and grills at Boles Field, Red Hills Lake, Willow Oak, Lakeview, Indian Mounds and Ragtown Recreation Areas.  The supervisor felt that the restrictions were necessary because drought was intensifying and no rain was in the forecast.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), April 15, 2011
Places: Sabine County, TX, Shelby County, TX

Title: Trees, shrubs dying in Smith County, Texas
Description: I have lived on this property for the past 10 years & have seen changes in plants that I have never seen before on this property. These have all happened within the last 12 months. First, I have lost two established rose bushes and two established azalea shrubs. Next, several large trees on my property appear to be damaged by the lack of rain. Although parts of the trees have new leaf growth, several large branches now have only dead leaves. Finally, several small seedling trees only have dead leaves on them. I do not see any loss of bark at the present time. Since this is a pretty large piece of property, other than my garden, I have never watered but have always relied on rainfall. This has never been a problem in the past.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Tyler 8.1 ENE on 4/20/2012
Places: Smith County, TX

Title: The Frying Pan Ranch fire in Andrews County, Texas burned at least 20,000 acres
Description: The Frying Pan Ranch fire burned 20,000 to 40,000 acres and was 40 percent contained, according to a Texas Forest Service estimate.  The 9-1-1 dispatch supervisor for Andrews County stated that the fire had charred 90,000 to 100,000 acres.  The county was in extreme drought.  Odessa American (Texas), April 15, 2011
Places: Andrews County, TX

Title: Wildcat Fire in Tom Green County, Texas burned 35,000 acres

The Wildcat Fire burned into Coke County, prompting the evacuation of the towns of Robert Lee and Bronte.  Dry conditions and high fire danger allowed wildfires to burn across many parts of Texas.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 17, 2011
Places: Coke County, TX, Tom Green County, TX

Title: Drought severely stifled milo, corn near New Braunfels, Texas

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 4/18/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Mason and Llano Counties: Supplemental feeding of forage, protein and mineral to livestock continues across both counties due to drought stressed spring pastures. Livestock were culled much heavier than normal. Ponds, stock tank levels, creeks, and rivers continued to decline across the counties due to drought conditions and brush coming out of dormancy. Pastures and rangeland were stressed due to low soil moisture and windy conditions. Warm season grasses were greening up in the counties due to recently received moisture but is declining due to high temp and windy conditions. The threat of wildfires remained severe in both counties due to high winds and very dry conditions.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Mason County, TX

Title: Wildfire burned 71,000 acres in Stonewall, King and Knox counties

As of April 17, the fire had blackened nearly 120,000 acres and was 90 percent contained.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 17, 2011

The remaining 600 cattle might be given hay soon if rain does not fall.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), April 10, 2011.

Title: Water Supply & Quality impact from Government submitted on 4/10/2011
Description: Sabine River Authority has implemented stage 1 of their water shortage drought plans. (User-submitted media report; http://www.beaumontenterprise.com/news/weather/article/Sabine-River-Authority-encourages-voluntary-water-1329283.php).  Water customers of the Sabine River Authority of Texas (SRA-TEX) were urged to voluntarily conserve water because the water level of the Toledo Bend Reservoir dropped to 165.1 feet above mean sea level and stayed at or below that level for the last two weeks. SRA-TEX entered Stage 1 of the reservoir’s Water Conservation and Drought Contingency Plan. Title: Wildfire burned 60,000 acres in Jeff Davis County, Texas

Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 10, 2011.  When the fire was finally extinguished, it had burned 108,000 acres, a minimum of 23 houses and roughly 150 livestock.  El Paso Times (Texas), April 17, 2011

Title: Wildflowers sparse in Washington County, Texas
Description: Bluebonnets in Washington County were about half the normal height with smaller flowers than usual as drought limited their size and number.  There were few Indian paintbrush to be found.  The vegetation management director for the Texas Department of Transportation stated that dry conditions since the fall hurt wildflower displays.  Wildflowers were sparse in the Hill Country also.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), April 1, 2011
Places: Burnet County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Washington County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Wildlife incursions and no wildflowers in yard near Seguin, TX
Description: No wildflowers in my yard this year. This is the first time in 17 yrs. that I have lived here that we did not have the flowers. We have had more tree branches come down (some are pretty large) as the older trees dry out. Wildlife are coming closer to the house in search of water. CoCoRaHS report from Seguin 11.7 ESE on 5/5/2011.
Places: Guadalupe County, TX

Title: Armadillos damaging residential lawn in search of grubs near Marion, TX
Description: Have been under a burn ban for about a month. Second morning in a row that there's varmint damage to the lawn. Probably an armadillo digging for grubs. Significant because armadillos are satisfied with digging in the wild, but the drought has depleted their underground food. So they come to the yard where it's been watered, and grubs are still plentiful. Trying to refill the holes is difficult, makes the lawn lumpy. Also, outside the lawn, where we have a gray clay called "gumbo," cracks have opened up in the soil. Can drop a yardstick 15" down. When it gets really droughty, the yardstick will disappear. (Report from CoCoRaHS Observer at Marion 2.2 SSW, submitted on 4/19/2011)
Places: Guadalupe County, TX

Title: U.S. Border Patrol began “Operation Heatwave” in July to locate and rescue immigrants who might perish in hot, dry conditions
Description: Heat and drought played a role in the deaths of at least 33 migrants this summer in Brooks County, an area where many illegal immigrants enter the U.S.  Since October 2010, more than 160 people were rescued mostly during the hot summer as people became disoriented in the heat and lost their way.  The U.S. Border Patrol began “Operation Heatwave” in July to locate and rescue immigrants who might perish from dehydration, heat stroke and other causes on the strenuous and dangerous journey.  The Border Patrol’s Search, Trauma and Rescue team employs helicopters and additional agents to seek out immigrants who may need life-saving assistance.  Operation Heatwave will continue through September.  Texas Observer, Sept. 12, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Brooks County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Parker County, Texas

The high fire danger and prevalence of wildfires across the state prompted roughly two-thirds of the counties in the state to adopt burn bans.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 6, 2011.
Places: Parker County, TX

With additional recent wildfires in the county as well as straight winds/tornadic activity, the farmers and ranchers of the county continue to suffer and need assistance.  From the weather extremes, the wheat crop, grasses and affect on livestock has been unusual.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Livestock producers having difficulty finding hay in Bandera County, Texas
Description: All of our pastures are dirt and rock. Grass is dead and there are just patches. We raise cattle. There was no spring grass and hay went from $60 a bale in April to $90 a bale in July and our supplier said even at that price he's having a hard time finding hay to bring in. I sold 60% of my herd just keeping my best because I can't make a profit feeding them on hay.
Places: Bandera County, TX

Title: Drought reduced bluebonnet population near Bryan-College Station
Description: Drought drastically reduced the number of bluebonnets in the vicinity of Bryan-College Station, according to the state climatologist.  Some have managed to grow along roads where they received extra water that ran off the pavement.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), March 31, 2011
Places: Brazos County, TX

Title: Drought led to greater number of snake sightings around Houston
Description: Residents in the Houston area noticed more snakes recently as drought and mating season drew snakes out into view.  A snake removal specialist stated that he received a high volume of telephone calls from people who have discovered snakes around their homes and said that the drought was driving the snakes to search for water.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), March 31, 2011
Places: Sugar Land, TX, League City, TX, Harris County, TX, Houston, TX

Title: Agricultural producer supplementing feed and water for livestock in Val Verde County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 4/4/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Week of March 27th through April 3rd--Supplemental feeding of protein to livestock is continuing across both Mason and Llano counties due to current drought conditions. Stock tanks continue to decline with some reports of livestock water being hauled. Late winter early spring (cool season)grasses are declining quickly due to hot and dry conditions. Risk of wildfires is extremely high with several every week. Herd culling seems to have slowed in anticpation of spring rains. Subsoil moisture is reported to be as low as 2 foot.  As brush comes out of dormancy, creek flow is beginning to slow considerably.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Mason County, TX

Title: Ban on outdoor burning in Hardin County
Description: A ban on outdoor burning was reintroduced in Hardin County as drought conditions increase the wildfire threat.  Beaumont Enterprise (TX), March 21, 2011
Places: Hardin County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 3/28/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Week of Mar-20 thru 27th for Mason & Llano Counties. Nothing new here,no rain, high seasonal temps, and windy conditions even for March. Wildfires are becoming comon place due to high winds,low humidity and dry pastures--Volunteer Fireman are having to travel further to get water to fight fires since many of the earthen tanks do not have sufficient water to pump out of anymore.  The brush is beginning to come out due to the warm temps and with that it begins to consume soil moisture which is very low. Livestock are in fair conditions only because of suplemental feeding which has been much heaavier than normal. Producers are beginning to cull herds due to the drought with local salebarns beginning to post sizeable numbers. Sub moisture conditions are poor. Impact Source:  Government
Places: Mason County, TX

Title: Burn ban effective in Wharton County
Description: Burning restrictions were put into effect for Wharton County on March 17 as strong winds and a lack of rain made burning too dangerous.  A controlled burn in the western part of the county illustrated the fire danger on March 10 when it escaped containment and consumed 100 hay bales, some tractors, and a barn and came within 100 yards of a house.  Firefighters strove for at least seven hours to contain the fire.  The county recently had a burn ban that was rescinded on March 10.  Wharton Journal-Spectator (Texas), March 16, 2011
Places: Wharton County, TX

Title: Burn ban in place for Lavaca County, TX
Description: We're under a burn ban, and have been for a couple of months, I think. The local farmers are worried about spring pasture grass and planting. We're mostly non-irrigated farming for feed crops around here- other than home gardens. (Report from CoCoRaHS Observer at Hallettsville 8.0 N, submitted 3/16/2011)
Places: Lavaca County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Tarrant County, Texas
Description: A burn ban took effect in Tarrant County on March 15, according to the county fire marshal.  The high fire danger and prevalence of wildfires across the state prompted roughly two-thirds of the counties in the state to adopt burn bans.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 6, 2011 and Oct. 25, 2011.
Places: Tarrant County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 3/21/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Another week without rainfall--Stock tanks remain low at about 20% of capacity. Creeks and rivers continue to flow but with the oncoming spring with brush beginning to take on ground moisture the creeks and rivers will slow considerably. Livestock feeding is continuing at the same winter rate as before. Culling of herds is being reported with the spring approaching. Submoisture is reported at 3 foot. If Mason and Llano Counties suffer a dry spring, poor grazing conditions will quickly intensify.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Mason County, TX

Title: High wildfire risk in Parker County, TX
Description: It very, very dry. Stock pond on my property is dry. Wildfires all around today. Windy conditions add to danger of Wildfires. Heavy smoke in my area from wildfires. Evacuation plan is ready to remove my horses and other animals if wildfires threaten my property. Requires extreme vigilance. Watering pastures to reduce threat. (Report from CoCoRaHS Observer at Aledo 2.9 SW, submitted 3/13/2011)
Places: Parker County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 3/14/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Supplemental feeding of protein, mineral and hay to livestock increased in Mason and Llano counties in the last week. Stock tank levels remained very low at approximately 20% of capacity. Calving season has begun and cattle herds are being culled more and harder than usual. Cool and warm season grasses are progressing very slow due to the drought conditions and cooler night temperatures. The counties continue to be at high risk of wildfires due to very dry conditions and high winds. When conditions permit the brush to come out of dormancy conditions quickly and rapidly deteriorate in terms of submoisture and available stocktank and running water (creeks).Impact Source:  Government
Places: Mason County, TX

Title: Brazos Valley counties implement burn bans in anticipation of deteriorating drought conditions
Description: There are burn bans in Brazos, Burleson, Grimes, Leon, Madison, Robertson and Washington counties in anticipation of deteriorating drought conditions.  A fire operations chief described the fire season in Texas this year as “an incredibly serious situation,” given the rising severity and duration of fire seasons over the past dozen years or so.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Tex.), March 4, 2011.  Leon and Madison counties no longer had current burn bans.   Bryan-College Station Eagle (Tex.), June 11, 2011.  Outdoor burning was permitted in Brazos Valley.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), Nov. 30, 2011
Places: Brazos County, TX, Burleson County, TX, Grimes County, TX, Leon County, TX, Madison County, TX, Robertson County, TX, Washington County, TX

Title: Forage for livestock scarce, wildfires occurring in Kerr County, Texas
Description: Forage for livestock is way down. Wildlife is increasing competition with livestock for grazing and browsing. We are having to supplement with purchased hay, an economic hardship for us as it is something we only expect to do in the winter. As a firefighter, we are spending more time fighting fires, and we are responding full priority to the smallest grass fire. We are no longer permitted our burn barrels, and have had to switch off our electric fences. As a family, we elected not to plant any decorative plants this year. We are very concerned that our well will dry up this August.
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Kerr County, TX

Title: Drought affects water supply, landscape, river flow, human and wildlife health in Kerr County, Texas
Description: Significant water conservation activity. Landscape deterioration. River flow slow requiring extra health precautions when swimming/boating. Deer health deteriorating. Allergy problems surfacing. Severe fire danger. Outside activities curtailed. CoCoRaHS Report from Hunt 5.8 WSW on 6/28/2011
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kerr County, TX

Title: West central Texas grains hurt by cold temperatures, drought
Description: Winter wheat and other small grains in west central Texas manifest significant damage from bitterly cold temperatures and drought, according to AgriLife Extension agents.

Title: Dryland wheat damaged by drought in the South Plains
Description: Dryland wheat in the South Plains region was severely hindered by dry conditions and in some fields was a complete loss, according to AgriLife Extension agents.  El Paso Times (Texas), March 1, 2011
