Title: Power generation low at Lake Texoma
Description: Power generation at Lake Texoma has remained at about 15 percent of average, or 1.2 hours per day, since May 2012 to conserve water in the lake.  The generation totals for the last three fiscal years, from October 2010 through September 2013, have been the lowest since the project began in 1950.  Lake Texoma recently entered Drought Level 2 on Nov. 6 when the lake receded to 612 feet, or 77 percent of conservation pool storage, so power generation is likely to remain low in the near future.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), Nov. 6, 2013
Places: Bryan County, OK, Johnston County, OK, Marshall County, OK, Cooke County, TX, Grayson County, TX

Title: Low water level of Toledo Bend on Texas/Louisiana border led to $4 million revenue shortfall
Description: The Sabine River Authority lost more than $4 million in revenue during the last fiscal year because there was too little water in Toledo Bend for hydroelectric power generation.  Electricity sales were anticipated to bring in $5 million in the present year’s budget, but the executive director of the SRA acknowledged that the probability of that happening is low.  Alexandria Town Talk (La.), Oct. 25, 2011
Places: De Soto Parish, LA, Sabine Parish, LA, Newton County, TX, Sabine County, TX, Shelby County, TX

Title: Rancher fillling water tanks for cattle daily in Austin County, Texas
Description: Drought began last fall. Cattle pond has been empty for 3 months. Filling water cattle tanks daily with several hundred gallons. Pasture grass in very poor condition to no grass condition. Supplement feeding ongoing daily. Large trees 200 years old in the area now dead. Burn burns since last fall. Area wildlife under severe conditions as well.
Places: Austin County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Public submitted on 6/9/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Farms plant crops and pray only to see their crops burn in the 103 degree heat. Crops and pastures are drying up, water is scarce. Hay that was harvested last year was enough to last 3 winters, all of it has been exhausted because there is poor grazing land conditions for the cattle to graze on due to lack of moisture and/or fire.Impact Source:  PublicMore Information:  http://www.myfoxlubbock.com/news/local/story/Ag-Day-extreme-drought/Y9nkTriAJUewfhQmN_3Fng.cspx
Places: Hale County, TX

Title: Llama rescue operation facing difficulties in midst of drought in Kerr County, Texas
Description: We rescue llamas and have a non-profit established. Because of the drought, wells are drying up, hay prices are higher, and feed prices. Donations are down as others are impacted because they have to purchase hay/feed. What would normally be pasture is just bare dirt. The number of llamas needing rescue is at an all-time high as ranches/farms are closing their operations due to the cost of care of animals. We also have poultry for pest control and eggs. The predators/wildlife do not have their normal feed supply so the predators are eating more poultry to survive and other wildlife are eating the feed we put out for our animals.
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kerr County, TX

Title: Wildlife, homes affected by drought in Williamson County, Texas
Description: Deciduous trees are losing their leaves. Ground cover vegetation, both lawn grass and unmaintained areas with weeds and grasses, has turned brown and is brittle under foot. Walking across my brown lawn reminds me of walking across ground that is covered with snow that has refrozen and crunches when stepped on. The impatiens my wife planted finally died off last week despite watering them sufficiently to keep them alive without over watering them to the point of burning their leaves. This is the first time that has ever happened. Wildlife has few sources of water. I have observed Starlings and Grackles waiting in trees around parking lots for cars to pull out of a parking space so that the birds can get a drink from the little puddle of water created from the car's air conditioning. I refill the bird bath in my yard twice per day. I have seen rabbits standing on their hind legs to get a drink from the bird bath. I had never seen a rabbit drink water in my 50 years until last week. I go through 100 pounds of bird seed for my bird feeder each month. I have a high concentration of heavy black clay in my soil. Despite watering as much as possible within the confines of the mandatory water restrictions we are under, I have not been able to prevent large cracks from opening in my back yard. Some cracks are 2" wide with no measurable bottom to the crack. An 8' rod can be inserted in the cracks to the full 8' depth without hitting bottom. My concrete driveway has sections that have risen (or lowered) by as much as 2". Using a rubber mallet produces a hollow sound in some sections of the driveway. Cracks have developed in most of the concrete slabs on my driveway. One slab has a crack to full depth and a corner of the slab representing about 20% of the slab has broken. When my wife pulls into the driveway I can watch the slabs move up and down. My back door leading to my deck behind the house has gotten to where I won't open it anymore because it sticks so bad. I fear I may have a cracked foundation (slab). Electricity costs for air conditioning needed due to the record breaking high temperatures have increased by about 10% from past years. My water bill exceeded $100 last month for the first time ever due to watering my lawn.
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: Society & Public Health impact from Public submitted on 6/17/2011
Description: Local firworks are cancelled because of the drought. (User-submitted media report; http://www.myfoxlubbock.com/news/local/story/fireworks-4th-july-festival-broadway-lubbock/bxxAKK7ll0WOc_b5d3iwPg.cspx)Impact Source:  PublicMore Information:  http://www.myfoxlubbock.com/news/local/story/fireworks-4th-july-festival-broadway-lubbock/bxxAKK7ll0WOc_b5d3iwPg.cspx
Places: Hale County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 1/13/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Since October of 2010, Stephens County has had a very small amount of rainfall.  Pasture lands have not grown any winter grass and what little remains is fire hazard.  There are no small grains to be grazed and some appeared to have died.  Stock tanks are getting very low and in need of water.  Producers are feeding above normal to maintain their herds.  Pastures, (Native, Improved and small grain) are in poor condition.  The rains that have been received have all been less than 1.0 inch, which has not helped to produce any growth in the county.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Stephens County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Fire impact from Public submitted on 1/11/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.We have had very little rainfall since September 2010. Small grain crops, such as wheat and oats, are failing. What has come up cannot be grazed. Producers are feeding cattle.There is an abundance of dry grass throughout the county. With the shortage of moisture, fire danger is high.Impact Source:  Public
Places: Eastland County, TX

Title: Drought taking toll on Bastrop County, Texas
Description: The seasonal creek which borders our land is dry, and pond and tanks in our area are nearly dried up. Wildflowers were very sparse this spring. Pines and oaks on our wooded property are dying. Grasses are sparse in our meadows. Hot dry winds have caused damage to vegetables in our garden, and we are losing plants even drought-tolerant plants in our landscaped areas. A local small vegetable stand had very little to sell this year, and closed early for the season. A burn ban is in effect, as well as a fireworks ban. We have already had one small fire on an adjacent property, and the danger of fire is extreme. Deer are coming to drink from a tub of water in our meadow, frequently in the middle of the afternoon. This is one of the few sources of water in the vicinity, since our neighbor's tank is nearly dry. All day long, birds are concentrating around our birdbath, and we are seeing many more visitors to our birdfeeders than we usually do this time of year.
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX

Title: Hudspeth County, Texas, forced to sell cattle, no pasture grass for livestock
Description: 2010 was the last year we had beneficial rain. We have had less than 10 inches of rain in over two and a half years. Most rain has been light showers and very spotty. We fear some of our grass has died while wells have gone dry and our springs have quit flowing. We made no grass in 2012, and we forced to lease a ranch for a portion of our cattle. We sold over a third of our cows and many cows did not breed back.  We have been feeding year round. This month we received some isolated rain, which will help us significantly.  The runoff had greened up grass in the draws and we are hopeful we will receive more.  If it does not rain this summer we can not survive another year.  This drought has been devastating; impacting our cattle and wildlife.  It is impossible to put a dollar amount of the impact.  We have lost hunting income, forage, water sources and suffered significant wind erosion of land.  We are very hopeful however conditions are going to improve.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Van Horn 9.0 SW on 6/25/2013
Places: Hudspeth County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Public submitted on 4/14/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.The lack of rain has significantly reduced our prospects for grain crops, no spring grass is comming, and we have nothing for cattle to eat. Ground conditions are not any where close to what they should be in order to plant hay, or grass.  We spent $425.00 ac. on fertilizer and it has not rained a drop since Feb. 2011.  The conditions in this county is SEVERE!!!Impact Source:  PublicMonetary Loss:  Currently up to $500,000
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Producers selling cattle; wells going dry in Gonzales County, Texas
Description: No rain for two months. 85 days over 100 degrees. Hottest July, hottest August, hottest summer on record. Only 12 inches of rain in the past year. That's a shortfall of 26 1/2 inches or 70% below normal. Already worst drought in history. Fires burning all around. Forecast = La Nina, no rain to speak of until probably next April. We have no grass, three ponds dried up, there's no hay available. We're struggling to try to feed something to our cows. Everyone is selling all their cattle around us and expect we will have to, too. Wells going dry all around us. The cities of San Antonio and Austin are fighting it out over which one can steal all our underground water first, and government water districts are conspiring with them with rules that prevent farmers from digging wells down to the deep aquifer. They can't actually sell our water but they collect a handsome "transport fee" for all the water taken. We will be having devastating subsidence on top of all the other drought consequences. We haven't got a chance.
Places: Gonzales County, TX

Title: Forage costs double; cattle herds stressed in Guadalupe County, Texas
Description: We are halfway through the 10th month of the current drought, with a total rainfall to date of 9.78 inches, which equals about 39 percent of normal rainfall for this location. The drought is worsening, as agriculturally significant rainfalls (i.e. over one inch in 24 hours) occurred mainly in the early second and fourth months. The only exception to this pattern was a 1.65-inch rain recorded in the ninth month. This current drought follows a one-year period of normal rainfall. Before that, this station suffered greatly from the effects of a two-year drought that began Sept. 5, 2007 and lasted until Sept. 7, 2009. From September 2007 through August 2008 rainfall totaled 19.19 inches at this station, and from September 2008 through August 2009 rainfall totaled 15.94 inches, for a two-year total of 35.13 inches, or just over 50 percent of normal. The toll on Plants and Wildlife for that two-year drought could be estimated at more than $10,000 to $20,000 because of the loss of several hundred mature trees on a 40-acre property in the Post Oak Savannah ecosystem of Texas. The losses included several hickory trees estimated to be 100 years old or older, plus numerous post oaks, blackjack oaks and Shumard oaks. In the current 10-month drought, two out of three stock ponds went dry in the eighth month. The main impact, to date, is the doubling of the cost of forage (hay) to sustain a small herd of cattle and three horses; stress on the cattle herd, contributing to the death of one cow; and necessary culling of the herd, forcing the sale of otherwise healthy and productive mama cows.
Places: Guadalupe County, TX

Title: Wildlife affected by drought in Bandera County, Texas
Description: I chose 9-8-2010 as the start date as that was last time we received almost an inch of rain. Since the first of the year, including todays rain, we have received 4.07 inches of rain. The drought has not ended. Oak trees are dying. The grass never turned green this year. We are lucky enough to have the last flowing creek (Mill Creek) run through our property. It continues to trickle over the dam. Many of us in this area are dependent on Mill Creek for drinking and household water, so it is essential for our ability to live in our homes. We find more dead fawns than we have seen live ones, and no turkey poults have been sighted. We are a rural area and are blessed (that is the only word I can think of that applies) that there have been no fires.
Categories: Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bandera County, TX

Title: Wilson County, Texas, increased price of water, water restrictions
Description: All communities are at a minimum Stage II drought condition.  Landscaping has suffered drastically, as have all outdoor activities.  Regular watering has not been allowed in three years.  The cost of water per gallon has skyrocketed, as well.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #La Vernia 3.6 SSW on 5/9/2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Wilson County, TX

Title: Local lake levels low, high temperatures affecting activity in Victoria County, Texas
Description: We just broke the record for most 100 plus degree days in a row. The record was set in 1911 at 16 but we just had an offical 101 today which puts us at 17 days continuous and are forecast to get 100 plus at least the next four days. I am inland from the Gulf of Mexico about 25 miles and normally the sea breeze keeps us cool and we only get high temperatures when the wind is from the southwest off of Mexico desert. We have had 7.63 inches of rain this year with our normal rainfall around 40 inches. The grass is dead with large cracks, have to be careful when walking out in yard. The trees have dropped about half their leaves because of the lack of water. The local lake is about half full and the boat ramps are closed. I am seeing alot of animals and birds using my gold fish pond for water. With the heat index near 109 every day work is slowed way down and people are not going out so business is slow. We are in the highest rating of drought and have had a burn ban for months now. The forecast is for little or no rain thru September and above normal temps. I saw a lot more irrigation of crops this year than in the past. The harvest this year was poor due to the quality of the crops. Electric use is way up due to the high temps. We also have set three record high-low temps with the temps at night around 80 degrees.
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Victoria County, TX

Title: Low water levels and wells running dry in Kendall County, Texas
Description: Water table level is at record low which means that water wells are going dry. Mine is still ok. No gardening or landscaping due to lack of water. Daily 20-30 mph winds dry out soil faster than can be watered. One local water company has banned landscape watering entirely. Heat wave of 100 degree days adds to problems and makes people do less activities. Creeks and ponds are dry. River close by is at 1.5ft and moving at 12cfs. Inflow to a large lake is now less than outflow thus lake level is now falling. Some large area lakes are down by 30 feet or more. As stated in daily report, junipers are dying in large numbers. Big increase in grass and brush fires. Only hope for relief will come from the tropics.CoCoRaHS Report from Boerne 8.5 NNW on 6/18/2011
Places: Kendall County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Fire impact from Government submitted on 4/12/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Due to lack of rainfall pastures are in severe condition and stock ponds are drying up.  No grass is going and wildfires are increasing daily.  The county has not had any significant rain since September 2010.  The county is in an extreme drought condition and producers are having to supplement hay and some have begun to sell off their herds.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Stephens County, TX

Title: Water delivery reductions and level 2 drought alert continue in San Diego County
Description: The San Diego County Water Authority board chose to continue its water delivery reductions and level 2 drought alert for an additional year.
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Diego County, CA

Title: Drought eliminated honey production in Nueces County, Texas
Description: A beekeeper in Calallen, northwest of Corpus Christi stated that drought prevented his bees from making honey the past two years.  Without rain to grow flowers, the bees do not produce honey.  He noted that he lost half of his bees due to the current drought.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), May 6, 2012
Places: Nueces County, TX

Title: Persistent drought leads to herd reductions in Young County, Texas
Description: Although the county has recieved some rain, conditions for livestock producers remain grim. Livestock producers are still having to reduce herd size due to lack of grass and feed sources. Tanks levels are still low and water remains a valuable commodity that is often being trucked in for livestock usage. High winds have already begun to reduce soil moisture levels and the rain was insufficient for row crop farmers to plant a viable crop. Drought conditions are persistent.
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Millions of trees continued to die in California's Sierra Nevada after end of drought
Description: California suffered the loss of another 18 million trees since the fall of 2017, a substantial number, but fewer than the 27 million dead trees counted in the fall of 2017 or the 62 million dead trees documented in the fall of 2016.  The return to more rainfall and less drought has helped trees resist the bark beetles that have damaged and killed so many trees.  Since drought began in 2010, more than 147 million trees on 9.7 million acres died.  The slowing rate of tree mortality was encouraging.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Feb. 11, 2019Trees continued to die in the Sierra Nevada more than a year after the end of California’s multiyear drought.  The U.S. Forest Service reported that 27 million trees died since November 2016, bringing the total of dead trees to roughly 129 million on about 8.9 million acres of land since 2010.  The trees were stressed and dehydrated by drought, making them more vulnerable to bark beetle infestations and other ills.The density of dead trees was so great in areas that foresters closed roads and campgrounds to protect the public from falling trees.  Views in Yosemite and Sequoia national parks were marred by the spectacle of rust-colored trees, as were some stretches along the coast.  San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com) (Calif.), Dec. 11, 2017
Places: California, Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Mono County, CA, Nevada County, CA, Placer County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: California's Bay Area residents taking to native plants, drought-tolerant landscaping
Description: Despite the easing of water restrictions in California, Bay Area nursery and gardening businesses still see high demand and preference for drought-tolerant landscaping and feel the change is permanent.  Residents have taken advantage of their water districts’ lawn removal rebate programs and have curbed their water use.   The Contra Costa Water District has paid $1 per square foot for 1.5 million square feet of grass to be removed since January 2014.  The East Bay Municipal Utility District compensated customers for removing 2.8 million square feet of grass from January 2014 to March 2016.  The Bay Area Water Supply and Conservation Agency in San Mateo began offering lawn-removal rebates in 2010, but 225 of the total 290 rebates were issued within the past two years.The Bend Bulletin (Ore.), June 19, 2016
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Alameda County, CA, Oakland, CA, Contra Costa County, CA, Marin County, CA, Napa County, CA, San Francisco County, CA, San Mateo County, CA, San Mateo, CA, Santa Clara County, CA, Solano County, CA, Sonoma County, CA

Title: Many millions of dead trees in California's Sierra Nevada
Description: California has had about 102 million trees die in its forests since 2010, according to the results of an aerial survey released by the U.S. Forest Service.  Sixty-two million trees died in 2016 alone.  The die-off presents an enormous fire threat, not to mention the challenge of removing the trees, particularly those near power lines, roads and near people.  Most of the dead trees were in the central and southern Sierra.  Los Angeles Times (Calif.), Nov. 28, 2016Roughly 66 million trees died since 2010 in a six-county region of California’s central and southern Sierra Nevada most severely affected by the drought, a bark beetle epidemic and warm temperatures, according to the U.S. Forest Service.  The tree mortality from Tuolumne to Kern counties rose by 65 percent since the last figures announced in October 2015, which documented 40 million dead trees.  The sheer number of dead trees could fuel catastrophic wildfires and endanger people’s lives, said officials.  California’s Gov. Jerry Brown declared an emergency and formed a task committee to quickly remove the trees for public safety, but the tree removal process has not gone quickly enough.  U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack, who oversees the Forest Service, said in a statement, "Tree die-offs of this magnitude are unprecedented and increase the risk of catastrophic wildfires that puts property and lives at risk.  We must fund wildfire suppression like other natural disasters in the country."San Francisco Chronicle (SFGate.com), June 22, 2016California’s ongoing drought and a bark beetle epidemic contributed to the largest tree die-off in the Sierra Nevada’s modern history, leaving around 40 million dead trees that could fall on people or fuel ferocious wildfires that could threaten mountain communities.  Most of the dead trees were in the central and southern Sierra, and the epidemic was moving north.Crews were felling trees, but have no way to dispose of them all.  One option is to use 10 large mechanized incinerators to burn up some of the trees, but environmentalists say that is not a good solution.  Some of the trees can also be sent to biomass plants that turn agriculture and tree waste into electricity.Redding Record Searchlight (Calif.), June 19, 2016
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Alpine County, CA, Amador County, CA, Calaveras County, CA, El Dorado County, CA, Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Lassen County, CA, Madera County, CA, Mariposa County, CA, Modoc County, CA, Mono County, CA, Plumas County, CA, Sierra County, CA, Siskiyou County, CA, Tulare County, CA, Tuolumne County, CA

Title: Brewster County, Texas, stressed vegetation, forced to cut cow herd due to lack of feed, burn ban
Description: Very little precipitation during 2013 water year.  So far in the 2014 water year beginning 10/01/2014 there has been slight precipitation and more wind than ordinary.  We had extreme icing conditions for a five day period with 20 power poles snapped and complete power outage during the five day period.  Also several extended hard freezes (2-4 day duration), and a very late hard freeze (20 F) in late April.  The late freeze killed the leaves of most mesquite bushes, many shrubs and trees.  Mesquite is coming back from the base and most damaged trees and shrubs are leafing out again.  A few trees and shrubs might have been killed.  The combination of extreme windy, dry conditions with cold temperatures have stressed all vegetation.  There is very little if any grass growing.  Livestock are being fed hay, cake and grazing on whatever they can find.  We are being vigilant removing poisonous plants from pastures to prevent livestock deaths.  We have been forced to shut down our swine operation due to the increased operating costs from the drought.  We have cut the cow herd by 75% because of lack of feed.  The wild deer look horrible, we are letting them eat with the other livestock to help them out.  The numbers of mature Rio Grande Turkeys on the ranch are diminishing.  We have not observed a clutch of young in the last two years.  We have not seen quail for six years.  We have quit watering our landscape with the exception of a few select trees and shrubs.  Our well began sucking air during Summer 2012 while we were attempting to irrigate some areas of good native grass for the livestock.  We have not irrigated since and have not had any further problems with the well.  Brewster county has had a burn ban in place for over four years.  It has been briefly lifted during that time when we have snow or a lengthy wet period.  But most people do not burn even then and we all have large piles of brush that we will someday burn or just let decompose.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Alpine 7.9 SE on 5/7/2014
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions
Places: Brewster County, TX

Title: Metropolitan Water District increasing water rates, cutting deliveries
Description: The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California will be increasing its water rates by 19.7 % over a two year period and will be reducing its water deliveries by 10 % beginning in July.  The MWD serves customers in Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino, San Diego, and Ventura counties. The Press Enterprise (CA), Apr. 15, 2009.  UPDATE: As of Oct. 31, 2010, stage 2 mandatory water use reductions of 10% are still in effect. Board members will vote Nov.9 on whether or not to end restrictions. The Press Enterprise (CA), Oct. 31, 2010.  The Metropolitan board decided to resume full water deliveries after a winter of plentiful snowfall.  Orange County Register (Ca.), April 12, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Los Angeles County, CA, Orange County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA, San Diego County, CA, Ventura County, CA

Title: Producer sells some breeding stock, continues to buy supplemental feed in Brewster County, Texas
Description: We have had to sell some of our breeding cattle and pigs, keeping only the best because of the huge increase in feed prices and lack of grass.  We continue to buy hay and supplemental feed for the remaining cattle and horses at a much higher cost for lesser quality feed.   We have lost most of the grass in the pastures and almost half of the trees have died.  We have spent a lot of time and money pulling out dead trees and trying to prevent severe erosion and gullies forming when we do get rain.  With the drought, the ground water is not being replenished and our well is not supplying water as it historically has.  We have sucked air a few times while attempting to water the remaining windbreak trees around the farm and keep some of the pasture grass from dying.  We keep three thousand gallons of water in stock tanks available for fire fighting and for deer, turkeys and other wildlife to drink.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Alpine 7.9 SE on 4/30/2012
Places: Brewster County, TX

Title: Producers selling cattle, wells going dry in Real County, Texas
Description: Wells are going dry. Even with some rain there is still a severe drought. My neighbors have sold off all their beef cattle. Corn crops are 60% of usual.
Places: Real County, TX

Title: Frustration with the Lower Colorado River Authority's management of water during dry years in central Texas
Description: Many residents and Austin city officials feel that the Lower Colorado River Authority should have managed the Highland Lakes differently since 2008 to conserve more water, according to the Austin American-Statesman.  When Lake Buchanan and Lake Travis fall to 30 percent of capacity, Austin will enact more stringent water restrictions.  The only worse drought the region has experienced was from 1947 to 1957.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), July 21, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX, Llano County, TX, Travis County, TX

Title: Producer selling heifers early in San Luis Obispo County, California
Description: We have been experiencing severe drought for the past 10 years.  There have been two years of good rain mixed in, but those were only short-term fixes.  This year (2018) has been particularly difficult.  Prior to March 1 we had about 2 inches of rain.  We started gathering all of our animals for sale.  We sold all of our non-replacement heifers early in preparation.  Fortunately we have had some recent rains that have helped; however, the grass is still very short and we plan to start selling off cow/calf pairs.  The oak trees and pine trees have seen mass die-off over the past few years.  This is in San Luis Obispo County.From San Luis Obispo County, California, on March 20, 2018
Places: San Luis Obispo County, CA, Shandon, CA

Title: Land in the San Joaquin Valley of California has been sinking as farmers pump excessive amounts of groundwater
Description: Some of the highest rates of land subsidence in the world were found in the San Joaquin Valley, where water is over pumped to irrigate crops amid ongoing drought, stated a hydrologist with the U.S. Geological Survey.  Parts of the Central Valley were sinking more than one foot each year, and some areas were ten feet lower than they used to be.  The subsidence has buckled the walls of irrigation canals, damaged pipes, created giant sink holes and cracked homes.   CBS News, Aug. 18, 2015Amid persistent drought and low water allocations, Central Valley farmers continued to over pump groundwater to irrigate crops at a high cost to groundwater stores, which were critically endangered prior to the drought.  Some areas have seen drops of 50 feet or more in their water tables in a few years with alarming and permanent land subsidence causing structural damage to canals, roads and bridges.    A Los Banos farmer noted that over pumping and land subsidence meant that water, to which he has high priority rights, would need to flow uphill to reach his fields.  He intends to fallow 2,300 acres of his 10,500 acres.  New York Times, April 5, 2015Land in the San Joaquin Valley continues to sink as farmers pump excessive amounts of groundwater.  The subsidence was especially pronounced from 2008 to 2010 during drought as farmers pumped more groundwater than usual to make up for decreased water allocations.  Bakersfield Californian (Calif.), Nov. 21, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Fresno County, CA, Kern County, CA, Kings County, CA, Madera County, CA, Merced County, CA, San Joaquin County, CA, Stanislaus County, CA, Tulare County, CA

Title: Relief, Response & Restrictions impact from Media submitted on 8/29/2007
Description: The Kings County Board of Supervisors declared a local emergency due to drought. The board first adopted the resolution declaring a local emergency on June 19, and they have re-authorized the declaration every two weeks since June 19.  The drought emergency remains in effect as of March 2, 2011 because one of the Kings County supervisors mistakenly pushed the wrong button during the vote to extend the measure.  He stated that he will vote differently on March 29 when the issue will be revisited.  Hanford Sentinel (Ca.), March 2, 2011Impact Source:  MediaMore Information:  http://www.hanfordsentinel.com/articles/2007/07/30/news/doc46ae1ea1ed8b3613547530.txt
Places: Kings County, CA

Title: Many female tortoises died in California's Joshua Tree National Park
Description: Numerous female desert tortoises have died in Southern California, and it seems that the creatures died trying to reproduce amid the recent drought.  The tortoises likely used up their water and energy to lay eggs.  Fewer males have died than females in the Joshua Tree National Park.  From the state of deterioration of the carcasses and chalkiness of the bones, a biologist with the U.S. Geological Survey estimated that the tortoises died within the last 5 to 10 years, which encompasses the past five years of intense drought.  Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 17, 2017
Places: Riverside County, CA

Title: Fewer saguaro cactus seedlings in the Sonoran Desert in the Southwest
Description: Saguaro cactuses in the Sonoran Desert in southwest Arizona and extreme southeast California were reproducing less and were beginning to migrate as temperatures rises.  In a 2018 report, the National Park Service stated that climate change, drought, invasive plants and certain activities, such as woodcutting and cattle grazing, have reduced the number of seedlings to replace older cactuses.  Seedlings and juvenile cactuses have been declining since the 1990s.AZ Central (Phoenix, Ariz.), June 18, 2020
Places: La Paz County, AZ, Maricopa County, AZ, Pima County, AZ, Pinal County, AZ, Santa Cruz County, AZ, Yuma County, AZ, Imperial County, CA, Riverside County, CA, San Bernardino County, CA

Title: Drought was linked to a decrease in the desert tortoise population in a one square-mile study plot in Joshua Tree National Park in southern California
Description: Drought was linked to a decrease in the desert tortoise population in a one square-mile study plot in Joshua Tree National Park, according to a study by the U.S. Geological Survey.  The tortoises were monitored from 1996 through 2012, during which there were periods of drought, and their numbers fell from 175 to 200 tortoises at the beginning of the study to about 25 tortoises at the end.  Two to three years of drought were observed to seriously compromise the tortoises’ survival.  Drought kills the annual plants, leading to a die-off of the rodents that eat the plants.  Then coyotes, which normally eat kangaroo rats and rabbits, begin eating tortoises, said the lead researcher of the USGS team.  Los Angeles Times, Dec. 13, 2013
Places: Riverside County, CA
